Title: We taught Auro to speak because he wasn’t barking: Rithvik Raja
Content: If you happen to scroll through the Insta stories of Carnatic musician Rithvik Raja and his classical dancer wife, Shweta Prachande , you would be certain to see more pictures of their darling pet Auro , a Golden Retriever , than of themselves. It doesn’t surprise us because when they speak about Auro, they come across as pet parents who are passionate about animals. We think that their calm nature has impacted Auro, too, as we hardly hear him bark during the course of the interview. “We were worried why he wasn’t barking. So, we taught him to speak (responding to sign language) because he wasn’t barking. And now, whenever we do a particular sign, he barks,” says Rithvik. Amid cuddles and lots of games, Rithvik and Shweta share their journey as pet parents...A friend of a friend had a litter of seven Goldens and Rithvik and Shweta had both decided to go there and play with the pups. “It just so happened that this guy (Auro) kept following me around. Seeing our love for pets , our friend asked if we wanted to adopt him. We wanted some time to think as we are artistes who travel a lot. Three days later, he sent four pups home, with Auro marked in a blue thread. While they all played with us, there was something about Auro, which made us decide to welcome him home,” says Rithvik.Shweta says, “Initially, we thought we’d get a trainer. But we wanted to give raising a pet a shot ourselves. We started reading and watching a lot videos to train him.” Rithvik acted as the trainer. “I am sure he thinks of me as a bullying monster,” he jokes. As for Shweta, she takes him on walks.“Auro is very intelligent. He is responsive to the atmosphere around him. A lot of students come home for classes. Some are OK with cuddling him, while others aren’t. He knows that and will just wag his tail as a sign of welcoming them home. Whenever I am practising, he will just sit next to the tanpura and begin to doze off,” says Rithvik.The couple says a lot has changed ever since Auro came home. “I am definitely more up on my feet,” says Shweta, “You start to work your schedule around him.” They also ensure he gets his regular exercise as Goldens tend to put on a lot of weight. “He loves Thayir Saadham and Sakkarai Pongal. No matter where he is, Auro will come near the refrigerator if someone opens the thayir paathiram. Sometimes, I give him boiled veggies. And he eats them only if I put a dollop of curd on them,” shares Shweta.Rithvik says he misses Auro the most when he is not in Chennai. “He’s always on my mind and I wonder if he’s had his food or if he’s sleeping well. I can’t really imagine a life without him. No matter what kind of a day I am having, when I get back, he brightens my day with his ‘welcome home’ love. Everything else becomes inconsequential when he’s with us,” he signs off.Rithvik says, “It is a myth they shed a lot. They will shed if they are unattended to. Once in 10 days, Shweta gives him a bath and combs with a furminator. It will hardly take 10 minutes of your time. Also, it is important to do research when you have a pet. What works for others may not work for you. The first two months are crucial and giving them the right food is a must.” He adds, “Also, please pick up your dog’s poop when you take them on walks on the road. There are some lovely devices. Lastly, ensure they get enough attention. They are just like kids.”Why the name Auro? “Just for the record, it has nothing to do with Auroville, in Pondicherry,” jokes Rithvik. He says they were looking for something more Indian and hyperlocal, but couldn’t settle on any particular one. They even thought of naming him after a raga. “But I don’t want to scream Kapi or Thodi on the road and no one responding to me,” laughs Shweta. In the end, it was she who came up with the name Auro, informs Rithvik. “Auro means gold-like in Italian,” reveals Shweta, who had been to Italy and was learning Italian at that point of time. “It refers to the character of a person. Given that he’s a Golden Retriever, it made absolute sense,” she explains.

Title: Amrutha Ramamoorthi returns to Kannada TV with Kasthuri Nivasa
Content: Actress Amrutha Ramamoorthi , who had taken a five-month break from acting, has returned to television with the serial Kasthuri Nivasa . The actress has replaced Varsha, who quit the show for personal reasons. The soap opera, directed by Mussanje Mahesh , has Dileep R Shetty in the lead role.Speaking to us, Amrutha says, “I had been working continuously for the last seven years. After getting married, I wanted to spend some time with my family. Although I was getting offers to act in serials, nothing interested me. Mrudh- ula’s role excited me as the character is that of a guilty girl who doesn’t want traditional rituals to be forced upon her. She is a straight-forward girl, who speaks her mind.” When asked if it was challenging to portray a character, which was earlier played by Varsha, she says, “Not really. People have seen me on television before. It doesn’t matter who is playing the role. All that matters is giving our best to the character we portray on screen.”

Title: My First Shot: For ADs, the formative years can become their identity, says SP Muthuraman
Content: My first film as a director was Kanimuthu Paappa. It was written by VC Guhanathan, and was actually a multi-starrer — it featured Jaishankar, Muthuraman, Lakshmi, Jaya... Even Sridevi was a child artiste in the film. The first sequence that I shot for the film was a combination shot of Muthuraman and Jaishankar. Both were big heroes at that time and had equal footage in the film. We shot it in a studio in Chennai. Appollam ella padamumum studio-la dhaan eduppom.I started my career as an assistant director. Assistant directors and associate directors are like the right hand of a director. Whatever a director feels, we have to grasp it and convey it to the rest of the people on the set. Director Tirulokchandar is my guru. Whenever he had to go for a song recording, he would tell me, ‘Muthuraman, andha shot-a eduthurunga.’ So, even before I turned director, I’d canned so many shots as an assistant! And those days were truly a learning experience. I want those who are working as ADs to take their job seriously because these formative years can become their identity. I want to narrate an anecdote to supplement my statement. After Kanimuthu Paappa, Guhanathan had written a story for Jayalalithaa.Before he went to narrate it to her, he said that he was going to pitch my name as the director. I told him that she is a senior artiste and I was a newcomer, and if she was not comfortable with the idea of working with me, he should go ahead and rope in whoever she wanted to work with. Naan pudhusa vandhirukkaradhunala avangalukku oru thayakkam irukkalam. So, he went and met her and narrated the story, which she loved. When she asked who was going to direct it, Guhanathan mentioned my name. He said, ‘Muthuraman has directed Kanimuthu Paappa and has worked with AVM also. Aana ungalukku vera karuthu irundha sollunga.’ But she immediately told him, ‘Tirulokchandar oda assistant dhaane? I’ve seen him work on one of my films with Trilokchandar — Enga Mama. Avar nalla velai senjadha naan paathurukken. So, you give him the chance’. I got an opportunity to direct Jayalalithaa in Anbu Thangai only because she had seen me work hard as an assistant director. That’s why I want to tell all those who are working as ADs to give it their all, because they are being noticed for their work.

Title: When Sandalwood and Bollywood celebs went temple hopping in Kudla
Content: All roads led to Karavali for some of our Sandalwood and Bollywood celebs this week. Actress Sruthi Hariharan was in Kollur on Wednesday with her husband Raam Kumar , mother Jayalekshmi and other family members for baby Janaki’s anna prashanam. “Mookambika temple has always had a lot of importance in our life. So, when it was time for Janaki’s anna prashanam, we unanimously decided to go to Kollur. We travelled by train and she was so excited,” says Sruthi. The family then travelled to Udupi to offer their prayers at the Krishna temple. “We are also going to Murudeshwar, after which we will head to Thiruvananthapuram for a few days,” the actress adds. Singer Vijay Prakash, too, chose to celebrate his 19th wedding anniversary at the Kateel Sri Durga Parameshwari temple recently. Vijay also had a concert at the venue, which was another highlight of his visit.Bollywood actor and Kudla’s own Shilpa Shetty was also in Kateel on Thursday to attend the Brahmakalashotsava and enthusiastically shared pictures of the same on her social media page. Dressed in rustling silk saris and Mangaluru mallige in her hair, the actor spent happy moments in her hometown with mother Sunanda Shetty Kundra, sister Shamita Shetty , husband Raj Kundra and son Viaan.

Title: Bengaluru artiste Nitish Chachra collaborates with Sandeep Chowta
Content: Bengaluru’s Nitish Chachra is on cloud nine as his first-ever music album along with DJ Cheeze released on Friday. Titled Chalk & Cheeze, the new album sees Nitish collaborate with Bollywood music composer-singer, Sandeep Chowta . “I first met Sandeep at a music event in Bengaluru, and we instantly connected. Given our love for house music, it was quite natural that we eventually collaborated for an album,” says Nitish adding, “The speciality of Chalk & Cheeze is that it has elements of 70s’ and 80s’ disco music. In addition to this, we have components of Indian classical music, particularly that of the sarangi, interspersed with the vocals.” Giving a little more insight into their new work, Nitish says “We hope that the compositions will be liked by music lovers both at clubs and at festivals, while the album appeals to people of all age groups, who want to dance and have a good time.”Talking about working with Sandeep, Nitish says, “Sandeep is an inspiring figure. As a child, I used to listen to his music, and it’s like a dream come true for me to be collaborating with him.”

Title: I want to learn Sunil Chhetri's leadership skills, says Bala Devi
Content: For an Indian athlete to break into the big league and make an international impression is quite a feat. And when it's a woman playing a sport that is traditionally thought to be male bastion, even more so. Naturally, 29-year-old Manipuri footballer and former national team captain Bala Devi's induction into the Scottish Women's Premier League is a big deal - something that she is both excited and nervous about. Getting to where she is today, though, she says is the fruition of a nearly two decade old dream. On the sidelines of the event announcing her move to the Rangers FC in Bengaluru, the footballer spoke to us about her journey in the sport, her dream come true and moreI am thankful and elated, as this has been my dream since childhood. I wanted to play football, reach a greater audience and play in a premier league someday. This contract is validation that I have got what I set out to achieve and I am, no doubt, glad.The 2002 FIFA Football World Cup set it up for me. I was 11 or 12 years old at the time and hooked to the television screen, as I watched Ronaldinho and Ronaldo score goal after goal. I knew I wanted to be like them and even had posters of them at my house for a while. .I come from a small village in Manipur. I still remember that when I started out, people used to tell my father that he should not let me play football and to instead get me to focus on studies. But I always knew that I would someday show them what I can achieve. Deep down I knew that I will bring my village and my country into the spotlight. And now, they all support me.Not at all. In my family, everyone is in sports. One of my brothers is a bodybuilder, while the other plays football. My twin sister used to play football like me, but gave up along the way. I used to play with the boys in my neighbourhood and beat them at their game. So, I was taught by everyone and sports was something that sort of defined all of us. In fact, my father used to coach me, so there was no issue in pursuing my passion at home. .When I started out, I used to play with seniors and learnt from their experience. Over the years, I have grown as a player and as a senior member of the teams I play for, I am able to impart whatever I learnt to the younger ones, while also handling team management, etc. I now know what it takes to represent one's country and teach that to the younger players. The technical wisdom of the years of experience apart, now, when I go to the field, I am always at ease and don't get agitated. Leadership is something that I am still learning.The government has been extremely supportive, in the sense that we don't have to take on work stress. We have to just focus on sports.The scene has changed drastically since 2002. Now, people know what a huge platform sports and government support has also been phenomenal - be it in terms of infrastructure, finance or other benefits.There's a lot of potential in the upcoming players, especially the U-17 players. They have what it takes to take India to greater heights at the upcoming U-17 Women's World Cup.Sunil Chhetri. He is extremely cool and composed and his leadership skills are something that I want to imbibe in my day-to-day activities.If not this then I would have joined the Indian Navy. I love the discipline and how cool and smart Navy personnel look. (Laughs).I am not looking at challenges. The only thing I am focused on right now is that I need to give my 100% there. I think it is going to be a great experience to meet and play with players from different parts of the world and be a part of Rangers FC as a family. If I begin to think about the difficulties and challenges ahead, I will limit myself, so I won't do that.I just love the city! I keep coming here for my fitness and performance training and I just love the weather and the food. Also, in a lot of ways, Bengaluru is like Manipur, so I don't really miss home when I am here.

Title: I was mentally and physically harassed: Sanam Shetty
Content: Even though she wasn’t a part of Bigg Boss Tamil Season 3, Sanam Shetty hogged the limelight, thanks to the speculation surrounding her relationship with Tharshan Thiyagarajan, one of the popular contestants of the show. The model-turned-actress has now come out accusing Tharshan of harassing her mentally and physically. The Sawaari star says that they were engaged much before the show took off, but Tharshan started behaving rudely once he came out of the reality show.She explains, “I got engaged to Tharshan before the show started. At that time, he’d asked me not to talk about it, and I complied. We had made plans to get married in June. But he started behaving indifferently after the show. He avoided me, humiliated me, and I was harassed mentally and physically. I was also threatened by his family. They said they know how to silence me if I talk about the engagement, the harassment, et al.”Sanam continues, “For a few months, I tried convincing him, but he refused to even acknowledge my presence. He never treated me like a girlfriend; in fact, I’m his fiancée. With no options left, I have now filed a complaint at the office of the Commissioner of Police. I will be filing the same with the Women’s Commission, too.”According to Sanam, the case has been filed under Section 420 of the IPC for breach of trust, cheating, threatening and harassing a woman. She adds that Tharshan kept accusing her of having affairs with her co-stars. “He knew that I’m an actress. It’s I who did everything for him. I have spent over `20 lakh to buy him various things, including the engagement and wedding-preparation expenses. I have helped him in his visa procedures. I also sent his application for Bigg Boss Tamil, and helped him with contacts in the industry,” she adds.Sanam says that she didn’t open up on these things earlier as she was ‘waiting for things to fall in place’. “I have suffered grave injustice — as an actress and as a woman, this is my last resort. I have been told that the case will be registered on Monday and summons will be sent to him. He can’t deny my accusations,” she signs off.When we tried reaching out to Tharshan, his manager, responded by saying that Sanam’s accusations were nothing but lies. However, Tharshan chose not to respond directly to our attempts to get with him till the time of going to print.

Title: Ruslaan Mumtaz to become a father soon
Content: Actor Ruslaan Mumtaz and his wife Nirali are all set to become parents. The couple is waiting for their bundle of joy to arrive in April. Ruslaan said, “Everyone at home is excited, too. Nirali and I have been watching baby videos to know more about parenthood. We recently went for a babymoon to Thailand and had a great time there.”The first-time parents have already thought of a name if they welcome a baby girl. “However, we haven’t thought of a name if we have a boy. If that happens, we will have to start looking for a name,” he said. The couple tied the knot in March 2014, after being in a relationship for a few years. They first met at Shiamak Davar ’s dance class and the dance choreographer was instrumental in bringing them together.On the work front, Ruslaan was seen in the TV show 'Main Maayke Chali Jaungi', last year. He is currently shooting for an English film in Africa . He said, “I am currently doing films, but I enjoy TV as much because the shows are shot at a fixed location and the sets are mostly in Mumbai. When you are shooting for a film, the locations are often out of Mumbai and you have to be away from your family.”

Title: Bigg Boss 13: Paras Chhabra is annoyed to regularly hear taunts of living off on Akanksha's money; discusses with Mahira
Content: Bigg Boss 13 is currently in the last leg and with finale approaching closer, the game is getting interesting. The recent connection task wherein friends and family of housemates have entered to support them have led to several fights between the contestants. Shehnaz Gill's brother Shahbaz and Paras Chhabra got into an ugly verbal fight wherein the former called him names.Paras interfered in Mahira and Shahbaz (Shehnaz) brother's fight and soon things go out of control when Shahbaz calls him Mahira ka Pappu. Mahira gets furious hearing this and fights with Shahbaz. She asks him if even she should taunt his sister Shehnaz and call her Sidharth ki pappu. She calls him badtameez and says that by making such comments he is showing everyone how shallow thinking both brother and sister have. Paras also gets angry hearing his remark and says that if he has seen the show, he should know that in the first month who was behind him. This agitates Shahbaz and he starts making mean comments against Paras. He also goes on to say that he is someone who lives off a girl's money (hinting at his girlfriend Akanksha who is taking care of all his necessities on the show). This annoys Paras.Later, Paras lies on the ground and looks distrubed. He talks to Mahira that since the weekend ka vaar episode, he has been hearing these comments and he is not liking it. He tells her he has done seven shows in his career, but no one knows that and in the outside world this has become a news which is a wrong information.Shahbaz is slammed by Vikas Gupta, Shefali and others for his personal remarks against Paras.

Title: Women activists heckle Post Card founder Mahesh Hegde at MIA
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

MANGALURU: After comedian Kunal Kamra ’s run-in with Republic editor Arnab Goswami in air, action returned to terra firma with women activists heckling founder of Post Card Mahesh Vikram Hegde at Mangaluru international airport on Friday. The activists – Kavitha Reddy, Amulya Leona and Najma Nazeer – took turns to heckle Hegde for more than 30 minutes as he waited to board an IndiGo flight to Bengaluru as the latter maintained his composure amidst this incident in public glare.

Noting that the incident took place sometime between 8.15am to 8.45am when he boarded the flight, Hegde told TOI that the women activists perhaps chose the airport than resort to a la Kunal Kamra type of approach lest they too be put on the no-fly list. Incidentally, the activists who had participated in an anti CAA/NRC protest rally at Town Hall on Thursday were on the same flight as Hegde and made no approach towards him in the flight or after they landed in Bengaluru.

Noting they asked him to sing ‘Nada Geethe’, Vande Matharam, Sare Jahan Se Achcha so that he could prove his credentials as a ‘nationalist’, Hegde said the incident was much more that the small 2-minute-odd clip that has gone viral due to the Tweet by one of the activists. Asserting that they bore a grudge for ‘torture’ they underwent because of him on Facebook , Hegde said he never individually attacked any of these three, but has gone full throttle against the ‘Tukde Tukde’ gang.

“I am always opposed to the likes of Kanhaiya Kumar,” Hegde said adding he too could have asked the trio lots of questions of his own. “This was neither the occasion nor the place for it,” Hegde said adding that their act was akin to batting maestro Sachin Tendulkar asking Indian skipper Virat Kohli to hit a six at an airport and not at the stadium. Even fans of comedian Kapil Sharma expect him to act out a comic scene wherever they meet him, Hegde said in defence of his silence.

With the incident going viral on Twitter and video clips on WhatsApp, both supporters and opponents of Hegde jumped to his support or hailed the activists for their boldness in showing mirror to the face of this journalist. Immaturity of the activists stood out in them asking him to sing Vandhe Matharam , Hegde said adding for person with common sense would know one who attends RSS shaka will know this song. They do not come to a shaka to see what happens and harbor their notions, he added.

Title: Zakir Hussain: Ustad Zakir Hussain: To be able to feel young again is like a new lease of life
Content: For someone who has been playing on stage professionally for almost six decades now, globally, Ustad Zakir Hussain ’s sheer enthusiasm for his craft, even now, is awe-inspiring. Seated comfortably in his pretty SoBo apartment, the legendary musician talks to BT about the events planned for Abbaji’s (his late father, the legendary Ustad Allarakha ) upcoming barsi (which is in its 20th year), why he marvels at the composers of today, how being a, “travelling musician” keeps him away from Bollywood, and what keeps him busy when he is not on stage. Read on…In its 20th year, the dawn-to-dusk event, A Homage to Abbaji – Ustad Allarakha , has always seen some of the greatest luminaries of Indian music on stage, and this year will be no different. What’s special is that Abbaji’s sons, Zakir-Taufiq-Fazal, who have not played together on stage for the last three decades, will perform at the upcoming event. Sharing his excitement, Zakir Hussain says, “Fazal, Taufiq and I are going to make a presentation in the second session, Taal Tapasya. It’s almost been 28-30 years since we have played together. I’m very happy that I will get to perform with my brothers on February 3.” The homage concert will also ring in the beginning of the centenary year of Pandit Ravi Shankar . Elaborating on this, he adds, “It’s great that one is finishing and the other is starting and it all coincides well. We are trying to figure out how to find more space on stage. There are so many musicians coming in, including Hollywood music composer Greg Ellis, Salim-Sulaiman, Louiz Banks, Sheldon, Gino Banks, Sanjay Divecha, Darshan, sitarist Purbayan Chatterjee and George Brooks. I will also be performing with Suresh Wadkar and his students.”Zakir Hussain feels that it is not easy for a classical musician to work in Bollywood. He explains, “Being an Indian classical musician, you have a certain amount of spontaneity in your DNA and you are impulsive in your creativity. And being an Indian classical performer, you also have a certain amount of vanity and ego, ‘I know what I am doing, I’m a composer and an artiste, etc.’ When you sit in a music room with a producer and an actor, and they hand you something that they have heard and say, ‘I want something like this’, then your sensibility as an artiste comes into question. For an Indian classical artiste, it is harder to be able to break away from that kind of mindset and say, ‘Yes, sure, I can copy this out’. For this, you require a special kind of person, who can not only maintain the integrity of his or her own creativity, but at the same time, be able to satisfy the needs of whatever the producer or director wants. I marvel at musicians and composers today; how they are able to deliver what is needed and what is wanted, keep their creative process in check and not feel like they are being choked. Shankar- Ehsaan-Loy (SEL), for instance. Shankar is a classically trained musician, Ehsaan is a great blues guitarist and so is Loy. They have found an incredible balance where they are able to sneak in at least one very interesting tune that is, you know, ‘aaah SEL’. Salim-Sulaiman and Vishal Shekhar , all these guys also do that. And that kind of temperament is something that an Indian classical musician has a hard time with. I saw that with Shiv-Hari ( Pandit Shivkumar Sharma and Pandit Hariprasad Chaurasia ), and they finally had to give up Bollywood. My father did music for about 40 Bollywood films, at a time when music was more classically oriented. But even he started facing situations where his integrity as an artiste, to him, came into question. And that was it. It was over. He just wanted to play Indian classical music. I totally admit my shortcoming, which is not being able to cope with the requirements of being a Bollywood film composer. I only do these independent, smaller projects like Aparna Sen’s movie or Rahul Bose’s film. In that situation, the collaboration is at a different level because it is a small project and the time sequences are in place. This has got nothing to do with the process that a Bollywood film goes through in order to create work. It is just the way I am.”Tabla players are no longer considered just accompanying musicians, they are as much lead as the vocalists and instrumentalists. Zakir Hussain believes that this was true even back in the days. “I think, 35-40 years ago, too, they were doing what they are doing now. Only that now, there is more visibility and far more focus on what artistes are doing. Today’s artiste is not just a performing artiste, but also a networking artiste and knows how to project his or her musical life, in a more magnified manner. Therefore, more and more people know what each musician is doing. That makes the information much more readily available, so the assumption is that this is happening now and that it never happened before. But that isn’t the case. My father, for instance. He played with so many great artistes as an accompanist, but at the same time, he also played an equal number of solo concerts. He was a leader. Then, he also did taal vadya concerts where he led the concerts. There were many tabla players who played a lot of solo concerts as lead artistes. Ustad Ahmed Jan Thirakwa did hundreds of solo concerts and so did Pt Kishan Maharaj and Pt Samta Prasad. The recognition of tabla players today is on a more all-round level than it was before.”While most of us know about Zakir Hussain the musician, not many know who he is when he is not on stage or in the media glare. “How a regular day in my life is, depends on where I am at that moment. If I am at home, in California, there is a certain amount of freedom in terms of doing things that involve the outdoors. I go to the hills, walk the trails, do five-six-mile hikes. I go to the beach, walk around, sit and watch sunsets. Sometimes, I go to the East side and look at the full moon rise. It is beautiful. Doing outdoor things is something that I really like. Apart from that, I love to cook. When I am in Mumbai, I am not even allowed in the kitchen, but abroad, I am not only allowed to cook, but also allowed to do the dishes (laughs!) In India, I’m mostly indoors, and I read, practise and compose. But what is really close to me is walking about in nature, soaking in the sun and realising that each sunrise and sunset is so different and beautiful that I am never going to see that one again.”The maestro, who is loved the world over, is a complete homebody at heart. Even while his calendar remains choc-o-bloc all year round, he ensures that for all the birthdays, anniversaries, New Year and Christmas celebrations, he is home. However, earlier, it wasn’t so. “In my younger days, I used to be gone for three-to-four months and my father was the same way. Once, when he left for a concert, my head was under his chin and when he came back, I was taller than him. When I was young, I couldn’t afford to come back home between tours. But now, even if I have three days off between tours, I go back home. I have a four-and-a-half-year-old granddaughter in Los Angeles and to be able to spend time with her is important to me. To be able to feel young again is a new concept to me, it’s like a new lease of life. And those kinds of things are precious and should be enjoyed to its maximum.”

Title: Music review Malang: Music review: Malang
Content: A romantic action thriller, Mohit Suri ’s '', features Aditya Roy Kapur , Disha Patani, Anil Kapoor and Kunal Kemmu in lead roles. The album of four songs (at the time of going to press) is predominantly love tracks and has been composed by four different musicians with distinct styles, thereby making the album an interesting one.Composed and sung by Ved Sharma , '' penned by Kunaal Vermaa and Haarsh Limbachiyaa has debuted our charts this week at No 6. DJ Phukan and Akull arranged and programmed this EDM love track that has a slow, yet addictive tempo. The lead stars rule the visuals with their picture-perfect hot bods as the song shows them falling in love with each other.The next, '' showcases the win-win combination of composer Mithoon and singer Arijit Singh. This combo has earlier given us hits like 'Darkhaast' ('Shivaay'), ' Phir Bhi Tumko Chaahunga ' ('Half Girlfriend'), 'Tum Hi Ho' ('Aashiqui 2'), 'Humdard' ('Ek Villain') and many others. Mithoon has a way of creating soul-stirring melodies that you could listen to on a loop and this romantic track, written by Sayeed Quadri , will stay on with you for long.An Oxford-based band of Western and Indian-classical musicians, The Fusion Project, have composed the next, ''. This one is a slow rock track. Sung by Sachet Tandon , who is known for his rendition of chart busters like 'Bekhayali' ('Kabir Singh'), 'Psycho Saiyaan' ('Saaho') and others, this romantic number has everything going for it. Sachet has done a good job with the vocals and his range is applaud-worthy.' is a heart-wrenchingly beautiful story, written by Prince Dubey and Ankit Tiwari ’s composition with its rock-jazz vibes get to you just as does his rendition.The subtle sarangi, drums along with the prominent guitar and bass, makes this one a song you would go back to. This album is surely not one that you should ignore.

Title: Sharad Kelkar : I owe Akshay Kumar Rs 500
Content: After impressing the audience with his stellar performance in 'Tanhaji: The Unsung Warrior' as Udaybhan Singh Rathore, Saif Ali Khan is all set to step into the shoes of another negative character. The talented actor will be going face-to-face with Prabhas in Om Raut's upcoming film 'Adipurush'.Saif, who started his career with 'Parampara' in 1993 has gone on to deliver several blockbusters on the silver screen. The versatile actor, who is known for taking up challenging and entertaining roles, has always managed to do justice to his characters. While the news of Saif stepping in as Lankesh in Adipurush' has got fans excited, we take a look at the dark and negative characters which the skilled actor has essayed on the silver screen.

Title: Amp up your style quotient with boots
Content: Winter is here and while you may have made a few outfit changes, have you donned the right footwear to complement it? Boots, a cold season fave, can rev up your style like none other. While it may not be as cold in Mumbai as other places, here’s how you can still rock boots and look uber stylish...Pics- istockForget lace-up heels, now is the time to opt for lace-up boots. They’re extremely stylish you can team them up with dresses, skirts and even shorts.These boots don’t cover your entire feet, so make sure you’ve had a pedi before wearing them. Giving your feet some breathing space, these boots can be teamed up with long skirtsor dresses.Resembling a man’s shoe, these ankle-length boots come with block heels. They are found in two key varieties — shiny faux leather and a more subtle matte finish. Choose the one you like!Ideal for Mumbai’s not-very-cold weather, the stylish sock boots can be paired with denims as well as tailored pants. These can even be worn to parties and concerts along with cute dresses.If you want to jazz up your outfit, leather boots are ideal. Gone are the days when they were available only in a couple of shades. To stand apart from the crowd, opt for shades like red or white, as these add a pop of colour to your outfit.You can team up these boots with any western attire. The suede material gives it a classy look while keeping your feet warm at the same time.Wearing a pair of towering heels may not always be possible. To give your ensemble a unique look, opt for a pair of chic platform boots instead.

Title: syed mujtaba hussain kirmani: We never had a coach, but we still won the World Cup: Syed Mujtaba Hussain Kirmani
Content:
Syed Mujtaba Hussain Kirmani (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)

‘UP Cricket Association should conduct inter-school cricket tournaments’

‘My personal achievement was being awarded the Best Wicket Keeper in the world from 1979 to 1986’

Syed Mujtaba Hussain Kirmani (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)

‘Why team India doesn’t have a wicket-keeping coach?’

‘You can not be on top at all times, there have to be failures’

‘We never had a coach, but we still won the World Cup’

Veteran cricketer and former wicket keeper of the Indian cricket team, Syed Mujtaba Hussain Kirmani , was in Lucknow recently. The cricketer, who is full of praises for the city, recalled his last visit to Lucknow nearly two decades ago. “I have been to Lucknow on many occasions before also but as far as cricket goes, I have played the Indian veteran cricketers versus Pakistan veteran cricketers match here in Lucknow in the late ’80s. It’s a lovely city. Saari duniya mein yeh bohot hi mashhoor baat hai ki yahan pe khaane-peene ke jo lawazimaat bante hain, they are very tasty and very rich. Aur jo yahan ka nawabi culture hai, aur yahaan ki jo zubaan hai bohot hi fasih (popular) zubaan hai. Aur jo akhlaq yahan ke hain, manners, the respect and regards for seniors and elders is tremendous.” Then, giving a mock salute, he adds, “Lucknow ke log jo ek doosre ke liye respect aur regard rakkhte hain, usey maanna padega.”Talking about cricketers from UP and the potential of the youngsters here, Kirmani said there are many Indian cricketers from the state like Suresh Raina , Mohamad Kaif, Piyush Chawla and there could be quite a few more also. “But you could be rest assured that there is no dearth of talent in our country. The talent has to be initiated from the school level. The UP Cricket Association should conduct inter-school cricket tournaments in the age group of 12-16 and from that competition you will get a lot of hidden talent,” advises the veteran cricketer, adding, “And this is how it should start off to unearth and groom talent because this is the grooming place for the young cricketers to go and play the higher standards of the game and climb the ladder of success. From here, the right talent has to be picked, taken into the state academy like we have in Karnataka, the cricket academy.”Speaking about the changes in the game since he played active cricket, Kirmani says the biggest honour for him was when the team had won the World Cup in 1983. “My personal achievement was being awarded the Best Wicket Keeper in the world from 1979 to 1986 and it was given by none other than the all-time great wicket-keeper from England, Godfrey Evans. But it is very unfortunate that nobody mentions this. Everyone talks about the 175 knock of Kapil Dev in the Zimbabwe match which was unfortunately not recorded for television. That was the most crucial match for the Indian team during the 1983 World Cup matches to qualify for semis and the finals. This was the biggest and the most devastating and the best innings I have ever seen from the bat of Kapil Dev who scored 175, and everyone talks about that but nobody talks about who gave him the support; Yours sincerely,” says Kirmani, pointing towards himself.He goes on to add, “We were 17 for five and 120 for eight when I walked in. And we had the partnership going for the eight wicket of 128 runs. If I had not given that stand to Kapil Dev we wouldn’t have won the World Cup. Nevertheless, it does not matter to me as long as the country has won the World Cup. It is just that not many know that I had been awarded the Best Wicket Keeper in the World award.”Syed Mujtaba Hussain Kirmani (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)And while team India already has a bowling coach, a batting and also a fielding coach, there's no one to coach wicket keepers. Laughing out loud, the cricketer says, “I am asking the same question as to why team India doesn’t have a wicket-keeping coach, which is the most important place in cricket. Wicket keeping is not like batting or bowling or fielding. It according to me holds the most important place in cricket and so you got to have a wicket-keeping coach. When you can add these three areas, bowling, batting and fielding why not wicket keeping which is the most crucial place in cricket? Any team can walk in without a bowler without a batsman and without an all-rounder but they can not walk in without a wicket keeper. So on that count, I think that a wicket-keeping coach is a must. Because you can not get away by saying that it is a result-oriented thing so, no technique is required in wicket keeping,” says Kirmani, adding, “We have never been given an opportunity by the board of my own state to coach upcoming promising wicket keepers. This is the least that I can do to give back to this great game of cricket whatever little experience I have gained from my 50 years of experience. So now it’s my appeal to the president of the Board of Control for Cricket in India Sourav Ganguly , my dear friend, get me some place to share my experiences with the youngsters, particularly in the wicket keeping aspect. I would like to train these youngsters how to become good gentleman cricketers. This is the least I can do. The way I have been groomed, the way I have seen success.”Answering the question of why Indian cricket team has not been able to win the World Cup since 2011, Kirmani says that after the Indian team won the World Cup in 1983 – the first-ever World Cup won by the Indian team – it took 28 years for the next Indian team to win the next World Cup in 2011 where MS Dhoni was the captain. “You can not expect a team to be the world champion at all times. There were instances like West Indies, who ruled cricket for nearly two decades, they won the inaugural 1975, they won the 1979 World Cup and we broke the hoodoo by beating them in 1983. After 28 years India won and then it is a matter of luck, the matter of application and it is the matter of how you progress in the entire tournament. In 1983 nobody expected the Indian team to even qualify, even we did not think that. But there were some very finer points of the games through which we had a belief in ourselves. We believed in our capability. In this great game of cricket, this is the bottom line, which has its glorious uncertainties. You can not be on top at all times, there have to be failures which are part and parcel of this great game of cricket. So I suppose this was the part and parcel of the Indian team which could not win the World Cup which went by.”Talking about the techniques getting updated today and also increase in sledging on ground, Kirmani laughs and says, “Indeed from our time to this era of cricket, there has been a vast change in this game. We never had a coach, but we still won the World Cup. We just had a manager, we had an assistant manager to take care of our travel. And now you have got eight support staff. Globally, in each and every team, there is so much of technology which has gone into this game and in our times, I suppose, we played like gentleman cricketers. I can very proudly say that we never sort of abused any player, we appreciated each and everybody’s good efforts. We never cursed any bowler or any batsman. If you see the videos of our entire 1970 to 1986 matches, the bowlers were so well mannered, just taking wickets. Like when Kapil Dev took 8 wickets, he never ran around the ground with all the players running behind him. There was no television or such media in our time. So the time has changed but the gentlemanliness according to me, with due respect to the gentlemen who aäre globally in each and every team, the gentlemanliness is gone from the game, according to me. The proof is that fines are being imposed upon cricketers because they abuse, mics are put behind wickets or inside the ground, the third umpire is there. We never had such neutral umpires also and there was so much biased feelings among the umpires in our time. New Zealand umpires would not give out to Glenn Turner who was their best batsmen. Viv Richards, they would never give out to him when he was stumped by Bishan Singh Bedi even though he was yards out just because the umpire was a big fan of Viv Richards and wanted to see him score a 100. So there was partiality in our time. Yes, changes have to come in. In our time it was 60 overs to start with in the first World Cup in 1975.Then came 50 overs and now it is 20 overs, and talk of 10 overs is also going on. So good changes have taken place, there’s no two ways about it. But according to me, that gentlemanliness is gone from the team. Each tournament is like a war now and not appreciating each others’ good work. If a batsman hits you for a six on a good length delivery, the bowler gives a ride look at the batsman and then he bowls a bouncer to him trying to injure him. It’s now a game of one upmanship.”— With inputs from Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui

Title: Team 'Malang': The film was more draining emotionally than physically
Content: When one sees the trailer of the upcoming action film Malang , the phrase ' masala potboiler' comes to mind. The film’s lead actor Aditya Roy Kapur , who was recently in Delhi with the rest of the team, does not disagree with the masala tag but adds that there is much more to the film. “I think it is easy to label it as masala and there is nothing wrong with that term," he says, adding, "But I think there is also a lot of interesting stuff set in the real world. There are a lot of interesting characters; a lot of thought has got into the screenplay."When we sit down with the star cast of the film – Aditya, Disha Patani Kunal Kemmu and Anil Kapoor – they stress that the film has something new and fresh, despite being, in their words, a "romantic action-thriller". Kunal says, "You see a lot of action in the trailer of the film, but for all of us it was more emotional than physical at times. There is so much in the film that would emotionally and mentally drain you, but it’s so special for an actor to get an opportunity to do that."Even Anil Kapoor, who has a much larger body of work as compared to the other actors, says there was a chance to do something new for him here. "There are a lot of things in this film everyone is doing for the first time. As an actor I try not to repeat what I have already done. It might look a little jaded."Sunny days are back: Kunal Kemmu and Anil KapoorThe veteran actor adds, "When filmmakers make these kind of stories, they cast people who are new and fresh, which adds to the freshness to the film, and then surround them by people who are slightly more experienced. It is that kind of a film where it has got experience as well as freshness, so it becomes a good package."Recently, Disha said that she was inspired by Angelina Jolie for her grey character in this film. Talking to us, all the four actors say they channel their favourite action stars while doing action. "For me, it's Schwarzenegger, Stallone, Van Damme and Jackie Chan," says Aditya, elaborating on how he grew up devouring films by these action legends. "I've watched their whole filmographies. I've even seen Jackie Chan's badly-dubbed Chinese movies. I grew up watching them and loved them," he says. Disha shares, "For sure, Jackie Chan and Angelina (Jolie). I've grown up with Jackie Chan's films. I think nobody can touch what he has done. That's why he is a legend. It's not easy to do comedy with action. When you do action, the last thing you think about is your expression. It’s so hard to think about how to make it funny."Ladki beautiful: Disha PataniFor Anil Kapoor, the definitive action star today is someone who he has worked with in the past – Tom Cruise. "At the moment, when you think action and a leading man, someone who has remained a leading man for 30-35 years now, is Tom Cruise. He looks good, does all his stunts and he is still one of the biggest stars. I think Tom Cruise is someone I really look up to where action is concerned," he tells us.Kunal, however, finds his idols closer home. "For me it's Dharmendra, Amitabh Bachchan , Sunny Deol and Nagarjuna. That's how I wanted to be as an actor," he says, going back to Nagarjuna's iconic fight scene from the 1989 hit Shiva. "I remember in Shiva, when Nagarjuna takes out that cycle chain, it just became iconic," he says.When it comes to the younger actors, most online news articles on them use adjectives like 'hot', 'stylish', and 'chiseled'. But very rarely are words like 'talented' used. The actors say it's a direct result of them being active on social media more than the previous generation of actors. Disha says, "When your film comes out, that's the only time when people can talk about your talent. But I think it's fine. That's how the world works." Aditya adds that they have all become more vain as a result of trying to constantly look good for social media. He says, "Instagram has changed the world in the last five years. It's gotten people to be more conscious about how they look. We are more vain, maybe, in general. Earlier, being vain was not seen as a good quality. But now, people unabashedly want to look good. That was looked down upon ten years ago. It's just a sign of the times. That's why people keep talking about how everyone is looking all the time. There's no use trying to fight it."Kunal admits that initially, he tried posting pictures he had clicked instead of his own pictures on social media, only to be admonished by friends. "Honestly, when Instagram came around, I thought it's for photographers to put stuff up and I started doing that. People asked me, 'What are you doing? Why are you taking pictures of buildings, doors, flowers? This is not what it is. The camera is supposed to be facing the other way,'" he says with a laugh. Aditya adds, "I think that’s how it started. Now it has turned into this beast. It's a lookbook of sorts. It's your personal portfolio. People say, 'You're so boring. Put up pictures of yourself na!' It's just the times we live in."

In our time it was 60 overs to start with in the first World Cup in 1975.Then came 50 overs and now it is 20 overs, and talk of 10 overs is also going on. So good changes have taken place, there’s no two ways about it. But according to me, that gentlemanliness is gone from the team. Each tournament is like a war now and not appreciating each others’ good work. If a batsman hits you for a six on a good length delivery, the bowler gives a ride look at the batsman and then he bowls a bouncer to him trying to injure him. It’s now a game of one upmanship.”— With inputs from Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui

Title: Rahul Raj Singh’s name cleared in Kesha Khambati case
Content: Soon after Pratyusha Banerjee ’s death in April 2016, as many as four women had come out, accusing Rahul Raj Singh , who recently changed his name to Rahul Harshbardhan Singh , of swindling them. One of them was South actress Kesha Khambhati, who had accused Rahul of borrowing Rs 2.5 lakh from her. She alleged that he had borrowed the amount to pay his rent, but didn’t return it even after several months.Kesha filed a lawsuit against Rahul at the Metropolitan Magistrate Court, Andheri, in December 2016. The latest development is that he has been acquitted in the case.Rahul says, “Kesha had accused me of taking Rs 2.5 lakh from her, but she couldn’t prove it before the court. I had to wait for three years to get my name cleared. The final hearing took place in December 2019. I have been through a lot in the past. People refused to rent out flats to me because of my past. They look at me as a fraudster and criminal. I want to breathe peacefully in this city just like I used to before April 1, 2016 (Pratyusha had died on the day).”Despite repeated attempts, we couldn’t reach Kesha for comment.

Title: What you eat affects your mood
Content: Diet is important for not just our physical health but mental health too. Multiple studies suggest that a balanced diet full of veggies, fruits and antioxidant-rich food can reduce stress & anxiety levelsWhat you eat affects not just our physical health, but mental health, too, by influencing our mood. A new study published in the journal European Neuropsychopharmacology established a link between poor diet and the worsening of mood disorders, including anxiety and depression. According to researchers, the link between diet and mental health can be firmly established in certain cases like the impact of Vitamin B12 deficiency on depression, among other things.Nutritionists and health experts tell us about the food items that one must incorporate in their daily diet for the overall well-being of an individual.Ashwagandha, also known as Indian ginseng or winter cherry, is a popular supplement with medicinal properties that can help in reducing stress and anxiety. Lovneet says, "Indian adaptogens like ashwagandha and brahmi can be had in a fat medium, either in milk or coconut oil mixed in warm water (if you are lactose intolerant), or ghee. A single root of ashwagandha can help in tackling stress or anxiety, and improve your mental health by balancing the spiked up cortisol levels, which is a stress hormone."Items of nuts and seeds family, pumpkin seeds, lentils, cashews and peanuts that are rich in magnesium help in relaxing muscles and act as a mood stabiliser, resulting in overall mental well-being.The deficiency of serotonin (a monoamine neurotransmitter, that contribute towards feelings of well-being and happiness) can lead to depression. Bananas are rich in tryptophan, which is converted to serotonin.Studies suggest that fish oil contains omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA), and PUFAs are known to induce an antidepressant effect. Vegans or vegetarians can buy algae plant oil, which is packed with omega-3 fatty acids that help in fighting depression.You feel full and energetic for a couple of hours after having these complex carbs as they help in providing a sustained energy resource, which is needed when you are dealing with stress, anxiety and depression. Lentils are a rich source of magnesium, and the fibre helps in improving gut health. Having enough amount of soluble fibre soups ensures the environment inside your intestine is alkaline and helps in the absorption of other nutrients, which improves gut health. That, in turn, improves one’s mental health.Depression could be a condition because of an existing, underlying condition, it could be post-partum or because of the thyroid. The reasons can vary. "So knowing the cause of your anxiety or depression helps in food intervention. If you have thyroid, and if you feel fatigued as soon as you wake up, and if that’s the reason for feeling blue, then having dairy products like milk and yogurt helps as it is rich iniodine and helps in beating stress and anxiety," says Lovneet.Nutritionist and health coach Tapasya Mundhra suggests people suffering from mental health issues should restrict the consumption of these foodStudies have shown that negative mood-related drinking can make people vulnerable to developing both major depression and alcoholdependenceSeveral studies suggest that the intake of sweet food, beverages and added sugars has been linked with depressive symptoms in several populationsCaffeine brings down the serotonin levels in the brain, studies suggest. "This can make anxiety worse, and or even trigger an anxietyattack," says Tapasya.

Title: Welcoming Israeli art in Delhi
Content: It is that time of the year again when artists and art aficionados flock to the city to see artwork from all over the world at one of the biggest art events in Delhi. Just a day before the art event kicked off, the Israeli ambassador Ron Malka hosted a few such aficionados at his residence.Israeli ambassador Ron Malka with wife Lea Malka The ambassador's drawing room looked no less than an art gallery, with the creations of two Israeli artists – Yaacov Agam and Roy Yariv – adorning it. The two artists' creations is also a part of the art event. The ambassador hosted a pre-event reception at his residence to introduce his guests to Israeli art. "We are happy to welcome Israeli art in Delhi," commented the ambassador as he showed his guests the different artwork displayed at his residence.Greek Ambassador Dionyssios Kyvetos and Agis Loizou, High Commissioner, Republic of Cyprus , catching up at the Israeli ambassador's residenceIsraeli artist Roy Yariv, whose work was showcased during the evening, was also present at the reception. He told us that this is his second visit to India. "I came to India last year. It's an amazing country and I get inspired each time I come here. While walking on the street, you see so much chaos, but there is an order to that chaos, things keep moving. I was fascinated by this. Also, you see many contrasts co-existing here, it is this contrast that I am trying to present in my work also," he said, adding, "The other day, I was walking on the street and I saw a lady sitting on a carpet wearing a sari. I thought that if I could just paint this sari and put it in a gallery, people will love it. Art is present everywhere on the streets of India. The colours, patterns, everything fascinates me."He also shared that the next time he comes to India, he will get his "Bollywood-inspired" artwork. "I can't reveal much right now, but that will be something for India," he said.

Title: Economic Survey 2020 pitches reforms, says free market part of India’s ethos
Content:
Survey makes it clear that wealth creators need not be viewed with suspicion and markets are best left to gove... Read More

‘Effect of curbs opposite of what was intended’

NEW DELHI: The Economic Survey for 2019-20, released on Friday, continues the post-liberalisation tradition of pushing for pro-market reforms, but arguably with greater vehemence than ever before.More importantly, its source for inspiration in this direction is not, unlike in the past, the experience of other fast-growing economies like the Asian tigers but India’s own past. The author of the Survey argues strongly that India’s civilizational ethos has celebrated wealth creators and that this is what had allowed the country to be the “dominant economic power globally” for “more than three-fourths of known economic history”.India’s four-decade long ‘dalliance with socialism’, the Survey maintains, was an aberration from this norm of relying on “the invisible hand of the market for wealth creation with the support of the hand of trust”.Citing Kautilya and Thiruvalluvar liberally, the Economic Survey for 2019-20 makes a case that ethical entrepreneurship was India’s intrinsic genius and a return to it is what would allow it to once again shine on the world stage.The hands-off prescription extends to doing away with the Essential Commodities Act, government intervention in grain markets, and even drug price regulation, an area in which the current government boasts of having pushed the envelope. In each case, it argues, the actual effect of regulation was the opposite of what was intended, making controlled items costlier and in short supply. In the same vein, the Survey suggests that debt waivers were counter-productive.Acknowledging the slowdown in the economy, which it attributes to the financial sector dragging down the real economy, the Survey observes, “Considering the urgent priority of the government to revive growth in the economy, the fiscal deficit target may have to be relaxed for the current year.”It argues for an aggressive push to disinvestment in PSUs in the coming year, pointing out that the strong mandate to the government gives it the ability to undertake bold reforms. Public sector banks are cited as examples of inefficiency and wealth destruction. Yet, the Survey stops short of calling for their privatisation, instead suggesting steps that need to be taken to make them “more efficient so that they are able to adeptly support the nation in its march towards being a $5 trillion economy”.The Survey makes a bold statement, saying the government could explore the privatisation of education at all levels to augment capacity. It calls for a boost for labour-intensive exports by making ‘Assemble-in-India’ an extension of Make in India. The Survey coins the term “Thalinomics”, dedicating a chapter to the idea. It tries to establish that steps taken by the government to moderate inflation have made the common thali more affordable for working people than would otherwise have been the case.Beyond this broad thrust of enabling a market-driven economy with a strong underpinning of trust, the Survey exudes optimism about the future suggesting the economy would grow between 6% and 6.5% in the coming year. It also seeks to refute suggestions that India’s GDP numbers are questionable.Overall, the Survey makes it clear that wealth creators need not be viewed with suspicion and markets are best left to govern themselves with governments only making sure rogue elements don’t undermine trust. It attempts to “put to rest any scepticism about the benefits accruing from a market economy, both in economic thinking and policymaking” and emphasises the idea of “trust as a public good that gets enhanced with greater use”.Referring to trade agreements, the Survey departs from official thinking, saying exports have received a greater boost from such agreements than imports.

Title: Culture and theater curry for Bareillywallahs!
Content:

Title: Nirbhaya convicts hanging latest news: Court defers Nirbhaya case hangings, no new date set
Content:
A Delhi court on Friday and “postponed till further orders” hanging of the four convicts in the 2012 Nirbhaya ... Read More

Trial court cites prison rules, says 3 convicts can’t be hanged separately

NEW DELHI: Redress of grievances through procedure established by law is the hallmark of any civilised society, said a Delhi court on Friday and “postponed till further orders” hanging of the four convicts in the 2012 Nirbhaya case.Additional sessions judge Dharmendra Rana stated, “The courts of this country cannot afford to adversely discriminate against any convict, including death row convicts, in pursuit of his legal remedies by turning a Nelson’s eye towards him.”Special prosecutor Irfan Ahmed said that Mukesh had exhausted all his constitutional and legal remedies and the mercy plea of another convict Vinay Kumar Sharma was pending. In case of the other two, Pawan and Akshay, there weren’t any pleas pending. The state prosecutor, therefore, said that barring Vinay, the other three men could be hanged on February 1.Ahmed submitted that any relief to the three convicts apart from Sharma was tantamount to abuse of the process of law and lead to travesty of justice.The court, however, dealt with the prosecution’s contention stating that Rule 836 of the Delhi Prison Rules provided that if an appeal or an application is made by only one convict, the execution of sentence shall be postponed in the case of co-convicts. Appearing for the three convicts — Sharma, Gupta and Thakur — advocate A P Singh argued that while Sharma’s mercy plea had been filed, convict Thakur intended to file a mercy plea before the President of India.Amicus curiae Vrinda Grover and advocate Soutik Banerjee, who appeared for convict Mukesh, submitted that the convict had been “earnestly” and “sincerely” pursuing his legal remedies without any unnecessary delay.Grover stressed that since all convicts were held guilty for the same offence and were convicted by a common judgment their fate could not be segregated and convict Mukesh’s case couldn’t be dealt with separately.Grover relied on a precedent of the Supreme Court in the matter of Harbans Singh versus the state of UP to contend that the execution of the death sentence would lead to an “irreversible and irreparable” process. She also argued that in case the mercy plea of similarly placed convicts is favourably considered by the President of India, the change in circumstance would entitle Kumar to file a fresh mercy plea.Present in court were Nirbhaya’s parents, who paid close attention to the proceedings. Advocates Seema Kushwaha and Jitender Kumar Jha, who represented them, argued that the convicts were trying to thwart justice by adopting delaying tactics. Jha also stated that according to a provision of the Delhi Prison Rules, 2018, the jurisdiction to decide such applications, filed by convicts, lay with the government and not with the court.Unimpressed with the contention, the court observed, “I cannot agree with the contention of the counsel for the victim that the jurisdiction to dispose of the application at hand vests with the government and not this court.” Neither did the provision, it went on to add, confer any power upon the executive authority to cause the order of the death sentence to be carried into effect nor did it give any judicial power to the authority to deal with such applications.The court also pointed out that the execution of sentence shall in all cases be postponed pending receipt of orders of the President. The court, as a result, had no “hesitation in observing” that the execution of warrant with respect to convict Vinay ought to be postponed. The court held, “As a cumulative effect of the discussion, I am of the opinion that the execution of warrants issued by this court by order dated January 17, 2020 deserves to be postponed till further order.”In Video: Nirbhaya case: Delhi court stays hanging of convicts till further orders

Title: Coronavirus: Air India lifts 366 from Wuhan, to be isolated in Delhi-NCR camps
Content:
First batch of Indian passengers in Air India special flight from Wuhan (ANI)

NEW DELHI/BEIJING: Around 366 Indians evacuated from Wuhan , the Chinese city at the heart of the deadly coronavirus outbreak, and expected to land in New Delhi on Saturday morning, will be placed in complete lockdown for 14 days at two quarantine facilities set up by the Army at Manesar and by ITBP at Chhawla in Delhi.Not even military personnel and doctors and other staff will be allowed to leave the facility unless “compelled by extreme urgency”, an Army officer said.Air India on Friday afternoon sent a double-decker Jumbo 747 to Wuhan from Delhi. After a delay, boarding finally began at Wuhan around 10.30pm (IST). AirIndia said another special plane might be sent on Saturday.Meanwhile, six suspected novel coronavirus cases have surfaced in capital and are being kept under observation in Ram Manohar Lohia (RML) hospital. Apart from Army and ITBP isolation facilities where the returnees from Wuhan in China will be kept under observation for at least 14 days, a 50-bed isolation unit has been set up at Safdarjung Hospital for critically ill patients.Once the Boeing 747 carrying students from Wuhan returns to Delhi, the passengers will undergo initial screening at the airport by a joint team of Armed Forces Medical Services (AFMS) and Airport Health Authority (APHO), and then taken directly to the quarantine centres. About 280 male students are to be taken to the Manesar camp and about 90 passengers, comprising families and women, will go to the Chhawla camp, the health ministry said.The plane, with 15 crew and five cockpit members, has 423 passenger seats. It’s carrying five doctors from RML Hospital and one paramedical staffer of Air India, along with medicines, masks, overcoats, packed food and other equipment. “A team of engineers and security personnel are also in the special aircraft. The rescue mission is led by Captain Amitabh Singh, director (operations) at Air India,” said Dhananjay Kumar, the airline’s spokesperson.At Wuhan, nearly 400 Indians had reached the airport ahead of their evacuation. They had received their boarding passes and were expecting to fly early morning on Saturday.The returnees went through a check-up at Wuhan. Reports reaching Beijing indicated that none of the travellers was stopped at the time of giving boarding passes. Most of them are students studying medicine and other subjects in five universities in Wuhan. They were among students who had chosen to stay back during the Spring festival holidays.At Delhi airport, the Army said the evacuees will be classified into three groups. The first group of “suspect cases” showing signs of fever, cough or respiratory distress, will be directly transferred to an isolation ward at the Army Base Hospital in Delhi Cantonment (BHDC).The second category will be of “close contact cases”, which will include individuals who have visited a seafood/animal market or a health facility or have encountered a Chinese person with symptoms in the last 14 days. They will be escorted in earmarked vehicles directly to the quarantine facility. The third group of “non-contact cases” will also be clubbed along with the “close contact” category and sent to the quarantine facility.The facility near Manesar consists of accommodation barracks for the students, administrative and medical facilities areas. “To prevent any mass outbreak, the facility has been divided into sectors, each with a maximum capacity of 50 students. Each sector has been further subdivided into barracks. The students in different sectors will not be allowed to intermingle,” said the officer.All returnees and visitors, in turn, will wear three-layered masks. After 14 days, persons with no symptoms will be allowed to go home with their detailed documentation being sent to their district/state surveillance units for further observation.“Those suspected of having been infected with coronavirus will be discharged after clinical recovery and two successive negative samples tested for n-COV. No civilian or serving personnel detailed to work at the facility will be allowed to go outside unless compelled by extreme emergency,” an Army officer said.Meanwhile, the six individuals admitted to RML Hospital with suspected coronavirus symptoms have all recently returned from China, including a 24-year-old woman who had been staying in China since 2015 and returned on January 29.The rest are all men, including a 19-year-old youth who was in China from November 2019 to January 24, and 34-year-old who returned on January 16 after a 10-year stay in that country.While five of the six self-reported to the hospital on Thursday, a 32-year-old man who had visited China from January 4 to January 11 was admitted on Friday. “The samples of all the six patients have been sent for testing and the reports are awaited,” an RML official said.In Video: Watch: First batch of Indian passengers board Air India special flight in Wuhan

Title: IBM CEO: Arvind Krishna to lead IBM, joins club of global Indian CEOs
Content: BENGALURU: IBM just added to the roster of Indian-origin executives leading some of the foremost technology companies in the world.IIT Kanpur alumnus Arvind Krishna will lead the 108-year-old, $80-billion American company from April 6, when CEO Virginia Rometty steps down from that position. The company’s share price, which has been trending down since 2013 except for occasional spikes, rose by 5% in opening trade in the US following the announcement.Indian-origin CEOs now lead tech companies that together command a market capitalisation of nearly $2.7 trillion. These include Satya Nadella of Microsoft, Sundar Pichai of Alphabet/Google, Shantanu Narayen of Adobe, Sanjay Mehrotra of Micron Technology , Nikesh Arora of Palo Alto Networks, and George Kurian of NetApp.Krishna, 57, son of an Indian army officer, joined IBM in 1990, right after university, and is currently IBM’s senior vice president for cloud and cognitive software, two of the company’s biggest focus areas. He led the company's $34-billion acquisition of open source enterprise software company Red Hat in 2018, a deal that was the biggest in IBM’s history, and on which a lot of IBM’s future rides."Arvind is the right CEO for the next era at IBM," said Rometty. "He is a brilliant technologist who has played a significant role in developing our key technologies such as artificial intelligence, cloud, quantum computing and blockchain.”Many would be watching to see whether he can do for IBM what Nadella did for Microsoft. IBM’s annual revenue fell steadily for many years from 2011, when it had touched a high of $107 billion, and has risen only slightly in the past couple of years. It was weighed down by its legacy businesses, and could not transition to newer digital offerings with as much agility as younger companies like Amazon and Google. Nadella rejuvenated Microsoft with his focus on the cloud and partnerships with companies that were once regarded as competitors.In IBM’s case, analysts remain divided on whether it can pull itself up in a sustainable way. The company’s decision to repose faith in a man who has been a researcher and core to IBM’s new-age offerings in cloud and AI has raised hopes. Krishna hold 15 patents, and perhaps because of his research focus, has been relatively low profile.Rometty described Krishna as a superb operational leader, “able to win today while building the business of tomorrow.” Arvind, she said, has grown IBM's cloud and cognitive software business and led the largest acquisition in the company's history. “Through his multiple experiences running businesses in IBM, Arvind has built an outstanding track record of bold transformations and proven business results, and is an authentic, values-driven leader. He is well-positioned to lead IBM and its clients into the cloud and cognitive era," she said.Alex Gorsky, chairman of the Board's executive compensation and management resources committee said Krishna “thinks and executes squarely at the intersection of business and technology."Going by the track record of Indian-origin CEOs, there’s a good chance that Krishna will deliver. Nadella, Pichai, Narayen, Mehrotra, Arora, and Kurian have all produced great results as CEOs till now.In Video: #Arvind Krishna: How Indians are taking over global IT giants

Title: NPR: Government allays fears, to tweak NPR form
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Women shout slogans during an anti-CAA protest in Mumbai on Friday (PTI)

NEW DELHI: Acknowledging the apprehensions of NDA allies regarding some new fields introduced in the National Population Register (NPR) questionnaire, the government has offered to tweak the NPR form to include a disclaimer that not replying to questions relating to date and place of birth of parents shall not impact the respondents’ citizenship status or put them in the ‘doubtful’ list.

Sources said at the NDA meeting on Friday, allies like JD(U), LJP and Akali Dal flagged the apprehension among certain sections about the new NPR form, leading home minister Amit Shah to state that while dropping columns from the form may not be feasible at this stage, a disclaimer that providing date and place of birth of parents will be optional could be inserted. “The government has already made it clear that it won’t be mandatory for respondents to share these details and that there is no need to produce any documents,” a source said.

The meeting also saw PM Narendra Modi striking a forceful note on CAA and saying that NDA members need not be defensive about it even as he assured Muslims that they should not worry about any infringement of rights which were safe. “The PM assured all that every citizen from minority communities, including Muslims, have as much rights as he has. He said the Constitution is supreme and there is no room for discrimination among citizens,” LJP patriarch Ram Vilas Paswan told TOI.

Other leaders also said the PM urged them to fully support the CAA and back it strongly in Parliament. Sources said Akali Dal, which had demanded that Muslims from Pakistan should also be brought under CAA’s purview, too said that it was strongly with the decision, even though the party has its own ideology.

The NPR exercise is scheduled between April and September. While Paswan had hinted at changes in the NPR form while talking to reporters in Patna on Tuesday, JD(U) chief Nitish Kumar suggested the question could be left out, considering there was confusion among people that leaving the relevant columns blank may create trouble for them in future.

The government, meanwhile, is also considering allowing the NPR form to be filled online by around 60 crore residents whose Aadhaar details are available in the NPR database from 2010 and 2015.

The NDA allies passed five resolutions hailing the PM for the Bodo accord and settlement of Bru migrants in Tripura. The other resolutions passed were on nullifying Articles 370 and 35A and opening of Kartarpur corridor for Sikh pilgrims. The allies also hailed the government’s decision to give ownership rights to people living in over 1,300 unauthorised colonies in Delhi, which is expected to benefit nearly 40 lakh people.

Title: Farrukhabad: Man who took 25 kids hostage killed by cops, villagers stone wife to death
Content:
A murder convict held 25 children hostage for several hours

KATHARIYA VILLAGE (FARRUKHABAD): Subhash Batham, a murder convict who held a fake birthday party for his daughter in UP’s Farrukhabad and then held 25 children who were his “guests” hostage for several hours, was shot dead by police early on Friday morning. His wife, Ruby, who was allegedly an accomplice to the act, died in a hospital soon after after angry local residents pelted her with stones, lynching her. Police on Friday filed an FIR against 300 unknown people under Section 302 (murder).Police, forensic teams and the bomb disposal squad ( Moradabad ) claimed they had recovered 145 crude bombs, including a cylinder bomb and a can bomb, along with wire, battery, tape, sutali (thread) that they said were used in a bomb hurled by Batham during the night, injuring two constables.Twenty live cartridges, 11 used cartridges of a country made pistol and a .315 bore rifle were recovered from his house, police said, along with the used cartridge of an AK-47. Some of the children who had been held hostage had, however, told TOI that they saw only a katta and another country made rifle with Batham.Police said Batham — who never attended school — acquired his “bomb-making skills” during a 12-year stint in jail after he was convicted of murder. The basement in which he held the children hostage doubled up as his laboratory where he painstakingly readied the crude bombs, cops added, suggesting he had been planning his act for a long time.But as far as his motives are concerned, there are different theories — anger at the residents for boycotting him for a long time for marrying a Dalit woman, allegedly being left out of government schemes, and enmity against those who testified against him in court in the murder case.According to police, Batham had claimed on the night of the incident that the gram pradhan of Kathariya village and a local MLA had falsely implicated him in his uncle’s murder due to which he had ended up wasting his youth in prison. The gram pradhan, Harvir Singh, told TOI that he indeed testified in court against Batham and that’s why the man held enmity against him. “Batham murdered his uncle in 2001 after he had caught him stealing valuables from a neighbour’s house and scolded him. I was a witness in the case.”Commenting on a letter that Batham had written to authorities — demanding a house and toilet under government schemes — and which he handed to police on Thursday night, the gram pradhan said his demands were baseless. “He had written the letter for a house under the PM Awas Yojana and a toilet under the Swachh Bharat Mission years ago.” The real motive, he insisted, was revenge against him and village residents.Bhojpur MLA Nagendra Singh — who was also the target of Batham’s fury — said that he didn’t know the man but had visited the spot to defuse the situation. “He wanted revenge as he was boycotted by the community for marrying a Dalit woman four years ago,” he said.SP (Farrukhabad) Anil Kumar Mishra said, “The hostage situation could have been created to extort money as he demanded Rs 1 crore for each kid. He also wanted all criminal cases expunged against him.” Batham had five criminal cases going on against him in local courts.Whatever the motive, he was well-prepared, claimed police. “The quantity of bombs was good enough to kill everyone in a radius of 50 metres if they went off at once,” said Farrukhabad special operation group in charge Dinesh Kumar Gautam .Batham was shot even as the crowd of 300 pelted stones at their house. “As they were attacking the couple at the front door, we entered the house from the back. When he saw his wife being attacked, he grabbed his country made rifle after which he was shot dead,” said Mishra.Some residents, however, alleged that policemen “encouraged local residents to pelt stones at the couple”. On Friday, the couple’s bodies were sent for autopsy, while their two and a half year old daughter Kusum was handed over to child authorities.In Video: UP Police rescue all 23 kids kept hostage in Farrukhabad, suspect shot down

Title: Parties should justify fielding tainted politicians: SC backs EC
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Supreme Court of India

NEW DELHI: The Supreme Court on Friday turned down Election Commission’s stand for taking action against candidates facing criminal charges and political parties for fielding them, but endorsed the poll watchdog’s suggestion that a party which chooses to field a candidate with criminal background should mandatorily spell out reasons justifying its choice.

A bench of Justices R F Nariman and S Ravindra Bhat said it is in agreement with the EC’s suggestion that political parties be directed to publish the credentials, achievements and criminal antecedents of candidates in newspapers, social media platforms and the party’s website along with the reason for preferring a candidate facing criminal cases.
