“It shall be mandatory for all political parties to upload on their websites details of individuals with criminal antecedents, who have been selected as candidates, along with reasons why other individuals without criminal antecedents could not be selected. The reasons shall have to (provide) qualifications, achievements and merit of the candidate concerned and winnability shall not be sufficient justification,” the Commission said.

Though political parties might address this requirement by noting that the candidate faces politically coloured cases, the condition does force parties to place their reasons on record. Perhaps, the expectation seems to be that the embarrassment over having too many criminals on its slate might impel parties to be more discriminating in the selection of its candidates.

The court’s order also reflects limitations of efforts to keep “tainted” candidates off the ballot, given presumption of innocence until convicted. Also, the task of separating “minor” infractions like arrests during protests and dharnas and more serious criminal charges can present a different set of problems.

The bench also took into account opponents resorting to malicious litigation to get a candidate benched.“Cases with political overtones get filed and it is easy to get charges framed against a political opponent by slapping sedition charges and accusing them of being anti-national. We have to be careful as you may knock out a good candidate out of election. It would become an instrument of oppression. If charges are framed on the last date of nomination, the aggrieved candidate would be remedy-less. We have to be keenly aware about those situations,” the bench said.

The EC’s suggestion was filed in compliance of an apex court order asking its counsel and senior advocate Vikas Singh to sit with senior advocate Gopal Sankaranarayanan , appearing for petitioner and BJP leader Ashwini Upadhyay , and frame a joint proposal. The court said criminalisation of politics continues unabated and something had to be done in national interest to deal with the menace.

The Commission further said political parties must put all information in public domain about a candidate within 48 hours of nominating him and the party must also submit a report regarding publication within 24 hours. Emphasising the need to curb political parties from fielding tainted people, the Commission said there has been an alarming increase in the number of criminals in politics and told the bench that 24% of MPs had criminal background in 2004 but the number went up to 30% in 2009, 34 % in 2014 and the present Parliament as many as 43%MPs with grave criminal cases pending against them.

The bench disagreed with the suggestion that the poll panel be empowered to take action against the political party and a candidate under Article 324, including cancelling the nomination in case of non-compliance.

Title: Taarak Mehta Ka Ooltah Chashmah's Disha Vakani aka Daya Ben spotted at a family function with daughter Stuti; see pics
Content: Taarak Mehta Ka Ooltah Chashmah's Disha Vakani aka Daya Ben , who has been missing from the show for more than two years now was recently spotted a family function with her little daughter, Stuti and their pictures have gone viral over the social media. Fans are beaming with joy to see their favourite actress after a long gap and are in total awe of the pictures.Disha, who is an extremely private person stays away from the media and doesn't socialise too. Hence, the actress has been away from the media glare. But she recently attended a family function with her husband and daughter, Stuti.In the pictures, Disha can be seen wearing a pink saree with traditional jewellery, looking absolutely gorgeous, while her little daughter is dressed in a blue jacket. Disha is seen spending some quality time with her family members and enjoying the wedding festivities with her family. The actress' daughter Stuti is seen fully-packed in a blue hoodie lost in her own thoughts.In the images, the actress can be seen getting mobbed at the wedding and her fans are seen getting pictures clicked with her.Disha and her husband, a Chartered accountant from Mumbai, Mayur Pandya embraced parenthood on November 30, 2017, with the arrival of their first baby, Stuti. The actress essayed the role of 'Dayaben' in Taarak Mehta Ka OOltah Chashmah and has been playing the character since 2008. She took a break from the show in November 2017, for her maternity break and since then the actress has not returned to the show. Disha has been enjoying her motherhood phase and is busy spending time with her daughter, Stuti.Recently, a couple of months ago there were talks of the actress' comeback, but Disha only returned to shoot a scene and there has been no development on her return even since then.

Title: Ram Nath Kovind: Amid protests, President Ram Nath Kovind says accept laws passed by House
Content:
President Ram Nath Kovind

NEW DELHI: In what was seen as a reference to protests against the Citizenship Amendment Act, President Ram Nath Kovind on Friday said laws passed by Parliament should be accepted by citizens and that violence weakened society.The President’s remarks during his address to the joint sitting of Parliament came amid slogans, placards and banners marring the ceremonial function that marks the start of the budget session. The NDA and opposition benches clashed in a rare commotion during the usually staid address that is written by the government.“Our Constitution also places an expectation that the decisions taken through democratic processes will be accepted by the countrymen,” Kovind said. While the President stoutly defended CAA and the decision to scrap Jammu and Kashmir’s special status, there was no reference to the National Register of Citizens.Kovind said Mahatma Gandhi had held that Hindus and Sikhs of Pakistan who did not wish to live there after Partition could come to India. “It is the duty of the government of India to ensure a normal life for them,” he said quoting Gandhi and added, “I am happy that both the Houses of Parliament have fulfilled this wish by enacting the CAA.”The President said BJP icon Syama Prasad Mookerjee had protested the special status to J&K during the Nehru government. “Today, after seven decades, the whole country is happy that the dream of crores of freedom fighters including Mookerjee has come true,” he said.The remarks elicited thumping of desks by BJP members, the applause turning inordinately long, with even the President having to pause. It turned into a provocation for the opposition as cries of “shame, shame” rent Central Hall, followed by loud slogans — resulting in scenes not witnessed in contemporary history of the joint address which is usually an unremarkable affair.The protesters included Congress, DMK, IUML and other parties. Though the President resumed, the disruption recurred a few times later. At one point, Trinamool Congress MPs stood in their places and unfurled banners with slogans in blood red denouncing CAA-NPR-NRC while some like Congress’s Assam MP Abdul Khaleque demanded “CAA be out of Assam”. He also accused BJP ministers of spreading violence.As a mark of protest, Congress wore black bands to Central Hall and sat at the back, with even veterans Sonia Gandhi , Ghulam Nabi Azad and Adhir Ranjan Chowdhury giving up their front row seats. Only former PM Manmohan Singh sat in the front row. Some 14 opposition parties sat as a bloc. Two Congress managers went to Singh to inform about the plan but he chose to stay in his seat.Among those present in the front row were PM Narendra Modi, home minister Amit Shah and defence minister Rajnath Singh.Seeking to quell doubts over CAA, Kovind said, “My government would like to clarify once again that the procedures, which have existed for people from all faiths of the world who believe in India and who wish to obtain Indian citizenship, remain unchanged. A person of any faith can follow these processes and become a citizen of India.”He also assured that precautions had been taken to buffer the north-east from any cultural impact of CAA.As the President focused on CAA and Article 370, he condemned the “atrocities on minorities in Pakistan”, referring to a recent incident in Nankana Sahib to buttress the point. “I urge the world community to take cognizance of it and take necessary steps in this regard,” he said.The President also urged people to “buy local for a better tomorrow”. He urged people’s representatives from panchayat upwards to help in making “buy local” a success, which he said would help small entrepreneurs.In Video: Wish of Mahatma Gandhi has been fulfilled through enactment of CAA: President Ram Nath Kovind

Title: 37 politicians who visited Jammu and Kashmir to report on status of government steps
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Law minister Ravi Shankar Prasad visited Jammu and Kashmir (File photo)

NEW DELHI: All 37 central ministers who visited Jammu and Kashmir as part of the government’s outreach will submit feedback to the Prime Minister’s Office (PMO) on the implementation of various development initiatives in the Union Territory , officials said on Friday.

So far, 14 ministers have submitted their assessment on implementation of the welfare schemes to the home ministry, which will be forwarded to the Prime Minister’s Office for follow-up action. The remaining ministers are expected to turn in their feedback soon, a home ministry functionary said. While the ministers had sent in their detailed reports earlier, PMO officials are said to have sought information to be recorded in a standard proforma, giving out precise details regarding penetration and impact of development and entitlement schemes.

The ministers had visited J&K earlier this month following a directive from PM Modi, who wanted an honest assessment of various welfare schemes being carried out in the newly-created UT.

Among those who visited J&K included law minister Ravi Shankar Prasad , sports minister Kiren Rijiju , ministers of state for home G Kishan Reddy and Nityanand Rai , among others. The ministers only spoke about development initiatives and there was no reference to political issues, an official said.

While interacting with local people, the ministers got first hand information about local roads, healthcare facilities, availability of LPG cylinders, power situation, functioning of academic institutions besides other issues.

There will be two sets of feedback — one on the initiatives taken by the UT administration and the other about the central government initiatives, the official said.

Most central ministers stayed overnight at the respective places that they visited in J&K like Baramulla, Ganderbal and Doda.

Title: From Make-in-India to Assemble-in-India
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: Make-in-India has got a makeover. The Economic Survey has advocated that the government make an aggressive ‘Assemble-in-India’ pitch, without jettisoning the Make-in-India anthem, to create four crore jobs in five years. The idea is to take advantage of the trade war and adjustments due to rising labour costs in China.The strategy, which has already yielded results in assembly of cars as well as mobile phones, is seen as the panacea for employment generation, especially in the manufacturing sector, at a time when job creation has become a major concern.The other focus seems to be on entrepreneurship, with government’s annual economic report card indicating that there is a massive activity at the ground level, seen in the establishment of 1.2 lakh firms in 2018, an over 70% rise over the 70,000 new entities set up in 2014.But India becoming home to global giants such as Apple, Samsung and Sony, much like China, is seen to be the main driver in addition to the focus on traditional sectors such as textiles and footwear.The underlying theme is availability of labour and the massive potential for exports, given the low share of network products such as telecom equipment, office machines, electrical machinery and road products. To to do this, India has to be part of a global value chain as developing countries find it tough to create a market for capital-intensive products in quality and brand-conscious richer countries. It will also require government to allow import of components at low tariffs.As an example, China received less than $8.5 for assembling every iPhone 7 , but the value added was very high given the large volumes, which make it a global assembly hub.Going by current projections, India’s export of network products is projected to rise from $32 billion in 2018 to $248 billion in 2025 and top $490 billion in 2030. As a result, direct employment is projected to increase from 4 4 lakh jobs in 2020 to 1.4 crore jobs in 2025 and over 2.5 crore in 2030. If the overall impact is included, the impact on jobs will be much higher, the Survey said.

Title: Middle class to benefit from I-T rejig, says Nirmala Sitharaman
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman (Photo: PTI)

MUMBAI: Middle-class investors will pay tax on dividend income from shares and mutual funds at lower rates, said finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman on Friday, adding that they will have more money in their hands to spend following the proposals announced in the Budget.

Sitharaman had proposed dividend income to be taxable in the hands of investors at their income tax slab rates and abolished the payment of dividend distribution tax, or DDT, by companies and mutual funds.

In the current system, after the deduction of DDT by companies and mutual funds, dividend becomes tax-free in the hands of investors. However, in the new system, the tax burden on investors in the higher income tax rate bracket increases, while it comes down for people in the lower slab.

The finance minister said changes proposed in the personal income tax also puts more money in the hands of the middle class and they are “capable of deciding where to put that without being directed by anyone”.

“Eventually, we want to have an income tax framework with low tax rates and easy compliance.” Sitharaman added that the government wants to decriminalise laws. “We started with Companies Act and now we are looking at the Income Tax Act. We want to ensure that civil offences are not treated as criminal offences,” she told newspersons in Mumbai.

Before addressing the media, the finance minister, along with her team, held a session with economists, financial services players and professionals for their feedback on the Budget proposals. The government has also proposed to list LIC on the stock exchanges which would “bring retail investors into the picture”.

“The IPO of LIC will make issues more transparent,” Sitharaman said. An IPO unlocks value in a company, offers the outfit access to capital markets and makes it disciplined. The LIC stock market launch, when it happens, will be India’s largest IPO.

The Budget has also increased insurance cover on bank deposits five-fold to Rs 5 lakh. Deposit insurance, provided by the Deposit Insurance and Credit Guarantee Corporation, an arm of the RBI, had been static at Rs 1 lakh since 1993. The government is working on the Financial Resolution Deposit Insurance (FRDI) Bill, but not sure when it will be tabled in the House, said Sitharaman before heading to Chennai for an interaction with industry captains.

Title: Mokama BDO’s erroneous ‘NRC’ letter creates flutters
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

PATNA: A letter seeking explanation from principals of three government schools under Mokama block in Patna district three days ago for their failure to send teachers for training on census created a flutter in political circles in the state on Friday.

Referring to the controversy over the official letter issued by Mokama BDO Satish Kumar on January 28, which mentioned National Register of Citizens (NCR) instead of NPR, leader of opposition in state assembly Tejashwi Prasad Yadav and RLSP chief Upendra Kushwaha tweeted that CM Nitish Kumar’s “lie” has been caught and his (CM’s) stand on the issue “exposed”.

The two leaders also shared screenshot of two different letters issued to the heads of the government secondary schools of Marachi, Mor and Rampur Dumra. The principals of the three schools were asked to furnish names of two teachers from their institutions by January 23 for training on the ongoing ‘NCR’ exercise.

The letter made a mention of personal details of the teachers being required for the ‘NRC’ and the principals were rebuked by the Mokama BDO Satish Kumar for “apparently being opposed to NRC at the instance of some particular political party”.

Sharing screenshot of the letter on his twitter handle, the leader of opposition in the state assembly Tejashwi wrote, “While lie of Nitish Kumar caught. Now you all have to decide who the real Sanghi is (sic)”.

Kushwaha tweeted, “@Nitish Kumar ji, you left even the BJP behind. PM@narendramodi says NRC has not been discussed and you got orders passed. And you have the temerity to accuse school principals of collusion with a political party (sic)?”

Defending the government, IPRD minister Neeraj Kumar said, “The opposition leaders would have done better by sharing the corrigendum issued by the Mokama BDO the very next day, whereby the earlier letter had been cancelled”.

“That the chief minister feels there is no need for NRC in the state needs no reiteration. Further, in the light of the averments by the Prime Minister, it is obvious that the reality of this issue is not lost on the opposition leaders, though if they want to enjoy themselves, it is their choice,” the minister said.

When contacted, BDO Satish Kumar said, “It was a human error, which was rectified the very next day. The correct letter was dispatched and also sent on WhatsApp of the principals concerned.” The BDO said that a show-cause notice was served to office clerk Santosh Kumar for the mistake.

Title: No bird flu outbreak in Patna: Zoo director
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

PATNA: Amid recovery of dead crows from several areas in the city over the past few days, Patna zoo director Amit Kumar on Friday ruled out outbreak of bird flu in the zoo as well as in the city. “Disinfectants are used in the zoo throughout the year for safety of birds. It is a routine process,” he added.

Kumar’s statement came a day after reports in a section of media that the zoo staff have been warned about bird flu and asked to wear mask. “According to the guidelines issued by Central Zoo Authority, Union ministry of agriculture and farmer’s welfare and animal husbandry department for prevention of bird flu, samples from the zoo are sent to regional disease diagnostic laboratory in Kolkata every month,” Kumar said in a press release.

It may be recalled that the zoo was closed for 49 days from December 25 in 2018 following the death of six peafowls due to bird flu.

Title: Uttara Kaanda may be my last novel, hints SL Bhyrappa
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Acclaimed Kannada writer SL Bhyrappa was on Friday conferred the Ambikatanayadutta Award at Bendre Bhavan in D... Read More

Dharwad: A veritable colossus in the world of Indian letters, SL Bhyrappa , who has kept his pen firmly on the page for more than 50 years in the course of which he has authored more than 25 novels hinted that his long innings as an active writer was nearing its end.

Bhyrappa, in Dharwad to receive the prestigious Ambikatanayadatta Award instituted by the Dr Da Raa Bendre National Memorial Trust at the Bendre Bhavan in Sadhanakeri, cited his advanced years as being one of the reasons for contemplating a farewell to writing. Uttara Kaanda , which was a re-telling of the Hindu epic Ramayana published in 2017 was Bhyrappa’s last novel .

Admitting that he had been seized by an impulse to drop his pen for good earlier as well, Bhyrappa added, “But I was often gripped by another idea, another theme and I would set to work on those. This has not come to pass this time around since I have no theme to work on. Considering my age, I do not think Kannada literature can expect another novel from me.”

Sharing his thoughts on the rather contentious issue of introducing the mother tongue as a medium of instruction in schools, Bhyrappa said, “I have discussed this subject with Prime Minister Narendra Modi and impressed on him the need for the native language of the state serving as the medium of instruction till class IV. I suggested that the Supreme Court’s order on this issue needs to be overturned by means of a legislation.”

Bhyrappa said that the PM had concurred with his views on the subject. “However, he expressed helplessness pointing to the habit of the opposition parties to question each bill tabled in the Parliament. He told me that his party colleagues also spoke after the manner of the opposition parties,” Bhyrappa added.

‘Brahmins unjustly blamed for caste system’

In his illustrious career, Bhyrappa refused to identify himself with any particular literary movement , and on Friday, he underscored the perils of an artist’s association with a set of ideas. “Literary movements tie down writers to a particular ideology. A writer associated with such a movement will have to produce works that conform with its ideology,” he said. Training guns at the cliquish power structures at play in the world of letters, Bhyrappa said, “One will find that works adhering to an ideology will be reviewed favourably by critics who are also acolytes of the same. Similarly, when a writer deviates from this ideology, he or she is reproached. I believe that a writer must steer clear of any such movement.”

The doyen of Kannada literature opined that Brahmins had been unjustly been made to wear the yoke of being the perpetrators of the caste system. “In India, caste was tied to professional benefits. It was mutually beneficial for the daughter of a weaver to marry a man in the same profession. Today, you will find doctors choosing spouses in the medical profession,” Bhyrappa added.

The Ambikanayadutta Award bestowed on Bhyrappa carries a citation, memento and a cash reward of Rs 1 lakh. Despite the state government slashing funds to the trust, the members decided against reducing the purse for the award.

GM Hegde, Harsh Dambal, Sangamnath Lokapur, Shashidhar Narendra, Malati Pattanshetti and Venkatesh Machakanur were among those who participated the event. Chairman of Bendre Trust DM Hiremath proposed the vote of thanks at the event.

Title: Over 6k employees join two-day public sector bank strike in city
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Transactions and clearing of cheques worth over 1,400 crore will not take place for next three days

Surat: Banking operations in the Diamond City were severely hit with public sector banks remaining shut as a part of nationwide strike for two days called by United Forum of Bank Unions from Friday.

Over 6,000 bank employees of 17 public sector banks, including State Bank of India (SBI), joined the strike under the banner of Gujarat Bank Workers’ Union (GBWU). About 350 branches of PSU banks across the city were closed.

It is estimated financial transactions and clearing of cheques to the tune of over Rs1,400 crore will not take place for next three days as Sunday happens to be a holiday.

The striking bank employees gathered outside Bank of Baroda (BOB) headquarters on Ghod Dod Road and participated in a demonstration. The bank employees shouted slogans against bank management for not accepting their long-pending demands including 20% pay hike, five-day work a week, merger of special allowance with basic pay, scrapping of new pension scheme etc.

Vasant Barot, organizational secretary of GBWU, said, “The strike was successful on the first day with about 350 branches of 17 public sector banks remaining closed. This will continue on Saturday as well. The banks will reopen only on Monday. Our demands for pay hike and five-day work a week are genuine, but the bank managements are not in our favour.”

Meanwhile, trading community in the city including textile and diamond traders were critical of the bank strike. Champalal Bothra, secretary of Federation of Surat Textile Traders’ Association (FOSTTA), said, “It is month-end and time for giving wages and salaries to employees. The strike has been called at a wrong time. The business in textile market has been severely affected as clearance of cheques will not take place for two days.”

Title: Sachin GIDC members allege scam in estate beautification project
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Surat: Authorities at the Sachin GIDC are in a fix for spending lakhs of rupees for purchasing plants as as part of the industrial estate beautification project.

Several members have raised questions over Rs 42 lakh spent for purchase of 4,000 plants, when the plants were available free-of-cost from the forest department and the Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC).

Former secretary of the Sachin GIDC Cooperative Society, Mayur Golwala has demanded an inquiry alleging a scam and has written letter to the top authorities of the Gujarat Industrial Development Corporation (GIDC). Also, he has demanded that the new proposal for purchasing plants worth Rs 50 lakh be cancelled.

Sources said the decision to plant 4,000 trees in the estate was taken by the Sachin Notified Area Authority in its 38th board of management meeting in October 2018. The notified area had invited quotations from various nurseries in and around Surat for supplying the saplings. The lowest bidder who had quoted Rs 42 lakh for 4,000 trees was given the contract to plant trees in the open spaces of the GIDC estate till June 2019.

“For every single plant, the authorities have spent Rs 1,000. The authorities have not followed the tendering process. The price itself has raised questions against the GIDC authorities when the tree saplings are distributed free of cost by the SMC, forest department and other NGOs,” said Golwala.

Golwala added, “I have demanded an inquiry into the issue. Recently, the board of notified authority has passed a resolution to purchase plants worth Rs 50 lakh two months ago. I have demanded that the proposal be cancelled in the wider interest of the members of GIDC.”

Chairman of Sachin GIDC Notified Area Authority, Mahendra Ramoliya said, “We have purchased the plants as per the guidelines of the GPCB and the National Green Tribunal (NGT). Our purpose is to make the entire GIDC estate green in the next couple of years. The allegations levelled against us are totally baseless and we are ready to face any inquiry.”

Title: Man stabs cousin to death over old dispute in Rajula
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Rajkot: A man was arrested on Friday for allegedly stabbing his cousin to death and injuring another cousin over an old dispute in Rajula of Amreli district on Thursday evening.

Police said the accused, identified Wasim Varaiya (26), had stabbed his cousins — Irfan Varaiya (23) and his brother Imran Varaiya (22) — in Ghanchiwad locality of Rajula.

While Imran was seriously injured, Irfan succumbed to his injuries at Rajula Civil Hospital.

Yunus Varaiya, father of Irfan and Imran, said in his complaint that Wasim and Irfan had been at loggerheads over a trivial issue and had been picking up fights with each other for the past four months. The issue was as trivial as ‘why you are giving me a stare?’

On the day of the crime, when Irfan and Imran came for lunch, Wasim called them out their house and stabbed Irfan. When Imran intervened, he, too, was stabbed.

Both the brothers were rushed to Rajula Civil Hospital, where Irfan died shortly after admission, while Imran was referred to Mahuva Civil Hospital as his condition became critical.

Wasim was arrested from his home on Friday.

Title: 40 robbers attack NTPC plant, 1 dies
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Khargone: Forty armed robbers entered an under-construction plant of National Thermal Power Corporation (NTPC) in Selda Dalchi town of Khargone on Friday to steal construction material, prompting security personnel posted there to open fire. One person was reportedly killed after suffering the gunshots.

Khargone ASP Shashikant Kankane told TOI that 40 armed people entered NTPC plant early on Friday to steal scrap and cables. “As security guards tried to stop them, the armed people started pelting stones at them. This forced the guards to fire in retaliation. At the same time police patrol van passed by. On hearing its siren, the robbers fled from the spot. In the attack, one SAF jawan Jayant was also injured”, said Kankane.

After the incident, a man reached Khamkheda police post with the body of his brother - Ramesh Masania, 37 and told police that some villagers took him on Thursday night to be a part of their robbery bid. He said they left his body in front of his house in Umarbad. Kanakane said that the deceased was among those who tried to rob NTPC plant and there were bullet shots on his body.

Police teams of Sanawad, Kasrawad and Bedia have been deployed at the spot. SP Sunil Kumar Pandey said that the body was sent for postmortem examination and investigation has been started. Pandey said preliminary reports stated that Masania died due to gun shot. His brother gave names of miscreants involved in the robbery and they will be arrested soon.

Title: Patna: Banking operations hit as employees go on two-day strike
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Bank employees demonstrate near Gandhi Maidan

PATNA: Banking operations were hit in the city and elsewhere in the state on Friday due to a two-day nationwide strike call given by the United Forum of Bank Unions (UFBU).

The UFBU, which comprises bank unions like All India Bank Employees’ Association (AIBEA) and Bank Employees’ Federation of India, saw active participation of thousands of bank employees. Several demonstrations were held at different locations in the city, including New Dak Bungalow Road.

The strike, which was limited to government and state-owned banks, also witnessed participation of private banks, many of which were shut for transactions and other operations. Ruby Verma, the manager of a private bank in Kankarbagh, told this newspaper, “Deposits, withdrawals, cheque clearance and other services at all branches were affected due to the strike. However, ATM services and online transactions were not affected.”

Meanwhile, many people visited ATMs on Friday as cash will not be refilled during the strike. “Banks will be shut on Sunday and refilling of cash will not take place. That will be a huge problem,” said Suman Yadav, a resident of Bans Ghat.

AIBEA general secretary J P Dixit said, “In a meeting held on Thursday, the UFBU had demanded a 20% hike in employees’ wages, including performance-linked incentive. The Indian Banks’ Association, however, agreed for an increase of 13% and the bank unions refused it. The issue is pending since 2017 and we have not yet found a solution.”

He added, “Some of our other demands include scrapping of new pension scheme, uniform working hours in every city and five-day workweek. Besides, the agenda of transforming mass banking to class banking is unacceptable as it will hit the people living in rural areas. The bank unions are totally against it.”

Title: 'Inflammatory speech': Kafeel Khan remanded to judicial custody, transferred to Mathura jail
Content:
Dr Kafeel Khan addressed students, protesting against CAA, in AMU on December 13.

AGRA: Paediatrician Dr Kafeel Khan , who was arrested by the special task force of UP Police from Mumbai airport for his alleged inflammatory speech during an anti-CAA protest meeting on the AMU campus, was remanded in judicial custody for 14 days on Friday.He was brought to Aligarh after the local police was granted transit remand by Mumbai's Bandra Court on Thursday.Confirming this, Civil Lines circle officer, Anil Samaniya, said that Khan was remanded in judicial custody for 14 days. He has been transferred from Aligarh to Mathura jail in order to maintain law and order situation in the city, he said.Khan was arrested from Mumbai by the STF on Wednesday in connection with a case registered against him in Aligarh under section 153-A (Promoting enmity between different groups on ground of religion) of IPC at civil lines police station on December 13 for disturbing communal harmony by delivering a provocative speech at Aligarh Muslim University (AMU).Police brought him to Aligarh on Friday and produced him in the court of chief juridical magistrate, said Samaniya.Dr Kafeel was one of the nine accused in a case involving deaths of several children due to alleged disruption in supply of oxygen at Goakhpur’s BRD Medical College.

Title: 84-year-old woman among 100 to become Jain monk today
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Of them, there is an 84-year-old woman, 20 children aged 10 to 17 and 45 men and women aged 18 to 40

SURAT: People came out in large numbers to see the 100 diksharthis being taken out in processions before they renounced the world and became Jain monks at three different venues in the city on Saturday.

Seventy-seven people will take diksha at Vesu Ballar farm from Acharya Shreyash Prabhsuriswar Maharaj, 22 at Pal from Acharya Yashovijaysuriji Maharaj and five at another venue in Pal from Acharya Abhaydevsuriji Maharaj. There are eight families where all their members have decided to begin their journey to monkhood in the presence of 1.5 lakh people who have come to the city from various parts of the country.

Those taking diksha at Ratnamayi Samarpan Mahotsav (as the event has been named) hail from Ahmedabad, Coimbatore, Mumbai, Pune, Surat, Banaskantha, Sabarkantha and different cities of Rajasthan. It is first time in 528 years that so many people will be taking diksha together in one day.

Kantaben Chimanlal Shah, 84, mother of six children, who own diamond company named Ankit Gems, will be among the 77 to take diksha at Vesu Ballar farm. She said it was right time for her to take diksha. There are 20 children aged 10 to 17 and 45 young men and women aged 18 to 40 in this group. Out of these 45 youths, 17 are professionals like chartered accountants. Yashraj Prakash Jain, 10, son of a cloth merchant from Mumbai; Bhavya Kumar Paresh Shah , 12, son of a construction contractor from Rajasthan; and Vivan Harish Chauhan , 10, will be taking diksha along with Kantaben.

A one lakh square feet mandap with a 16,000 square feet wooden Jain temple with glass and wooden flooring has been built at a cost of Rs45 lakh at Vesu Ballar farm. This place can accommodate more than 35,000 people.

An organizer at Vesu mandap told TOI, “It is a privilege for Surat that people mostly choose this city to take diksha. We are lucky to be a part of such a grand event.”

Title: West Bengal: Scholar on his way home, but may be quarantined for 14 days
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: Hours before he was to take the special Air India flight back to India, Wuhan University researcher Samya Ray on Friday said he would feel “safe” only after he returned to his East Burdwan home. Ray, along with others from Wuhan who were returning on Friday, have been asked for their explicit consent to be quarantined for a fortnight, possibly in Delhi, before they return home.Another flight, sources said, is being arranged in a few days for those who are stuck in the Hubei province.“I hope I have not been affected. It has been nine days and I am feeling fine. I have remained inside my home all this while,” he said, waiting at the pick-up point with five others headed to the Wuhan Tianhe International Airport . “I do not know about those from the other universities who will be travelling with us, but we do have a closed social media group of all students and researchers in Wuhan University and have been sharing information. Till now, none have complained of any fever-like symptoms. But we are taking all precautionary measures,” he said.Ray added that since there had been a lockdown in Wuhan, the chances of the disease spreading have somewhat been controlled. Over the past three days, Ray said, the Indian Embassy has been in regular contact with them. “They have been helpful and cooperative,” he said, adding that the embassy has asked them to individually file consent forms which specified that, given the situation, they would be quarantined and kept under observation for 14 days before being allowed to return home.“So even if we reach India, it will be a while before we can go home. I will only feel safe when that happens. The anxiety and tension are palpable out here,” he said. Ray said he and the others have been asked to carry drinking water on the journey and the embassy has assured them of making arrangements for food.

Title: Bihar: Raghuvansh Prasad Singh, Jagdanand Singh vow to strengthen RJD
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Raghuvansh Prasad Singh

PATNA: Two founding members of RJD – state president Jagdanand Singh and national vice-president Raghuvansh Prasad Singh – held an hour-long meeting at the party’s state headquarters in a damage control bid on Friday.

Sources said the two Rajput stalwarts of the party, who had been at loggerheads with each other, met following party president Lalu Prasad ’s intervention who told them to bury the hatchet and prepare for the upcoming assembly polls in the state.

Incidentally, Raghuvansh is scheduled to meet Lalu at Rajendra Institute of Medical Sciences (RIMS) in Ranchi on Saturday.

“The two senior party functionaries were asked by Lalu to sit together and prepare a blueprint for the upcoming assembly election. Raghuvansh will share the outcome of the meeting with Lalu on Saturday,” said a senior party leader.

Raghuvansh had recently raised objections over Jagdanand’s style of functioning and compared him with ‘Hitler’.

Raghuvansh had also written to Lalu on January 9 and marked a copy to Jagdanand, lamenting party’s “lethargic” approach towards formation of committees at the grassroots level ahead of the assembly election.

After Friday’s meeting, Raghuvansh said there was no tussle between him and Jagdanand. “We are committed to strengthening the party. Jagdanand has agreed to all the 11 proposals recommended by me at the meeting, including formation of committees at the grassroots level. We will also work at the booth level and focus on the grievances of the poor, farmers, elderly people and students,” Raghuvansh added.

Jagdanand also said he had no difference with Raghuvansh. “All of us are united and follow the same path. We all believe in socialist ideology. As far as Raghuvansh’s visit to the party office is considered, there is hierarchy in all the organisations. Being the vice-president of the party, he can come to the office and monitor the work being done. We will abide by his instructions,” Jagdanand said.

However, though both leaders refuted rumours of differences between them, they addressed the media separately from the same office.

Title: Woman's murder: Police to seek arrest warrant against retired DSP
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: The city police plans to move court to seek an arrest warrant against retired DSP Uttim Singh , 63, for allegedly killing a 45-year-old Meena Devi with whom he had a relationship.

Singh had dumped the body in Gandak river in near Hajipur on December 5 last year. The body was never traced.

Patrakar Nagar police station SHO Pramod Kumar said the slain woman’s son, Piyush Raj (23), had lodged a missing complaint on December 5 last. “He later pointed at the retired DSP as a possible suspect and told the police that his mother had a relationship with him,” Kumar said, adding, she was killed on the same day by the ex-DSP, after he had called her to Hajipur.

“Singh is absconding so police would move court for an arrest warrant against him,” the SHO said, adding, the retired officer’s close friend Ramakant Singh and his wife Girija Devi were taken into custody on Thursday for aiding in the crime.

“Uttim had an illicit relationship with Meena. She was pressuring him to marry her. In addition, it has also emerged that the woman had also demanded a share of his property after which he decided to kill her,” the SHO said.

“Ramakant and his wife Girija were picked up from their residence at Choti Pahadi under Agamkuan police station area on January 29. During interrogation, the duo confessed that Uttim strangulated Meena and they had helped him commit the crime. Later, Uttim carried Meena’s body in his car and threw it into the river,” Kumar said.

The retired officer is a resident of Hajipur town in Vaishali district while Meena lived in a rented accommodation at Jogipur under Patrakar Nagar police station area in the state capital. The retired officer had served as SHO of Agamkuan, Gandhi Maidan and a few other police stations in Patna . He had retired barely a month after being promoted as DSP.

Title: Mangaluru: Woman saves stray dog from 30-foot well near Ballalbagh
Content:
Brave effort: A video-grab of Rajni rescuing the dog

MANGALURU: Animal rescuer Rajni Damodar Shetty, 40, rescued a stray dog that had fallen into a 30-foot deep well near Ballalbagh on Thursday.Rajni told TOI that children found that a dog had fallen into a well. They immediately alerted locals and many people rushed to save the dog by using tyres.“The moment I received a call, I rushed to the spot. The dog may have landed in the well in the morning and it was already 2pm when I got there. The animal was scared. I was a bit nervous, but at the same time, I knew that I cannot allow the dog to die. I did not want to take a chance. Locals told me that I should get into the well only if I was confident, and should not risk my life,” she said.Further, Rajni explained that it is an unused well with at least 10 feet of water in it.“With the help of a rope tied to my waist, I got into the well. The dog had managed to sit in a corner of the well, and was initially scared; it even tried to bite me. The moment I petted it; it became friendly. I was quick to tie a rope around it and the moment it was secure, people from top pulled the dog out first ,and with the help of ropes, I climbed out of the well,” she said.Rajni has been feeding stray dogs for almost a decade. “Every night between 12am and 2am, we feed nearly 150 dogs of the city. About 8 kg rice mixed with leftover chicken is boiled and offered to the dogs. I have also been rescuing and treating injured birds, animals and snakes at my house, before releasing them into the wild,” she said.In Video: Watch: How this brave heart woman rescued a dog

Title: CPM, Cong cry foul
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The CPM and Congress on Saturday termed the Union budget as anti-public and anti-state while being pro-corporate. CPM state secretary Kodiyeri Balakrishnan said the budget ignored the state completely and it is a gross injustice that the Centre slashed its share to the state by Rs 5,000 crore, compared to last year.

The state’s share for all social welfare programmes, including the employment guarantee scheme, have been slashed. He said that the compensation for GST, increasing of the borrowing limits of the state etc have also been ignored in the budget. Also, the Centre has ignored the speedy implementation of national highway development and proposed rail corridor project in the budget.

Opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala said the budget is completely disappointing and the state has been totally ignored against which strong protest should come up. He said the country is facing the biggest unemployment rates in the last 45 years and there are no concrete steps to contain this problem in the budget.

The budget has embraced the corporates by ignoring the general public, said KPCC president Mullappally Ramachandran in a statement. Mullappally said the term most used in the budget was PPP, indicating privatization. Even the tax sops have stringent provisions attached, he said, adding that issues like joblessness and problems faced by the agricultural, industrial and service sectors have been completely ignored.

LDF convenor A Vijayaraghavan said that the Centre has continued the same policy of neglect towards the state which it had earlier shown in providing flood relief assistance.

Title: Neglect puts Hope Bridge’s replacement in peril
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

The neglect of the bridge has killed the craze for it among people

Surat: Residents of the walled city and Adajan still reminisce about the evenings that they spent on the benches on Hope Bridge built in 1877 across Tapi River. They had lots of hope from the bridge that replaced this heritage structure in 2015, but it has simply failed them. In a bid to keep old memories alive, Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) had constructed a heritage walkway resembling the old one on the new structure at a cost of Rs53 crore. The cast-iron benches on the new bridge remained damaged for long time, but now they have been stolen by thieves. The lighting on the bridge is not working at many places and decorative balloon lights either have been damaged or stolen. About 14 paintings depicting the historical importance of the erstwhile port city have also gone missing.

For about 88 years, Hope Bridge was the only link between two parts of the city-Chowk Bazaar and Rander. In 1999, the bridge was banned for vehicles and later for pedestrians as well after a feasibility study found it to be unsafe.

The heritage walkway beckoned people in hordes when it was thrown open for people on April 3, 2015 . The numbers swelled at dusk when residents would gather on the walkway to spend quality time with their friends and family amid the cool breeze coming from the river. However, the neglect of the bridge has killed the craze for it among people.

Akshay Pandya, executive engineer (bridge cell), told TOI, “We had tried to replicate Hope Bridge and were successful too. But, some elements stole cast-iron benches, damaged paintings, flower pots and decorative balloon lightings, thus throwing a spanner in the works. We have moved a proposal for installing conventional benches, which are unbreakable. People would be able to sit and enjoy their evenings again.”

Title: Ceiling of balcony collapses of apartment at Athwalines
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

The building is about 25 years old

Surat: A major accident was averted in a residential apartment at posh Athwalines area when the ceiling of balcony of a house on ninth floor collapsed here on Friday evening. There were no casualties.

Sources in fire and emergency services department of Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) said the incident occurred at about 5:30pm at Sargam apartment. A portion of the concrete slab of the balcony of a pent house suddenly collapsed and got stuck in the balcony of the house below the pent house.

Fire officer Nilesh Dave told TOI, “The ceiling of the balcony of the pent house came crashing down. Some debris fell on the ground, while the remaining got stuck in the balcony of the house located below the pent house. No one was injured. A team was called from Athwa zone for safely removing the concrete debris. Residents of houses on other floors located below the pent house were asked to evacuate.”

Hiren Shah, a textile businessman and owner of the pent house, said, “We heard a loud noise in the balcony. The ceiling had collapsed. Just a few minutes ago, we had shut the balcony door. The building is about 25 years old and we never thought that such an incident would happen. Now, it is risky to live in this house as anything can happen. We will follow the directions of the civic body with regard to structural stability of the apartment.”

There was traffic jam on the road as commuters and pedestrians had stopped to see the collapsed ceiling. A police team from Umara police station cleared the road for traffic.

Title: PSU Banks Inefficient On Every Parameter
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Mumbai: In a strong critique of the performance of public sector banks (PSBs), the Economic Survey said while Rs 4.3 lakh crore of taxpayers ’ money has gone into PSBs , every rupee invested has lost 23 paise as on 2019. The survey also described Indian banks as suffering ‘dwarfism’, with only one bank in the top 100, while six are needed for an economy like India’s size.

PSBs should be asked to share corporate data among themselves through a GSTN-like entity ( PSB network) and undertake analytics of the data using fintech. PSB employees should hold stake through Employee Stock Option Scheme across all levels. “Part-ownership of PSBs by employees will reduce agency problems. This is because employees who own shares are incentivised to increase market value of equity.”

Assessing the performance of government banks after completion of 50 years of nationalisation in July 2019, the government’s report card on economy said on every performance parameter ‘PSBs are inefficient compared to their peer groups’.

As of January 2020, every rupee of a taxpayer’s money invested in PSB is fetching a market value of Rs 71 paise. As against that every rupee invested in a private bank fetches a market value of Rs 3.7, which is five times of the return in PSBs.

According to the report, if the market-to-book ratio of each PSB becomes equal to that of the second-worst new private bank, the improvement would gain the government Rs 9.1 lakh crore, which is about 8.5 times the disinvestment budget for 2019.

Highlighting the importance of banks, the survey said historically the top-five economies have always been supported by their banks. “India becoming a $5-trillion economy will require at least eight Indian banks to be large enough to belong in the top 100 globally.” However, credit growth in PSBs has been sluggish, largely because of their large stock of bad loans. In 2019, PSBs reported gross non-performing assets (NPAs) of Rs 7.4 lakh crore, which is 11.9% of their loans. “NPAs of Indian banks, particularly PSBs, could have been prevented if data and analytics were employed in corporate lending.”

While there have been arguments of the social impact of bank nationalisation, the survey said there have been multiple factors at work. Noting that rural branches have increased 10-fold and credit to rural areas rose 20-fold in the first decade after nationalisation, it said some caution is necessary in interpreting the above trends as being entirely caused by nationalisation.

“A key confounder in such an interpretation is the role played by other interventions around bank nationalisation. For instance, the government initiated a green revolution and anti-poverty programmes.” To further confound matters, the RBI had introduced directed lending programmes, which set priority sector targets for banks and the RBI used both formal means and moral suasion to persuade lenders to achieve its targets.

Explaining reasons for disproportionate share of bad loans among PSBs, the report card said a plausible explanation could be that in Indian economy’s growth phase between 2004 and 2011, PSU banks grew their loan portfolio but this credit growth was of suspect quality.

On outlook for banks, the survey highlighted the country’s demographics and the Jan Dhan-Aadhaar-Mobile combine as the two big driving forces.

As against the earlier reports that made a push for dilution of government stake, the survey made a strong pitch for employee ownership of PSBs. Even as the Indian Banks Association is negotiating a wage settlement with unions, it said the current flat compensation contracts and pressures from ex-post monitoring by the vigilance agencies, it is hardly surprising that the staff prefer safety and conservatism over risk-taking. So, there should be transfer of a portion of government stake to employees exhibiting good performance across all levels of the organisation through ESOPs. The report card pushed for lateral recruitment, stating that professionals with domain skills in technology, data science, finance and economics are required, given challenge from fintechs.

Title: Dentist files dowry harassment plaint against AF pilot husband, in-laws
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Surat: A dental surgeon has registered a case of dowry harassment in Puna police station against her husband, who works in the Indian Airforce , as well as her in-laws. She has alleged them of torturing her physically and mentally for bringing Rs20 lakh as dowry and have been putting pressure on her demanding Rs 51 lakh more.

According to the case details, the woman had married Abhisheksingh Vinodsingh Tanvar, wing commander in Indian Air-force based at Coimbatore in TN in 2017. He is a resident of Shahibaug in Ahmedabad. The dental surgeon runs a clinic in Khatodara area of Surat.

She alleged that her father-in-law Vinodsingh Rajput and mother-in-law Shashi who lived in Ahmedabad along with their elder son, Ankush Singh and his wife Shiba kept torturing her for more money. According to her complaint, all her in-laws constantly harassed her for Rs 51 lakh more.

The woman said that she had already given her husband Rs 20 lakh to buy a new car, but the in-laws made her life miserable with their constant demands. Not being able to withstand the torture any more, she approached the police.

An investigating officer of police said, “We have registered the complaint under IPC 498(A), 114 and anti-dowry Act sections 3 and 4 . We are in process of gathering evidences. The accused in-laws have also made some counter allegations. The families originally hail from Rajasthan,” the cop said.

Police further said that after all evidences are gathered and statements of the people are recorded to corroborate with the evidences, cops will act on the case. “Meanwhile, our investigations are going on,” the officer said.

A source in the police said that often the root cause of the case, particularly in educated families, turn out to be different than what the complaints project. “We can't act unless we have some concrete evidences of torture,” the officer added.

Title: NGO stops giving sanitary pads to girls after SMC body’s objection
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Surat: Meena Mehta , 62 , also known as ‘pad wali dadi’ (granny who gives pad) used to distribute kits containing sanitary pads and undergarments to poor adolescent girls studying in the primary schools run by the Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) to help them maintaining menstrual hygiene.

However, she has stopped supplying pads to the girls, after the Nagar Prathamik Shikshan Samiti (NPSS) of the SMC recently asked her not to take videos of the girls during distribution. The NPSS also further ordered that the kits be distributed to girls only by the teachers.

President of NPSS, Hasmukh Patel said, “She (Meena) was taking videos of schoolgirls wherein she would ask about the colour of the underwear she was distributing. We found it objectionable and decided that the kits would be distributed by the teachers and did not allowed her to take any videos and photographs.”

Mehta, who has been distributing the kits monthly since 2013, had got inspiration after reading about the chairperson of Infosys Foundation and a social worker, Sudha Murthy, who had donated four trucks of sanitary napkins as relief supplies in Chennai after the 2004 tsunami.

Her organisation, Manuni Foundation, in last seven years has distributed kits to over 5,000 girls in 35 municipal schools.

Talking with TOI, Mehta said, “We were taking photographs and videos of the girls for our record. There was nothing objectionable. Still, the school authorities wanted us to give the kits to the headmaster and banned us from taking any video or photograph in the school.”

“After the direction of NPSS we decided to discontinue the work in the municipal schools,” she added.

Title: NBFC health check to limit borrowing
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Mumbai: The Economic Survey has suggested that policymakers should use a dynamic health index, which captures liquidity risks in non-banking finance companies (NBFCs), to avoid financial fragility in the sector. It added that the score could be used by the regulator for limiting the amount NBFCs could borrow from other institutions to reduce systemic risks.

The health tracker index would factor in re-financing risk, which would be determined by the extent of reliance on short-term financing and balance sheet strength of the NBFCs.

At a most fundamental level, the root cause of crisis in the NBFC sector could be traced to over-dependence of NBFCs on short-term wholesale funding market. A health score would have identified the fragility in the sector even during their high-growth phase. “Overall it was found that the health score for the housing finance sector exhibited a declining trend post-2014.”

After growing very fast in 2017-18 and the first half of 2018-19, the NBFC sector decelerated sharply since then. The growth of loans from NBFCs declined from 27.6% in September 2018 and 21.6% in December 2018 to 9.9% at September-end 2019.

The balance sheet of the NBFC sector grew by 17.9% from Rs 26.2 lakh crore to Rs 30.9 lakh crore during 2018-19. This growth was on top of a growth of 21.3% recorded during 2017-18 despite concerns over NBFCs. The third quarter of 2018-19 witnessed liquidity stress. The cost of funds for NBFCs declined by March 2019 and further by September 2019, as reflected in the three-month CP discount rate.

Title: Woman found murdered in Junagadh village
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Rajkot: The body of a woman was found on the outskirts of Datarana village of Menderada taluka in Junagadh district on Thursday evening.

The family members of the victim, identified as 21-year-old Anju Mal, suspect one Nilesh Vaghasia of being involved in the crime. Police have launched a manhunt for Nilesh who has absconded ever since the body was found.

The police have also sent the body for forensic postmortem to GG Hospital in Jamnagar to ascertain whether it was sexually assaulted before the murder was committed.

Mal used to work as a farm labourer in the farm owned by Babu Vaghasia. “Nilesh was the owner of an adjoining farm. We suspect that he tried to rape the victim, but when she resisted the attempt, he strangled her,” said A B Desai, sub-inspector with Menderada police station.

The victim and her husband Kalpesh Mal had come from Balaiya village of Fatehpura taluka in Dahod district to work as farm labourers.

“We suspect Nilesh of having committed necrophilia as the victim was found half-naked. However, whether any sexual crime was committed or not, would be ascertained once the postmortem report is released. Our investigation has found that it was Nilesh who had called Mal to his farm,” added Desai.

Title: Eight of Surat family injured in accident near Dhordo
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Rajkot: Eight members of a family including two children aged three and 11 years from Surat were injured when their SUV went off road in the White Rann of Kutch on Friday morning.

The accident occurred when the driver of the SUV lost control while negotiating a steep curve on Khawda-Dhordo Road near the desert.

The injured were identified as Darshak Lakadawala (43), Bhavin Lakdawala (41), Panna Lakdawala (70), Dipali Lakdawala (42), Kinjal Lakdawala (40), Pratham Lakdawala (3), Arnav Lakdawala (11), and the SUV driver, Umar Desai.

“The family had come from Surat on an excursion to the White Rann. They had hired the SUV from Ahmedabad. The injured were admitted to a private hospital in Bhuj,” said an official from Khawda police station.

Title: Goa: Coordinated effort required to tackle substance abuse, say stakeholders
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: Stakeholders have called for a coordinated effort to tackle the substance abuse problem in the state. Founder of Human Touch, Peter Borges, highlighted the need for a state drug policy and for looking at substance abuse in an integrated manner.

“We have not looked at substance abuse in an integrated manner. There is no agency which drives demand reduction programs in Goa apart from a few NGOs. The state needs to financially provide for demand reduction. We need to make a financial budget to address the problem of substance abuse,” he said, adding that the focus in the state is largely restricted to seizures of narcotics and role of police.

He was speaking at the Goa state consultation on drug abuse organised by the Goa Institute of Management, Sakhali.

Dean of Goa Medical College Dr Shivanand Bandekar advised students of healthcare management at the institute not to give in to peer pressure and not to take it for granted that their willpower would get them out of addiction. “Most addicts are introduced to substances by close friends and not unknown peddlers,” Bandekar said.

Sharing tragic stories of youth addicted to alcohol and narcotics, Bandekar busted some myths, like alcohol assures sound sleep, that there’s no harm in trying it out just once, and that it takes away one’s problems.

Founder of Kripa Foundation, Joe Pereira, stressed on the need to look at it as a human problem and not only focus on demand reduction. He urged students to help create a community of winners (former addicts), who could act as role models to get the message across to others.

Title: Kerala’s coronavirus patient passed via Kolkata last week
Content:
A passenger being screened at Kolkata airport on Friday

KOLKATA: India’s first and only confirmed patient of the novel coronavirus (nCoV) — a student from Thrissur in Kerala — had travelled through Kolkata airport on January 23, four days before she showed signs of flu. She tested positive for the virus on Thursday. On Friday, Kolkata airport officials said the woman had not shown any symptom of nCoV when she was screened at the airport, but they had warned the Kochi airport about her upon learning that she was coming from Wuhan and was heading to her hometown via Kochi.“We had screened her with thermal guns and did all the necessary checks, but she had not shown any signs of infection at that point. But we alerted Kochi airport to keep tabs on the woman,” said a senior official of Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose International airport.According to records maintained by Kolkata airport, the woman came to the city on a China Eastern Airlines flight from Kunming on the night of January 23, the day the Wuhan airport was locked down. She had apparently come out of Wuhan along with some other Indian students the night before and was among the last batches of Indian nationals from Wuhan who could come back on their own. China Eastern Airlines has a direct flight between Kunming and Wuhan, but they suspended services on January 23.From Kolkata, she took a direct flight to Kochi on January 24, and then travelled by road to her hometown at Mathilakam. At Kochi airport, she was advised by officials to report to the nearest health centre if she showed any symptom of flu. She was asked to stay at home for the next 14 days, maintain personal hygiene and wear a mask.On January 27, she developed symptoms of flu and contacted the state health department, which sent a team of officials to her home and moved her to an isolation ward at the Thrissur General Hospital. Her body fluid sample was sent to the National Institute of Virology (NIV), Pune, the same day and on Thursday morning, the NIV informed that the case was positive.Following the first case, the Centre announced that all persons who have come from China after January 15 need to be tested for the virus as it has an incubation period of 14 days. It has also prescribed a 14-day home isolation procedure and advised citizens to avoid trips to China.“There could be scores of symptomless patients since signs of the virus take a week to 14 days to manifest. So, every individual who has travelled through the affected regions should be quarantined immediately after they reach India,” said Fortis Hospital’s internal medicine consultant Joydeep Ghosh.At Kolkata airport, passengers from China have to undergo thermal screening to check body temperature. Officials said that so far, 5,700 persons have been screened, but none have showed any alarming symptoms. The immigration and other staff members at airports have been sensitized and dedicated ambulances have been placed at ports. Drills to check preparedness and management of possible cases have also been practised at Kolkata airport and medical and para-medical staff have been kept on standby for emergencies.“However, no matter how rigorous the screenings are, we have to rely on self-declaration by passengers. We can never know if they visited Wuhan unless they declare it. But most passengers have been co-operative,” said Kolkata airport director Kaushik Bhattacharya.

Title: HUL’s volume growth halves to 5% in December quarter
Content: MUMBAI: With a sharp decline in rural growth and discretionary spends, the year-on-year volume expansion of Hindustan Unilever ( HUL ) halved to 5% in the third quarter ended December 31, 2019. But on a sequential quarter basis, volumes were consistent since the June quarter.Faced with a double whammy of a steep rise in raw material costs and a de-growing soaps market, HUL plans to hike soap prices by 5-6%, beginning March this year. Although not strictly comparable, both sales and net profit numbers were sequentially lower in the December quarter as compared to the September quarter of the current fiscal.However, despite the market challenges in soaps and a delayed winter impacting growth in skin care, the FMCG bellwether reported a 12% rise in net profit in the December quarter of the current fiscal to Rs 1,616 crore, while growth in its domestic consumer business was up nearly 4% to Rs 9,696 crore. Tightening of belt in terms of costs is visible with growth in advertising and promotional spends muted in the December quarter. Cost of materials consumed in Q3 is down 13%.While rural market slowdown persisted in Q3 as well with rural growing below urban, a key highlight of the December quarter was a slowdown in the urban markets. “This quarter (December) witnessed an overall challenging market environment, mainly reflecting a sharp slowdown in rural and discretionary spends,” said HUL CMD Sanjiv Mehta.At the company’s third quarter (Q3) results update, HUL CFO Srinivas Phatak said the company will take prices up in a staggered manner. Cost of vegetable oils has risen by up to 30% over the previous year. While this could prop up the category’s value growth in forthcoming quarters, it may even backfire as consumer purchases have gone down in soaps. HUL had cut prices of soaps last year, and yet growth in personal wash has been elusive.Mehta said he hopes the Budget on Saturday boosts consumer confidence and puts more money in the customer’s hands.While home care and food and refreshments portfolios reported a 10% and 8% growths in Q3, respectively, the beauty and personal care portfolio declined 1%. Having a diversified portfolio, HUL was better positioned to navigate the challenging market conditions.Phatak said market growth continues to be sluggish and the near-term demand outlook remains challenging. The HUL scrip was down 1.2% at Rs 2,034 by close of trade on the BSE on Friday.

Title: Government plans to regulate wood industry: Bihar deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Sushil Kumar Modi

PATNA: Deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi on Friday said that during the forthcoming budget session the government would introduce a Bill in the state assembly for regulating wood-based industry which will have a bearing on the activities of investors and carpenters engaged in this sector.

In accordance with the same, Modi said the idea of giving exemptions to the investors in the sector has also been under active consideration of the state government.

The deputy chief minister also said that the policy decisions were taken at the pre-budget consultative meeting held on issues related to forests, afforestation and environment protection with around 50 persons representing various activities in the sector.

Half-a-dozen representatives also gave their recommendations. Finance department principal secretary S Siddharth and head of the environment and forest department Dipak Kumar Singh were also present at the meeting.

SuMo said that the budget of the environment and forest department has increased from Rs 50 crore in 2005-06 to Rs 911 crore in the 2019-20 financial year, while the department would be spending Rs 2,756 crore over three years under the ‘Jal-Jeevan-Hariyali’ campaign that will be marked by planting of 7.7 crore saplings. Further, 8.46 crore saplings of popular variety of trees were planted during the 2012-18 period.

Title: DRI nabs smuggler with 1kg gold at DDU junction
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

VARANASI: The Varanasi unit of the Directorate of Revenue Intelligence ( DRI ) caught a man with one kilogram gold worth approximately Rs 40 lakh at Deen Dayal Upadhyaya Junction (Mughalsarai) in Chandauli district on Thursday.

According to DRI sources, the arrested person was identified as Mohammed Mohsin, a resident of Delhi. Acting on a specific intelligence, the DRI team nabbed the smuggler while ha was on board Rajdhani Express travelling from Kolkata to New Delhi.

During interrogation, he revealed that the gold concealed in the shocker of motorcycle was smuggled from Bangkok to Kolkata by plane. He was carrying gold from Kolkata to New Delhi in the train when the DRI team caught him. The gold was seized and further investigation is on.

Title: Bihar: CPI(ML) plans to gherao state assembly on February 25
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Dipankar Bhattacharya

PATNA: CPI(ML) general secretary Dipankar Bhattacharya on Friday said the members of the party and its frontal organisations would gherao the state assembly on February 25 to press CM Nitish Kumar to get a resolution passed in the House against implementation of the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), National Population Register (NPR) and National Register of Citizens (NRC).

The budget session of the assembly is slated to begin from February 24 with the governor’s address to the joint session of the state legislature. Deputy CM-cum-finance minister Sushil Kumar Modi will present the state budget on February 25.

Dipankar, who was addressing the Jan Ekta meeting organized by Insaaf Manch at the open theatre of Bharatiya Nritya Kala Mandir here, said popular protests against the CAA, NPR and NRC that started from Shaheen Bagh in Delhi had spread to several cities and towns in the country as well as to institutions of higher education, including in Bihar , in the last one-and-a-half months.

Bhattacharya said though Nitish has admitted that some of the questions in the NPR questionnaire should be dropped, the issue is the withdrawal of CAA, NPR and NRC, as people have begun to realize the serious implications of the three instruments conceived by the Centre.

“Given the variety of proofs sought to prove one’s citizenship, the implementation of the three instruments would deprive more than six crores of people of the country of their citizenship,” Bhattacharya said, adding those shorn of their citizenship would not only be deprived of their civic and other rights, but also be disenfranchised and made become ineligible to own property or get into any kind of job in the country.

He said of the 19.5 lakh people deprived of citizenship in Assam due to implementation of the NRC on the orders of the Supreme Court, 56,000 had their roots in Bihar. The Assam government had sought details on 73,000 Biharis, but the Bihar government could provide details of only about 17,000 of them, he claimed.

Title: Kerala: A ‘Thousand Eyes’ to fight crime
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

Title: Farrukhabad hostage horror: He gave us food, chocolates, some of us slept off, say kids
Content:
Parents and family members hold their children after they were rescued from being held hostage by murder-accus... Read More

KATHARIYA VILLAGE, FARRUKHABAD: When 25 children in UP’s Farrukhabad district entered Subhash Batham’s house on Thursday evening, apart from the missing confetti there was little indication that this wasn’t, in fact, a birthday party. They were welcomed by Batham’s wife into a 10 x 8 basement where several packets of snacks, biscuits, chocolates and milk were kept.The cold, mud floor was covered in mats for the kids to sit on. In the ensuing 10 hours in which the crisis unfolded, Batham and his wife reportedly took turns to check up on the kids, with the latter even serving them roti and sabzi.For these children in Kathariya village, most of whom were aged between one and 15, a birthday invite was as rare as it was alluring. Many hail from poor households, with their parents struggling to make ends meet. So when word spread around on Thursday afternoon that a party was to be held, they were eager to join the celebrations. Their parents too felt there was little reason to worry.Batham had a chequered past — he had spent 12 years in prison for killing his uncle — but he hadn’t displayed aggressive behaviour towards anyone in the village and as one villager said, “It had been years since that incident in 2001.” But within hours, as news came that Batham was armed and making demands to release the children, parents started assembling in front of the house, fearing the worst. Inside, the children were anxious but well-fed.A day later, many of the children TOI spoke to said they were still shocked with the turn of events but happy to be back home.The younger ones, however, showed little understanding that they had been at the centre of a raging drama that had everyone on tenterhooks. But most seemed to agree on one thing — their kidnapper was not out to harm them. “I don’t believe he (Batham) wanted to harm us. He warned us to keep quiet and said there would be consequences if we didn’t, but he didn’t hurt anyone,” said Anjali Kumari, the eldest among those who had been held hostage. Batham had a pistol and a rifle with him, said the children, but he never pointed it at them.On Friday, when TOI visited the spot, candy wrappers were strewn across the basement. Instead of a staircase, a ladder paved the way to the dingy space bereft of windows, with an LED bulb the only source of light. A metal door separated the basement from the rest of the house. It was this door that Anjali bolted shut after the children had been stuck in the room for hours and their patience started wearing thin. This cut off Batham’s access to the children and minimised their chances of getting caught in a crossfire. “After I locked the door, Subash uncle and his wife banged on the door several times, but I didn’t open it. Two hours later, we were rescued by police,” said Anjali.While initially scared, the children said they felt better once food was served. Arun Kumar, 10, said that the couple served everyone food and water. “We were given biscuit, chocolate, milk, water and some ate roti and sabzi. But when we wanted to pee, we were told to go in a corner and relieve ourselves,” added Soni Kumari, 12, who was confined along with two of her siblings. As there wasn’t much to do, some of the children went to sleep.When an infant wouldn’t stop crying, Batham decided to go outside to release her. That’s when Anjali shut the door from inside. The children didn’t have to wait long though. A couple of hours, later, police made their way to the building and shot Batham dead.Residents of the quiet village said they were still coming to terms with the incident that had shoved them into the limelight. But things could have turned out differently, said Babli Devi, whose house is next to Batham’s. “Three of my children were in there too. And I will always remember this traumatic night but would I have wanted them dead for it? I don’t think so. Perhaps, police could have caught Batham, instead of killing him.”A police officer said, “We negotiated with Batham for hours and went into the building to arrest him, but he brandished a gun. So we had to shoot.”In Video: Farrukhabad hostage drama: Unaware of trap children wanted to enjoy party

Title: Bihar: PPU teachers observe black badge protest
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

PATNA: Teachers of different postgraduate departments and constituent colleges, which fall under the jurisdiction of Patliputra University (PPU), observed ‘Protest Day’ on Friday. They wore black badges and demonstrated against the murder of T P S College associate professor Shiv Narayan Ram (52).

The deceased was on his way to the college when a criminal shot him in his head near Janta Flats at Postal Park under the Kankarbagh police station area on Wednesday and escaped.

According to Patliputra University Teachers’ Association (PPUTA) president A K Singh Thakur, the teachers strongly condemned the murder and demanded immediate arrest of the killers. They also expressed solidarity with the family of the deceased.

PPUTA general secretary Hridya Narayan Singh said, “The association members have submitted a memorandum to governor-cum-chancellor Phagu Chauhan and chief minister Nitish Kumar in this connection. We have urged them to give Rs 1 crore ex gratia to Ram’s family and full salary to his widow till the day of his retirement.”

PPU vice-chancellor Gulab Chand Ram Jaiswal also expressed shock and grief at the brutal killing of Ram and demanded immediate arrest of the culprits involved in the gruesome crime.

Title: Govt working on river-linking project, says UP minister
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Urban development minister Ashutosh Tandon was here to lay the foundation of development projects worth over R... Read More

AGRA: Uttar Pradesh urban development minister Ashutosh Tandon on Friday said both state and the central governments are working on a plan on linking rivers.

The idea behind the interlinking of rivers is to deal with the problems of drought and floods affecting parts of the country, while decreasing farmer’ dependency on uncertain monsoon. The move is also aimed at curbing extraction of groundwater and developing an infrastructure for piped water supply to each household, he added.

Addressing a gathering at the Jal Sansthan here, minister Tandon said, “The underground water reserve is depleting rapidly. Prime Minister Narendra Modi has called for minimum usage of groundwater. State and central governments are working to ensure that piped water supply reaches each household. Soon, the work related to linking of the river will be initiated.”

The minister was here to lay the foundation of development projects worth over Rs 221 crore. Besides, Rs 33.25 crore projects of the civic body, those related with Agra Smart City, Jal Nigam and District Urban Development Agency (DUDA) were also launched.

Tandon said the river-linking project was mooted by the Atal Bihari Vajpayee-led NDA government in 1999. The proposal was modified to intra-basin development as opposed to inter-basin water transfer. By 2004, the then UPA government again opposed the project concept.
