In February 2012, while disposing of a public interest litigation (PIL) on the matter, Supreme Court had refused to give any direction for implementation of “rivers interlinking project”. However, the apex court had directed the ministry of water resources to constitute an experts’ committee to pursue the matter with the governments concerned as no party had pleaded against the implementation of the project.

Regarding Agra, the minister said, “State government is focused on development of Agra. I am aware that lack of proper water supply infrastructure is a major problem in the city. We have been working in this regard. The officers of the urban development department have been directed to ensure all the houses in the city get piped water supply. Required infrastructure will be developed in a planned manner. Officials have also been directed to adopt time-bound repairs of the old water pipelines, which are subjected to wear and tear.”

In a ceremony organized at Agra Municipal Corporation, Tandon emphasized the need for public participation in the maintenance of sanitation and hygiene in the city. He also handed over keys of 50 houses to beneficiaries of the Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojna of the central government and Asra scheme of the state government.

The minister laid the foundation of a plant which would have the capacity of processing 300 metric tonnes per day of biodegradable municipal solid waste into compost. The plant will be established at Kuberpur landfill site and is estimated to cost Rs 12 crore.

He also laid the foundation of the Rs 27.35-crore project for capping of waste at the Kuberpur landfill site, a Rs 175 crore work related to upgradation of water supply infrastructure and Rs 6.91 crore road, interlocking and drainage development works.

Tandon opened the Kanha shelter facility for cows and other destitute animals, a facility to process 120 metric tonnes per day of non-biodegradable waste, an automatic plant for processing waste collected from hotels, marriage halls and housing societies.

Under the smart city project, minister inaugurated smart classrooms developed at AMC’s inter college for girls in Tajganj locality, e-toilets developed at four places and four micro skill development centres.

Title: coronavirus in kolkata: NICED to test West Bengal man’s samples
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: The National Institute of Cholera and Enteric Diseases (NICED) at Beliaghata will start testing patients suspected to be infected by the novel coronavirus . The first samples to be tested are likely to be that of a 31-year-old man from Asansol who had returned from Wuhan on January 15.The health department has kept Somnath Kar under home quarantine. Though he is asy-mptomatic, he has been asked to be confined at home for now as a precautionary measure. “The health department is in touch with him. He is absolutely asymptomatic, but we will be sending his samples to NICED in a day of two,” said Ajay Chakraborty, director, health services.The central health ministry has asked NICED to [prepare its laboratory to test swabs and blood samples of suspected patients in the state, as well as from places in the eastern region. “Since NICED has been given this responsibility, we are in the process of preliminary validation. Once we get the green signal from NIV, Pune, we should be in a position to start testing samples,” said NICED director Shanta Dutta.So far, NIV, Pune, has been the only centre in India that was testing samples of suspected coronavirus patients

Title: Woman mukhiya among four killed in Bihar in 24 hours
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

BEGUSARAI/SITAMARHI/PATNA: Four people, including a woman mukhiya were killed and two others were seriously injured in four separate incidents in the state during the last 24 hours on Friday. While two killings were reported from Begusarai, one each was reported from Vaishali and Samastipur districts.

Sources said that unidentified armed criminals shot dead a woman mukhiya Hema Murya of Samsa panchayat during an idol immersion of Goddess Saraswati in the canal at Samsa village under the Naokothi police station area in Begusarai district on Friday. Police said the incident took place when Hema was taking part in the procession.

On getting information, DIG, Begusarai range, Rajesh Kumar rushed to the spot and pacified the supporters of the slain mukhiya, who were demanding immediate arrest of the killers. The DIG didn’t rule out the involvement of one Bambam Mahto, whose son was killed earlier. Bambam, who had accused the slain mukhiya’s close relative Ranjeet of killing his young son, is absconding after the incident.

In another incident, a 40-year-old man, Sanjay Mahto, was gunned down by some armed criminals at Paharpur village under the Balia police station area in Begusarai district late on Friday night. The assailants attacked Sanjay and his uncle Ramdev Mahto when they had gone to their agricultural field to irrigate the crops.

Begusarai SDPO Anjani Kumar said that land dispute is stated to be the reason behind the incident. Altogether six persons have been named as accused in the FIR lodged with the Balia police station in connection with the incident. “One of the six named accused has already been arrested and raids were underway to nab others,” the SDPO said.

In Vaishali district, Gulshan Singh, a resident of Patedha village, was killed by unidentified armed miscreants near Rampur village under Belsar police outpost on Friday. Police said the incident occurred when the deceased was returning home from Jarang village on his motorbike. Sources said that Gulshan was involved in illicit liquor smuggling in the area.

A 22-year-old youth, Golden Kumar Singh, was gunned down by unidentified armed criminals on NH-28 under the Dalsinghsarai police station area in Samastipur district on Friday. He was stated to be a resident of Muktapur village under the Bhagwanpur police station area of the district.

Title: Need more Navodaya schools: Telangana to Centre
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

B Vinod Kumar (Twitter image)

HYDERABAD: Telangana state planning board vice-chairman B Vinod Kumar on Friday wrote a letter to Niti Aayog chairman NK Singh saying injustice is being done to Telangana in allocating Navodaya schools , and there should be one school in each of the 33 districts. Telangana has only nine Navodaya schools.

“CM K Chandrasekhar Rao also wrote a letter to the PM to allocate more Navodaya schools,” he said in the letter. tnn

Title: Four lion cubs sneak into abandoned school rescued
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

The cubs inside the dilapidated school building in Rayadi village near Khambha in Amreli district

RAJKOT: When the sun gradually rose over Rayadi village on Friday and the villagers started moving around, these four little Simbas realized that they were in the middle of human habitation.

When mistaking them for dogs, a woman threw a stone at them, these lion cubs, aged three to 6 months, took shelter in an old dilapidated school building in the village.

Rayadi is a village surrounded by the forest of Rabarika in Tulsishyam range of Gir East of the Gir Wildlife Sanctuary. The nearest town is Khambha. This range is a home to about 25 to 30 lions. Lions are frequently sighted in Khambha and its surrounding villages.

It so happened that a lioness had entered the village on Thursday night with her four cubs.

The lioness had preyed on a cow and her cubs joined her on feast. Out in the open and under the sky over the village, the big cat and her cubs kept on feasting on the cow till early Friday morning. It was when the movements of the villagers started, the lioness abandoned her cubs and went back into the forest.

“The woman who had thrown a stone at the cubs, mistaking them for dogs, informed us, and we rushed to the spot. We rescued the cubs. As we knew the location of their mother, we took the cubs there. When we spotted the lioness, we released the cubs who went scampering towards their mother in the forest,” said a forest officer of Tulsishyam range.

Title: Loudspeaker rules relaxed for 15 events in Goa
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

The relaxation will be applicable at Carnival on February 25, Holi on March 9, Easter eve on April 11, the sec... Read More

PANAJI: The government has permitted the use of loud speakers and public address systems beyond 10pm and up to midnight for 15 days in 2020.

The relaxation will be applicable at Carnival on February 25, Holi on March 9, Easter eve on April 11, the second day of Ganesh idol immersion on August 23, the fifth day of idol immersion on August 26, Anant Chaturdashi on September 1. The other days include the first and last day of Navratri on October 17 and 24, Kojagiri Purnima on October 30, Diwali eve on November 13, Diwali on November 14, Tripurari/Kartiki Purnima on November 29, Christmas eve and Christmas on December 24 and 25, and New Year’s eve on December 31.

Permissions will be granted on these 15 days on a “case-to-case” basis to applications made by the panchayat, municipal corporation, council or individual concerned.

The authority under the Noise Pollution (Regulation & Control) Rules, 2000 will monitor noise levels during the permitted festive occasions and take prompt remedial action in the event of any violation, the director/ex-officio joint secretary (environment) stated in a notification.

Title: Indiabulls realty co to merge with B’luru-based Embassy
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

MUMBAI: Indiabulls Real Estate, the listed arm of the Indiabulls group, and Bengaluru-based realty major Embassy, which is unlisted, have agreed to merge through a share-swap deal. After the merger, global private equity major Blackstone will infuse $200 million into the entity. As part of the deal, the merged entity will be controlled by Embassy and its promoter Jitu Virwani, while Sameer Gehlaut, the promoter of Indiabulls will become a passive shareholder. This will also mark the exit of Indiabulls Group from the real estate sector.

Exiting the real estate sector was part of Indiabulls Group’s plan when it was seeking to merge Lakshmi Vilas Bank with itself. The move was shelved after the RBI declined it the green signal.

The current shareholders of Indiabulls Real Estate will get the scrips of the merged entity, which will also be listed on the bourses. The share-swap ratio will be decided by independent valuers and merchant bankers, the company said. The promoters of Embassy Group and Blackstone will also hold shares in the merged entity.

After the merger, the company will become the development arm for the Embassy Office Park REIT, the first listed real estate investment trust in India which is a joint venture between Embassy Group and Blackstone. The REIT will benefit by getting more developed assets, thereby increasing the yield of the REIT, which intends to provide compounding returns to its unit holders by flow of regular assets in the instrument, company sources said.

Indiabulls group also has a strong relationship with Blackstone, which in the last two years have sold properties worth about Rs 12,000 crore to the PE giant. Currently, Embassy Office Park REIT has a market capitalisation of Rs 32,000 crore, while Indiabulls Real Estate is valued at Rs 4,865 crore. Since listing in April last year, Embassy’s REIT has given a 30% return to its investors.

Indiabulls Group founder & chairman Sameer Gehlaut said that the deal, which marks the exit of the group from real estate development business, is according to the plan that was announced in June 2019. “We will now fully focus on our financial services businesses,” Gehlaut said. Indiabulls Real Estate will have zero net debt at the time of the merger, the company said. After the deal was announced, the stock price of Indiabulls Real Estate on the BSE closed 5% higher at Rs 107.

Title: Former PMC boss, ex-BUIDCO MD held responsible for waterlogging
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

PATNA: Urban development and housing department (UDHD) minister Suresh Kumar Sharma on Friday said the four-member committee formed to probe the causes for prolonged waterlogging in Patna in September last year, has found former Patna Municipal Corporation (PMC) commissioner Anupam Kumar Suman and former Bihar Urban Infrastructure Development Corporation (BUIDCO) managing director Amrendra Prasad Singh responsible for the menace.

Sharma told TOI over phone on Friday that necessary action would soon be initiated against the two officers based on the report of the probe committee.

“Anupam Suman and Amrendra Singh have been mainly found responsible for waterlogging in Patna and action will be taken against them. We have already initiated action against many engineers of BUIDCO, who were found negligent in performing their duties,” Sharma said.

Earlier, the four-member committee headed by development commissioner Arun Kumar Singh was formed by the state government on October 14 and it was tasked to submit a report based on its findings in a month.

“The committee had submitted its report on waterlogging in Patna to the home department more than a month ago,” development commissioner Singh said.

Home department additional chief secretary Amir Subhani said the report would be sent to UDHD.

UDHD secretary Anand Kishor said the department had not received the report till Friday evening.

Earlier, chief secretary Deepak Kumar had announced the formation of the high-level committee after CM Nitish Kumar held over a four-hour-long meeting on October 14 with top bureaucrats to discuss the waterlogging issue in the city.

Other members in the committee included principal secretaries of road construction department Amrit Lal Meena, disaster management department Pratyaya Amrit and finance department S Siddhartha. The committee members were tasked to find the reasons and lapses behind waterlogging and prepare a plan to address the issue of recurring waterlogging in the city.

Three days of torrential rain from September 27 last year had submerged many localities of Patna, especially Rajendra Nagar, Kankarbagh, Sanichhra and Pataliputra.

UDHD had earlier taken action against 11 senior officers of BUIDCO, including a chief engineer, two superintendent engineers and seven executive engineers for negligence. PMC had taken action against two of its executive engineers, a city manager and six sanitary inspectors. The state government had even transferred UDHD principal secretary Prasad to science and technology department in the same capacity and BUIDCO MD Amrendra Prasad Singh was made administrator in Bihar State Road Transport Corporation.

Title: Deo Surya Mahotsav begins today
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

AURANGABAD: The three-day Deo Surya Mahotsav, a joint venture of state tourism department and Aurangabad district administration, will be inaugurated on Saturday.

A cultural extravaganza is also being organised on the occasion in which artists like Anup Jalota and Sumitra Guha will perform. District information and public relations officer Dharamvir Singh said, “Apart from Jalota, Bhajan singers Sunil Mishra and Alka Mishra, Bhojpuri singer Tanu Priyanka and Kathak dancer Prachi Pallavi Sahu will also perform on the inaugural day on Saturday.”

“Bhojpuri singer Sunil Chhaila Bihari and folk singer Neelu Navgeet among others will perform on the second day. The highlight of the closing ceremony on February 3 will be Bollywood singers Rakesh Raj and Akanksha Sharma. Classical singer Padma Shri Sumitra Guha will also perform on the concluding day,” Singh said.

The main event of Surya Mahotsav will be held at the Mela ground located near Ranipokhar at Deo block headquarters. The inauguration ceremony will be chaired by state mines and geology minister Brajkishore Bind, while tourism minister Krishna Kumar Rishi will be the chief guest of the ceremony.

Other dignitaries to be present on the occasion are Aurangabad MP Sushil Kumar Singh, Karakat MP Mahabali Singh, legislative council members Awadhesh Narayan Singh, Sanjeev Shyam Singh, Rajan Kumar Singh, MLAs Virendra Kumar Singh, Ashok Kumar Singh, Anand Shankar Singh, Virender Kumar Sinha, Manoj Kumar and Rajesh Kumar.

Aurangabad town, also called Suryanagari, has been decorated and a huge pandal has been set up for the three-day event. The main stage has been decorated by artists from other states. A development fair has also been organized in which various departments will showcase their achievements in their stalls. Competitions will be also organized among local children at various level.

Title: Tourism corporation gets new MD
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

PATNA: The state government on Friday notified transfer and posting of altogether four IAS officers, including the appointment of a new managing director (MD) of the Bihar State Tourism Development Corporation (BSTDC).

According to a notification issued by the general administrative department, Prabhakar, a 2007-batch IAS officer of Sikkim cadre, who had been waiting for posting after his interstate deputation in Bihar, has been made the new MD of the BSTDC. He has also been asked to hold the charge of additional secretary in the tourism department till further order.

Besides, Vijay Kumar, a 2007-batch Bihar cadre officer, has been notified as additional secretary in the agriculture department. Kanval Tanuj, (2010 batch) currently working as additional secretary in the rural development department, has been given the additional charge of director, cultural affairs in the art, culture and youth department.

Cabinet secretariat department additional secretary Himanshu Kumar Rai (2010 batch) has been transferred to the general administration department as additional secretary.

Title: Sensex up 3% since last Budget
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Mumbai: It’s been a volatile seven months for Dalal Street investors since the last Budget by finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman on July 5, 2019, with the sensex up 1,201 points or 3% to Friday’s close at 40,732, while some of the other indices have lost ground.

Riding the gains in blue chips like Bharti Airtel (up 36%), Asian paints (32%), ICICI Bank (20.5%), HUL (13.6%) and Reliance Industries (12%), investors’ wealth also jumped by a little over Rs 5 lakh crore with the BSE’s market capitalisation now almost at Rs 156 lakh crore.

The gains in the last seven months since the Budget had come mainly on the back of buying by mutual funds, which together bought stocks worth Rs 45,300 crore. Foreign funds, however, mostly remained muted with a net inflow at Rs 1,632 crore. One of the main triggers for the rally since the last Budget was the government’s September 20 decision to cut corporate taxes sharply that added a little over 1,900 points, or 5% to the index in a single session.

Outside of the index, stocks of insurance and mutual fund companies recorded stellar gains with HDFC MF up over 60%, ICICI Life up 28% and HDFC Life up 26%. Stocks of pharma and related sectors also showed good gains, BSE data showed.

Among the business groups, investors in Adani Group saw their total wealth rise by 19% or by nearly Rs 33,500 crore to almost Rs 2.1 lakh crore. The shareholders of HDFC group also saw their total wealth rise by nearly 6% or by almost Rs 70,000 crore to Rs 12.8 lakh crore. This professionally managed financial services group still remains the most valued business house in India.

Title: Four booked for attempt to murder bizman
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Rajkot: A businessman lodged an attempt to murder complaint against four persons with the Malaviyanagar police station in Rajkot on Friday.

In his complaint, Hari Bambhawa alleged that the accused, identified as his cousin Vikram Shiyaliya, Hamir Shiyaliya, Lakhman Shiyaliya, and an unidentified associate tried to kill him by ramming his car twice with their car on Gondal Road.

“After causing the accident, the accused stopped their car and allegedly pelted stones at Bambhawa’s car, shattering the rear windscreen. When Bambhawa got out of the vehicle, the accused allegedly tried to run him over with their car,” said N N Chudasama, inspector with Malaviyanagar police station.

Bambhawa alleged that his brother and Shiyaliya were involved in a financial dispute over a commission on the sale of a property for the past five years.

Bambhawa said he had come to meet his daughter in Geetanagar on Gondal Road in Rajkot and on his way back to his native Vagadia village of Muli taluka in Surendranagar district he was allegedly attacked by the accused.

“The accused first allegedly rammed into Bambhawa’s vehicle near a car showroom on Gondal Road and then hit it again some 200 metres away. Bambhawa was also hit by a stone on the head which one of the accused had hurled at him,” added Chudasama.

Title: SBI sees highest quarterly net of Rs 5,583cr in Oct-Dec
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Mumbai: SBI reported its highest ever quarterly net profit of Rs 5,583 crore — up 41% from the corresponding quarter of the previous year. The gains were bolstered by a sharp jump in net interest income.

This was partly because of the recovery of Rs 11,000 crore following the resolution of the Essar Steel default due to its sale to ArcelorMittal under the insolvency process.

The bank managed to grow its net interest income (NII) by 22% to Rs 22,779 crore despite loan growth being subdued at less than 7%. This was because the bank managed to cap the increase in interest outgo to less than 1% despite deposits growing by 10%.

“For the quarter, our net interest margin (NIM) was 3.59%. If we remove the impact of the Essar Steel recovery, the NIM would be 3.37%. We are maintaining the cost of deposits very well and passing on the benefit to the borrower, which is how we have managed to maintain our NIM,” said chairman Rajnish Kumar .

Kumar said that in the current quarter, the bank was anticipating recovery from one large steel company and a textile company. “Going forward, it is now credit growth that is on my wish list. If there is credit growth, our NII will go up. If we can grow credit at 12% instead of 7%, it will mean an additional credit growth of Rs 1.5 lakh crore, which will improve NII by Rs 4,000-5,000 crore,” he said.“SBI reported results were in line with estimates on healthy growth and asset quality. One-time gain from Essar Steel resolution sale was utilised for a housing finance company (DHFL) provision, divergence and deferred tax asset adjustment (DTA) for lower tax adoption,” said ICICI Securities in a note.

According to Kumar, adjustments towards DTA were complete and, from next quarter, the bank would record full benefit of lower tax rates.

“Results for Q3 had several moving parts, but on the whole the performance was healthy. The management appeared confident and has taken the full impact of FY19 divergences, and still posted healthy operating performance. We believe SBI is well on its way of declining asset stress,” said Lalitabh Shrivastawa, deputy vice-president, Sharekhan.

The profits would have been higher but for the provisions on DHFL, which was classified as an NPA during the quarter. Besides loans to DHFL, SBI had also purchased a pool of home loans disbursed by the stressed housing finance company. Kumar said that the bank had done thorough due diligence before purchasing the loans. “We do very thorough due diligence at the time of purchase of the pool. We will have a relook in light of what the enforcement directorate has said,” said Kumar.

Title: Women safety: Another forgettable year as rape, abduction cases rise
Content:
Representative image

BHOPAL: Gandhi Nagar on city outskirts has emerged as the most unsafe area for minor girls with around 12 rape cases being reported in 2019. Habibganj and Kolar shared the second spot with nine cases each while six cases each were reported from TT Nagar, Govindpura and Shahjehanabad areas in 2019.Kolar, Habibganj, Ashoka Garden and Piplani topped in number of rape cases reported by women. A dozen cases each were reported in these areas during 2019. Chhola and Piplani topped in molestation of minor girls with 17 and 16 cases being reported respectively during the year.As per the data released by Bhopal police, out of 342 rape cases in 2019, 147 were of minor girls, a rise of around 10% than 2018. There was a spurt in abduction cases of women in 2019 with 674 cases being reported, a rise of around 80% as compared to 2018 when 373 abduction cases were reported.Senior police officers claimed that demographic and socio-economic disparity factors were the main reason behind rise in crime against minor girls in these areas. Officers maintained police along with NGOs have started interacting with people residing in the areas where the rate of crime against women is high and spreading awareness on sensitising people about measures to stop such crimes.Speaking on issue of rise in abduction cases, cops maintained that in most cases girl and boy elope, but since they are minors, a case of abduction is registered against the boy. In many cases sections of rape is also added. Cops claimed that it is a social issue and should be addressed accordingly. When asked why high number of crime against women and girls were reported in Gandhi Nagar, Chhola and Nishatpura area, CSP Lokesh Sinha said that police take incidents of crime against women and children very seriously and registers case in every incident reported, so there is rise in numbers.He said Gandhi Nagar is on city outskirts while Chhola and Nishatpura are densely-populated areas. All three areas have people mostly from economically weaker section. In most families, both parents work and leave their children at home with neighbours or relatives during daytime. CSP Sinha said police teams visit and interact with people in slum areas regularly and are spreading awareness to sensitise people on the issue.Speaking on rise in crime against women and girls in Piplani and Govidpura area, CSP Amit Kumar said there are many girls’ hostels and many students from other cities reside there. Many a times, boys stalk or make obscene phone calls to girls. In many cases it was found that the boy and the girl were friend and after a dispute the boy started harassing her.CSP Kumar said a large part of these areas fall under the BHEL township. There are several slum areas in the jurisdiction in which migratory labourers reside. Many cases of crime against women were reported from these areas.Speaking on rise in number of rape and molestation cases in Kolar, CSP Bhupinder Singh said the jurisdiction of Kolar police station is very wide. More than 40 slum areas are situated in the area and there is socio-economic disparity. The area is overpopulated and underdeveloped. Similar is the case with Habibganj area where many slum areas are located. Most of the cases were reported from these areas.CSP Singh added that increasing use of social media platforms have also led to increase in crime against women cases. Women and girls come in contact with strangers over social media platforms and become friends. Many a times, unidentified people exploit women and girls.A senior woman cop wishing anonymity said many cases of molestation and rape go unreported as people fear social stigma.“People need to be made aware that such incident must be reported as it happens,” she added.Director Childline Archana Sahay said the National Crime Record Bureau (NCRB) reports state that in cases of crime against children the involvement of known people was around 95 to 97%. It is important to teach the children differences between good touch and bad touch.DIG Irshad Wali said that police along with NGOs and social organisations have already started spreading awareness on measures to control crime against women and children by visiting in different areas of the city. Special focus is on economically weaker and slum areas from where such cases were reported in the past. The joint teams conduct counselling sessions and ask women to install MPeCop App on their phones which can be used in SOS situation.He said police have identified the spots with high rate of harassment complaints. ‘Maitri’ teams and Shakti Squads regularly visit in these areas, especially school and colleges and keep a check on miscreants.”

Title: Small savings hold up interest rate reduction
Content: Mumbai: Small savings rates are preventing rate cuts by the RBI from being passed on to the banking system, the Economic Survey indicated, reiterating a point made by the central bank in the past. Until rates on small savings like the public provident fund ( PPF ) fall, term deposit rates are unlikely to decline.Although there is a formula where small savings rates are reset by the government every quarter, the revision has not been very effective. In December 2019, RBI governor Shaktikanta Das had said in the context of monetary policy transmission that there is also a need for greater flexibility in adjustment in interest rates on small saving schemes.The survey has pointed out that while there has been a reduction in the savings deposit rate by 25 basis points (100bps = 1 percentage point) in 2019, the term deposit rate, which is more important, has seen a decline of only 16bps from January 2019 to October 2019. “An important limiting factor seems to be the rates on small savings schemes like PPF. In 2014, the weighted average term deposit rate was the same as PPF, however, the gap between them is 115bps at October-end 2019,” the survey said.Das had in his policy said the RBI has communicated its vieAccording to the survey, RBI’s monetary easing and release of liquidity have had some impact on short term interest rates. However, this impulse is not feeding through to longer-term maturities. Since beginning of the year, yields on short term government securities (364 days T-bill) have declined much faster than that of long-term government securities (10-year G-sec).Typically when the RBI cuts rates, yields on government bonds fall. A fall in yields hikes price of existing stock of government bonds held by banks, who make profit by selling these bonds. At the same time, it also brings down the cost of fresh government borrowings as the RBI can issue long-term bonds at lower rates.However, after August 2019 the yield on 10-year government bonds has not declined much, barring the small decline after special open market operations by the RBI. Despite a decrease in policy rates, credit growth in the economy has been declining since the beginning of this year. Bank credit growth moderated from 12.9% in April 2019 to 7.1% as on December 20, 2019.

Title: Thumbs-down for loan waivers
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Political parties use farm debt waivers as a key tool to win over farmers (Reuters)

NEW DELHI: Political parties use farm debt waivers as a key tool to win over farmers , but such an option does not get the support of the Economic Survey which on Friday said debt waivers not only disrupt credit culture but also choke formal credit flow to farmers.

Though the Survey did not reject government intervention outright, it suggested that government “must systematically examine areas of needless intervention and undermining of markets”. Referring to past debt waivers by states and the Centre, the Survey said, “The full waiver beneficiaries consume less, save less, invest less and are less productive after the waiver, compared to the partial beneficiaries.” It said eliminating such instances will enable competitive markets, spurring investments and economic growth.

The Survey noted that though the phenomenon of granting debt waivers to farmers just before or after an election had died down in the early nineties, the practice saw a revival after the large-scale farm debt waiver announced by the Union government in 2008.

Referring to studies which analysed impact of debt waivers in different states, the Survey said it was clear that “an unconditional and blanket debt waiver is a bad idea. It does not achieve any meaningful real outcomes for the intended beneficiaries while the costs to the exchequer are significant.”

Title: Bhubaneswar-Varanasi daily flight operations begin
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

VARANASI: The Alliance Air , a subsidiary of Air India , launched its daily direct flight operations between Bhubaneswar and Varanasi on Friday. The airline has deployed its 70-seater ATR 72 600 aircraft.

The Air India station manager at Lal Bahadur Shastri International Airport Atif Idrish said that on the first day as many as 36 passengers arrived in the city from Bhubaneswar, while 32 passengers from Varanasi flew to Bhubaneswar. The flight (9I 747) departing from Bhubaneswar at 12:15pm arrived in Varanasi at 2:05pm, while the flight (9I 748) from Varanasi took off at 2:30pm.

Idrish said that the flight services between Varanasi and Bhubaneswar have been started as a regional connectivity scheme (RCS) route under the UDAN. This flight would cater to the need of swift connectivity for tourists, students, business community and traders. The option of daily direct flights between the two destinations would reduce the travel time making it convenient for passengers.

Title: ‘Focus only on promotion of corporate farming’
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The Union Budget lays focus only on promotion of corporate farming, said minister for agriculture V S Sunilkumar. “The budget asks government to implement certain acts which are all meant to safeguard the interests of corporate farming. Kerala has not implemented any of these acts. The budget does not inspire any hope for the state,” said Sunilkumar.

Finance minister Thomas Isaac said that the budget does not offer anything concrete for agriculture sector apart from pompous statements. The allocation under the sector is also the same as that of previous fiscal, he said.

Officials said that a proposal being mooted in the budget may evoke the state's interest; the one that proposes making use of self-help groups. The budget proposes a village storage scheme as a backward linkage run by self-help groups. This will provide farmers a good holding capacity and reduce their logistics cost.

Title: Help desks set up to address property tax complaints
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Kozhikode: Mayor Thottathil Raveendran here on Friday informed the council that the civic body has already set up helpdesks at the corporation main office and three zonal offices to address the grievance and public complaints related to revised property tax introduced after a gap of 25 years.

He further said that residential buildings having an area up to 2,000sq ft and constructed before 2016 were exempted from the revised tax rate.

He further said that houses having 660sq ft need not remit any type of tax if the house owner only has a single house. The tax exemption is not applicable to house owners who have two residential houses in his name and carried out modifications before.

Mayor also directed the additional secretary to look into the demand notice of Rs 28,740 on property tax received by a house owner in the Kolathara ward when Kolathara councillor Kunhamutty brought the issue to his attention.

Mayor said that the public can either approach him or deputy mayor Meera Darshak to resolve their complaints related to revised tax. He said that the revised tax has proposed Rs 14 per square meter for residential buildings. Mayor gave a reply in this regard when a joint resolution on revised property tax with retrospective effect from April 1, 2016 moved in the council by councillors K Nisha of CPM and M Kunhamutty of UDF. Moving the adjournment motion councillor Kunhamutty said that a person in his ward got demand notice of Rs 28,740 of property tax with retrospective effect. K Nisha urged the mayor to decrease the tax rate and give extra three months of time for the building owners to remit the pending arrears of property tax. The council also passed an adjournment motion moved in the council by town planning standing committee M C Anil Kumar of CPM, condemning the incident of a gun wielding man opening fire at students who were protesting against the Citizenship Amendment Act and National Register of Citizens near the Jamia Millia Islamia in South Delhi on January 30 in which a student got injured. 66 UDF and CPM councillors supported the motion while six BJP councillors voted against it for mentioning the attacker was a RSS man. The council also witnessed a mayhem when mayor denied permission to K T Beeran Koya of IUML to move a resolution on dysfunctional streetlights. Speaking to media persons soon after the council, mayor said that the workers of Karnataka State Electronics Development Corporation Ltd (KSEDC) have already commenced replacements of streetlight with LED lights.

Title: No misuse of prescription drugs: FDA
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: The Food and Drugs Administration ( FDA ) hasn’t found misuse of prescription drugs after it brought about strict controls.

Compared to cases registered in the past against the misuse of ketamine, we have not found misuse, FDA director Jyoti Sardesai said. “There is a special task force that conducts surprise checks with focus on habit forming drugs, which are likely to be misused,” she said, adding that the checks are carried out in coastal areas.

Title: On opening day, leaks detected in Gangajal treatment facility
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

The raw water tanks made of concrete were found to be leaking.

AGRA: The Gangajal water treatment facility at Jeevani Mandi water works station here inaugurated by state urban development minister Ashutosh Tandon on Friday was found to be leaking at over a dozen places. The inlet and tube settler unit for supply of Ganga water in different parts of the city had been operationalized on January 21.

Under the Rs 2,887-crore Gangajal project, funded by Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA), Agra is getting 140 cusecs of Ganga water from Palra headworks in Bulandshahr's Upper Ganga canal. For this, a 130-km pipeline was laid. The project was launched in 2005 and its deadline has been forwarded several times.

Under the project, Jeevani Mandi water works station is being upgraded. In December 2019, the upgradation of 225 million litre per day (MLD) capacity raw water treatment plant was completed.

After inspection of the facility by the minister, who was accompanied by principal secretary Manoj Kumar Singh and managing director of the Jal Nigam Vikas Gothalwal, the raw water tanks made of concrete were found to be leaking.

On inspection, TOI found over a dozen leakages in the base of the treatment facility. The drain pipes were covered with rust. At several spots, sealants were applied to stop the leakage.

According to sources, over Rs 92 crore has been sent on upgrading the Jeevani Mandi water works station. A private company was contracted for development of the 225 MLD water treatment plant. The leakages have occurred due to flaw in design and use of sub-standard quality material in constructing the tanks, it is learnt.

When questioned about the leakages in the Gangajal treatment facility , minister Tandon said, “The matter has not come to my knowledge. I will talk to the officials in this regard. The matter will be investigated.”

Gothalwal said, “Usually leakages do not take place in a water treatment facility. The reason behind the leakages will be investigated. Suitable action will be taken.”

Title: No headway in AMU talks, university could be ‘shut temporarily’
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Aligarh Muslim University. (File photo)

AGRA: Though the Aligarh Muslim University ( AMU ) administration has decided to reschedule examinations after commencement of classes in a few faculties, a section of students have intensified their protests in the campus on Friday and refused to resolve any issue without the resignation of VC, registrar and proctor.

According to administrative officials, the situation is getting worse by the day and if students don’t relent, the university could be closed for some time. The VC, Tariq Mansoor, has already indicated the possibility of shutting down the university, if the campus protest continue and call for a lockdown is not withdrawn. He has stated this in an open letter addressed to students earlier this week.

On Thursday evening, the VC again appealed to students and members of the teaching staff to help in resorting normalcy and functioning of academic activities in a peaceful manner. In a video released by the AMU administration, the VC expressed deep regret at the unfortunate incidents that took place on the intervening night of December 15 and 16.

He further assured, “As far as other grievances of students are concerned, all issues will be discussed, once normalcy is restored.”

Though the university reopened after a month-long winter break on January 13, protests against the ‘police action’ on CAA protesters have continued in the campus, with demands of resignation of Vice-Chancellor Tariq Mansoor, Registrar Abdul Hamid and Proctor Afifullah Khan for their “failure to protect the students”.

Other demands include withdrawal of all “false cases” registered against protesting students, no further police action or harassment against those who carry out peaceful protests on campus. The students are also seeking an assurance that no information related to students will be passed on to police and local intelligence unit, and in future, police won’t be allowed into the campus. Though the administration has agreed to most of these demands, the students are refusing to relent.

University spokesperson, Shafey Kidwai, said that the administration is making all efforts to restore normalcy in the campus. He said, “We are hopeful of bringing back normalcy by Monday.”

Title: Assembly won’t discuss oppn resolution to call back guv
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: With the ruling LDF taking a strong position against the notice served by opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala, the business advisory committee (BAC) of the state assembly decided not to allow the substantive motion under rule 130 requesting the President to call back governor Arif Mohammad Khan .

In the BAC meeting, opposition UDF leaders pressed for the notice but parliamentary affairs minister A K Balan disputed all arguments and conveyed without any doubt that the treasury benches were not willing to allow the motion. With the government detaching itself from the move to humiliate the governor, a truce between governor and the council of ministers , who had been at loggerheads over the Supreme Court suit filed by the state challenging the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, has been in place.

Speaker P Sreeramakrishan who had earlier said that the notice was in accordance with rules took a stand in BAC that discussion on the 130 notice could be held only with the permission of treasury benches. Minister Balan, said sources, disputed even the existence of the notice saying that the Speaker hadn’t accepted it. He also said there was no precedence of the assembly discussing such a notice.

Later Balan told reporters that the session would be running with a tight schedule and there wouldn’t be time to discuss the motion. He said that practical reasons as well as legal angles prompted the government to take a stand against the notice. “We also don’t want to allow the issues between governor and government to escalate”, he said.

Opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala alleged that the stand of the government once again exposed the tacit understanding between the government and the governor. He said the ruling front doesn’t have the courage to take on governor. “Had this resolution be discussed and passed, that would have been a lesson for entire country. Kerala assembly had set several models for other houses. This would have warned PM Narendra Modi and home minister Amit Shah against using governors to unsettle state governments,” Chennithala told reporters.

He also disputed the arguments of Balan. “The position that there was no precedent in the state assembly is not correct. In 1969, when EMS was the CM, the Kerala assembly passed a resolution condemning certain actions of West Bengal Governor. Later, when E K Nayanar was the CM, the then Speaker Varkala Radhakrishnan allowed a resolution that registered the dissatisfaction of the assembly over a decision taken by governor Ramdulari Sinha. The Tamil Nadu assembly had passed a resolution demanding to recall governor when Jayalalithaa was the CM,” said Chennithala.

Title: Minister releases handbook on road safety for teachers
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: As first step towards integrating road safety lessons in the school curriculum, Kerala Road Safety Authority (KRSA), National Transportation Planning and Research Centre (NATPAC) and State Council of Educational Research and Training (SCERT) have jointly published a handbook on road safety for teachers.

‘Surakshithayatra’, published with an aim to inculcate the habit of following traffic rules among students from primary class, was released by transport minister A K Saseendran recently.

“The integration of road safety rules in school syllabus has been a long-term project and it is being implemented now. The handbook for teachers is just the beginning of this initiative, which is the first ever attempt in the country. Next, mapping will be conducted on how to include the lessons in the school textbooks, as the lessons has to be different for each standard based on their class level.

For example, road safety rules can be included in social science and first aid can be part of biology,” said Rajagopal K, director, communication and public relations, Kerala Road Safety Authority. “There have been enquiries from the Centre about the handbook and we are planning to translate it to English,” he added.

The 110-page book, which begins with a note to teachers, consists of details related to safety of motorists, passengers and pedestrians, traffic rules and first aid. The matter is explained with representative picture and there are questions and answers section and activities for teachers in the book.

Around two lakh copies of the book will be printed and distributed among school teachers across the state. The handbook will be part of vacation training classes for teachers to be held in the next academic year.

“The revision of school curriculum has started as per the directive from the Centre. Regarding the integration of road safety lessons in school textbooks, decision will have to be taken whether to include the lessons in textbooks or as a separate book for children to read,” said J Prasad, director, SCERT.

As part of the activity, road safety clubs will be formed in all government schools after school reopens in the next academic year. “Road safety lessons are likely to be introduced in the curriculum in 2021-22 academic year. Road safety is a matter to be dealt at the grassroot level and integrating it in the school syllabus is the apt way to reduce the number of accidents. There are notes and pamphlets on traffic rules, but it is the first time that a detailed book for school is published. It is proposed to start the training programme for teachers in schools located near national highway and state highway for the safety of students," said an official from SCERT.

Title: Global campaign to restore Satyajit, Ritwik, Mrinal’s ancestral homes in Bangladesh
Content: Ritwik Ghatak’s home in Rajshahi was leased by then military government of Hussain Muhammad Ershad to a pri... Read More KOLKATA: An international campaign to restore Satyajit Ray , Mrinal Sen and Ritwik Ghatak ’s ancestral homes in Bangladesh has been initiated. The decision was taken on Thursday at the central executive committee meeting of the Federation of Film Societies of India (FFSI), founded by Ray in 1959.“The matter will be taken up at the international level so that the Bangladesh government gives due importance to preserve all the three ancestral homes of the great masters of world cinema. The issue will be brought to the notice of the Indian government’s ministry of culture, Indian National Trust for Art and Cultural Heritage and Unesco,” said Premendra Mazumder, vice-president of FFSI and the Asia Pacific secretary of the International Federation of Film Societies (IFFS).Ghatak’s home in Rajshahi was leased by then military government of Hussain Muhammad Ershad to a private homoeopathy college in the 80s. A recent plan to demolish to make way for a bicycle garage raised a hue and cry among residents and intellectuals in Bangladesh and abroad, with protests being held in in Rajshahi, Dhaka and Toronto. Film personalities of Bangladesh, including Tanvir Mokammel, Morshedul Islam, Nasiruddin Yousuff Bachchu and Shameem Akhtar, staged demonstrations and signed a petition, asking the Bangaldesh government to save not only Ghatak’s home but also that of Ray and Sen. The demolition plan was stalled.While Ray’s ancestral home is at Mashua in Kishoreganj, Sen’s house is in Faridpur’s Jhiltuli. Ray’s ancestral house is in a dilapidated state now. “Film activists of Dhaka had appealed to the government through the district administration for its immediate renovation and preservation. Sen’s ancestral house has a private owner. Restoring it might prove to be a challenge, unless the current owner cooperates. Most of the property has been demolished to build a new structure. But parts of the original house still remain and can be renovated,” Mazumder added.Directors in Bangladesh have welcomed FFSI’s initiative. Bachchu told TOI from Dhaka, “The work on building the bicycle garage at Ghatak’s home was stalled. We are now trying to convince the government to build a Ritwik Cultural Centre there. Ghatak’s Dhaka-based niece, Aroma Dutta, an MP, is supporting the cause. We are happy with FFSI initiative.”Ghatak’s grandniece Ina Puri, who will visit Bangladesh soon, is equally happy: “Given that his twin, Pratiti Devi, died only weeks ago, the need to preserve the legacy of my granduncle’s ancestral home becomes more important now, than ever before. It will be wonderful if his house is preserved, and perhaps, made into a museum.” The Ray family has also welcomed the move.

Title: Traders organise ‘budhi-sudhi yagya’ to protest against Agra Municipal Corporation
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Agra: On the eighteenth day of the indefinite strike, traders of Sanjay Place on Friday organized a ‘ budhi-sudhi yagya ’ to protest against the Agra Municipal Corporation over the issue of parking fee. Traders gathered at the dharna spot in the parking space raised slogans against the AMC administration and mayor Naveen Jain .

Meanwhile, Congress and Samajwadi Party leaders also participated in the trader's protest. Congress workers led by state secretary Shabana Khandelwal begged to register their protest against AMC. In support of the traders, national general secretary of Samajwadi Party Ramjilal Suman addressed the traders and declared support in the protest.

Since January 14, traders in Sanjay Place are on an indefinite strike against the Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC) administration for charging parking fee at 38 places in the market. They claimed that it violates norms as they had already paid a fee for parking at the time of purchasing the property.

President of the Sanjay Place market association, KN Agnihotri said, “The dispute over parking fee between traders of Sanjay Place and AMC is sub judice. We want AMC to cancel the parking contracts till the court delivers its final orders in the matter. In this regard, we had handed over a memorandum to the urban development minister Ashutosh Tandon at the circuit house. Few BJP leaders who were around the minister didn’t allowed us to explain the entire matter.”

Hiren Agarwal, secretary of the market association, said, “The AMC administration is trying to exploit traders by illegally charging the parking fee. We have already paid for the parking space. To muzzle the voice of the traders, a fake FIR has been registered. We will continue our fight against the parking mafia.”

Association’s treasurer Vinay Mittal alleged that despite the ongoing case at the sessions court, the AMC administration had issued parking contracts for three years to people associated with the BJP. “AMC officials also get a share of the parking fee illegally collected from the market. We will not withdraw our protest till the AMC rolls back its decision,” he said.

Title: Probe alleged encroachment of land by NGO in Govardhan: NGT to UP
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

AGRA: The National Green Tribunal (NGT) on Friday directed the Uttar Pradesh government to probe the allegations of encroachment of public land, water bodies and heritage sites under the garb of social services by an NGO in Mathura’s Goverdhan. The NGT asked the UP to get the probe done by some central agency.

A bench headed by Justice Raghuvendra S Rathore said that they are of a considered opinion that a prima-facie case of encroachment of public land, heritage sites as well as water bodies is made out against the NGO. Therefore, the state government should have this case investigated by any central agency, which shall place a report before the competent authority for appropriate orders.

The bench said that this action is immediately warranted because of “continuous destruction of environment.”

The directions came on a plea filed by ‘ Giriraj Parikrama Sanrakshan Sansthan’ seeking directions to Uttar Pradesh government for conducting investigation against the “illegal” actions of the NGO.

Title: Goa meets January GST target with 14% increase in mop-up
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: Goa’s goods and services tax ( GST ) collections for the current financial year have shown an 8.76% year-on-year increase with the tax mop-up in January hitting the monthly target, even showing a 14% increase for the month over last, the authorities said. However, in comparison to the tax revenue under the VAT regime, the state is facing an over 30% shortfall in tax earnings.

Commissioner for GST Deepak Bandekar told TOI that the GST collection for the April-December period stood at Rs 1,668 crore against Rs 1,533.8 crore for the same period in 2018-19.

“In October we had negative collections, but November and December showed good growth. For December there was a 30.9% growth,” Bandekar said.

For January, Goa collected Rs 412.7 crore in GST as on January 28 and with the state meeting its monthly target, no compensation is due from the Centre for the month.

Bandekar said that while the growth in GST collections was encouraging, the state is still not meeting its annual GST collection targets. According to a senior finance department official, Goa has seen a 30% shortfall in GST collections in comparison to the tax revenue earned under the VAT regime.

In 2017-18, Goa pulled in an average of Rs 171 crore per month, which increased in 2018-19 to Rs 183.5 crore per month on an average.

“The GST rates for 250-300 items have been reduced and this is bound to affect the collections,” Bandekar said.

The reduction in GST rates for hotels has led to a Rs 100 crore cut in tax collections for the state.

The department of commercial taxes and state GST has also initiated action to plug tax leakages, especially from unregistered hotels and guesthouses. A special drive was organised to crack down on businessmen who are evading GST registration.

“We have identified and are initiating action against such evaders. Two hundred and twelve cases have been identified,” Bandekar said.

The department of commercial taxes has also penalised 153 vehicles for not filing e-way bills for inter-state transport of goods. It has collected fines amounting to Rs 90 lakh through fines for e-way bill violations.

Title: Mixed reaction from professionals over new income tax slabs
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The new amendment in income tax, proposed in the Union Budget by finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman, evoked mixed reaction among professionals in the city. The choice to let go of the deductions or to opt for reduced slab of tax has led to confusion among the people.

“In a first look, it seems newly proposed income tax slabs will benefit people, but when we checked in detail, it was not the case. The new scheme removed all deductions and that would reduce the investments of employees. Earlier, mployees were forced to invest some amount or try to invest in different schemes to get the benefit of tax saving. That indirectly helped them to have some investments that’s unlikely with the new scheme. Industries like ours which don’t have any retirement benefits will get benefited from these savings. The government is trying to project this scheme as a benefit for tax payers, but actually trying to discourage long term investments, said Raneesh A R, president of Prathidhwani, a socio-cultural organisation of techies.

CA Ramakrishnan H, secretary of The Institute of Chartered Accountants of India, Thiruvananthapuram branch said that the amendments relating to income tax are mere eyewash as far as the individuals are concerned. “Because the new liberalised slabs are applicable only if they are willing to forgo the concession given for investments such as housing loan interest. It is of no use to people, if they want to avail 80C reductions, housing loan reduction, standard deduction of Rs 50,000. Concessions are applicable only if they forgo these concessions. Overall, the budget is good as it gives thrust to agriculture sector, manufacturing sector and rural area, the amendment in income tax could have been avoided,” said Ramakrishnan.

Progressive Techies, a forum of IT employees said that the old regime of income tax is a better option for them and new provision discourage people from investing.

“There is confusion on the new tax amendment among techies. Even though the income tax per slab has been reduced, the decision to exempt the deductions has caused confusion. So, techies who have invested as per the old tax regime are in trouble. And, those who doesn’t have any investment or housing loan may avail the new provision in income tax. Also, the new regime results in discouraging them from doing investments,” said Anand P, general secretary, Progressive Techies.

Title: Business worth Rs 250 crore hit due to two-day bank strike
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Demonstrations were staged at various places on the first day of the strike on Friday

ALLAHABAD: Transactions worth Rs 250 crore were affected on the first day of the two-day nationwide strike of the bank unions, on Friday

Though, business of private sector banks remained unaffected, but the the employees of all public sector banks refrained from their duty affecting the routine activities.

The strike call has been given by the United Forum of Bank Unions (UFBU), an umbrella body of nine bank unions including All India Bank Officers’ Confederation (AIBOC), All India Bank Employees Association (AIBEA) and National Organisation of Bank Workers (NOBW).

Over 500 employees of different banks staged a demonstration near Central Bank of India in Civil Lines, said Shashi Kant Srivastava, convener, UFBU Allahabad adding that demonstrations were also staged at other places.

The demands of employee include wage revision that is pending since November 2017, 20% pay hike on pay slip components, five-day week, scrapping of the new pension scheme and merger of special allowance with basic pay.

Title: Safety step: AIIMS Nagpur reserves two beds for coronavirus suspects
Content: Nagpur: The All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) Nagpur has reserved two beds in case any coronavirus suspects approach the hospital. AIIMS also released the Dos and Don’ts for coronavirus.“AIIMS has initially reserved two beds with all isolation facilities in case we get any suspect of this viral infection. But we have the entire set-up ready to tackle any situation in the future,” said AIIMS Director and CEO Major Gen (Dr) Vibha Dutta, adding that vigilance is the key to tackle this infection.“Public health measures, including quarantining in the community, timely diagnosis, and strict adherence to universal precautions in health care settings are important for prevention of the viral infection. As vaccines or anti-viral drugs are not available on this virus, it can be treated symptomatically,” she added.Dr Dutta claimed that the outpatient department (OPD) of AIIMS has been receiving a good response with the average footfall of 400 to 500 patients per day. “The construction of the 300-bedded In-Patient Department (IPD) is on in full swing and we are planning to complete it by the end of this year. It will have 24 modular operation theatres (OTs), ICUs, imaging facilities like MRI, CT Scan, and Linear accelerators,” she said.In academics, AIIMS will start PG courses in pre-clinical and para clinical subjects by mid 2020 and MD/MS courses by 2021.Second foundation day of AIIMS on Feb 2AIIMS, Nagpur, will celebrate its second foundation day on February 2 at its Mihan campus from 9.30am. Union Minister Nitin Gadkari will be the chief guest. Former chief minister Devendra Fadnavis, AIIMS president professor PK Dave, secretary of ministry of health and family welfare (Govt of India) Preeti Sudan and secretary of medical education and drugs (Govt of Maharashtra) Dr Sanjay Mukherjee will address the faculty, staff and students.A souvenir will be released and the annual prize distribution function will be held. A presentation ‘Milestones achieved’ based on AIIMS Nagpur’s progress will be shown.IGGMC is now nodal VRDLIndira Gandhi Government Medical College (IGGMC) has received the status of nodal Viral Research and Diagnostic Lab (VRDL) for Nagpur. As per MAYO Hospital’s Assistant Medical Superintendent Dr Sagar Pande, the hospital already has a PCR Machine which is used for the diagnosis of coronavirus infection. “We need an agent which is a must to diagnose this virus. It will reach the hospital by Monday from Pune based national institute of virology (NIV). We will start collecting samples and conducting tests after that,” he said. The health department will collect details of people who travelled back from China in the month of January this year and check their blood samples in case they develop any signs and symptoms like respiratory problems, fever, cough, shortness of breath or diarrhoea.Tips given by AIIMS Nagpur* In you have fever, cough and difficulty in breathing, seek medical care early* Share previous travel history with doctor* Avoid direct/unprotected contact with live animals & farm animals* Avoid consumption of raw, uncooked animal products* Meat, milk and all animal products should be handled with care* Avoid close contact with anyone who has fever and cough

Title: Agricultural land sale: Ex-Union minister calls for laws to be tweaked
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Ramakant Khalap

PORVORIM: Amid public outcry to protect Goa’s land and prevent its sale to non-Goans, MLAs cutting across party lines have failed to close loopholes in the law that allow farmers to sell their agricultural land to non-agriculturists and business entities, said former Union minister and legislator Ramakant Khalap on Friday.

He said the state’s land revenue code, the Goa Mundkar Act, 1975, and the Goa, Daman & Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act, 1964, need to be amended and implemented in a time-bound manner.

“Goa’s biggest defect has been these loopholes in the laws and the failures of the legislators to remain vigilant about what the law says and does not say and to close these loopholes through proper legislation,” Khalap said. He was addressing reporters at a workshop on assembly proceedings organised by the Goa legislature secretariat and Goa Union of Journalists.

The former Union minister said that despite the tenancy act and mundkar act coming into force in the 1960s and the 1970s, respectively, issues have not been resolved till date.

“Is it not the duty of the legislators to see to it that a certain sunset clause, a date by which even the last vestige of this slavery is removed? Amendment motions should be moved to that act, so that once and for all, this issue can be solved,” Khalap said.

He said Goa’s land revenue code does not contain provisions to prevent the sale of agricultural land to non-agriculturists and the law, which was rolled out in 1978, permits virtually any non-agriculturist, businessman, company or person to buy land in the state.

Khalap, who headed the Goa Law Commission, said that the state needs to separate the judicial functions of mamlatdars from their administrative and executive functions so that pending mundkar and tenancy cases are resolved quickly.

He also said that it is the duty of the legislators to ensure that the government updates land records in Goa.

Title: Rs 16 crore chit fund scam: Kerala government to attach firm’s land in Ernakulam
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Kerala CM Pinarayi Vijayan

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The state government has ordered the temporary attachment of the properties of an under-probe chit fund firm accused of cheating investors to the tune of Rs 16 crore.

Additional chief secretary (home affairs) Vishwas Mehta , on Thursday, issued the order to attach 2.53 acres of M/s Tathwamasi Chits and Investments Private Limited and M/s Tathwamasi Ayurday Resorts Private Limited.

The order to attach the property at Edavanakkad , Ernakulam was issued under Section 3 of the Kerala Protection of Interests of Depositors in Financial Establishment Act, 2013.

The section empowered the government to pass an interim order to attach the property of any financial establishment—and transfer it to a competent authority—if the firm defaulted in returning the deposits, with interest, after maturity. The government also entrusted the Ernakulam district collector to apply before a special court to implement the attachment order. The order was issued based on a recommendation by the collector. The recommendation followed a proposal by the superintendent of police, crime branch, Thrissur, who found the property was acquired by using the money collected by allegedly cheating the investors.

The firm has been facing 88 cases, registered across the state under sections 406, 420 and 34 of the IPC, relevant sections of the Chit Funds Act, 1982, and Kerala Protection of Interests of Depositors in Financial Establishment Act, 2013.

In Thrissur alone, 45 cases were registered. “Investigation revealed that the accused directors of the company, with the intention of cheating the public and extracting money from them, collected huge amounts under the guise of chit business and acquired movable and immovable properties,” the order said.

Title: Telangana: Tweet leads to new school building
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Telangana: Tweet leads to new school building

Representative image HYDERABAD: After a Twitter user tweeted about a dilapidated school building in Mulugu , the education minister of Telangana, Sabitha Indra Reddy directed the commissioner of school education to construct a new building.

Title: West Bengal: Raising ‘One Billion’ voices against citizenship law
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Students of Loreto schools in the city perform at the event at Allen Park

KOLKATA: It’s not enough to talk about violence against women only. Voices have to be raised against atrocities on minorities and the marginalized as well, and anyone who is feeling insecure in the current circumstances, when even something as basic as citizenship is coming up for questioning. This was the rhetoric at the three-hour One Billion Rising programme organised by the Loreto nuns at Allen Park on Friday.

Hundreds of students at Loreto schools in the city gathered to sing, dance and add voice to the “Rising”, the sixth celebration in the city of the global movement started in the US by writer-women’s rights activist Eve Ensler in 2012. The concept is based on the fact that one out of every three women worldwide is subjected to violence at least once in lifetime. The OBR organiser in the city, Kolkata Mary Ward Social Centre, is a unit of the Loreto order and this year, it collaborated with Loreto Elliot Road to bring the Rising to life. Every year, one Loreto school, along with the Mary Ward, carries the baton.

The slogan, ‘Rise, Resist, Unite,’ also included voices against CAA and NRC , following a resolution to this effect taken at the OBR Delhi headquarters. “At OBR, people are taught to respect women, but as things stand now, there is an atmosphere of fear and uncertainty in the entire civil society. OBR is a natural platform of protest and hence, we are using it as an umbrella to include minorities and their fears. Let OBR be the platform, where we can preach respect for the Constitution,” said Nandini Bhattacharjee, a teacher at Loreto Elliot Road who coordinated the programme.

The chief of the city’s OBR, Monica Suchiang, a Loreto nun, also the director of Mary Ward, felt women worldwide have been rising, pledging to stand by one another. “The conviction is uncanny… you have finally met your tormentor eye-to-eye and that is the magic moment when you know you have conquered him,” Sister Suchiang said. The Superior of Loreto order, Sister Sabrina, was also present at the event.

The high point of the programme was the discussion, Addressing Inequality Challenges, where ‘inequality’ transcended ‘gender issues’ and encompassed discrimination meted out to religious minorities and communities. The speakers included Nandita Pal Choudhury, Anchita Ghatak, Deep Purakayastha, Saira Halim, Madiha Ahmed and Nick Rampal. The talk was moderated by Anglo Indian MLA Shane Calvert. The speakers likened the current political situation to fascism. “Even a few years ago, the challenges of being a woman was there but I was not made to feel like a minority,” said Halim, a social activist and writer. Calvert pointed out that mankind progressed only when there was tolerance and congratulated the organizers for extending the scope of OBR this time.

Title: NGO for recovery of Rs 966 crore from mining companies for illegal operations
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Goa Foundation has sought prosecution of those persons (including officials) responsible for violating the Env... Read More

PANAJI: After halting illegal mining in the state by approaching the Supreme Court seven years ago, NGO Goa Foundation has filed a petition in the high court of Bombay at Goa seeking recovery of over Rs 966 crore from mining companies involved in extraction of iron ore through illegal mining.

It has sought recovery from mining companies operating from 2007 to 2012 and between October 15, 2015 and March 15, 2018.

The NGO has sought direction to the state government to deposit the amount recovered from the mining companies in the Goa Iron Ore Permanent Fund.

Goa Foundation has sought prosecution of those persons (including officials) responsible for violating the Environment Protection Act, 1986 and provisions of the MDMR Act, 1957, as amended.

“Pending hearing and final disposal of this petition for an order restraining disposal of assets by mining companies and all owners, directors, key officers involved in such illegal mining should not be allowed to travel abroad,” the petition states.

The NGO has sought an interim order directing the state government to estimate the actual amount recoverable from mining companies.

The petition also seeks direction to the chief secretary to ascertain the circumstances in which mining operations were permitted in the absence of valid environmental clearances (ECs) and submit a report to the court.

The Goa Foundation petition states that all the ECs were not valid beyond 2010 or 2011, apart from the fact that many of these ECs had no validity from 2007.

“The mining companies and the authorities were aware that they did not have valid ECs when they re-commenced and carried out mining in the state after their leases were renewed post the Supreme Court judgment. So the companies could not have carried out extraction, mining and sale of ore from 2015 to 2018, even if they had a renewed lease. Neither could the authorities have permitted them to do so,” the NGO said.

Goa Foundation said the recovery amount is based on the payment of royalty at 15% and also takes into consideration payments made under different heads, including the District Mineral Foundation and the Goa Iron Ore Permanent Fund.

Title: Labourer dies after falling in dry well at Makarpura GIDC
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Vadodara: A labourer working at a sewage pumping station of the Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) died after he fell from a height in a dry well on Thursday night. The worker had been employed by a contractor. The deceased was identified as Vinod Rastogi. The incident took place when machinery in the dry well at the Makapura GIDC sewage pumping station was being repaired. Three persons had entered the well to do the repair work.

Rastogi was climbing up the ladder of the well after finishing the work when he slipped or missed a step and fell into the well. The worker was rushed to the SSG Hospital for treatment. He died at the hospital late on Thursday night. tnn

Title: Nagpur Municipal Corporation opens 20th UPHC at KT Nagar
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

The Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) in association with Tata Trusts has opened the 20th Urban Primary Healt... Read More

NAGPUR: The Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) in association with Tata Trusts has opened the 20th Urban Primary Health Centre (UPHC) at KT Nagar in Dharampeth Zone on Saturday. UPHC has been developed under the central government’s Urban National Health Mission Programme.

Deputy mayor Manisha Kothe inaugurated the UPHC while chairman of NMC health consultative committee Virendra Kukreja , corporators Harish Gwalbanshi , Amar Bagde, Maya Iwnate, Darshini Dhawad, Vikram Gwalbanshi, additional municipal commissioner Ram Joshi, deputy director of health Dr Bhavna Sonkusre, assistant commissioner Prakash Warhade, additional assistant health officer Dr Vijay Joshi, project chief of Tata Trusts Dr Amar Navkar, Tikesh Bisen and others were present.

A centre for screening, controlling and creating awareness about tuberculosis was also opened at UPHC.

The UPHC will remain open from Monday to Saturday from 8am to 2pm. Patients can get facilities like OPD, maternity checkup, pediatric, family planning counseling, vaccinations, RTI and STI counseling, leprosy and tuberculosis checkup, diagnosis and treatment of epilepsy and asthma, diabetes, diagnosis and treatment of vector-borne diseases etc.

Title: More you honk, the longer you wait! Signal to stay red if decibel level high
Content:
Honking causes noise pollution and has an adverse effect on health.

Horn not okay, please! Find out how the @MumbaiPolice hit the mute button on #Mumbai’s reckless honkers.… https://t.co/yJn4tf7d4U — Mumbai Police (@MumbaiPolice) 1580442358000

MUMBAI: The city traffic police have conducted trials of what could be a solution to the menace of needless honking—a punishing signal.Special decibel meters were connected to traffic signals at five locations and when noise exceeding 85dB was recorded, the signal timer would reset itself.This forced motorists to wait longer at the signal by “punishing” them for their impatience and teaching them to not honk the next time. A video clip of the experiment tweeted by Mumbai police ’s Twitter handle on Friday got 22,000 likes and was retweeted over 9,000 times.Honking causes noise pollution and has an adverse effect on health.“The trials were carried out for a few hours in November and December 2019. We selected locations that are most prone to congestion such as CSMT, Marine Drive, Pedder Road, Hindmata and Bandra Turner Road. In future, we will implement this at more signals,” said joint commissioner, traffic, Madhukar Pandey.He further said there could be congestion on some stretches as a result, but this would be managed by deploying additional forces.The video, made in partnership with private agency FCB Interface, gives glimpses of confused motorists who wait at a signal, honk continuously and learn it the hard way that honking is not the way out.Anti-noise activist Sumaira Abdulali commended the police for acting on on their own. “I hope the decibel meters will be put up permanently so that people become aware of the unacceptably high levels of noise from honking. At the same time, we have been demanding an enforcement campaign against honking, on the lines of the police’s helmet campaign, for a very long time. We hope that alongside the awareness created by decibel meters, they will take up an enforcement campaign which will continue over a sufficient period of time so that honking levels drop to within permissible limits,” said Abdulali.An RTI plea made by a media professional had revealed that only 1,293 motorists were booked for needless honking between January 2009 and September 2019. Deputy inspector general Harish Baijal, who was formerly with the traffic department, said, “We had the first ‘No Honking Day’ on April 7, 2008, and put up balloons and banners at Marine Drive, Bandra and Mahim Causeway and challaned 16,000 people. To drive home the point, I had challaned my own driver. After that, there was no major action taken by the traffic department and this video clip is really refreshing and reassuring,” said Baijal.Transport expert Hussain Indorewala has his doubts about the project though. One, said Indorewala, is how effective will it be in changing behaviour? It is likely that people will figure it out quickly and avoid honking where such a system is installed, but continue the practice where it isn’t. “People generally do not alter behaviour when they perceive they are being ‘tricked’ into doing things. So it may not work to alter social behavior, but simply make people smarter than the system,” he said. Two, added Indorewala, it seems Mumbai police is attacking a symptom, not the cause. Private transport on India’s precarious roads is an extremely stressful activity and forces people into sloppy behaviour, one of which is excessive honking, he said. “These kind of smart devices shift the burden of responsibility from public policy to individuals, and sidestep the more serious problem of traffic congestion by attacking traffic noise. Why not reduce stress by introducing traffic management instead?” he suggested. Three, he said, “such clever techno-fixes tend to create unanticipated problems. What happens if there is a fire truck or ambulance wanting to pass? A silencer gone bad? A Diwali night? Or what happens when some people deliberately create a din to arrest traffic?”Robby Mathew, chief creative officer, FCB Interface, said, “Sometimes, the stick works better than the carrot. And a signal that gave us a gentle rap on the knuckles for honking unnecessarily, seemed like a good idea to me”.
