According to doctors, a 3D model of the shoulder was prepared to identify the exact defect.

It is for the first time that 3D technology was used in a government hospital in Gujarat to treat a patient with such a peculiar condition.

“We had tried to reduce the relocated shoulder. But in rare conditions, the dislocation of shoulder continues for long. This patient too had to face it multiple times,” said Dr Tejas Chovatiya , senior resident at GMERS Gotri Hospital.

The doctors made a 3D model of shoulder bones. “Through this, we could learn the dynamics of dislocation and where exactly the defect lay – in the socket and the ball of the shoulder. We could also ascertain whether we should opt for soft tissue repair or go for bone graft transfer,” he said.

Using 3D model, the doctors identified that there was bone loss of nearly 20% in Mali’s socket and another 10% bone loss in the ball of the shoulder.

“We then decided bone transfer surgery through which we took another bone (coracoid bone) from the same shoulder and transferred it to the defective socket. We also saw everything through arthroscopy right from the beginning of the surgery,” said Chovatiya, who performed the main surgery with the support of Dr Smit Shah and Dr Rakesh Srivastava.

In private hospitals, such a surgery costs anywhere around Rs 2 lakh whereas at Gotri Mali had to spend less than Rs 10,000.

Title: Math & English top doubts chart ahead of board exams
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

BHOPAL: With boards just a month away, students are seeking the help of counsellors to sort out exam stress related issues.

Since January 1, students from across the state made over 7,000 calls on the Madhya Pradesh Board of Secondary Education (MPBSE) helplines. Students asking subject-specific questions are put in touch with experts. Most of the doubts related to Math and English, said the counsellors.

“Children are facing lots of problems in Math and English. Students are also calling to clear doubts in Physics and Chemistry . Students from arts are seeking tips and techniques to memorize the topics,” said director MPBSE, Hemant Sharma .

“This is the time when students mostly ask about particular subjects, deal with stress and are unable to focus. Many students face problems in retaining what they have studied. For this, the counsellors advise them to take a 10-15 minute break after each hour of studying, to let the mind relax and be fresh for a new sitting.”

Now that only a month is left for the exams, it is advisable for students to thoroughly revise everything they have already studied, and not to take up a new topic.

“This is the time to solve previous years’ question papers, sample papers to gain more confidence, and solve the questions in allotted time. Solving papers is a good way to manage time and speed, and length of answers according to the allotted marks,” added Sharma.

Students are also calling up to ask the counsellors about their roll numbers and exam centres to avoid the last-minute hassle.

Title: Miscreants kill woman, escape with jewellery
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Vijayawada: Unidentified miscreants murdered a woman by slitting her throat and robbed gold ornaments from her home in Crombwe Road area under Bhavanipuram police station in the city on Friday evening. The deceased was identified as Yedupati Padmavathi (55).

According to Bhavanipuram police, the incident happened around 6pm when Padmavathi was at her home alone. Eyewitnesses informed the police that two persons were seen at her doorstep and entered her home the moment she opened the door.

The cops found traces of chilli powder on her eyes and a sharp cut on her throat. All the jewellery she wore was missing. Police said they were yet to ascertain the value of the jewels stolen.

Clues teams have reached the spot to collect forensic evidence and have dispatched teams to examine local CCTV footage to identify the miscreants. tnn

Title: State issues coronavirus alert to all ports, airports
Content: Vijayawada: The state government has issued an alert to all ports and airports in the state in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak in China. The state has also appointed nodal officers in every district to screen suspected patients for the virus.Health minister Alla Nani held a review meeting with the higher officials on Friday and directed them to be ready to deal with any positive cases that are found. He told officials to create quarantine zones in every hospital and to procure masks and other equipment needed.An alert was sounded at all ports and airports to scan all passengers arriving from foreign countries . Nodal officers will coordinate with various departments in virus screening. tnn

Title: Tamil Nadu: Man to spend life in jail for sodomising, killing boy
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

R Pradeep

Title: Woman robbed of gold chain; house burgled in Trichy
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: Police have launched separate investigations after cases of chain-snatching and a housebreak were reported from the city on Thursday. M Maria Michael, 55, of Lalgudi in the district was the latest to be relived of gold chain while she was returning home after attending a wedding.

The incident happened at 1.30 pm while she was walking to central bus stand to catch a bus home. As the woman walked by the Aristo roundabout, a couple of men on a two-wheeler approached her from the opposite side.

As they slowed down the two-wheeler, the pillion rider snatched 2.5 sovereigns of her gold chain sped away before she could react. However, the women the woman cried for help, but there was nobody to chase down the miscreants who had disappeared by then. The Cantonment police registered a case.

Elsewhere, an unidentified gang of miscreants broke into a locked house and made away with six sovereigns of gold and some silver ornaments. The burglary took place in the house belonging to P Kamal, 40, of Srinivasa Nagar in Trichy while he was on an outing with family.

On returning home on January 29, he found his house broken and ornaments missing. The police valued the stolen goods at Rs 65,000. Police said that the burglar gained entry into the house by breaking open the main door

Title: STENCHNAGARI’S GAS PROBLEM
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Vadodara: Lakhs of residents of northern and eastern parts of the city have been spending sleepless night as a strong stench wafts through these areas. The foul smell resembling to some gas caused irritation to many and even triggered panic among the locals in some areas.

This is the fourth time in as many yeas that these areas have reeled under ‘mysterious’ foul smell which has brought the role of chemical industries on the northern end of the city under the scanner.

The areas which were worst affected included Gorwa, Gotri, Nizampura, Chhani, Karelibaug and Harni.

Environment activist Rohit Prajapati said that the exact cause of this stench is still a mystery.

“It may be due to industrial pollution on the northern end of the city or due to discharge of effluents in storm water drains. The GPCB has to do systematic monitoring of air quality round the year but it doesn’t do it and hence we aren’t able to find the exact cause of the foul smell,” Prajapati told TOI.

The stench became stronger by late evening in Gorwa and soon spread to other areas. These six areas combined have a population of nearly three lakh.

Chandrahash Desai, a resident of Chhani, said, The stench was so intense and we faced bit difficulty in breathing even inside our home. I have been staying here for last 40 years, but the smell and pollution seems to have gone up over last few years.

Ami Ravat, who also runs an NGO working for environment, added, “The stench has now become a regular phenomenon during winters. Environmental experts say that this gas is harmful for pregnant women, children and senior citizens.”

Ravat has written a letter to GPCB, municipal commissioner and district collector, demanding full investigation in the nagging issue.

Prajapati’s team is also monitoring the air in these areas for some days and try to find out the exact cause. The stench problem mostly aggravates during winters due to wind direction and the air getting heavier.

GPCB regional director, R B Trivedi, “It is yet to be seen if the stench was due to some fault in any industries’ system or it is a regular phenomenon. We will monitor both Nandesari GIDC and the petrochemical complex areas.”

“We have started monitoring air quality from Thursday night using equipment to find out the component of the gas along with the source. We have also asked some industries to submit reports of the air quality in their premises,” he added.

Title: Postpone marriages, other social functions to prevent coronavirus outbreak: Kerala health minister
Content:
Kerala health minister KK Shailaja

THRISSUR: A day after a female student who had returned from Wuhan tested positive for novel coronavirus (nCoV), health minister KK Shailaja asked families of those who have returned from China and other coronavirus-hit regions and currently under home quarantine to postpone marriages and other social functions to prevent possible outbreak of the disease.“Relatives of those under home quarantine after returning from China and other coronavirus-affected countries must postpone marriages and other social functions in their families for a period of 28 days. Those family members who had direct contact with the returnees must also remain in their homes for the period,” said the minister.“The health department officials will provide all assistance to these people in their homes,” said the minister.A high-level meeting was convened by the health minister at Thrissur collectorate on Friday to review the situation.The health department shifted the girl from General Hospital to Thrissur Medical College Hospital on Friday morning.On Friday morning, the minister called a meeting of private hospital authorities and IMA members and then another high-level all department meeting at collectorate.Isolation wards have been set up in major private hospitals and all facilities are in place, said the minister.“Training will be provided to all department heads to manage the situation. None should spread panic. A control room has already opened for monitoring the special situation in the district,” she said.“The private hospitals should inform the health department if any person comes to their hospitals with symptoms of nCoV infection,” she said.“The government has already arranged facilities to screening the people coming from nCoV-affected countries at international airports,” said Shailaja.A total of 125 people are under observation in Thrissur district and 15 have been admitted in isolation wards, 12 in medical college and 3 in general hospital. A total of 110 people continue to be in home quarantine, said Shailaja later during a news conference.2 classmates of student with nCoV in isolation wardAlappuzha: Alappuzha Medical College Hospital sources have said that two persons had been admitted to the isolation ward of the hospital. “The admitted students were classmates of the student, who tested positive for nCoV in Thrissur,” sources said.“Their body fluid samples have been sent to National Institute of Virology (NIV), Pune and we hope that the results will be received soon. Their condition is stable, ” said an official from the MCH.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: YSRC, TDP head for capital showdown
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

YS Jaganmohan Reddy

AMARAVATI: The setting up of select committee to look into the bills regarding three capital cities and CRDA repeal is heading towards another showdown between YSRC and TDP as the process is yet to begin.

Sources said that senior officials at legislative council have not sent any official communication to whips of political parties seeking names to constitute the panel.

Legislative council chairman M A Shariff had announced the bills would be referred to a select committee on January 22. He had used discretionary powers under Rule 154 despite knowing that the case did not merit such a call. Subsequently, the chairman asked legislature secretary to send letters to whips of TDP, YSRC and PDF to suggest names for the panel.

A week later, the committee is yet to be formed. Sources said the council secretariat officials are revisiting rules on the procedure. It is not clear whether the officials could say no to chairman’s directive.

Sources said the senior officials were in a tight spot after YSRC raised objection about the formation of the select committee.

The leader of the council and deputy CM Pilli Subhash Chandra Bose wrote to assembly secretary asking him not to initiate any action on the chairman’s decision as it was against the rules. “The chairman has no powers to refer the bills to the select committee by using his discretionary powers. The select committee could not be constituted till the House is reconvened and voting is taken on the issue,” Bose said.

He said the chairman had not put the issue of referring the bills to the select committee for voting irrespective of the fact as to who had the majority. Bose said the chairman announced his decision under pressure from Chandrababu Naidu and left the House. “Can the chairman dissolve the House by using his discretionary powers? Rule 154 has its own limitations and it can’t be used in this case,” said Bose.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Etawah jeweller fakes murder bid to frame neighbour
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

KANPUR: In a bizarre incident, an Etawah jeweller faked a murderous attack on him with the help of his driver and a friend to frame his neighbour in a false case. He asked his friend to shoot him.

The police have arrested the jeweller and his two accomplices.

The jeweller wanted to frame his neighbour to teach him a lesson as his neighbour had lodged a molestation case against his father in November 2019.

According to reports, the jeweller Ketan Soni, was reportedly found with bullet injuries in Bakewar area on January 22. An FIR was registered against unknown persons in this connection.

SSP Akash Tomar, said, “Ketan wanted to teach a lesson to his neighbour who had booked a case of molestation against his father in November 2019 and planned a fake attack with the help of his driver Navin Katheria and friend Kapil alias Akash. “He asked Akash to shoot him,” he said. His plan was revealed after the police verifications with the help of e-surveillance.

“A case has been filed against the three accused and they have been sent to jail,” said the official.

Title: Rayalaseema leaders mull statehood for region
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Vijayawada: It looks like trouble is brewing for chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy in his home turf – Rayalaseema region. A section of leaders from the region are holding consultations to launch a separate statehood agitation. A sub-regional party is also being considered to take forward the demand.

Though Jaganmohan Reddy had promised to shift the high court and other legal bodies of the state government, including the department of law from the secretariat to Kurnool in the region, these leaders are not happy with it. “The crux of our demands is to give more funds to the region and focus on the irrigation projects,” said M Purushotham Reddy, convener of the Rayalaseema Intellectuals Forum.

A preliminary meeting of senior leaders from the dominant Kotla, Gangula and KE families of the region had felt the need to start the movement, along the lines of Telangana Rashtra Samiti (TRS). These families from the region, who represent Congress and TDP, are now trying to start the movement, even if the high court becomes a reality for the region. Former minister and senior leader from the region, M V Mysoora Reddy, took the initiative, in holding this preliminary meeting of the leaders.

It was decided to start a regional party for Rayalaseema and the process is likely to be completed in the next six months. The leaders have decided to meet in the next two weeks with the draft proposal to move forward, raising the demand for separate Rayalaseema state.

The leaders have felt that there is a political vacuum in the region, though the former chief minister and the present chief minister are from this region. “The former chief minister and the present chief minister are locked in a battle over Amaravati and not raising the issue of Rayalaseema,” a senior leader who was part of the meeting said.

“The chief minister talks about the Sri Bagh Pact and had promised us the high court. But there is ambiguity in the decentralisation Bill,” Purushotham Reddy said.

The chief minister had promised that all legal bodies, including the commissions for SCs, STs, BCs, minorities and women would be located in Kurnool along with the high court. The legal and quasi-judicial bodies of the state government too would be headquartered in Kurnool. All the judicial commissions of the government would also be moved to Kurnool.

“We are asking for our due share in development. That does not mean we are against Amaravati,” Purushotham Reddy told TOI.

Title: Watch Kathakali with Hindi, Eng commentary
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Guru Raju N from Bangalore performed Kuchipudi dance on the inaugural day of Pratibhotsavam a two day All Indi... Read More

Nagpur: The beauty of painted faces and amazing postures in performing Kathakali dance takes everyone’s breath away, but what goes behind to put this act together is the script and story selected from mythology.

People, especially non-Malayalis, often fail to understand the essence of these stories since it is narrated in Malayalam. Now, here is an opportunity for all Kathakali lovers to understand the story as the songs will be accompanied by Hindi and English commentary.

Kathakali dance drama ‘Narakasuravadham (the death of Narakasura)’ will be performed at 7pm on Sunday as part of the ongoing three-day All-India Classical Dance Competition and Festival being held at Sai Sabhagruh.

Janardhanan Nair of Pratibha Natya Mandir believes the commentary will attract all dance lovers. “The narration is always in Malayalam. As Nagpur is a multi-lingual city, we wanted people to understand the storyline so that they could enjoy the performance to the fullest,” he said.

Manish Nair, who will be doing the commentary, said,“Kathakali reflects Malayalam culture. Hence, we decided to use Hindi and English to make the performance more people friendly. The story of Narakasura will sure be liked by Kathakali lovers,” he said.

The act will be performed by Kalamamdalam Adthiyan and troupe from Kerala. The story of Narakasuravadham revolves around demon king Narakasura who deputes Nakrathundi to capture damsels from heaven. The demoness travels to heaven, nabs a few and starts her return journey.

“On her way, Nakrathundi meets young and handsome Jayantha, son of Indra. Attracted to him, the demoness approaches Jayantha in the guise of beautiful Lalitha. She reveals her longing for Jayantha, but he turns down her proposal for marriage,” said Manish, explaining the story.

A disappointed Lalitha then turns into ferocious Nakrathundi and tries to abduct Jayantha. In the tussle that follows, Jayantha mutilates Nakrathundi by cutting off her ears, nose and breasts. The rest of the story is about the revenge of Narakasura who defeats Indra, but is later killed by Lord Krishna.

“The performers are on their way to present their art in all its glory. However, the songs will be in Malayali,” said Rajan Nambiar, president of NSS.

Diwali sybolizes the victory of Lord Krishna over Narkasura--good over evil.

Title: MPs, MLAs to discuss water scheme
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Aurangabad: MPs , MLAs and ZP presidents from the region cutting across party lines, as well as experts, will meet in the city on February 4 to discuss the water grid project and demand that the government continue it, said Gangapur MLA Prashant Bumb of BJP on Friday.

The announcement comes a day after deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar expressed doubts over the feasibility of the water grid project.

Bumb said that public representatives from Marathwada will try to convince the government to continue the project. “This is the fourth such meeting of region’s public representatives in the last 10 years. If the demand is valid, the government will listen to us,” he told reporters.

Bumb said the current state government is sensitive towards implementing measures to pull Marathwada out of backwardness.

Bumb said the acute water shortage, lack of industry, unemployment, poor education standards, lack of good roads, inadequate health machinery and irregular electricity supply continues to keep Marathwada in a poor condition.

“Even today, women in rural areas of the region have to travel 2 to 3km to get drinking water. Water availability would also allow industrial settlements in every district, ” the BJP MLA said.

Title: GMCH conducts first laparoscopic hernia repair
Content:
Team of surgeons who carried out the procedure at GMCH

Mesh installed into the abdomen

AURANGABAD: The department of general surgery at the Government Medical College and Hospital ( GMCH ) performed its first laparoscopic umbilical hernioplasty surgery on a 35-year-old man on Wednesday. The patient was discharged on Friday and did not suffer from any post-operative complication.Doctors at the GMCH said that the patient was diagnosed with umbilical hernia. Following diagnosis, it was observed that the case would require surgery.According to head of department of surgery at GMCH Suresh Harbade, umbilical hernia occurs at the time of the birth when the foetus is separated from the umbilicus. “The opening of umbilicus should close soon after birth but, in some cases, the opening stays, causing a bulge in the abdomen. This causes pain and, at times, strangulation of small intestine in some cases,” Harbade said. This defect requires a surgery in 0.5 to 1% of individuals due to the severity.Earlier, due to the lack of technology, umbilical hernia was treated by conducting an open surgery that required 5-6 centimetre long incision. However, the GMCH surgeons recently attended medical conferences at Odisha, Amrawati and at Aurangabad and acquired the skill for conducting laparoscopic umbilical hernioplasty surgery. The hospital also recently procured kits required for conducting the surgery under Mahatma Jyotiba Phule Jan Arogya Yojana.Subsequently, on Wednesday, a procedure was performed under the guidance of S.P Jadhav by surgeons Suresh Harbade, Junaid Athar and assisted by Vakil Khan, Kapil Dev Patil, Harsh Mehta and Shailesh Patil. Two incisions of 5 mm were made on the abdomen of the patient and the defect was repaired by installing a mesh into the abdomen.The doctors at the hospital said that the surgery was conducted for the first time in GMCH and was successful.

Title: Mumbai: Both FASTag & ETC charged at Sea Link, e-way toll booths
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: Motorists Atul Khatau and Joaquim Reis were in for a shock when the toll booth at the Bandra-Worli Sea Link deducted the toll amount twice at one go—through both their new FASTag stickers and old ETC tags fixed on cars.

Though the amount was refunded later, hundreds of motorists with both old and new tags have been facing the problem, admit officials. Toll booth staffers have therefore advised motorists to not put up FASTag on window screens till the ETC tag is fully exhausted.

Complaint log books at the sea link plaza are filled with refund requests, said Khatau’s father Harsh.

On Mumbai-Pune Expressway , too, motorists have been facing similar issues. Pune’s Prashant Patil was charged twice last week.

A senior MSRDC official said complaints of double deduction are being resolved by not charging motorists on their return or next journey. MSRDC joint managing director Vijay Waghmare said till two days ago, there were 76 complaints out of 4,000 transactions on the sea link and the process was on to refund the wrongly deducted amount on return journey in genuine cases. “All ETC passes will expire in February and then on only FASTags must be bought and used. We hope to resolve the matter soon. Also, double deduction complaints on the E-way have reduced as the system is getting synchronised well now,” he said.

Rajiv Singh, chief general manager, NHAI, Mumbai Circle, said complaints at NHAI booths are being resolved through a helpline on ‘myfastag’ app. “People who have bought FASTag through any of the 24 banks can register complaints on the respective websites as well as on Indian Highways Management Company Ltd website or helpline (1033), NHAI’s own endeavour.”

Title: HC summons Anuppur collector
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Bhopal: A single-judge bench of MP high court has ordered Anuppur collector Chandramohan Thakur to be personally present in court in connection with a contempt petition for non-compliance of a court order by which it had stayed transfer of the petitioner.

The court took strong exception to collector writing in his note-sheet that the court has stayed transfer of the petitioner without examining the transfer order.

The bench of Justice Sanjay Dwivedi while asking for personal presence of the district collector said “From the document Annexure-C/4, the note-sheet written by the respondent/collector, it is a clear case of contempt.Collector Anuppur is directed to remain present before this Court on February 4, 2020.”

Counsel for the petitioner, P N Chaturvedi, told the court that despite the interim stay granted by the high court over his transfer from Anuppur to Gwalior, the collector and other officials concerned didn’t allow him to join at Anuppur again. Besides, a fresh transfer was issued on December 6, 20`19, thereby, transferring the petitioner to Badwani in place of Gwalior. The operation of modified transfer order was also stayed by the court.

Title: Schedule of KBA annual general polls notified
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Kanpur: The elders' committee on Friday notified the forthcoming annual general election of Kanpur Bar Association ( KBA ) according to the provision of Rule 54 of model bylaws framed by the UP Bar Council.

The meeting, held under the chairmanship of Satyendra Kumar Nigam, took the unanimous decision of notifying the election, said special assistant to the elders' committee, Sushil Kumar Verma.

As per the notification, the election schedule is: February 10-Publication of the proposed voters list, February 13-filing objections by 5 pm, February 14-disposal of objections, February 15-publication of the final voters list, February 17 and 18-filing of nominations, February 20- scrutiny of nominations, February 24-withdrawal of names and publication of the final list of the contestants, March 3-voting and March 4-counting of votes.

Condolence: The bench and bar at a joint meeting held here on Friday condoled the death of senior lawyer Surendra Pratap Singh at Kanpur Bar Association hall. District judge Ashok Kumar and several former presidents, general secretaries of Kanpur Bar Association and advocates were present at the condolence meeting.

Title: Gadchiroli officer secures second position in debate on human rights
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Sub-inspector Swapnil Gopale of Maoist-affected Gadchiroli district has been awarded with the second position ... Read More

NAGPUR: Sub-inspector Swapnil Gopale of Maoist-affected Gadchiroli district has been awarded with the second position in the Marathi section in the debate competition based on human rights and its awareness. Gopale was handed over the award by director general of police (DGP) Subodh Jaiswal on Saturday.

The state-level debate competition was organized by the department of protection of civil rights (PCR) at the DGP office on the issues of human rights. Gopale, who had won the district level competition representing Naxal range, comprising Gadchiroli and Gondia, was a direct entry in the state-level debate.

Speaking on the topic whether social traditions are protectors or exploiters of human rights, Gopale decided to criticise the existing systems which have led to hardships for several oppressed sections and also the marginalized. Having put his visions and opinions strongly, Gopale was chosen as the runner-up in the debate.

Apart from DGP Jaiswal, special inspector general of police, Kaiser Khalid, of PCR, too, was present.

Gopale has given the credit of his success to SP of Gadchiroli, Shailesh Balkawade , and his other colleagues.

Title: Kanpur: 10-year imprisonment to man for minor’s abduction, rape
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

Title: 100% voting in Ytl MLC bypoll, counting on Feb 4
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Voters line up to exercise their franchise in the MLC bypoll on Friday

Yavatmal: Fate of all six candidates vying for the MLC seat from local self-government bodies was sealed in the ballot boxes on Friday even as the bypoll recorded 100% voting. Counting of votes will take place at the district collectorate on February 4.

The bypoll was necessitated as Shiv Sena’s Tanaji Sawant resigned after being elected to the legislative assembly. The new incumbent will have a tenure till December 5, 2022.

The main contest is expected between BJP’s Sumit Bajoria and Maha Vikas Aghadi’s Dushyant Chaturvedi (Shiv Sena).

All 489 voters, including members of zilla parishad, municipal corporation, municipal councils and chairpersons of 16 panchayat samitis, exercised their franchise at seven polling stations set up across the district.

The bypoll is also considered a prestige issue for forest minister Sanjay Rathod (Sena) and sitting BJP MLA Madan Yerawar.

Earlier, a few independents had formed a local front and declared support to Sanjay Derkar of Wani. Later, one of the independents Shreekant Munginwar, a rebel Shiv Sena leader, extended support to the MVA candidate.

Title: ‘Study approach of Mahatma Gandhi to stop discrimination’
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Jagtik Ahinsa Din Ayojan Samiti and Swayam Samajik Sanstha are organizing a lecture by senior journalist Sures... Read More

Nagpur: History is being repeated as discriminatory laws devised 100 years ago are brought back into force to discriminate against citizens on the basis of their religion. In order to stop this, one needs to closely study Mahatma Gandhi ’s approach to such situations, said senior journalist and thinker Suresh Dwadashiwar at Sanskrutik Sankul, Vidarbha Sahitya Sangh, on Thursday.

He was delivering a lecture on ‘Gandhi’s thinking needed for social cohesion’. The event was organized by Jagtik Ahinsa Din Aayojan Samiti and Swayam NGO to pay homage to Mahatma Gandhi on his death anniversary.

Dwadashiwar said, “In all of the world’s history, there has been only one personality to respect every religion equally and distinctively while advocating unity in the name of humanity. And that was Gandhi. His ideology can be learnt through his way of life and the journey he traversed in the freedom struggle.”

He noted, “Whenever Gandhi was asked about his religion, he would claim that he is a Sanatani Hindu. Sanatani means eternal. He saw all religions as equal and accepted all the beliefs impartially. At the core, he believed in truth and humanity and spent his life guiding the path of non-violence.”

Turning the pages of history, Dwadashiwar revealed lesser known facts about Gandhi’s conduct during revolutionary movements. Delving into the origin of Hindu, Buddha, Islam and Christianity religions, he said, “There have been wars on the basis of religion and sub-groups which lasted for years together.”

“There has been a significant difference among those who advocate a religion and those who lost lives in the name of religion in these wars,” he added.

“Gandhi was not someone who just preached lessons. He was the one to rise to the moment to face any obstacle that followed. It is this country’s honour that a personality like Gandhi was born in this land.”

Present at the programme were former MP Vilas Muttemwar, MLA Vikas Thakre, Girish Gandhi and Baban Taywade.

Muttemwar said, “Gandhi’s thoughts are not orthodox. His notions are relevant today considering the discriminatory situation prevalent in the country. Everyone should take a pledge to emulate Gandhi’s ideology.”

Swayam NGO president Vishal Muttemwar, who anchored the programme, said, “The young generation must perceive Gandhi’s ideas and understand the current divisive game plan.”

Title: After 5 years, MPPCB set to get full-time chairperson
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Bhopal: The Madhya Pradesh Pollution Control Board (MPPCB) is set to get its full-time chairperson after a gap of five years. A committee, headed by the chief secretary, interviewed five shortlisted candidates earlier this week. The names have been forwarded to the chief minister’s office and the chairperson’s name is expected to get finalised any day.

In all, 29 environmental experts were in the fray for the MPPCB chairperson’s post. The scrutiny committee, comprising officials of the environment department, Environmental Planning & Coordination Organisation (EPCO) and designates, shortlisted five candidates and their interviews were conducted by the committee.

“A state government official meeting criterion for the post may be appointed as the chairperson,” said a official who was a part of the selection process.

In September last year, the state government had framed guidelines for appointment of the MPPCB’s chairperson — almost three decades after it came into existence.

MPPCB has been running without a full-time chairperson for the last five years. In case there is no full-time chairperson, the principal secretary, environment, is the ex-officio chairperson of MPPCB. The state government had to frame the appointment rules following directives of the National Green Tribunal (NGT).

Title: Two killed, one seriously injured in road accident
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Two men were killed and one sustained severe injuries in a road accident at Nelavayi on Chittoor-Puttur highway in SR Puram mandal of Chittoor district late on Thursday night. The deceased were identified as Rambabu (28) and Ajith Kumar (27), both from Puttur mandal.

According to sources, they were travelling on a motorbike when a truck hit the bike from behind. Rambabu died while being shifted to hospital and Ajith Kumar died while undergoing treatment.

Title: Lack of equipment affecting patients
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Aurangabad: Lack of equipment at the government medical college and hospital (GMCH) and government cancer hospital is affecting the treatment offered to patients.

The procurement of equipment worth Rs 36 crore from last financial year (2018-19) has not yet been completed. The GMCH authorities gave a presentation regarding the equipment procurement to district guardian minister Subhash Desai on Thursday.

In 2017-2018, funds worth Rs 53.83 crore were approved and received for GMCH and GCH but equipment worth Rs 29.18 crore was received. In 2018-2019, Rs 36.30 crore were provided for the two hospitals but not a single equipment has been received.

GMCH acting dean Kailash Zine said equipments such as ventilators and department specific instruments crucial for diagnosis and treatment are awaited.

The GMCH’s paediatric department has only four ventilators. The doctors have to use the ventilators based on the severity of the case and other patients needing ventilator support are kept on manually-operated ambu-bags.

“The directorate of medical education and research, under which, the institution runs has been informed about the delay in procurement,” Zine said.

3-tesla MRI machine to be operational in March

The installation process of 3-tesla magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) machine procured in 2019 is underway at GMCH. Zine said the machine requires specific type of civil work for its installation and it will be operational by March.

Title: Patna: Students clash with anti-CAA protesters during Saraswati idol immersion
Content:
Vehicles in flames after clashes between two groups during an immersion procession of goddess Saraswati at Ash... Read More

Additional police forces were deployed in the area to bring the situation under control

PATNA: At least two cars were torched and several other vehicles damaged as a group of students participating in Saraswati idol immersion procession clashed with anti-CAA/NRC protesters at Lalbagh on Ashok Rajpath under the Pirbahore police station area in the city around 8.40pm on Friday.A police sub-inspector (SI), Manoj Singh, sustained splinter injuries in crude bomb explosion during the clash. He was immediately rushed to Patna Medical College and Hospital for treatment.The two groups also pelted stones targeting each other. Additional police forces were deployed in the area to bring the situation under control. The administration made announcements urging locals to stay indoors.Naveen Kumar, a local student, told TOI that he was returning from an immersion procession when the trouble started. “Students from nearby colleges entering Krishna Ghat lane from Ashok Rajpath for idol immersion raised pro-CAA/NRC slogans. Those protesting against the CAA/NRC objected to it,” he said, adding the issue snowballed soon into violence. “Loud explosions were heard during the clash as the students hurled bombs,” he said.Iqbal Ahmed, owner of one of the torched cars, said he was returning after offering ‘namaz’ when the incident occurred.ADM (law and order) K K Singh said the situation in the area was tense but under control. “We are trying to identify those involved in the clash,” he added.In Video: Patna: Clash during Saraswati idol immersion, situation under control

Title: Bihar: Former MLA gets life term in rape case after 25 years
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

Title: Patna: Two youths dump friend’s body at hospital, disappear
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: In a bizarre incident, two youths visited at least three private hospitals in the city – first on a bike and then in an ambulance – carrying one of their friends who had received gunshot injury, in a failed attempt to admit him there. They, however, left their friend, Alok Ranjan (21), in the ambulance on reaching the campus of a private hospital at Kankarbagh after realising that he was dead.

The ambulance driver, Lallan Kumar, then took the body to Patliputra police station on the intervening night of Thursday and Friday. The dead youth was a resident of Gola Road under the Danapur police station area. He was preparing for engineering examinations. Alok’s father Ashok Kumar is an LIC agent.

SHO of Patliputra police station Kamleshwar Prasad Singh said efforts were on to locate the two youths – Himanshu Kumar and Abhishek Kumar – who had left Alok’s body at the Kankarbagh hospital. “The duo first reached a private hospital near Patliputra roundabout in a bike along with Alok. They later hired an ambulance and visited two more private hospitals. Finally, the two disappeared after doctors at Kankarbagh hospital declared Alok brought dead,” the SHO said.

He added that the bike used by the two youths was seized from road number 6 of Indrapuri. “The victim’s father has told police that the bullet hit his son accidentally while he was playing with a pistol along with his friends,” the SHO said, adding it was still not clear how the youths got the pistol.

Title: Hold anti-CAA protest, activist urges public
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Vijayawada: Social activist Swamy Agnivesh on Friday said urged people to protest against the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ) and the proposal to implement National Register of Citizens ( NRC ) and National Population Register ( NPR ).

The Alliance Against NRC, CAA and NPR organised a public meeting at Makineni Basava Punnaiah Stadium here on Friday.

The meeting was attended by Dr Rajaratnam Prakash Ambedkar, the grandson of Dr B R Ambedkar, Jamia Islami Hind state president Md Raffiq, former JNU student Umar Khalid and others.

Agnivesh said BJP and RSS were promoting violence to bring in a fascist regime in the country. He said the Jamia Milia incident was an example of how the BJP was instigating violence and added that the party was trying to split society along caste and religious lines.

Dr Prakash Ambedkar said the protests against CAA will not stop till it was rolled back. He said the BJP was trying to cancel reservations for Dalits. He appealed to people to rise above caste and religion to oppose the CAA and said that they would build more Shaheen Baghs across the country.

Title: Coronavirus in Hyderabad: Four new suspected Coronavirus cases in Hyderabad, government says no need to panic
Content:
Doctors at Gandhi hospital using the testing kit that arrived from Delhi on Friday

HYDERABAD: As four more persons with symptoms of Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV) were admitted to state-run Fever Hospital on Friday, the health authorities urged people to avoid crowded places. “People should not panic about Coronavirus, but be careful and avoid crowded places as a precaution,” read a statement issued by the health department.In a huge relief for authorities, the much-awaited testing kits arrived from Delhi and the state government said they would begin testing samples within 48 hours in Hyderabad. The samples of the four persons, including a woman, were sent to National Institute of Virology (NIV) Pune, along with two more samples for tests.These four persons are between 25 years and 40 years of age and travelled to China in the last fortnight. “With new suspected cases reported on Friday, we have a total of 15 suspected cases, of which nine have been tested negative. The report of six other samples are awaited from NIV Pune,” said Vijay Kumar, state nodal officer.Officials at Gandhi Medical College, where testing for Novel Coronavirus will begin, said that sufficient number of kits have arrived in the first batch. “Once the tests are done here, they will be sent to NIV Pune to check that the tests have been done correctly. After getting a go-ahead from NIV, all tests will be done locally,” said an official.Experts suggest maintaining high level of personal hygiene, exercise and self-isolation for 14 days in case people, who had travelled to China, witness symptoms. “Please do not send children to school if they feel sick. If a child has fever of 100F or above, he/she should rest at home until the fever is gone. If you have any health concerns, please consult with your physician or health care provider,” said Dr KK Agarwal, president of Confederation of Medical Association of Asia and Oceania (CMAAO), Heart Care Foundation of India (HCFI) and past national president of Indian Medical Association (IMA).

Title: Maharashtra: Longer wait this year for good supply of Alphonso
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

By March, markets receive mangoes in good quantities (File photo)

PUNE: Mango lovers will have to wait for nearly one-and-a-half months more this year for their favourite Alphonso to reach the markets in good quantities.

A horticulture department estimate revealed Ratnagiri was likely to produce around 1,30,000 tonnes of the fruit this March-April as against 1,53,000 tonnes during the same period last year. The dip in supplies during the initial period of the mango season has been caused by a delay in the flowering process due to last year’s extended rainy season.

Unlike in the past, mangoes are not expected to flood the markets this March and growers said there would be almost an 80% shortage of the fruit during the month because of the delay in flowering in the Ratnagiri-Sindhudurg mango belt. Mangoes usually start reaching the markets after mid-February. By March, the markets receive mangoes in good quantities.

Vidyadhar Joshi, director of Devgad Taluka Mango Growers’ Association, told TOI that not even 10% flowering of mango trees has so far started in Konkan — right from Raigad to Vengurla. “Konkan recorded heavy and prolonged rain last year. The extended rainy season stopped the flowering stage in mango trees and caused a vegetative flush. The flowering started only recently and the rate is slow. The flowering process is expected to continue during almost the entire February and March,” he said.

Mango fruits begin to develop only after the flowers are pollinated. “This means that there will be almost 80-90% shortage in mango supplies during February end and March in comparison to what these months normally get. Supplies will be almost 50% less than normal in April too, while a glut will hit the markets in May,” Joshi said.

Vivek Bhide, president of the Konkan Mango Growers and Sellers’ Association, said, “This seems to be the first time in many years that the arrival of mangoes in normal quantities into the markets may be delayed so much. The result will be 70-80% less supplies in March. Three conditions are needed during end of October to November 10 for mango flowering— ‘waaphasa' (mixture of 50 % air and 50 % water vapour in the cavities between two soil particles), night temperatures below 20ºC and appropriate wind flow. These conditions have to occur simultaneously. This did not happen in 2019 October-November.”

Mandar Desai, an Alphonso grower in Ratnagiri, said, “In comparison to last year, we may see a 70% shortage of the fruit in March this year. Usual mango stocks may start trickling in after April 20. People may face a shortage of mangoes during the two major festivals — Gudi Padwa (March 25) and Akshaya Tritiya (April 26) — when the demand for the fruit is high in Maharashtra .”

S K Godse, a retired professor of Balasaheb Sawant Konkan Krishi Vidyapeeth, said, “For the mango trees to flower, constant cold temperatures are needed for 10-15 days. This has not happened since November-December last year.”

Title: Our achievements are really a disadvantage
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

For Kerala, the Union Budget for FY21 is a dampener – glaringly, it didn’t get any notable project that is of specific benefit to the state or its people. However, there is a more disturbing aspect that is going to undermine the state’s own capital and revenue expenditures that fund developmental activities as well as usual administrative works and it is the decline of Kerala’s share of the tax revenue from the central government from Rs 17,872 crore in FY20 to Rs 15,236 crore in FY21.

A cocktail of reasons is behind Kerala’s dwindling tax share from the Union government – political as well as Finance Commission’s Terms of Reference (ToR) change and also Kerala’s achievement in social sector reforms.

Economists and policy wonks had only noticed this decline in Kerala’s share of ‘divisible pool’, the central government’s revenue from income tax and corporation tax, triggered by a change in the ToR used by the Finance Commission, an autonomous and constitutional body that works as an arbitrator between the Centre and states regarding sharing the revenue.

“The change in ToR has caused a decline in Kerala’s share of divisible pool,” said D Narayana, former director, Gulati Institute of Finance and Taxation. According to him, till the 12th Finance Commission, the share of each state was decided based on the population figures of 1971 and from the latest 14th Financial Commission, it is based on 2011 figures.

Between 1971 and 2011, the population of north Indian States like UP, Rajasthan, Bihar and Madhya Pradesh grew significantly while that of Kerala was almost stable. As the population share of northern states were high, they are getting more allocation. As a result, Kerala’s share of divisible pool came down from 2.5% last year to 1.93% this year.

According to K K Krishnakumar, fellow, Centre for Socio-Economic & Environmental Studies, Kochi, apart from the ToR change, there is another reason that is hurting the flow of resources from the Centre. “Kerala’s share of resources from almost all the flagship projects of the central government are relatively low compared to the northern states, because the state had already achieved considerable levels of development, especially in education and healthcare,” he said.

“Take the case of Samagra Shiksha, which funds opening new schools, where Kerala received only Rs 206 crore in FY19, instead of the original indicative allocation of Rs 413 crore. While Kerala’s actual allocation was only 49.84% of the indicative one, Tamil Nadu received 100%, Madhya Pradesh 103%, Odisha 105% and Bihar 106%,” Krishnakumar said.

“We have been penalised for our own advancement in social sector. We had been facing this issue since the 1990s,” he said.

Except for the employment guarantee programme MNREGS, Kerala’s share in all other flagship schemes like Samagra Shiksha, National Health Mission, PMGSY and Social Security Pension, is low, Krishnakumar said. High population density, land cost and environmental awareness are other factors that hinder allocation of flagship infrastructure projects in Kerala, he said. Bringing down the width of NHs from 60 metres to 45 is an example.

Title: YSRC MP visits dharna camps in protest area
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Amaravati: Making an attempt to broker peace with farmers in the capital city region, YSRC MP Lavu Srikrishnadevarayalu visited dharna camps in Mandadam and Velagapudi villages on Friday.

He said he would negotiate with chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy and said the CM is a pro-farmer leader. Krishnadevarayalu is the first YSRC leader to enter the protest zone and address the farmers.

Krishnadevarayaulu said that farmers should come out with their demands for an amicable solution with the government. “We know that your anger is genuine. We never found fault with your protests. The chief minister is more concerned about bailing out the farmers from any crisis, and not just in the capital city. He is a pro-farmer leader,” said the MP amidst Jai Amaravati slogans.

He cautioned the farmers not to fall in the trap of the vested interests that might drag the without resolving it. Farmers were raising their voice as agriculture land given for the capital were not earned through speculation, he said.

He said the state government was willing to resolve all issues of local land-owning farmers if they were ready to negotiate. He asked the farmers to get ready for talks. The CM would not go ahead on any issue if it meant a loss to farmers, the MP said and added the YSRC got 151 seats only due to support of all sections of society and the party would not ignore anyone. The process of rendering justice to farmers should begin soon, he said.

While local YSRC legislators V Sridevi (Tadikonda), Alla Ramakrishna Reddy (Mangalagiri) have kept themselves away from the farmers, local MP Galla Jayadev of TDP has been leading the protests from the front.

Title: Marathon for a cause on February 9
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The Pune chapter of the Prison Ministry India , a national voluntary organization, will hold a marathon run in the city on February 9 to raise funds for a rehab boarding at Kankavli in Sindhudurg district for the children of prison inmates.

The run, organised in association with running club blueBrigade, will be held in four categories — 3km walk, 5km run, 10km run and the half marathon. People can also sponsor underprivileged children wanting to participate in some of the runs.

Fr Wilfred Fernandes, state and central region coordinator, PMI, said the organisation serves 1,401 prisons across India.

Title: Pune: Cops recover five high-end bicycles from arrested duo
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A 20-year-old BPO employee and his cousin were caught on Wednesday while stealing a high-end bicycle in Karvenagar. The Alankar police , who apprehended them, have recovered five stolen bicycles worth Rs 75,000 from them.

The suspects, Mimoh alias Parva Rajkumar Soni and his cousin Himanshu Ramkumar Soni (23), both currently residing at Wadgaon Sheri but originally from Nagpur, have cases of theft registered against them by the Nagpur police.

Sub-inspector Suraj Gore from the Alankar police station told TOI that he received a tip-off that a bicycle thief had been spotted in Karvenagar area.

“During patrolling, our team, including police constables Rajendra Landge, Babulal Tanadale, caught the suspect and his cousin stealing a bicycle in Potnis Parisar area of Karvenagar. We also found a backpack containing cutters and other equipment to cut the locks of the bicycles,” Gore said. The duo would carry out a recce of societies. They would sell the bicycles at throwaway prices telling buyers they needed the money.

Title: Maharashtra: Census training to curtail summer break for teachers
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Government school teachers in the state will have fewer days of summer vacation this year. Their training for gathering census data will begin from June 1 and go on till June 15.

Schools close officially on May 1 for teachers, but post-exam and results’ work go on till May 15, and they reopen in the first week of June. Teachers can thus expect a mere 15-day break.

The Maharashtra Primary Teachers’ Samiti president Uday Shinde said the government was told to conduct the training before Diwali vacations.

“The last four months of the academic year have sports events, annual gatherings, science exhibitions and completion of the syllabus. Once the annual exams are over, teachers are into paper correction and results related work. The census training will ruin summer vacations for all teachers,” he added.

Bhau Chaskar, a teacher, said, “We had to face a similar situation during elections. We will have to sacrifice our summer vacation. Such trainings must be well-planned so that teachers are not burdened.”

Teachers’ associations said many teachers are involved in board exam related work during this period. The second phase of census work will be in October which again is examinations time.

Bhiwandi MLA Kapil Patil, who met director of Census Operations Rashmi Zagade on Thursday, demanded that teachers should be the last resource for census work.

“Teachers on deputation for census work should get 45 days of earned leave. It was approved and implemented during the last census,” he said.

Those above 55 years of age, pregnant woman, physically disabled, women whose children are below one year of age should be exempted from census work.

The Census department wants the Maharashtra government to provide 2.5 lakh teachers for the decennial headcount and collection of National Population Register (NPR) data across the state.

Census officials said the teachers would be helpful for the work once the formal notification was issued.

Title: Hawkers evicted from Shalimar and Dwarka junctions
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Nashik: The Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) and city police on Friday undertook a special anti-encroachment drive in several areas including, Shalimar , Nepali Corner, Dhumal Point, Raviwar Karanja and Dwarka .

Under the guidance of commissioner of police Vishwas Nangare-Patil, police personnel have been working on clearing congestion on city roads over the last few weeks.

The anti-encroachment drive was carried out following Nangare-Patil’s visit to the Dwarka junction where he inspected the flow of traffic. Subsequently, the municipal corporation, in association with the city police, conducted the drive to clear congestion on roads.

In the morning, ACP Pradeep Jadhav and senior PI of Bhadrakali police station Sajan Sonawane conducted a meeting with the hawkers at the Nepali corner and informed them about the anti-encroachment drive. Later in the day, the entire Nepali corner area was cleared of encroachments.

PI Sajan Sonawane said that encroachments from Dhumal Point to Raviwar Karanja were also removed as part of the drive.

The hawkers were given the option of relocating to the backside of the Regional Referral Hospital. However, many of them objected to the proposal.

Meanwhile, at Dwarka, some hawkers rushed to the nearby subway to secure a spot for conducting business. The police, however, said that it was upon the civic body to decide whether the hawkers can operate from the subway.

Title: Aurangabad: Smart city air quality monitors record distressing data
Content:
A screengrab of the air quality dashboard

Environmental sensors being installed in city

AURANGABAD: The air quality monitoring machines (environmental sensors) installed under the smart city project at two locations in the city have consistently shown poor air quality.Under the smart city project, the Aurangabad Smart City Development Corporation Ltd (ASCDCL) is establishing two command control centres. These centres would enable the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) and city police to monitor traffic movement, surveillance and delivery of civic services.Track the pollution level in your cityThe environmental sensors are part of various services to be integrated to these command control centres. The data from these sensors is displayed in real time on dashboards at these centres.Currently, the ASCDCL has installed the environmental sensors at Kranti Chowk and Mahanubhav Ashram and the real time air quality data is being accessed remotely through software integrated to these sensors.The software, based on various indicators, computes the air quality index (AQI). It also shows when the data breaches the national standards. Data for every two minutes since January 1 is accessible for both sensors.Based on the Central Pollution Control Board standards, the air quality index has been computed to poor quality (201 and 300) and very poor (301-400) at the two locations.Mahanubhav Ashram which is on Paithan Road sees heavy traffic in the evening and the AQI figure reaches around 500 which is termed as severe (401-500). At Kranti Chowk, the AQI turns poor during office hours.As part of the Smart city project, the real time air quality data will be soon put up on display at busy squares of the city to raise awareness about air quality.Aurangabad which is also a part of the National Clean Air Programme, is supposed to install digital boards to inform citizens about the air quality. Last year in November, Rs 12 lakh were released to the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) for implementation of the programme.

Title: RPF constable shoots self on moving train
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

An on-duty RPF constable from Uttar Pradesh shot himself in a moving train near Kadapa in Andhra Pradesh late on Thursday night.

According to railway police, RS Panwar, an RPF constable with Yerraguntla post under Guntakal division of South Central Railway zone, was found lifeless near the washrooms on train no. 11027, Mumbai CST to Chennai central, late on Thursday night.

Police sources said RS Panwar, along with another constable G Ravindra Reddy, were on escort duty on the train. The two were carrying two 9 mm pistols and 10 rounds of ammunition each.

Ravindra Reddy came across Panwar’s body near the washrooms, with one of the pistols in his hand when the train was ten minutes away from Nandalur railway station in Kadapa.

Ravindra Reddy alerted Yerraguntla and Kadapa posts and shifted the body onto platform no. 1 at Nandalur railway station with the help of some passengers.

Sources said the deceased constable, from Saharanpur in Uttar Pradesh, was troubled by family disputes.

A case was registered by railway police and the body shifted for autopsy.

Title: Police recover 5 stolen bikes from 19-yr-old thief
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Nashik: A 19-year-old youth has been arrested by Nashik Road police from Naitale village in Niphad taluka for stealing two-wheelers.

The police have recovered five stolen bikes worth Rs 1.42 lakh from the accused, identified as Ananda alias Akshay Devidas Mali.

“A motorbike parked near the statue of Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj on Nashik Road was stolen on Sunday at around 10am. A complaint in this regard was registered with us on Tuesday,” a police officer said.

“During investigation, senior police inspector Suraj Bijali got information that a history-sheeter was seen riding an identical motorbike in the Nashik Road area on Sunday,” he added.

Working on the information, a police team rushed to Naitale village and arrested Mali. During interrogation Mali confessed that he had stolen the motorbike from the Nashik Road area. He also confessed to have stolen four more bikes from city and rural parts of the district.

“Mali produced before a local court that remanded him in one-day police custody. Now he is in judicial custody,” the officer said.

Meanwhile, Satpur police also arrested three people for allegedly committing thefts in different parts of the city. The trio has confessed to have committed burglary in Satpur, Ambad, Dindori, and Ozar.

“We have recovered 55 gram of gold and 250 gram of silver jewellery, cash Rs 5,100 and two motorcycles — all worth Rs 3.60 lakh — from the suspects,” an officer attached with Satpur police station said.

Title: Four held for killing auto driver
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Four persons were arrested for killing an auto driver, Mohammed Azam , in Falaknuma on January 26. The accused are Mohammed Khaled, Mohammed Khaja Pasha, Mohammed Raheem and Mohammed Wajahat.

Azam was found dead with multiple stab injuries. Khaled had a fight with Azam over money and the former sustained injury on the head. Later, he hatched a plan to eliminate Azam.

Title: Students protest Telangana move to privatise 67 institutions
Content:
Students of AV College of Commerce and Arts boycott classes in protest over move to privatise the institution

HYDERABAD: Students of aided colleges across Telangana are up in arms against the collegiate education department’s decision to convert 67 institutions, running on government aid, into private institutions.The AV College of Commerce and Arts in Domalguda has emerged as the epicentre of the protests. Led by Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP), for five days now, protesting students have been demanding that the authorities’ roll back their decision.On Friday, hundreds of students gathered outside the main gate, as they unanimously boycotted classes. They said that the government’s decision to stop aid to 67 colleges, including AV College, promotes privatisation of education .“The government has transferred many faculty members to government colleges. It is unfair for many students as the fee structure for four courses has been enhanced from Rs 600 to Rs 22,500,” said Mahesh Kosgi, a student.Many students have also raised concerns on social media using the hashtag avcollegebachao (save AV College). Shiva Kumar, a student, tweeted, “Many years ago, AV College was established. It is aided college which is built by freedom fighters. Now it is going to convert into private college, fees will be increased and many poor students lose their education and bright future. Hence, please convert into government college (sic) #avcollegebachao.”As a mark of protest, hundreds of students from aided colleges across the state have also sent postcards to governor Tamilisai Soundararajan. Students are wearing black badges to their classes as well. There are many other aided colleges, such as Bhadruka College, Kasturba Gandhi College, Andhra Mahila Sabha College, where protests are likely to be intensified.Terming the protests as uncalled for, officials said that there was no change in the government’s decision. “The protests seem politically influenced, as there are barely two courses from a pool of 40-50 courses, which are aided. The college was converted into an unaided one during the last academic year itself and its status will remain unchanged,” said Navin Mittal, commissioner of Telangana collegiate education department, questioning the protests by students in the middle of the academic year.

Title: Doctors on alert as reports suggest novel coronavirus-conjunctivitis link
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The novel coronavirus may cause conjunctivitis too, besides flu-like and respiratory symptoms.The American Academy of Ophthalmology has issued an alert stating that there were anecdotal reports suggesting that the novel coronavirus can cause conjunctivitis and possibly be transmitted by aerosol contact with conjunctiva — the tissue lining the inside of the eyelids. Following the alert, the pan-India body of eye surgeons directed its members to keep a high index of suspicion while treating such patients.Eye surgeon S Natarajan, president of All India Ophthalmological Society, a national body of over 20,000 eye surgeons in India, said, “We have told eye surgeons to stay alert while treating patients with history of travelling to novel coronavirus-hit nations or coming in contact with people who have travelled to affected countries recently.”Eye surgeon Vardhaman Kankariya, secretary of Maharashtra Ophthalmological Society, said, “An eye surgeon should use protective N-95mask and specified goggles while examining such patients. All patients with conjunctivitis should not worry as the alert is only for patients who have travelled to China or come in contact with patients who have had such international trip.”Eye surgeon Aditya Kelkar, who heads the Pune-based National Institute of Ophthalmology, said, “The virus may enter the eyes when an infected patient touches them with his hands. The virus, thought to be spreading through sneezes and coughs, can also pass through the body to reach the eye, causing conjunctivitis. Hence, precautions are the way forward .”

Title: Mexican woman accuses bike taxi rider of harassment in Bengaluru
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

Title: CM Nath appeals to MEA for rescue of students from China
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Bhopal: Amid the spread of Coronavirus in China, Madhya Pradesh has taken up the issue with the Ministry of External Affairs (MEA) about students from the state being stranded in China.

Chief minister Kamal Nath said on Friday that the government has asked the MEA to immediately arrange for the safe return of the Indian students.

“Information has been received about three students of Khargone district of the state being trapped in China, and asking for help. We will request the Ministry of External Affairs (MEA) today to immediately arrange for the safe return of these students," tweeted Nath on Friday. An Air India flight was sent to Wuhan on Friday to bring back Indian students stuck in Hubei province, the epicentre of coronavirus.

The students, Shubham Gupta and Abdul Mateen Khan, in a video message released on Wednesday, had said that they had been confined to their rooms and risk of contracting the disease was so high that they covered their mouths throughout the day and spoke to each other on mobile phones, despite being in same hostel room. They had even contacted Indian embassy for their evacuation, they had said in the message.

Talking to TOI on Friday, Santosh Gupta, Shubham’s father said that his son informed him in the evening that he along with Abdul Mateen Khan were listed for evacuation back to India.

Gupta said that as flights had been started to evacuate Indians from coronavirus prone areas, Shubham and Mateen would hopefully be back in India within a day or two. "The citizens should not be worried about the infection of Coronavirus. The state government has already issued comprehensive guidelines for control and prevention from the virus. We have issued instructions to make special arrangements for this in all hospitals of the state,” stated the chief minister in a series of tweets.

Title: RSS chief in MP; hope he will will promote unity, says Cong
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Bhopal: Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS) chief Mohan Bhagwat reached here on Friday for his weeklong visit to the state. Bhagwat will take stock of the organisational activities during his visit, said sources.

Bhagwat’s visit has sparked a debate between BJP and Congress with the latter alleging that RSS was provoking youths in the name of Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA). The BJP has also hit out at Congress for “misguiding” people on CAA.

“RSS chief Mohan Bhagwat will be in the state. I welcome him. I also expect that during his visit, he will deliver the message of peace, unity and brotherhood,” said state higher education minister Jitu Patwari.

While the public relations minister PC Sharma said, “Bhagwatji will be in MP. I request him not to provoke youths during his stay in the state.” A day before, chief minister Kamal Nath had also welcomed RS chief to MP. “Bhagwatji is free to visit Bhopal anytime. We expect that he would give a right direction to the state and the country,” he had said on Thursday.

The chief minister also raised questions over the need of bringing CAA instead of focusing on economy and unemployment in the country. “What is the need for bringing CAA now, when the country is grappling with severe problems? Now they are roaming around to garner public support and misguiding people away from burning issues,” Nath had said.

BJP hit back at Congress.

“It is the Congress, who is spreading confusion and provoking people on CAA. MP chief minister will not decide what would be the next step of BJP and RSS on the CAA. The BJP and RSS do not require Kamal Nath’s certificate on any issue,” said BJP state president Rakesh Singh.

Sources said Bhagawat reached RSS regional headquarters Samidha in Bhopal on Friday afternoon and left for Guna after meeting some party cadres. On Saturday, he will inaugurate a three-day convention of college-going youths in Guna, which is being organised by the Sangh Parivar. The RSS chief will address 2,000 student volunteers in organisational activities. Senior RSS office-bearers, including Akhil Bharatiya Prachar Pramukh Arun Kumar will also participate in the camp.

Bhagwat’s three-day visit to Bhopal from February 4 assumes significance as in the political circles it is believed that he would discuss party’s public awareness campaign on CAA and the future plans to gain public support on ideological issues with BJP leaders. The BJP has also involved intellectuals and select social activists to hold discussions with the RSS chief during his stay. The BJP leaders are also preparing for a discussion over ideological issues during Bhagwat’s visit, said sources.

Title: Pune techie loses Rs 3.3 lakh in credit card cloning fraud
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Cybercrooks made online transactions of 3,372 pounds in London in the first week of January by cloning the credit card of a city-based software engineer, who’s currently in France with an office assignment.The fraud came to light when the techie received text messages on his phone about the transactions of Rs3.3 lakh from his credit card, police said.The techie contacted his wife in the city to inquire about the transactions because he had not taken the credit card with him.On Thursday, the techie’s wife approached the Wakad police and lodged an FIR against some unidentified persons.The techie, employed with a Talawade-based software company, stayed with his family in the Wakad area. Since December 7, 2019, he is in France with an assignment.“He contacted his wife on January 4 and asked her if she had made any purchase by using his credit card. The techie had left the credit card back home,” an officer from the Wakad police said.The officer added that when the complainant told her husband that she had not used his card, the techie told her that it was used for four times and transactions worth 3,372 pounds were made online.“He came to know about the transactions when the bank sent him messages about the transactions through his credit card,” the officer said.The techie contacted the bank and alerted them about the transactions. “The bank official told him that a one time password was not required for foreign transactions. The techie then told her wife to lodge an FIR,” the officer said.“Prima facie, it was a case of card cloning. The probe also revealed that the suspect had used the card at four spots in London providing bed and breakfast accommodation. Our investigation is on,” the officer said.

Title: Pune: Separate queue plan for flyers
Content:
File photo of Pune airport

PUNE: The airport authorities are considering separate queues for flyers arriving in the city from destinations, within the country and abroad, affected by the coronavirus Sources at the airport said they were on full alert after the first positive case was confirmed in Kerala as Pune has a direct flight to Kochi.“We have not received any specific instruction from top officials regarding screening of passengers at the airport. There is a possibility that passengers arriving from regions affected by the virus may be asked to form separate queues so that a team of doctors can check on them. Medical counters are being set up,” a source at the airport said.

Title: Aurangabad: Police register five more offences for child pornography
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: Almost 20 days after the Aurangabad city police registered three cases against unidentified suspects who used Facebook and other social media platforms to upload child pornography content, five more offences were registered under sections of Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act on Friday.

City police commissioner Chiranjeev Prasad said based on complaints lodged by cops serving with the cybercrime police station, the offences were registered with Jinsi, Waluj, Osmanpura and City Chowk police stations.

Police authorities said 10 ‘Tiplines’ have originated from Aurangabad city. Out of these, three offences were registered on January 10 and 11, while out of the remaining seven, five were registered on Friday.

Cyber police said that following the technical analysis of the uploaded content, their source was found to be from the limits of different police stations in the city.

Highly placed sources said that the offences are a result of a memorandum of understanding (MoU) between the National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB) of India and the National Centre for Missing and Exploited Children (NCMEC) of the US. As per the pact signed in the first quarter of 2019, the US will help India in receiving Tipline reports on online child pornography and child sexual exploitation content from NCMEC.

A cyber crime officer said police swung into action after a citizen sent an alert about the content. “Such tips sent to law enforcement agencies through helpline numbers or websites automatically get converted into a report for action and it is called Tipline report.”

The officer added that there is a unique identity number generated for each of the Tipline report and its status can be checked by punching the said number.

The agreement enables law enforcement agencies to remove child pornography and child sexual abuse material from cyber space, and initiate action against those uploading such content.

Title: Wife of man who held 25 kids hostage in UP's Farrukhabad lynched
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Subhash Batham (L), his wife Ruby

KATHARIYA VILLAGE (FARRUKHABAD): Subhash Batham, a murder convict who held a fake birthday party for his daughter in UP’s Farrukhabad and then held 25 children who were his “guests” hostage for several hours, was shot dead by police early on Friday morning.

His wife, Ruby, who was allegedly an accomplice to the act, died in a hospital soon after after angry local residents pelted her with stones, lynching her. Police on Friday filed an FIR against 300 unknown people under section 302 (punishment for murder).

Police, forensic teams and the bomb disposal squad (Moradabad) claimed they had recovered 145 crude bombs, including a cylinder bomb and a can bomb, along with wire, battery, tape, sutali (thread) that they said were used in a bomb hurled by Batham, injuring two dial 112 constables and SHO Mohammdabad.

Twenty live cartridges, 11 used cartridges of a country-made pistol and a 315 bore rifle were recovered from his house, police said, along with the used cartridge of an AK-47. Some of the children who had been held hostage had, however, told TOI that they saw only a katta and another country made rifle with Batham.

Police said Batham — who never attended school — acquired his "bomb-making skills" during a 12-year stint in jail after he was convicted of murder. The basement in which he held the children hostage doubled up as his laboratory where he painstakingly readied the crude bombs, cops added, suggesting he had been planning his act for a long time.

But as far as his motives are concerned, there are different theories — anger at the residents for boycotting him for a long time for marrying a Dalit woman; allegedly being left out of government schemes and enmity against those who testified against him in court in the murder case.

According to police, Batham had claimed on the night of the incident that the gram pradhan of Kathariya village and a local MLA had falsely implicated him in his uncle’s murder due to which he had ended up wasting his youth in prison. The gram pradhan, Harvir Singh, told TOI that he indeed testified in court against Batham and that’s why the man held enmity against him. “Batham murdered his uncle in 2001 after he had caught him stealing valuables from a neighbour’s house and scolded him. I was a witness in the case.”

Commenting on a letter that Batham had written to authorities — demanding a house and toilet under government schemes — and which he handed to police on Thursday night, the gram pradhan said his demands were baseless. “He had written the letter for a house under the PM Awas Yojana and a toilet under Swachh Bharat Mission years ago.” The real motive, he insisted, was revenge against him and village residents.

Bhojpur MLA Nagendra Singh — who was also the target of Batham’s fury — said that he didn’t know the man but had visited the spot to calm down the situation. “He wanted revenge as he was boycotted by the community for marrying a Dalit woman four years ago,” he said.

Anil Kumar Mishra, SP (Farrukhabad), said, “The hostage situation could have been created to extort money as he demanded Rs 1 crore for each kid. He also wanted all criminal cases expunged against him.” Batham had five criminal cases going on against him in local courts.

Whatever the motive, he was well prepared, claimed police. “The quantity of bombs was good enough to kill everyone in a radius of 50m if they went off at once,” said Farrukhabad special operation group in charge, Dinesh Kumar Gautam.

Batham was shot even as the crowd of 300 pelted stones at their house. “As they were attacking the couple at the front door, we entered the house from the back. When he saw his wife being attacked, he grabbed his country-made rifle after which he was shot dead,” said Mishra.
