Some residents, however, alleged that policemen “encouraged local residents to pelt stones at the couple”. On Friday, the couple’s bodies were sent for autopsy, while their two-and-a-half-year-old daughter Kusum was handed over to child authorities.

Title: KT Rama Rao wants ‘Punishing Signal’ in Hyderabad to curb honking menace
Content:
KT Rama Rao

HYDERABAD: Impressed with Mumbai police’s innovative concept of ‘The Punishing Signal’, Telangana minister KT Rama Rao advised the top officials of municipal and police departments to launch similar enforcement initiative to reduce noise pollution at traffic signals.To curb honking menace and reduce noise pollution on crowded city streets, Mumbai police have launched ‘The Punishing Signal’ initiative. Mumbai police installed decibel metres at select traffic junctions and connected them to signal timers. When the cacophony at the signal crosses decibel level of 85, the signal timer resets forcing the honking motorists to wait more.Sharing a video of the initiative taken by the Mumbai police, KTR tweeted, “Let’s get this done in our Hyderabad too. Need of the hour.” The minister tagged Telangana DGP M Mahendar Reddy, Hyderabad police commissioner Anjani Kumar and GHMC commissioner Lokesh Kumar in the tweet.Responding to KTR’s tweet, police officials said they are ready to launch the initiative. “It is a good initiative to curb noise pollution. We will do it in the city,” Hyderabad police commissioner Anjani Kumar said.Punjagutta, Khairatabad, Jubilee Hills Check Post, RTC X roads Paradise and Patny X roads are some of the crowded junctions in the city.Though police have not carried out any survey about contribution of honking to noise pollution at junctions, they seem to be certain that cacophony due to honking is a problem at few traffic junctions. “We are fining motorists for noise pollution using Sound Level Meter. To prevent honking at traffic signals, decibel metres have to be installed and awareness need to be created, before the enforcement. We have some of the busiest traffic junctions like Gachibowli, Cyber towers, Kothaguda, Aramgarh, Allwyn X roads, Miyapur X roads and BHEL X roads in the city,” Cyberabad DCP Vijay Kumar said.Rachakonda commissioner Mahesh Bhagwat, under whose jurisdiction fall crowded junctions like LB Nagar and Uppal X Roads, said once GHMC procures and installs decibel metres connected to timers at the traffic signals, they will start the initiative to prevent honking.

Title: 324 Indians board special flight at Wuhan, to reach Delhi at 7.30 am: AI
Content: NEW DELHI: A total of 324 Indians, mostly students, have boarded Air India ’s jumbo jet at Wuhan to be flown to Delhi around 1.30 am (IST) Saturday. The jumbo jet, which landed in the epicentre of the deadly coronavirus , is expected to reach Delhi at 7.30 am Saturday. The government had expected 366 Indians evacuees on this flight. Some were not allowed to travel due to high fever and stopped at Wuhan airport.The special flight on Boeing 747 “Ajanta” had left Delhi on Friday afternoon with four pilots, 15 cabin crew, a team of doctors from Delhi’s RML Hospital, medical equipment and other support staff. It landed there at 7.46 pm (Wuhan time), with the pilots exclaiming in the cockpit “khaali airport, khaali roads” during final approach to the ghost town — a bustling economic centre till a few days back. Ajanta was supposed to take off at 10 pm (IST) but delayed due to factors like passengers not being able to make it on time and then screening taking more time.This is the first of the evacuation flights by India for Wuhan and AI could operate the second one on Saturday. Special arrangements have been made at IGI Airport and no person and baggage from this aircraft will need to go inside the terminal. Ajanta will be parked at a remote bay (no aerobridge) where customs and immigration will set up special counters for doing the required clearance. Passengers will board an ITBP bus from the ramp and head to their quarantine centres. Crew and other personnel on this aircraft will also remain in isolation for about a week at their homes.With AI’s director (operations) Captain Amitabh Singh on board to supervise this evacuation flight, the 423-seater aircraft took off with four pilots — two commanders Captain Kamal Mohan, Captain S H Reza; and two first officers Captain Sanjay Achalkar and Captain Bhupesh Narain. Everyone onboard the Delhi-Wuhan flight wore full protective suit on landing in Wuhan, before opening the aircraft door there.“No service will take place on the flight. Food packets and water bottles will be kept on each. There will be no interaction (between cabin crew and passengers),” said an AI official. Two lavs will be kept only for crew. AI chairman Ashwani Lohani, who was at Delhi Airport to meet the crew of this special flight, said masks have been arranged for the crew and passengers. “For our crew, we have also arranged complete protective gear,” he said.All the personnel volunteered for this flight, and subsequent ones, despite the risk of spending hours with possibly infected people in the closed environ of an aircraft, with cash-starved AI — which is unable to pay salaries on time — carrying out this operation from its resources. To be sure, all the crew and other staff will wear full protective gear during the flight back to India.Lohani tweeted: “The national carrier once again comes to the rescue - this time to evacuate Indians from Wuhan, the site of the outbreak of coronavirus. This mission begins today with a Jumbo 747 operating between Delhi and Wuhan. Jai Hind”AI, which is on the block, has in the past on numerous occasions carried out difficult and dangerous rescue missions to war zones like Libya, Iraq and Yemen, with the most famous being the airlift from Kuwait in 1990. In August 1990, AI and erstwhile Indian Airlines evacuated more than a lakh Indians from Iraq and Kuwait via 488 flights in 59 days, creating the world record for largest aerial evacuation since 1948-49.

Title: Scribe, three others killed as jeep rams stationary truck
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: Four people, including a journalist with a vernacular newspaper, were killed and five were seriously injured on the spot after their jeep rammed a parked truck on the Aurangabad-Jalna highway, near Gadhejalgaon phata, at 3am on Friday.

According to the Karmad police ( Aurangabad rural), the victims were returning from Igatpuri after paying obeisance at a temple. The injured, including a woman, are battling for life at different hospitals.

The victims were heading from Aurangabad in the jeeb when the driver, who probably could not spot the heavy vehicle parked on the left side of the road, crashed into it.

The deceased were identified as Kashinath Devrao Mehtre (62), Ravi Baban Jadhav (32), both hailing from Nasirabad of Sindhkhedraja; Sangita Ganesh Bunde (45) of Tandulwadi, also in Sindhkedraja; and Rushidhar Devrao Tidke (55) of Gondegaon in Jalna.

Karnad police said they have registered an offence and that a probe is on to ascertain facts. “Depending on the findings, a charge sheet would be filed.”

On December 25 last year, a major accident had occurred on the same highway that connects Nagpur with Mumbai.

Five of a family were then killed after a speeding car lost control and hit the divider before turning turtle and ending up ramming an autorickshaw coming from the opposite direction.

The accidents have raised questions over measures to control speeding and haphazard parking on the busy highway.

Title: Scindia inaugurates ‘smart bus’ in Gwalior by driving it
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Jyotiraditya Scindia in Kolhapur Congress leader Jyotiraditya Scindia was in Kolhapur to campaign for Congress... Read More

Bhopal: Senior Congress leader Jyotiraditya Scindia was seen in a different avatar — a driver. Amid cheers and applause, Scindia drove a bus in Gwalior on Friday. He drove a Smart Bus introduced by the Gwalior Smart City Development Corporation from the Moti Mahal area to Baija Tal.

The Gwalior Smart City Development Corporation invited Scindia to inaugurate the seven new Smart City buses.

When Scindia boarded one of them, he said, “I will not sit in the bus but will drive it.” He drove the bus as his supporters cheered. Ministers Tulsi Silawat and Pradhumn Singh Tomar were seen sitting beside him. He also took to twitter and wrote, “inaugurating the Smart City Bus by driving it. These buses run in Gwalior under the Smart City Development Corporation and will make commuting easy for residents of Gwalior.”Scindia also visited Shivpuri on Friday — the first time after his defeat in the 2019 Lok Sabha poll.

Asked about the implementation of development projects and schemes in the area, Scindia replied, “People had given me responsibility, but sadly they decided to free me from that accountability. I am not an MP and as a common man I have appealed to the minister-in-charge and administration to implement the schemes. Had I been an MP, I would sit and get the work done like I did before.”

Title: Teen falls off cliff in Mussoorie, hospitalised
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Mussoorie: A teenage girl was hospitalised after she allegedly fell off a cliff near Galogi power house on Mussoorie-Dehradun Road around 15 km from the hill town. Mystery shrouds the incident as it is being claimed to be an attempted suicide while the family members of the girl are denying it and called it an accident.

A 17-year-old, resident of Mussoorie , was rescued after passersby saw her fall from the cliff and was rushed to the hospital in Dehradun . Her condition is stated to be stable now but she has suffered severe injuries to her legs.

Meanwhile, sources said that this is a case of attempted suicide as the girl allegedly had an argument with her mother, following which she took the drastic step.

However, according to station officer Mussoorie, Vidhya Bhushan Negi, the parents of the girl said that it was an accident. Negi said, “The matter is under investigation as the parents of the girl are denying suicide and are claiming that it was an accident that took place when the girl fell off the cliff while clicking a selfie.”

Title: Pune: Fergusson College panel to probe student’s assault claim
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

File photo of Fergusson College

PUNE: Fergusson College ’s management on Friday constituted a committee to inquire into a second-year political science student’s allegation of being beaten up inside the institute by some students , who he claimed represented the Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP).

“On Wednesday, there was a pro-Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) event on the campus. I asked the organizers if they had the permission to conduct the event. This led to an altercation and I was beaten up. I have registered a non-cognizable offence against them. One of them is a college student and the other one is an ‘outsider’. Both of them belong to the ABVP,” Santosh Rasve said while addressing a news conference.

“The college authorities can check the CCTV camera footage and take action. They have not yet urged the police to take cognizance of the matter or conduct any inquiry,” he said.

Sharad Kunte, chairman of the Governing Body and Council of the Deccan Education Society, said, “The allegations are baseless. We treat all students equally. This is a place to study and we do not give permission for any political activity on the campus.”

Fergusson College principal Ravindrasinh Pardeshi said, “We are formulating a committee to inquire into the issue. We will also look at the CCTV camera footage. Students who are at fault will be punished.”

“We treat all students alike. We want the students to maintain peace on the educational campus,” he added.

ABVP-Pune secretary Anil Thombare said, “I do not know whether the people organizing the pro-CAA event are ABVP members or not. The ABVP had not organized any such event on the college campus.”

A cross complaint was filed on Friday by the two students named by Rasve in his complaint.

They claimed in the complained that Rasve had and beaten them up when they were “peacefully organizing the event”.

Title: Telangana: New policies on building plans, parking to be rolled out soon
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

KT Rama Rao

HYDERABAD: On the lines of TS-iPass determining industrial policy of Telangana , the government is planning to roll out TS-bPass for quick approval of building plans and self-certification. The government will also come out with new parking policy to address the problem of parking space shortage.

On Friday, municipal administration minister KT Rama Rao said the much-awaited Metro rail service on Jubilee Bus Station to Mahatma Gandhi Bus Terminal would be inaugurated within a week. “In next few days, the Metro rail corridor will be thrown open for commuters, after which Hyderabad will be second largest city in India, after Delhi, in terms of Metro rail connectivity,” he said, after inaugurating Credai property show.

He said the government’s aim is to ensure that people get building approvals in a time-bound manner and in a corruption-free environment. “The way TS iPAss has become a role model, TS bPass will also become a role model in the country,” he said. KTR had earlier said TS-bPass would allow a citizen to construct a house through self-certification if dwelling unit is to be built within 75 square yards.

He appealed to builders, developers and real estate promoters to look beyond Hyderabad so that tier-II and tier-III cities would also develop. “We will provide the required infrastructure.” On investments on infrastructure projects, he said capital infusion should be a continuous process.

KTR said the government is planning to develop a IT hub towards Pet Basheerabad and Kompally in the north of the city. “IT sector is presently concentrated in western parts. We want it to grow in all four corners of the capital.”

He also appealed to the developers and builders to hire good consultants and designers so that aesthetic and beautiful designs are given to the façade and elevation of buildings. “I had gone to Mangaluru and was impressed with the designs there. Stop building routine (dabba-type) buildings. You are constructing structures that would be dotting the landscape for a long time. They must have good designs,” he said.

Title: Sambhal doc, driver die as truck rams car
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Bareilly: A doctor and his driver were killed after a speeding sand-laden truck crashed into their car on Sambhal-Behjoi road near Kisauli village in Sambhal district on Friday morning.

Manish Varshney and his driver Deepu were killed on the spot. His wife, Dr Shikha Agrawal, sustained minor injuries. She said they were going to Delhi to buy a car. The truck driver fled after the accident, leaving his vehicle behind.

People working in the nearby fields said the front tyre of the truck burst with a loud noise as it hit the car. They ran to rescue the people in the car. The villagers pulled out all three and informed police as well as emergency 108 service. The truck coming from the opposite side, hit the car in the front, sending it into a roadside ditch, they said.

Meanwhile, Shikha informed family members about the fatal accident. Varshney ran Sumangalam Hospital on Arya Samaj road at Behjoi in Sambhal district.

Police said Varshney was driving the car while his wife was sitting beside him. His driver was on the back seat when the accident took place.

“The truck driver lost control of the vehicle and crashed into the car. We have lodged an FIR against the absconding truck driver impounding it,” said Ravindra Pratap Singh, SHO, Behjoi police station.

Title: Woman loses three gold chains worth Rs 3 lakh at Kranti Chowk
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: A 41-year old woman was robbed of three gold chains , collectively weighing about 65 grams worth around Rs 3 lakh by unidentified bike-borne men on Thursday evening.

Based on the complaint lodged by Archana Sheetal Mundada, a resident of Basaiyenagar, a robbery case has been registered at Kranti Chowk police station around Thursday midnight.

As per the complaint, the woman had gone to meet her relatives, who stay near Amarpreet signal on Jalna road. On her way back home, two unidentified suspects on a bike came close to her and snatched her three gold chains weighing 30gm, 20gm and 15 gm respectively.

This the first incident in the city, where in a woman has been robbed of three gold chains at a single go.

Police said that the suspects have been caught in more than one CCTV camera in the city. Taking serious cognizance of the incident, multiple teams, including those from the crime branch, have been tasked to zero in on the suspects on a priority basis.

Title: Police probing chart with ‘anti-national’ remarks
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Dehradun: A case relating to a chart, with derogatory and anti-national statements written over it, came to light on Friday. Police received a picture of the chart, which is allegedly put inside the classroom of a city-based college.

Talking to TOI, DIG Arun Mohan Joshi informed that police have received a picture of the objectionable chart and sources have hinted that the chart is put in a city-based college.

However, the officials of the college in question has denied to the presence of any such chart in classrooms. “The administration and faculty of the college, whose name has cropped up, has denied of having any such chart in any of their classes. Names of some students of the college have also come up in the probe. As of now, we are gathering more information in the case,” said Joshi. The official added that there is a possibility that such a chart is not there in any Uttarakhand-based college as its location can’t be ascertained from the picture.

When asked about the matter written on the chart, the cop said that it was too derogatory and sensitive to be shared.

Meanwhile, Nasir Kheuhami, spokesperson of Jammu and Kashmir Students Association, said that students will cooperate with the police in the probe. "The matter is sensitive and we will be supporting the police in the probe. We have full faith in the law," he added.

Title: 4 held for double murder in Rampur
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Rampur: With the arrest of four people, police here claimed to have solved the murder of two men, Harvansh and Jagat Singh, who went missing on January 25. Their bodies were found in a well at Bakeniya village under the jurisdiction of Patwai police station on January 27.

Addressing mediapersons, additional superintendent of police, Rampur, Arun Kumar Singh said, “Main accused Amar Singh revealed during interrogation that his married daughter was in a relationship with Harvansh. In order to get rid of him, Amar Singh invited Harvansh and Jagat Singh for drinks on January 25 at his house. After getting the duo drunk, Amar Singh and three of his accomplices -- Ram Singh, Jayveer and Umesh -- all residents of Bakeniya village, allegedly strangled Harvansh and Jagat Singh and threw their bodies into the village well.”

Harvansh’s brother, Ramveer Singh, informed police that the bodies had been found and registered an FIR against unidentified assailants at Patwai police station on January 27.

Police on Friday arrested all the four accused and booked them under IPC section 302 (murder) and 201(causing disappearance of evidence of offence).

Title: Don’t spread fake news: Cops
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Kozhikode: The Kozhikode city and rural police have urged social media users to abstain from spreading messages related to coronavirus without verifying facts.

“Some people have been trying to spread fear among public by circulating fake information about coronavirus. So we decided to issue an alert. The cyber wing of the city police is also on alert and any complaint regarding fake news will be dealt with seriously,” police said.

Meanwhile, the state police have also issued a circular warning social media users from spreading fake news as incidents of forging letterheads of medical officers were reported during Nipah outbreak in 2018. Police have urged social media users to stop forwarding messages without verifying its credibility. “We are planning to book people for spreading such messages.” an officer said.

More than 12 people were booked for circulating messages to create public scare during Nipah outbreak. The move was well-received by public. The propagation of fake messages over hartals was also stopped by enforcing strict action.

“Some people have been trying to spread fear by circulating fake news. Messages are being circulating saying a person from a particular area has been infected with coronavirus. Their motive is to create panic among people,” a police officer said. “So far we have not received any written complaint against fake news. However, we will keep vigil and ensure action against those trying to create fear among people,” he added.

Title: One dies, another gored by swamp deer, forest dept disagrees, says shy animal can’t attack
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

BHEL area shares boundary with Rajaji Tiger Reserve (RTR) from where animals often come into the BHEL resident... Read More

Haridwar: A 28-year-old man lost his life after the auto he was travelling in allegedly colliding with a swamp deer (barasingha) in Sector 1 of BHEL, Haridwar, and turned turtle on Wednesday night. This was followed by a rare incident in which, a biker was gored by the deer. He suffered stitches on the chest and was rushed to the nearest hospital along with the injured auto-driver.

BHEL area shares boundary with Rajaji Tiger Reserve (RTR) from where animals often come into the BHEL residential area and get into conflict with humans.

Big bushes around the area and unkempt solid waste have also turned the area into a perfect habitat for wild animals of Rajaji, which further leads to such incidents. Recently a man-eater leopard had to be killed after it had taken refuge in BHELs unkempt forest.

Confirming the incident, inspector of Ranipur police station Shankar Singh Bisht said, “Ravindera Agrawal (28) died after the auto collided with the deer while another person Chandra Prakash, a resident of BHEL Sector – V was gored by the same animal. He suffered five stitches as the barasingha attacked the victim by its horns.”

Meanwhile, Haridwar DFO Akash Verma said that it is not possible for the swamp deer to attack anyone as it is a very shy animal and never in the past any such case has been reported.

“It is a strange story being cooked-up by the people. According to eye witnesses, the auto driver had applied breaks suddenly while the biker was speeding and they both collided.”

Sighting of swamp deer in BHEL area and in fact other areas of Haridwar is quite common. Recently, the animal was seen entering Roshanabad court premises while earlier it had entered former Haridwar DM’s house, from where it was rescued by forest officials after hours.

Title: Composting centres, biomining to solve garbage crisis: Official
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Micro composting centres will not cause discomfort as they will not produce bad odour as widely believed, says... Read More

COIMBATORE: As many as 13 out of the 35 micro composting centres in the city have started functioning and the corporation has assured to put the remaining centres to use before the end of March, chairperson of the regional monitoring committee (south) of the National Green Tribunal (NGT) P Jyothimani said here on Friday.

Speaking to reporters after a review meeting with corporation officials, the official said that the city generates 1,000 tonnes of waste a day. “Of that, 60% is compostable. Adopting the decentralized concept to treat compostable waste, the corporation had decided to construct as many as 69 micro composting centres in the city,” he said.

Talking about the opposition from public on constructing the centres at open space reserve (OSR) sites, Jyothimani said it could not be avoided as there is not enough space in the city for building the structures. “The centres will not cause discomfort as they will not produce bad odour as widely believed.”

Decentralized waste treatment is considered as one of the best solid waste management methods and Tamil Nadu is the first state to implement it, the official said. “After it was implemented in the state, local bodies in Bihar are planning to adopt the method.”

Speaking about the lakhs of tonnes of legacy waste at the Vellalore dump yard, he said that the corporation has assured to scientifically dispose the waste accumulated at the yard through biomining process within 24 months once the work begins. “Rs 65 crore was allotted for implementing the process. The corporation will float a tender to identify a suitable bidder to implement biomining process in February. Professor Kurian Joseph of Anna university will certify the process.”

He visited the dump yard and listened to the grievances of people living around the place, Jyothimani said. “I told them that the problems they face will be solved once the biomining process begins.”

It was the third review meeting conducted by the committee in the city after NGT directed the corporation to scientifically dispose 15.50 lakh cubic metres of accumulated solid wastes at the dump yard in October 2018.

Title: Apex body of bank unions on two-day strike
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: United Forum of Bank Unions (UFBU), the apex body of various unions and associations of bank employees and officers, on Friday, resorted to a two-day strike, affecting the functioning for many government sector banks and undertakings.

The UBFU demanded that the government should consider their demand for wage revision settlement due from November 2017. To register their protest against the unwarranted delay by the India Banks’ Association, the UFBU resorted to the strike, said Devidas Tuljapurkar, convener of UBFO , Maharashtra .

He said that the UBFO — that represents nine unions — has decided to go on another three-day strike from March 11.

He said that the wages and service conditions of bank employees are governed by collective bargaining and bilateral agreements.

“The same is revised once in five years based on the demands submitted by the unions arising out of discussions with the IBA on behalf of all banks. Accordingly, the last settlement was finalized to cover the term from November 2012 to October 2017, hence the revision was due from November 2017,” Tuljapurkar said.

Title: Distressed man rescued from flyover
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

COIMBATORE: A person with learning difficulties , who had scaled the pillar of Valankulam flyover between Ukkadam and Sungam, was rescued by fire and rescue services personnel on Thursday.

The man, in his early 30s, was sent to a home for mentally ill in the city. Fire and rescue services personnel said that he stay put in the small space atop the pillar underneath the span of the bridge for the past two days.

“The pillar must be at least 20 feet high. Nobody knew how he scaled up that height,’’ said an officer from fire and rescue services. Officials presume that he must have got there when a vehicle was stationed close-by. He was lying there atop the pillar in a small space.

Motorists who passed by the way noticed him and asked him to get down. But he was neither able to scale further to the bridge nor get down. Since the public felt that the man could jump down and injure himself, they informed the fire service personnel. Once down, they gave him food and water. But the man was incoherent and was unable to give his identity. Subsequently, he was sent to the home.

Title: No maulana helped Muslims like Modi did: RSS leader Indresh Kumar
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

yyyyyyyyyyyyyy

Dehradun: While speaking at an event held to spread awareness regarding the Citizenship Ammendment Act (CAA), Indresh Kumar, head of Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh’s Muslim wing, said that the amendment doesn’t threaten citizenship of any Muslim and that the community must not get misguided by “Jamia professors”.

The seminar, held at Dehradun Municipal Corporation’s town hall on Friday, was attended by several people from the minority community. Kumar, who spoke for over 40 minutes, accused the Congress and other Left parties of inciting violence in the name of the Act.

“When Prime Minister Narendra Modi assumed office in 2014, some people claimed that Muslim colonies will be destroyed and they will be deprived of jobs and other facilities. Today, six years have passed and nothing bad has happened to Muslims. In fact, Muslims were given gas connection and other facilities. No maulana has ever helped Muslims like Modi has. The fear being spread in the name of CAA is ridiculous and wrong,” said Kumar.

During his speech, the right-wing leader explained the citizenship procedure followed in the counrty. “In India, citizenship is given on the basis of 11+1 rule, which means that a person has to stay as a refugee for 11 years and then on the basis of a report, he/she gets the citizenship in the 12th year. Hundreds of people have been given citizenship on the basis of this law. India has always given citizenship to the needy. Irani Muslims and Parsis, Balochs of Pakistan, Tibetans, and Sindhis, and people from other persecuted communities have been given asylum in the country. People from any religion can still apply for Indian citizenship under this 11+1 rule,” added Kumar.

Kumar also pointed out the atrocities being committed on minorities in Pakistan, saying “Minorities in Pakistan are treated as second class citizens.” He stressed that people from persecuted Muslim sects like Ahmadiyya, Shia, and others, can also apply for Indian citizenship. “The incumbent government is the only one working for minorities. Congress didn’t do anything for the upliftment of minorities in the past 70 years,” said Kumar.

He urged people to not oppose the Act and not subscribe to violence. “No one dreams in Arabic or any other foreign language. We dream in Hindustani languages because we are all Indians and no power can change it,” Kumar added.

Title: Courier operator stabbed to death in Gulmandi
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: A 24-year-old man was stabbed to death by four unidentified assailants at his office in Gulmandi area of the city on Friday afternoon.

The deceased, Prakash Jaswantbhai Patel, was a courier operator and hailed from Gujarat. The incident took place in the narrow lane of Nagarkhana situated in the busy Gulmandi area at 12.15 pm.

Deputy commissioner of police (zone-I) Nikesh Khatmode Patil told TOI, “We are working on more than one theories and have got certain clues. We are confident of cracking the case.”

At the time of incident, Sanjay and Kamlesh Patel were also present in the office when the suspects came into the office and one of them removed a firearm. Following this, Kamlesh and Prakash ran outside the office, while Sanjay ran inside another room in the office.

The suspects ran after Prakash and one of them stabbed him in the chest. The courier company owned by the Patels was called Ramabhai Mohanbhai Courier services.

After sustaining the injury, Prakash ran to another courier operator, Rajnikanti Courier services, situated around 50 metre away and collapsed soon after entering the office. Rajnikanti’s operator Ramesh Patel soon called for help and rushed Prakash to a nearby private hospital. The medicos at the private hospital immediately referred him to Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) where he was declared brought dead.

Soon after learning about the incident, police teams rushed to the spot and collected the CCTV footage. Sources maintained that they have an eye-witness to the incident and efforts are being made to extract specific description of the suspects.

GMCH sources informed that the body had a single stab wound on the left chest and Prakash might have succumbed to profuse bleeding. The process of recording statements of the witnesses is currently underway at City Chowk police station.

After the incident, members of courier and angadia services closed down their offices. One of them informed that Prakash had been to Surat for over a week and had returned on Friday morning.

Title: Society slams advisory on homeo, unani meds
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Breakthrough Science Society, a non-profit social welfare organisation established to create a science movement in the country, has expressed shock and anguish over the Centre’s advisory recommending the public to use untested ayurveda, homoeopathy and unani medicines to prevent and treat the illnesses caused by coronavirus.

In its statement, the society’s office bearers said that the Press Information Bureau (PIB) has released a statement recommending members of the public to use untested ayurveda, homoeopathy and unani medicines to prevent and treat the illnesses caused by coronavirus.

Even as the World Health Organisation (WHO) has only advised the public to stick to basic preventive measures like avoiding contact with people suffering from cold, washing hands, staying away from crowded places, farm or wild animals etc, Indian government after giving similar hygiene recommendations has also advised people to take to ayurvedic practices, homoeopathic drugs and unani medicines, it said.

A homeopathic drug namely Arsenicum album30, unani medicines like Sharbat Unnab and ayurvedic preparations like Shadang Paniya are advised to be taken either as preventive medicines or for symptomatic management against coronavirus infections. But there are no supporting evidence that these medicines are effective against the virus, the statement said. It further said that how are these drugs even relevant in the fight against novel coronavirus (2019-nCov), which is itself a new organism is not clear. In the absence of proper studies on the effectiveness of these medicines the government advisory on coronavirus is irresponsible, misleading, dangerous to the public health and against medical ethics, the statement said.

The coronavirus (2019-nCoV) has already claimed 132 lives. It has affected over a dozen of countries. According to the health ministry, 9,150 passengers have been screened for the coronavirus.

Title: 5 get double life terms for double murder
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: The five men, convicted in the 2017 Selvapuram double murder case, were sentenced to double life terms on Friday.

The special court for bomb blast cases sentenced S Surya, 21, R Surya, 29, Mohanraj, 20 and Vignesh Kumar, 23, of Selvapuram and Vijayaraj, 22, of the Sri Lankan refugee camp at Bouluvampatti for hacking Selvaraj, 38 and autorickshaw driver Anandh Kumar, 33, to death on September 22, 2017.

The sordid saga began in June 2017, when Selvaraj was arrested for the murder of G Vinodh Kumar, 36, a resident of Selvapuram and was lodged in the Coimbatore Central Prison. Selvaraj had killed Kumar as he was having an affair with his friend Gunduraja’s wife, police sources said. “Both Selvaraj and Gunduraja were arrested. When they came out on bail in September, the five convicts, who were Kumar’s friends, decided to take revenge on them,” a police officer said.

The five men began watching Selvaraj and Gunduraja and got a tip that the duo was coming to IUDC Colony in an autorickshaw on September 22. “They waylaid the auto, which only had Selvaraj. They hacked him and auto driver Anandh Kumar to death using sickles,” the officer added.

Judge T Malarvalantina also slapped them with fines ranging from Rs 11,000 to Rs 12,000.

Title: Farmers demand salary from government
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: The youth wing of a Mettupalayam-based farmers ’ association is planning to stage a protest next week demanding salary from the state and central governments.

In a petition to the collector during the farmers’ grievance day meet on Friday, members of the Tamizhaga Vivasayigal Sangam’s youth wing stated that they will raise the demand at the protest near the Mettupalayam bus stand on Wednesday. “Farmers are struggling due to the damages caused by wild animals, constant price fluctuation of produce, lack of adequate water and natural disasters,” said the petition. “If the government gives a basic monthly salary to farmers and thus remove the dependency on crop and crop pricing, it will attract youths to farming,” said Thennarasu of the association.

Title: Port, VCT step up to deal with coronavirus threat
Content: Visakhapatnam: After the first coronavirus case in the country was reported in Kerala, arrangements inside the Visakhapatnam Container Terminal ( VCT ) where international shipping lines load and offload their consignments have been stepped up, with immigration officials not allowing any crew members to disembark from ships.“Immigration officials are not granting shore permission for the crew members. No crew member is allowed to get down from the ships,” a senior VCT official told TOI.Around 25 to 30 ships dock at the VCT berths every month. At least 75 per cent of the vessels are from east and north Asian countries.“We are also not allowing any of our officials to enter the ship. Only one official is allowed to enter with the load plan. But as per the doctor’s advice he is not allowed to touch anything on board, nor is he even allowed to shake hands with crew members,” the official added.The VCT had organised a workshop on coronavirus on Thursday under Dr KVV Vijaya Kumar, superintendent of Chest and Communicable Diseases Hospital, Visakhapatnam. As per the doctor’s advice, all employees at VCT are using N95 masks while on duty.Meanwhile, the Visakhapatnam Port Trust has also initiated measures to fight the disease at the port area under the supervision of port health officer (PHO) Amit Gayan.Medical staff at the port trust have been provided with 500 N95 masks, 20 hand sanitisers, 500 sets of disposable gloves, five sets of disposable full-length body gowns and a thermoflash hand gun.“Recently, a vessel ‘Fortune Sun’, carrying 21 Chinese crew members docked in Vizag Port. Only after carrying out all mandatory examinations by the PHO did we permit port officials to enter the vessel. We are prepared to handle the situation,” said a port official.Port officials have also made it mandatory for themaster of the ship or vessel to give a health declaration for its entire crew every day. Any symptom of ill-health has to be brought to the notice of the PHO or port authority immediately and any suspicious case will be shifted to the isolation ward at the Infections Diseases Hospital (IDH) at Pedda Waltair.

Title: National skiing, snowboarding championship in Auli from Feb 8
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Dehradun: Uttarakhand Tourism Development Board in association with the Ski and Snowboard Association of Uttarakhand will host a three-day skiing and snowboard championship at Auli from February 8. The event will be held in categories of senior, junior and sub juniors. Garhwal Mandal Vikas Nigam (GMVN) has been made the nodal agency for the championship.

The events would be held under the categories of Slalom and Giant Slalom (Men/Women/Junior U-21, Junior-18), Giant Slalom (U-16, U-14), Snowboard – Slalom and Giant Slalom (Men/Women), Snowboard – Giant Slalom (Junior U-21, U-18) and Cross Country (Men/Women).

Tourism secretary Dilip Jawalkar said that the event will be a big boost for the state and the area as well. The IAS officer said that 250 players of 10 teams are expected to participate in different events. Food and lodging for all participants would be done by the GMVN.

Title: Novel Coronavirus: Health camps to come up at 26 Pilibhit villages near Indo-Nepal border
Content:
Representative image

BAREILLY: The health department will organize health camps at 26 villages in Pilibhit near the Nepal border to rule out the spread of Novel Coronavirus nCov-2019 ).The doctors will conduct health check-up at these villages to see if any person has symptoms related to the virus. Besides, ASHA workers have started conducting awareness drive to visit the hospital if anyone has a fever.As Nepal reported one confirmed case of Novel Coronavirus, officials are taking precautionary measures so that the virus does not spread in Pilibhit, which shares the border with Nepal. In India, one confirmed case was reported in Kerala.Additional director (health), Bareilly division, Dr Rakesh Dubey, said, “We have set up two mobile medical units at check-posts in Pilibhit to screen people entering India through the Indo-Nepal border for novel coronavirus. Apart from that, health camps will be conducted in villagers bordering Nepal. In the health camps, screening of fever and other symptoms will be done to rule out the spread of novel coronavirus.”Chief medical officer (CMO), Pilibhit, Dr Seema Agarwal, said, “A team comprising a doctor, pharmacist and lab technician will hold health camps in 26 villages. ASHA workers will conduct cluster meetings with residents of these villages to educate them about the disease. We will distribute pamphlets and put up flexes to create awareness.”Meanwhile, the health department in Bareilly has issued advisory to the public. CMO, Bareilly, Dr Vineet Shukla, said, “The risk is in the districts having airport or those sharing the border with Nepal, but we are also on alert. We have issued an advisory to the public and set up an isolation ward at the district hospital. Besides, we have sent the guidelines on novel coronavirus to all community health centres, IMA, private pathologies, and private medical colleges to notify us if they find any suspected case.”Health officials said the nCov virus spreads when a person sneezes and the infected droplets fall on nearby objects like tables or mobile phones. When healthy people touch these objects, they get infected.Experts said people can reduce the risk of coronavirus by cleaning hands with soap and water or alcohol-based hand rub. Besides, one should cover his nose and mouth with a tissue when coughing and sneezing, and should not reuse the handkerchiefs or tissues. People should avoid close contact with anyone with cold or flu-like symptoms.There should be no unprotected contact with live wild or farm animals, and people should eat thoroughly cooked meat and egg.Officials said nCov symptoms include fever, difficulty in breathing, chest pain, pneumonia and rapid heartbeat.

Title: PTR seeks nod to translocate tigers living in Pilibhit’s Amaria cane fields
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

BAREILLY: Pilibhit Tiger Reserve (PTR) authorities have written to principal chief conservator of forests (wildlife) for translocating tigers that have made the sugarcane fields in Amaria block home. Forest officials said 10 tigers are living amid the cane fields and fear that if the big cats are not shifted, it may lead to human-tiger conflict in the area. Of these, four are sub-adults.

According to forest officials, nearly 50 tigers, including the 10 in Amaria, are living in the cane fields in Pilibhit district .

Giving details, chief conservator of forests, Rohilkhand zone, Lalit Verma told TOI, “If our proposal is approved, it will be first time that sugarcane tigers will be translocated. However, it is yet to be decided where the tigers will be shifted.”

Though forest officials have proposed translocation of tigers, experts said tranquilizing and shifting the big cats will be a challenge. Verma said, “I will request PCCF (wildlife) to conduct a study on viable population of tigers that should remain in Pilibhit. Besides, the study should focus on the impact in the area if the tigers from sugarcane fields are translocated from there and if it will lead to a rise in population of wild boars or nilgai. Besides, we will ask senior officials to take help in the translocation process.”

Officials said tigers were first spotted in Amaria, an agriculture belt, in 2012 when a tigress with three cubs strayed there. Located about 18 km from Pilibhit Tiger Reserve (PTR) and 20 km from Surai range of Terai East forest division of Uttarakhand , Amaria’s sugarcane fields offer a perfect refuge for tigresses for breeding. The reasons: A thick cover of tall cane crop, easy availability of prey and water and complete protection from other male tigers who mostly prey on cubs to be able to mate with their mothers afresh.

It is no wonder that over the years, the number of big cats has increased here.

As the number of tigers has increased here, forest officials fear that if big cats are not shifted elsewhere, it may increase the risk of man-animal conflict. “We have adopted a few precautionary measures to minimize man-tiger conflict. Our forest staff regularly checks on Amaria. Besides, we have been conducting workshops with farmers to make them aware about living with tigers in the vicinity,” said Verma.

Title: Mela management hopeful Kumbh preparations will be completed in time
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Haridwar: The Haridwar Kumbh Mela 2021 administration said it was hopeful that the central and state government will release funds in time for completion of the event’s preparations. The Centre is yet to release funds, while the state has given a part of its share. Contractors, however, are not as upbeat and have threatened to not accept tenders in the future if the present state of affairs continues.

Mela officer Deepak Rawat told TOI on Thursday, “Government orders have been issued for 44 Kumbh works worth Rs.210 crore but the actual amount released is about Rs 80 core. Although no funds have yet been released by the Central government, we are hopeful that adequate grants, in the form of special assistance will be provided by the Centre.”

Chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat recently met the Prime Minister in Delhi and requested Rs 1,000 crore for Kumbh preparations.

In Haridwar Kumbh of 2010, the mela administration had received a grant of Rs.594.46 crore. The Kumbh of 2021 is expected to see a footfall of 15 crore, which is five crore more than the number of devotees who visited the 2010 Kumbh. This time, the management expects a turnout of two crore on the day of “snan” alone.

Contractors said that mela works might not be completed in time due to delay in payments and low availability of construction material. “Construction of eight Ganga ghats and a few roads has already been halted by contractors,” said Contractor Welfare Association president Ved Prakash Gupta.

Gupta added that contractors had to purchase building material from Haryana and Uttar Pradesh and pay the additional price for transportation, as mining in Uttarakhand is closed most of the time. The mela officer, however, dismissed the charges and promised to allay any difficulties contractors might be facing.

Title: Govt to finally consider banana in ‘fruit’ category
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Nashik: State agriculture minister Dada Bhuse on Friday said that the government was planning to give banana the ‘ fruit ’ status so that farmers get the desired subsidy from the state government through their various schemes.

Bhuse said that many farmers were pressing the status of banana to be changed. “The district guardian minister of Jalgaon, Gulabrao Patil, during the meeting, has demanded that the government should take steps to help the banana-growers as they were suffering immensely from the lack of decision. They were not getting the subsidy given by the state government through the various schemes and hence the demand has been made,” he said.

Since 1985, the farmers have been demanding yet the governments have failed to take a step towards it. “Through our agriculture department we will ensure the justice is done to the farmers,” he further said.

The farmers are not only losing the government subsidy in the plantation of bananas but also in transportation as well. “The government also gives subsidy in exporting of the bananas by air and by ship, but the banana-growers do not get even that as the bananas are not included in the category of fruits. As a result, the farmers have to bear the plantation cost, the transportation cost and still provide the fruit at a competitive price to stand in the market,” Dnyandev Mahajan, president of ‘Mahabanana’, the Jalgaon-based state-level association of banana growers.

Mahajan also pointed out that the government has the scheme of taking up plantations of fruits through the Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MGNREGA) in which not only the government offers a huge subsidy but at the same time the government also has a provision of providing labour payment for the ones who are working on the scheme.

The government, on the other hand, believes that since banana plantation has to be done at the most every 2 years – as against the orchards plantation which can go up to eight to 15 years once they are planted, it would be difficult for the government to provide subsidy for the same.

Box:

The state agriculture minister Dada Bhuse said that earlier government had discriminated between Vidarbha and Rest of Maharashtra and Maha Vikas Aghadi was for the overall development of the state. “Earlier farmers from Vidarbha got special treatment for power connections, while the farmers in the other parts of the state were still waiting for power connections and hence resorting to power thefts. We are now changing the picture and ensuring that all farmers get the power connections at the earliest,” Bhuse said.

(Caption Agriculture Minister Dada Bhuse (left), Deputy Chief Minister Ajit Pawar and Jalgaon Guardian Minister Gulabrao Patil at the meeting at Nashik)

Title: Hit by speeding SUV, pedestrian dies
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Dehradun: A 45-year-old man was killed after he was allegedly hit by a speeding SUV near Tunwala Chowk in Raipur police station area in the intervening night of Thursday and Friday.

The woman was identified as Prabha Devi, a resident of East Canal Road. Her husband Ranjit Singh Negi reported to the police that his wife was walking when she was hit by the SUV from behind.

Prabha Devi, who suffered serious injuries in the accident, was taken to hospital for treatment by the family members, but later succumbed to injuries during treatment, police said.

“On the basis of the complaint filed by the family members, police have registered a case under required sections of Indian Penal Code with the Raipur police station,” said an official of Raipur police station.

Meanwhile, police have also launched an inquiry into the accident that led to the death of the resident.

Title: Microbiologist finds link among inflammatory diseases
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Dr P Appa Rao, microbiologist

Visakhapatnam: In 1984, a general practitioner from Bobbili, Vizianagaram, Dr P Appa Rao made an important observation while treating asthmatic patients. Some asthma patients, he noted, who were treated with anti-histamine antibodies were relieved of arthritis pains, which was not why they were receiving treatment.

On applying the same treatment to arthritis patients, he observed that most of them made a full recovery.

Observations over subsequent years showed that a few patients who earlier suffered paralytic attacks, also recovered from paralysis, as well as from arthritis.

Similarly, an arthritis patient with a venous ulcer recovered from both the ulcer and arthritis.

One observation led to another and further research by Dr Appa Rao led to the discovery of a common link among all inflammatory conditions—a biological cycle that is referred to as the histamine vicious cycle.

“This hypothetical central dogma of inflammation is explained better by understanding experiential immunology. The human body has IgEb cell, which produces IgE antibodies. These IgE antibodies attach to mast cells. These mast cells liberate histamine (a chemical released by the immune system),” said Dr Rao.

A former professor at Osmania Medical College, Dr Appa Rao is currently professor and head of the department of microbiology at Andhra Medical College.

“To further explore the science behind my observation, I studied for an MD in microbiology, and undertook two trainings—one in immunology and another in rheumatology. I identified a common biological cycle in all inflammations, called histamine vicious cycle (Rao’s vicious cycle) and applied for patents for about 150 indications. This cycle has a potential role in healing or controlling many physical and psychological diseases such as depression, stress, dementia, autism, arthritis, paralysis, endocrine disorders, urinary, renal and other infections, cancer pain and certain types of cancers,” he said.

At Medical Microcon—a workshop held by AMC on Friday, Dr Appa Rao also presented case histories of many of his patients who recovered from various ailments, based on the hypothesis of a link between various inflammatory diseases .

Title: Gauchar, Chinyalisaur to be air connected with Dehradun in February
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

A chopper would take two trips a day. Rs 4,120 would be the fare for Gauchar and Rs 3,350 for Chinyalisaur. (R... Read More

DEHRADUN: In a major respite to the people living in the hills of Garhwal region, the government is all set to start chopper service to Gauchar in Chamoli district and to Chinyalisaur in Uttarkashi district from February 8. A chopper would take two trips a day. Rs 4,120 would be the fare for Gauchar and Rs 3,350 for Chinyalisaur.

Under the Ude Desh ka Aam Naagrik (UDAN) scheme of the Centre, CM Trivendra Singh Rawat will flag off the chopper services to the two routes — Sahastradhara-Gauchar-Sahastradhara and Sahastradhara-Chinyalisaur-Sahastradhara — from Sahastradhara helipad on February 8.

Aviation advisor to Rawat, Captain Deep Srivastava said that the chopper service is a result of the CM’s efforts. A double engine six-seater helicopter of a private firm would be used for the service.

While Chinyalisaur is around 120 km from Dehradun , Gauchar is 205 km from the state capital. It takes over five hours to reach Chinyalisaur and over seven hours to reach Gauchar, which is famous for the fair it hosts in November. With the chopper services, the journey can be reduced to a mere 30 odd minutes.

CMO sources said that the success of the heli services will motivate them to start choppers for others routes as well.

Dehradun resident Rajesh Purohit said that the chopper service was long overdue and it will be extremely helpful for the people of the two districts in case of any emergency. “Patients are either rushed to Dehradun or Rishikesh and it takes a long time to bring them. The chopper will drastically reduce the time. For others also, it will be extremely useful,” he added.

Title: Praveen Sood: Will make Karnataka cops best cyber sleuths
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Newly appointed DGP Praveen Sood with wife Vinita and daughter Aashita Sood Agarwal after taking charge at the... Read More

Title: Kerala University of Health Sciences to sensitise 1 lakh students on coronavirus virus
Content:
Representative image

THRISSUR: The Kerala University of Health Sciences (KUHS) will sensitize 1 lakh students and other members of academic community in the 320 institutions under it in the state on novel coronavirus (nCoV).KUHS vice-chancellor Dr Mohanan Kunnummel said these institutions are engaged in teaching healthcare related subjects and all of them will be provided with the educative materials on the measures to be taken in the backdrop of the coronavirus infection.All the educational institutions have been advised to conduct at least 10 sensitization programmes in the areas close to them. Noted health activist and former vice-chancellor of Kerala University Dr B Ekbal has agreed to coordinate the sensitization programmes.Kunnummel assured all support of the academic community attached to the university in the efforts to combat spread of coronavirus in the state and for the treatment of the infected patients.

Title: Minister inaugurates upgraded veterinary hospital in Erode
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

ERODE: Animal husbandry minister ‘Udumalai’ K Radhakrishnan inaugurated the revamped veterinary hospital at Velampalayam near Bhavani here on Friday in the presence of school education minister K A Sengottaiyan , environment minister K C Karuppannan, district collector C Kathiravan and other officials. The hospital was renewed at a cost of Rs 20 lakh. The minister also distributed milch cows to 50 beneficiaries.

Addressing the gathering, Radhakrishnan said the state government under the leadership of chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami has been introducing several schemes and projects for the welfare of the people. He said the chief minister would inaugurate Asia’s biggest cattle park at Thalaivasal in Salem on February 9. The park is set up at a cost of Rs 1,000 crore.

The minister said his department had introduced ‘Amma ambulance’ exclusively for cattle. “The ambulance service will be available round the clock and people could reach them by dialing the toll-free number 1962.”

Pointing out that his department had issued 50 electric grass cutting machines to as many beneficiaries at a cost of Rs 7.5 lakh, Radhakrishnan said, “We will issue another set of 210 grass cutting machines to as many beneficiaries at a cost of Rs 45 lakh soon.”

Title: Citizen’s group in Haldwani to collect 1 lakh signatures against CAA
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Nainital: Days after ending its 72-hour-long protest against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and the National Register of Citizens (NRC), locals of Haldwani have decided to collect over one lakh signatures from the people and send them to the President as well as Prime Minister and the Chief Justice.

Speaking to TOI, residents who have formed an umbrella group named Samvidhan Bachao Manch said that they will collect the signature and will also prepare a memorandum explaining why the Act is discriminatory and goes against the very principles of the constitution. “We held a meeting with several residents under the banner and have decided to take the movement forward by garnering support of locals through signatures and also preparing a memorandum,” said Kailash Pandey, CPI(ML) leader.

Pandey added that the memorandum and the signatures would be addressed to the President, PM and CJI. “We want the government to know that people are against the Act as it is against the constitution and it will not be approved by the people. They should listen to the citizens and therefore should repeal the CAA and clear their stance in the NRC,” he said.

The group has also announced that it will hold camps every Saturday to procure the signatures in large numbers. “We will hold camps as well as street plays to garner support against CAA and to also inform the people on why the Act is discriminatory. These camps will be organised every Saturday starting from February 1,” said Irfan Rasool, Imam of the Badi Masjid in Haldwani.

The group had earlier held a three-day dharna in Haldwani during Republic Day which saw active participation of several women and comparisons were being drawn to the similar protest in Delhi’s Shaheen Bagh.

Title: Police start investigation into ragging case at Rims
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Investigation into the ragging incident at Rajiv Gandhi Institute of Medical Sciences ( Rims ), Srikakulam started a day after police registered cases against two students of the college for harassing and beating two juniors.

Since the case is one of ragging and it is alleged that casteism also played a role in the incident—the victims are from the SC and ST communities—the deputy superintendent of police (SC/ST cell) has initiated an investigation, said the inspector of Two Town police station, Srikakulam, who registered the case.

It will be recalled that the complainants, Nitish Kumar and Akshay Kumar, are second-year MBBS students and had allegedly been attacked by two seniors, Rahul Roy and Nagesh Kumar, with cricket stumps on January 24 and 25 in the hostel room of the college.

Srikakulam district collector J Nivas also directed revenue divisional officer (RDO) MV Ramana to conduct an inquiry into the incident and prepare a report. The RDO visited the college campus with a team on Friday and found some empty liquor bottles near the hostel.

Sources said the RDO’s inquiry will focus on what led to disputes.

Title: Four abducted minor sisters, being taken to Delhi, rescued by Haridwar police
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

During interrogation, Pravesh confessed that they had kidnapped the sisters to force them into a begging racke... Read More

Haridwar: Haridwar police arrested two accused who had reportedly kidnapped four minor sisters from a slum colony on Wednesday morning and were taking them to Delhi to force them into a begging racket. The accused duo, which included a minor, was arrested from Roorkee railway station on Friday.

Victims’ father is a daily wage labourer and the family lives in a small hut near Vishnu Ghat under city police station jurisdiction. The girls are aged 12, 8, 5, and 2.

Reportedly, the girls had gone to play at the Vishnu Ghat on January 29 when they went missing. Subsequently, the family approached the police and lodged a missing case. Swinging immediately into action, the police launched a search operation for the missing girls.

SSP Senthil Abudai Krishna Raj S told TOI, “During investigation, we found out that accused Pravesh and his 15-year-old minor accomplice were also missing. They are the residents of Lohani Border, Delhi, but had been living in Haridwar’s slum for six-seven months. A team was rushed to Delhi but they were not found in their homes. Meanwhile, we received information regarding the sisters from Roorkee railway station officials and our team rescued the girls and arrested both the accused.”

During interrogation, Pravesh confessed that they had kidnapped the sisters to force them into a begging racket. The accused first befriended the sisters and then lured them to run away with them.

Title: Jamia Millia Islamia hands over bag of shooter to Delhi Police
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

The proctor’s office surrendered the bag to a police team on Friday evening

NEW DELHI: A day after a young man took out a gun and shot Jamia Millia Islamia student Shadab Farooq in his left hand at a protest march on Thursday, the Jamia administration handed over a red backpack believed to belong to the shooter to Delhi Police.

The proctor’s office surrendered the bag to a police team on Friday evening, which, in turn, handed the backpack and its contents to the Special Investigating Team of the Crime Branch probing the shooting.

Speaking to TOI, Jamia proctor Wasim Ahmad Khan explain how the university authorities had come across the bag. “One of our guards was given the bag by a student who had found it on the Jamia road. The guard brought it to our office,” said Khan. “When no one came to claim it, we looked inside and found a register with the name of the shooter inscribed on it, a participation certificate for a general knowledge competition, a few passport-size photographs of a couple, an accountancy textbook, a necktie of a Jewar school and a wallet.”

When the attention of the university’s administrative officials was drawn to the bag, they had opened it to find not only that its contents included books and certificates bearing the purported name of the shooter, but, according to sources, also a sheet of paper with the words ‘mandir wahin banayenge’ written on it. The sources disclosed that the sheet with the mandir slogan also had two saffron flags drawn on it.

Title: Vasu, aides enter SNDP union office
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Alappuzha: Tension prevailed in front of Mavelikkara SNDP union office on Friday after Subash Vasu and his seven supporters entered the office of the union after breaking the door’s lock.

Vasu told TOI that the eight-member team, including him, had come to the union office on Friday following the Kollam sub-court’s verdict. The charge was taken by secretary Suresh Babu and union president Vasu and other six members.

The Mavelikkara police said that the present union office secretary Rajesh has lodged a complaint with the police on Friday evening after Vasu and his supporters entered the office. “A case will be registered in this connection soon,” said the police.

Kollam principal sub court has ruled that Vasu and Babu could continue with the day-to-day functioning of the Yogam union committee. Principal sub-judge Doni Varghese, however, ordered that they could not take any policy decision.

The court order was on a petition filed by Vasu and Babu challenging the dissolution of their committee and the appointment of Sinil Mundappally as administrator. They have complained that no notice had been issued to them before dissolving the committee.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Crew of 3 ships denied permission to disembark at Paradip port
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Kendrapada: Paradip port authorities have since Monday refused disembarking permission to the crew members of three commercial ships that have sailed through China, Hong Kong and Singapore in the wake of the spread of novel coronavirus. Until now, the deadly disease has killed more than 200 people and infected thousands in China, leading the World Health Organisation to declare a health emergency.

On Friday, one ship was denied permission to allow its crew to disembark in Paradip. The ship is anchored 2 kilometres away from the port area. Dr Prahallad Panda, chief medical officer of Paradip Port Hospital, said, “On Monday and Thursday, crew members of two more ships were prevented from disembarking as the vessels had also anchored in countries hit by coronavirus before reaching Paradip port.”

Port authorities, though, refused to disclose the details of the ships or where they were coming from and how many crew members were present inside.

Sources said healthcare members would screen all crew members of the ships to detect if anyone is sick before deciding on whether to let them deboard. It is learnt that the process to screen the crew members could start on Saturday.

“The measure is being taken to check the spread of the deadly coronavirus that has already reached in 22 countries. Due to that we, too, are on high alert in the port area and have to examine the health of all crew members since they have sailed through the affected countries,” Dr Panda said.

“A special help desk has been set up at Paradip port on Monday to detect if anyone has been affected by coronavirus and to provide information to crew and others about the disease,” he added. An isolation ward has been set up at Paradip Port Hospital to treat any showing symptoms of the disease.

EoM

Title: Make digital payment for gas cylinder
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

SALEM: The Indian Oil Corporation Ltd (IOCL) has introduced digital payment options to refill cooking gas cylinder .

“The cash memo, to be signed by the customer on delivery of the cylinder, has the retail selling price, which is inclusive of the charges for delivering the cylinders,” corporate communication general manager R Chidambaram said.

On booking the cylinder through interactive voice response, customers will be sent an SMS on the registered mobile number with the link for paying online, which will be open for a day. By clicking the link, customer can pay the amount through any of the online payment options including net banking, credit card, debit card or e-wallet.

“Customer need not pay anything during the delivery,” Chidambaram said. “They can also insist on making digital payment at the time of delivery using the mPOS machine, which will be carried by the delivery staff. We support credit and debit cards, e-wallets, BHIM, UPI, Google Pay and Paytm. Cash should be the least preferable option.”

Title: Opposition slams government, says President speech ‘insult to protesters’
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Leader of opposition in Rajya Sabha Ghulam Nabi Azad (File photo)

NEW DELHI: Opposition parties attacked the Modi government for “lowering the dignity” of the President by making him deliver a speech in which the “highly controversial and divisive” Citizenship Amendment Act was listed as among the government’s key accomplishments.

Taking turns to criticise the government over pushing a divisive and polarising agenda through the citizenship law, members of Congress, RJD and Left said the Centre lacked compassion for those demonstrating against the controversial law.

Leader of opposition in Rajya Sabha Ghulam Nabi Azad said, “Today is an unfortunate day. It is expected from the President that he will not praise the government for the problems that afflicts the county. President is the custodian of the Constitution of the country. The Constitution is being affected by the wrong law that the government passed using its majority. His address was like an insult to the scores of people protesting against CAA across India.”

His party colleague Anand Sharma slammed the government for creating fault-lines through CAA. “It is a sad day on which the President of India listed as an accomplishment the attack on the Indian Constitution through the Citizenship Amendment Act. By including the contentious law of CAA in the President’s address, the government has lowered the dignity of the office of the Rashtrapati,” he said.

CPM general secretary Sitaram Yechury echoed Congress’s views and said he was concerned about what was happening in the country. “The government has not even signalled that it wants a dialogue with people protesting against the CAA-NPR-NRC. Instead, we are seeing them resort to state-sponsored violence in front of the police,” he said, referring to the shooting at anti-CAA protesters at Jamia Millia University on Thursday.

Congress’s prime focus of criticism, however, remains NPR. This was reflected in the protests in Parliament and will follow in the coming days. The party will also brief state in-charges and MPs on NPR on February 4. The enumeration exercise is to begin across the country from April. While Congress-governed Rajasthan has announced its non-cooperation on NPR, other states where the party is in office are likely to follow suit.

Title: CBSE exam counselling starts today
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Visakhapatnam: For the 23rd consecutive year, the Central Board of Secondary Education ( CBSE ) will provide free pre-examination psychological counselling to students appearing for the Class 10 and 12 exams this year. The facility is part of the board’s outreach programme.

Counselling will begin from February 1 and continue till March 30.

Options for counselling include interactive voice response on the toll-free number 1800 11 8004. Students, parents and stakeholders can listen to pre-recorded information on exams, including tips for preparation, time and stress management, important contact details of CBSE offices and FAQs.

Another option is live tele-counselling by 95 principals and trained counsellors from CBSE-affiliated schools and which will be available by dialling the same toll-free number. It is a voluntary, free-of-cost service provided by the board from 8 am to 10 pm on all days.

Students can also opt for question-answer columns in which CBSE experts will answer queries through weekly columns in major national newspapers.

Title: HVF guard guns down resting colleague in Chennai
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: A Defence Security Corps guard on duty at the Heavy Vehicles Factory , Avadi, shot dead a colleague just after midnight on Thursday, police said. While the reason behind the killing is yet to be ascertained, police identified the deceased as Gargesh Kumar of Himachal Pradesh and his killer as Nilambar Sinha of Tripura.

At 12.23am, a police officer said, Gargesh Kumar, along with three others, was resting at the guard quarters when Nilambar Sinha walked in. He immediately opened fire with his 5.56 rifle, striking Gargesh multiple times on the body. The other three men immediately ran and hid under some wooden benches before alerting the seniors. Police said Nilambar fired at least seven rounds.

Soon, 10 other personnel reached the scene and surrounded Nilambar, ordering him to drop the weapon. When he complied, they brought him under their control. A police team later arrested him.

Gargesh’s body was moved to the Government Kilpauk Medical College and Hospital for autopsy. The Avadi Tank Factory police registered a case and began investigations. A senior police officer who talked to the accused said he appeared to be under depression and that it could have triggered the incident. “He [Nilambar] joined the force here only three days ago and there seems to have been no enmity between the two,” the officer said.

Personnel of the DSC, who are responsible for providing security at all defence ministry installations in the country and are drawn from various disciplines, are part of the security detail at HVF, Avadi, too.

Police said Nilambar, who was on duty between midnight and 3am, is married and has two children who live with their mother in their native Tripura.

The shooting sent shock waves among staff at the HVF campus. Officials said the place was put on high security as hundreds of defence vehicles, including Army tanks and their components, are assembled and manufactured here.

Title: Dist gets additional funds for hill-stn, stadium
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Nashik: The state government has sanction Rs 425 crore for the district annual plan (DAP) for the year 2020-21, which will be used Igatpuri hill-station development, Shivaji Stadium in the city and boat-club project.

Speaking post the meeting with deputy chief and finance and planning minister Ajit Pawar at Nashik district collectorate, Chhagan Bhujbal said they made an addition of Rs 76.14 crore to last year’s DAP budget.

The Nashik the district is the third-largest district in terms of the population with 61 lakh people and it has 1382 gram panchayats, two municipal corporations, nine municipal councils, and six municipalities. It is also the second-largest district in terms of the area.

“The DAP has been planned to keep in mind the size of the district, population, human development index, rural and urban areas. Accordingly, we (the elected representatives) demanded more funds for the district and the deputy chief minister gave his consent for the same,” Bhujbal said.

The additional funds will help in carrying out various developmental activities in the district. “The most important thing is that additional funds would help the district in constructing and strengthening of other districts roads (ODR) and rural roads (Rs 16 crore). It will also help in construction and maintenance of schools and classrooms (Rs 14.14 crore) and also help in assistance for electrical infrastructure Rs 2 crore,” Bhujbal pointed out.

apart from that, the funds would also be used for the construction of the infrastructure of hill station at Igatpuri (Rs 10 crore), adventure sports training (Rs 1 crore), redevelopment of Shivaji Stadium (Rs 8 crore), Kalagram (Rs 5 crore), Boat Club at Gangapur (Rs 1 crore) and many other projects taking the total to Rs 76.14 crore.

Similarly, Nandubar the district has been sanctioned Rs 115 cr (against Rs 69.57 cr), Dhule Rs 190 cr (against Rs 147.28 cr), Jalgaon Rs 375 cr (Rs 300.72 cr) and Ahmednagar Rs 475 crore (Rs 381.39 cr).

Collectively the plan sanctioned for all five districts stood at Rs 1580 crore against the earlier capping by the government that stood at Rs 1247.82 cr.

(District Guardian Minister Chhagan Bhujbal on the left, Deputy Chief Minister Ajit Pawar listen to demands by MLAs of the district)

Title: People like Imam should be hanged in public and shot: BJP MLA Som
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Meerut: A day after a youth opened fire at anti-CAA protesters in Delhi, BJP MLA from UP, Sangeet Som, said on Friday that people like JNU student ‘Sharjeel Imam who want to break India’ should be hanged and shot dead publicly. Imam has been booked under several cases for allegedly delivering inflammatory speeches against Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) and National Register of Citizens (NRC). He was arrested by Delhi Police from his hometown Jehanabad in Bihar on January 28.

"People like Sharjeel Imam who try to divide the country should be hanged publicly and shot dead. They should not be spared at any cost," the Sardhana MLA Som said. Earlier, Union minister Anurag Thakur had been censured by the Election Commission for a similar utterance during a poll rally in Delhi.

Som's remarks came during his visit to Deoband where thousands of protesters, especially women, from Muslim community have been staging protests for the past three days. The MLA claimed that these protests had been funded by political parties and foreign groups and and a thorough probe will expose the 'conspiracy' behind the protests.

"All these women sitting on dharna have no work to do. They are being funded by political parties and sponsors from abroad. They have no idea what CAA is. I believe the day these protest in Delhi, Deoband, Bareilly and Lucknow are probed, cases would be lodged against these people and they would eventually be sent to jail," Som said.

After April 2019 bombing of a Sri Lanka church, Som, who is also an accused in 2013 Muzaffarnagar riots, had dubbed "burqa" as "symbol of terror". “The black attire that Muslim women wear has become a symbol of terror and is responsible for hundreds of deaths in Sri Lanka," he had said. His comments had drawn criticism from several quarters. Later, BJP had also distanced itself from his remark.

Title: FDI raids eateries selling flavoured hookah, nicotine
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Dehradun: A team of Food and Drug Administration (FDA), on Friday, raided several temporary restaurants and eatery shops along roadside near Dehradun Institute of Technology (DIT) University. During the raid, notices were served to those who were found with flavoured hookah and other nicotine objects like cigarettes and “pan masala”.

Talking to TOI, Yogendra Pandey, FDA inspector, who along with city police, raided the shops said that most of the shops were openly selling cigarettes to students.

“We have found 30 packets of flavoured hookah from Ajay restaurant near DIT. We have also recovered cigarettes and pan masala packets from other temporary eateries near DIT. They were issued a challan of Rs 2,000 under the Cigarettes and Other Tobacco Products Act (COTPA), 2003,” said Pandey, while adding that FDA is stressing on checking the temporary hotels near educational institutions as these are the places which serve addictive things to students.
