The FDA has also cited an order from Dehradun district magistrate C Ravishankar, issued in December last year, in which it was maintained that hookah bars and eatery joints serving nicotine substances should be checked in the city.

Title: Stop smuggling of subsidized fertilizers to Kerala: Farmers
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: The Tamil Nadu Vivasaigal Sangam has petitioned the district collector seeking to stop smuggling of subsidized fertilizers from the state to Kerala.

The association has also asked the district administration to file cases against those caught transporting subsidized manure to other states under the Essential Commodities Act instead of handing them over to the civil supplies department.

Farmers suspect the fertilizers are smuggled to be sold to industries.

“In the last two months, there have been two instances of fertilizers being smuggled to Kerala – one from Coimbatore district and other from Perambalur ,” state secretary of the Tamil Nadu Vivasaigal Sangam P Kandasamy said.

“However, instead of being charged under the Essential Commodities Act, which would have resulted in a jail term, they were handed over to the civil supplies department which levies fines,” he said. “For people who smuggle for profits running into lakhs, only prison can act as a deterrent,” he added.

Farmers said that it was unfair that subsidies which the government gives, with tax payers money, is diverted towards profit making traders.

“Unsubsidized urea will not be bought by farmers even in Kerala, so the urea is being smuggled to industries which require urea, like chemical manufacturers, corroborated sheet manufacturers among others,” said the petition. “It is happening only by traders tying up with some agriculture department officials,” it added.

Farmers said that they have also written to the agriculture produce commissioner and appealed to the district collector to closely monitor subsidized fertilizer distribution in the district and its movement near the borders.

Title: Kalakshetra’s move to nix permission for book launch unfortunate: TM Krishna
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Carnatic vocalist and social activist TM Krishan

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Carnatic vocalist and social activist TM Krishna has termed the decision by Chennai-based Kalakshetra Foundation to withdraw permission for the official launch of his new book ‘Sebastian and Sons: A Brief History of Mridangam Makers’ on its premises, as extremely unfortunate.

“I believe Kalakshetra lost a wonderful opportunity to be a part of the attempt to celebrate the lives of Mridangam makers. It’s their loss,” he said here on Friday at the Ka - Mathrubhumi International Festival of Letters, the event which witnessed the release of the book.

Kalakshetra withdrew permission for the launch after Krishna published excerpts from the book, which dealt with beef-eating practices from Vedic period and the killing and skinning of cows for making Mridangams played by Brahmins. The foundation pointed out that the content of the book would instigate political, cultural and social disharmony, and asserted that as an institution under the Union ministry of culture, it has to keep away from such controversies.

However, the official launch will be held at Asian College of Journalism in Chennai at 6.45pm on February 2, said Krishna while announcing the change of the venue.

“I see this book as a celebration of people, celebration of Mridangam makers, a celebration of so many generations over decades spread across South India . It’s a complicated book. It’s going to be a book which will trouble people of privileged classes, especially Brahmins. It’s going to be uncomfortable,” he said.

“But I don’t see a problem in anything I have said in this book. These are things we need to think about. For me writing this book was also questioning myself and not just other people,” he added.

Title: Animal adoption scheme at IGZP proves successful
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Visakhapatnam: As part of Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR), an IT company adopted a white tiger at the city’s Indira Gandhi Zoological Park (IGZP) under the animal adoption scheme.

Some individual donors also adopted various animals on the occasion of World Zebra Day.

CitYzen, the CSV (Creating Shared Value) arm of a Vizag-based IT products and solutions company, adopted the two-year-old white tiger named Balu for a year and contributed Rs 1.9 lakh towards the adoption. “We urge philanthropic individuals and companies to come forward and adopt as many animals as possible from the zoo to support its operations and help in conserving endangered species,” said director and CSV head at the company.

Individual donors also adopted various animals, which included pythons and a Royal Bengal Tiger.

Inspired by the adoption programme, students of AMG School, Bheemili contributed Rs 5,930 towards the adoption of zebras at the event.

Title: DMC takes feedback of 54k locals on civic facilities
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Dehradun: The Dehradun Municipal Corporation (DMC) has collected feedback from around 54,000 residents regarding the condition of civic amenities in Dehradun. Friday (January 31) was the last day for the DMC officials to collect feedback. During the exercise, officials also urged the residents to download the Swachhata App. Officials from each department of the municipal corporation were deployed to conduct the drive.

“We have completed our drive aimed at collecting feedback from Doonites. Feedback of around 54,000 people have been collected and we also urged residents to download Swachhata App. We deployed around 12-14 teams. Each team had 5-6 members to collect feedback from public. The feedback has been positive and we covered all the wards of the city during the drive,” said DMC commissioner Vinay Shankar Pandey.

Notably, a team from the Centre will come to Dehradun very soon to mark the city on the basis of selected parameters for the Swachhata Survey, 2020.

Also, Friday was the last day for the residents of the new 32 wards to avail an extra 5% discount on the commercial property tax payment. The DMC had given a discount of 25% on commercial property tax but from February 1, 2019, a discount of 20% will be available on commercial property tax for the new 32 wards. A discount of 20% on property taxes is available for the residents of the 68 old wards until February 15, 2019.

“It was the last day for the residents of the 32 new wards to avail an extra 5% discount on commercial property tax. As of now, we have collected Rs 25 crores and we are very confident of achieving our target of Rs 50 crores by the end of the current financial year,” said Pandey.

Notably, the residents of the 32 new wards are exempted from paying residential property tax for a period of 10 years (until 2028). Notably, the DMC had previously set their property tax collection target at Rs 75 crores for the current financial year, but later reduced it to Rs 50 crores.

Title: Cousin kills 15-year-old boy in M’nagar
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Muzaffarnagar: A 15-year-old boy was allegedly shot dead by his cousin in Muzaffarnagar's Kharpod village. His body with two bullet injuries was recovered from a field on Friday. He had gone missing on Thursday. According to police sources, the incident was result of a property dispute.

The deceased was adopted by his family 15 years ago. The boy’s father Chandrapal stated in his complaint, “On Thursday my brother's son, Lalit came to my house and asked my son to come for a ride on his bike but they did not return till late night. When I enquired about my son, my brother Jaipal said that Lalit had killed my son.”

On Friday morning, a search drive to find the boy was launched by family members and villagers and soon after his body was recovered from a farming field in the village.

After getting information about the incident, area police rushed to spot and sent the body to postmortem house. A case under section 302 (murder) of the Indian Penal Code has been registered against accused Lalit and his father Jaipal at Kakroli police station. Superintendent of police (Rural), Nepal Singh, said, “Raids are being conducted to arrest the accused.”

Title: Maharashtra: SSC students to get hall tickets from today
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representartive image

NASHIK: The state board for secondary and higher secondary education has released the hall tickets of the SSC students (Class X) for the March 2020 board examinations and those are available online at www.mahasscboard.in from February 1.

The board has directed all the headmasters and principals of higher secondary schools to download the hall tickets from the “school login” section of the website and start distributing them. The Maharashtra board examination of Class X is scheduled from March 3 to March 23, 2020.

The circular released by the board on Friday directs all Class X students, parents, teachers, headmasters and secondary schools to make a note of the instructions.

“The hall tickets are available at the board website through school login from February 1. The school administration is required to download them and distribute among the students,” the circular from the board stated.

According to the circular, the schools are not to take any fee against distribution of the hall tickets. “The hall tickets are to be printed, stamped and signed by the headmasters of the respective schools. If any technical error occurs, the school is supposed to contact their respective board’s divisional office,” the circular stated.

The school should rectify the error pertaining to the photograph, signature or student’s name, and inform the board’s divisional office regarding the same by sending a copy of the rectified hall ticket to them immediately.

If the photograph of the student is defective, a corrected photograph is to be stuck on the previous one and get it duly signed by the headmaster.

If a student loses his hall ticket, the school concerned should reprint it and write ‘duplicate’ on top of it with red ink before handing it over to the student, stated the circular.

Title: College diktat draws students’ ire, principal says it’s for their good
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Dehradun: Authorities of Dehradun ’s one of the oldest and only girl’s college, Mahadevi Kanya Pathshala (MKP) college have issued a unique diktat for its students that states that there would be disciplinary action against them if they were found taking selfies on the terrace.

The diktat also mentions that if the students have free time, they should go to library and study. The diktat comes weeks after the higher education minister mooted an idea of conducting student poll to ban mobiles in classes.

“All students are being informed that they are requested not to climb to the terrace of the college and if any student is found taking selfi on the terrace, the college will take disciplinary action against her. Go to the library instead in spare time,” the circular reads which was issued on January 29.

While college authorities cited reason of security of students, the students feel that the circular is derogatory. The diktat has irked the students who feel that they have all the right to decide what they want to do when they are free. After drawing criticism from the students, the college authorities made correction in the circular which reads, “If anyone is found on terrace taking selfie or doing anything….,”

“Nowhere in the circular is it mentioned that the terrace is dilapidated. The circular could have clearly said that it could be risky to climb on to the terrace rather writing that don’t go there to take selfies and go to library during free time. The circular is derogatory, it seems as if all girls are taking selfies in college rather than studying,” said a final year student who did not wish to be named.

Maneesha Rana, president of MKP students union said that the college administration is thinking about the welfare of the students as girls make Tiktok videos on terrace which could turn fatal at times. “People may find the language of the circular weird but the message is correct. They should study and should never climb on to the terrace as the college building is too old and this may lead to any accident,” she added.

Talking to TOI, principal Rekha Khare said, “Our college has no boundary wall on the terrace. Students go there to take selfies and there are ample chances for mishaps. Students are unhappy with the circular as they know that they do waste time. College is a place for studies and if they want to soak in the sun, they can go to the garden.”

Title: Foresters prevent villagers from killing leopard but fail to capture it
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Bijnor: Forest officials on Friday managed to prevent farmers from killing a leopard they had spotted in a field. Though the leopard eluded capture, the foresters team set up a cage and two camera traps at Dharampura village under Haldaur police station area, 14 km from the district headquarters.

After spotting the leopard, villagers armed with lathis and sharp objects surrounded the field with the intention to kill it. The forest department arrived in the nick of time after someone informed them. They took charge of the situation.

This winter, leopard sightings have increased in Bijnor. Over the past two days, a leopard each was killed in a road and train accident. Earlier, a leopard was beaten to death by villagers after it mauled a student to death in Bijnor’s Bhogpur village in Najibabad tehsil. A few days ago, villagers had surrounded a big cat at Fatehpur Sabhachand village.

Since November 27, six people have been killed in leopard attacks in the district, instilling fear among villagers.

To prevent another ugly man-leopard confrontation, a forest team rushed to the scene and laid the net around the field where the big cat was spotted. The newly formed forest task force installed a cage and set two cameras in the area,

Despite a seven-hour operation, forest authorities failed to catch it. But they mollified the villagers.

Talking with TOI, a village elder, Dharamveer Singh, said, “Leopard fear can be seen on the faces of villagers. They will spend the whole night wide awake to detect its presence. Forest authorities must capture it.”

According to sub divisional forest officer Hari Singh, “We got a tip-off that some villagers had cornered a leopard in a sugarcane field at Dharampura village. Our team reached there and laid a net around the farm and put a cage in the field with a goat tied inside as bait to lure the big cat. Cameras were also installed. Initially, the animal was seen running from one side to another. Then, it escaped from the field under the cover of darkness. Efforts are on to catch it.”

Title: Condition of girl, suspected for coronavirus, improving: AIIMS
Content: Dehradun: Authorities of All India Institute of Medical Sciences ( AIIMS ) Rishikesh, on Friday, said that the condition of the MBBS student who was admitted in the hospital with symptoms of coronavirus has shown remarkable improvement. The institution is now waiting for the test reports of 21-year-old girl from Pune Institute of Virology.AIIMS public relations officer Harish Thapliyal told TOI that the patient, who is pursuing medicine in China, has been kept under observation in the isolation ward. “Her condition is improving. We are awaiting her medical reports from Pune,” said Thapliyal.Meanwhile, the authorities of health department also conducted a review meeting on the deadly coronavirus, which has claimed over 200 lives across the globe and was declared as a pandemic by the World Health Organisation (WHO) on Friday. The meeting was attended by both government and private hospital representatives who informed the health department about their preparedness regarding the tackling of coronavirus cases.“The private hospitals were informed about the protocol they are supposed to follow in coronavirus cases. They had to inform the health department and government immediately and the patient should be kept in isolation,” said Dr Pankaj Kumar Pandey, in-charge health secretary. He added that anyone who is suffering from cough, cold, and respiratory issues and has visited China after January 15 should be treated as high priority cases.Director General (DG) health, Dr Amita Upreti told the authorities of Indian Medical Association (IMA) that no private lab is authorised to detect coronavirus and hence people should be informed regarding the same. “The private institutions must not disclose the identity of the patient which too is a part of the protocol,” she added.

Title: 5 dead, several feared trapped as explosion rips apart cracker factory in UP’s Shamli
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Muzaffarnagar: A massive explosion ripped apart a fire cracker factory in UP’s Shamli district on Friday afternoon leaving at least five persons dead. Three women were also among the dead. The impact of the explosion was so massive that the entire building turned into a big pile of rubble within second, police said.

A rescue operation was on till the last reports came in and the rescuers, with the help of earth movers, were removing the debris of the factory in Kandla area on Delhi-Saharanpur road.

The owner of factory, 57-year-old Intezar Ahmed was also among the dead. The others were Naresho Devi, Sarswati, Neelima and a youth, Shenki. According to locals, there were several other workers in the factory at the time of explosion. Several fire engines were also pressed into service to douse the fire which had engulfed the debris.

District magistrate and senior police officers were also rushed to the factory. All the five persons pulled out from the factory were decaled brought dead to hospital, police said.

District magistrate of Shamli, Akhilesh Singh, said, “As many as five dead bodies have been recovered from the spot. We are now searching the entire area of the factory.”

Superintendent of police of Shamli, Vineet Jaiswal, said, “Rescue operation is on, debris is being removed. It was a licensed factory and situated outside of the residential area. An investigation is being conducted to find the reason behind the explanation.”

Title: BJP govt snatching rights of local bodies: Congress
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Dehradun: Opposition Congress accused the ruling BJP of robbing local bodies of their authority after the state government moved to bring an ordinance that would enable it to shut down any slaughter house in the state. Congress contended that the state was encroaching on the municipal corporation’s department.

Congress state chief Pritam Singh said, “Finally they have taken a decision and it is against the local bodies of the state.” He also said that the move was not required.

Notably, the construction of a slaughter house in Manglaur, Haridwar district had brought the two parties at loggerheads. The project had been approved by the previous Congress government in the state, amid protests from BJP legislators like Swami Yatishwaranand and Sanjay Gupta. Congress legislators, including Qazi Nizamuddin, had supported the decision.

Commenting on similar lines, Congress vice president Surkyakant Dhasmana said, “If such acts continue, the role of civic bodies will be greatly reduced in the future. It appears to be a planned move to push the agenda of the ruling party.”

Title: Madras HC seeks government counter on plea for CBI probe into TNPSC scam
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Madras high court has directed the state government to file a counter on a plea seeking CBI inquiry in the Tamil Nadu Public Service Commission (TNPSC) group IV exam scam. I Mohamed Razvi, a resident of Ramanathapuram district, stated in his petition that lakhs of candidates had appeared for the exam conducted in September 2019. After the results were published, TNPSC filed a complaint before the CB-CID director general of police on a suspicion that 99 candidates had indulged in malpractice to clear the exam.

He stated that based on the complaint, a probe was ordered by forming special teams. The CB-CID sleuths arrested a few people in this connection and found that the candidates involved had used pens with evaporative ink to mark answers which were subsequently corrected by corrupt officials. Most of the candidates involved in the malpractice appeared at select centres in Ramanathapuram district and some even secured ranks within the top 100. He submitted that if such candidates get jobs then genuine candidates would lose their opportunity to get employment. Since there were possibilities of higher officials being involved in the scam, the CB-CID, which is a state agency, would not be able to bring them under probe.

The CB-CID sleuths have arrested only some candidates and middlemen. Since only a CBI probe would ensure free and fair investigation, the petitioner moved the HC Madurai bench seeking the same. When the case was taken up for hearing on Friday, the state government submitted that the investigation was on the right track and sought time to file counter.

Title: HC dismisses plea to conduct Big Temple consecration in Tamil
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Observing that no special status has been given to Sanskrit and due prominence is given to Tamil language as per agama principles as done in earlier years, the Madras high court has dismissed petitions which sought to perform the consecration ceremony of Brihadeeswara Temple (Big Temple) at Thanjavur in Tamil.

A division bench of justice M Duraiswamy and justice T Ravindran passed the order while hearing a batch of petitions seeking to conduct the consecration of the temple in Tamil. The judges observed that the petitioners have come forward with the petitions only on the ground that the ceremony which is to be held on February 5 would not be conducted in Tamil and the same would be conducted only in Sanskrit.

In the counter affidavit submitted by the Hindu religious and charitable endowments (HR&CE) department it was stated that importance is given to Tamil language in the practices adopted during the ceremony and it would be performed both in Tamil and Sanskrit as per agama dictum and as followed during the previous years.

The judges also cited that as pointed out by the temple authorities, the petitioners have not placed any reliable and convincing proof other than barely mentioning that the ceremonies have been conducted exclusively in Tamil according to the agama principles by King Raja Raja Cholan I, who had built the temple.

The judges further rejected the claim of the petitioners that the fire accident which took place during 1997 occurred only due to violation of agamas by performing the ceremony in Sanskrit, citing that there is no connection between the accident and the rituals performed at the temple.

Since it was stated in the counter that dhanam or gift is not confined to any particular community and it is distributed to all the people involved in the ceremony irrespective of caste or creed, the court does not find any infraction of the provisions of the Constitution, as alleged by the petitioners, the judges said.

“By considering the above said factual matrix, we (judges) are of the considered view and opinion that the court should be hesitant and reluctant to interfere with the religious practices, unless a strong case has been made out and established that the religious practices and functions of the temples are violative of the provisions of the Constitution,” observed the judges.

Hence, the judges dismissed the petitions and directed the authorities concerned and temple authorities to file a compliance report on the conduct of the ceremony within four weeks after the completion of the ceremony.

Title: Ashish Srivastava made Doon’s DM
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Dehradun: In a bureaucratic shuffle, the state government has appointed Ashish Kumar Srivastava as the new district magistrate ( DM ) of Dehradun. Kumar, who is also the Additional Secretary to the chief minister; Vice President of the Mussoorie-Dehradun Development Authority, and the CEO of the Dehradun Smart City Project, will continue his service in these capacities as well.

C Ravishankar, the former DM of Dehradun has now been made Haridwar’s district magistrate. He was made Dehradun’s DM in June, last year.

Meanwhile, Haridwar DM Deependra Chaudhary has been kept in the waiting list.

Title: Maharashtra: Onion glut at Lasalgaon, 70% drop in average wholesale price
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: The onion supply at the Agricultural Produce Market Committee (APMC) at Lasalgaon has doubled in January compared to what it was in December last year.

According to APMC officials, around 4.35 lakh quintal of onions were auctioned at Lasalgaon APMC in January against 2.37 lakh quintal auctioned in December.

The rise in supply of onions has also led to a drop in the average wholesale price of onions by almost 70%. From Rs 8,625 per quintal on December 16 last year, the average wholesale price recorded at Lasalgaon APMC on Friday was Rs 2,600.

The minimum and maximum wholesale price was recorded at Rs 1,200 and Rs 2,932 per quintal respectively. Around 22,000 quintals of onions were auctioned on Friday.

The unseasonal rainfall in October last year had badly affected the kharif onions. Fresh kharif onions usually arrive from mid-October. However, the delay in the arrival of showers during the retreat of monsoon delayed onion plantation. Moreover, 75% of the plantation had got rotten due to the continuous rains between August and September last year. This led to a shortage of onions in December last year.

However, despite all these factors, upto 45,000 hectare of area is under late kharif onion plantation as against the average plantation area of 30,000 hectare. “Usually, supply of late kharif onions begins in December. The arrival of late kharif onions was also delayed by a month. The arrival of onions began in the first week of January and the supply has now picked up at large,” said APMC officials.

In retail markets, good quality onions are being sold between Rs 30 and Rs 40 per kg.

“There had been a scarcity of onions in the last three months, which significant increased the wholesale onion prices. Onions have started arriving at the markets in almost all the onion-growing pockets in the state. The supply has increased as compared to the demand. This is the reason the wholesale onion prices have dropped significantly in the last one month,” said Bharat Dighole, president of Maharashtra Onion Growers Association.

Title: Cured, but waiting for social acceptance
Content:
Over three acres on the campus of Institute of Mental Health Sciences at Erragadda have been earmarked for the... Read More

A HALFWAY HOME IS A RESIDENCE-CUM-SKILL UPGRADATION CENTRE WHERE PROGRAMMES ARE RUN TO HELP THOSE WHO’VE RECOVERED FROM MENTAL ILLNESS IN THEIR TRANSITION TO INDEPENDENT LIVING. HERE ARE A FEW CASE STUDIES:

Ramulamma | 24 years

Sukku | 45 years

Vishnuvardhan | 49 years

Vijaya Kumari | 45 years

HYDERABAD: Yashwanth Kumar, 40, was admitted to the Institute of Mental Health Sciences at Erragadda in Hyderabad four years ago. A patient of schizophrenia , he was roaming on the streets of Khammam when police took him into custody and the district court referred him to the hospital at Erragadda.He was cured and reunited with his family in Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh, in February 2019. It wasn’t easy to trace his residential address and contact the members of his family, because Yashwant could only remember that he was from a place in Lucknow.However, not all the patients who have been treated of schizophrenia (a long-term mental disorder) are as fortunate as Yashwanth. There are about 130-odd patients, including men and women, who have been cured of their mental illness but either their families are not willing to take them back or some of them do not remember anything about their home.For such people, the Telangana government, in compliance with Supreme Court directions, is constructing a halfway home where they will be trained to help them get jobs and join the mainstream. Over three acres on Erragadda campus has been earmarked for the halfway home. The state government is set to complete its construction by this March.M Umashankar, superintendent, Institute of Mental Health and social worker Padma took special interest in tracing Yashwanth’s residential address.“We searched on Google and zeroed in on major commercial establishments and showed it to Yashwant. Finally, were able to contact his family members with the help of Lucknow police. The joy of his family members knew no bounds,” Umashankar told TOI.Yashwant was a farmer and went missing 17 years ago. His daughter was three years old when he went missing from home. She was 20 when he returned. Though cured of his mental illness, Yashwant does not remember how he reached Khammam. Doctors at the Institute of Mental Health said he could have boarded trains and got down at Khammam while he was mentally unsound.“There are several families who have refused to take back their family members though they have been cured of their mental illness. There are various reasons such as social stigma attached with the person or history of nuisance created by the patient. Some families could have moved on in life while others want to stay away from the additional responsibility of taking care of those people who have been cured. There can be various other socio-economic reasons too. We try to counsel them and send back as many as possible by reuniting them with their families,” said Umashankar.She wants to go back home and take care of her three daughters. But her husband, Ravi, an auto driver, is not willing to take her back. “If not my husband, my daughters will come for me after they grow up. I had run away as my husband used to beat,” Ramulamma said.“The Anantapur magistrate referred her to the institute in 2014, and she was cured in one-and-half-years,”said R Padma, a social worker at the institute. The hospital authorities contacted Ravi after Ramulamma gave them the name of her village in Karnataka.But Ravi doesn’t want to take her back.Guntur district court referred him to the institute in 2013 and within a year he was cured. But he only remembers that he is from Bihar. “I don’t remember anything about my family except that I don’t have parents,” he said. Doctors at the institute said Sukku takes care of other patients. Though the court ordered his rehabilitation, Sukku refused to go to any rehabilitation home.He stopped taking food and protested peacefully for 15 days till hospital authorities withdrew the plan to shift him to a rehabilitation home.He is a father of two daughters and resident of Kalwakurthy. His wife, Sharada, has stopped taking calls from the hospital authorities. He used to beat up his wife following which she had gone to the local police. When the cops took him into custody for questioning, he allegedly beat them up and escaped. “I am a changed man now. I am sure that my wife and daughters will come for me,” he said.Social worker R Padma said his wife had initially promised to take him back but now don’t take calls either.She was referred to the institute by the Kurnool district magistrate in 2013 and was cured in 2015. Now, she wants to stay with her daughter. She recalls the name of her father as Subbanna and her husband as Venkat Swamy. She also remembers that her husband is a labourer. Though not clearly, she says her son died when he was very young. However, neither does she remember the name of her village name or her state. “She helps other inmates. She suffers from mild hearing impairment,” said social worker R Padma.

Title: Nashik Metro gets head start with CM seeking funds from EIB
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Nashik: Chief minister Uddhav Thackeray on Friday urged the European Investment Bank (EIB) to fund the Nashik metro project , more popularly known as the ‘Metro Neo’ project.

Thackeray urged the banking institution after the Maha Metro and the EIB signed an agreement in his presence for disbursement of Rs 1,600 crore for the Pune metro project in the first phase.

The chief minister seeking funds from the EIB for the Nashik metro project has laid to rest speculations that the new Maha Vikas Aghadi government may oppose the project.

Managing director of Maha Metro Brijesh Dixit told TOI that Thackeray was very positive about the Nashik metro project.

“The state government has already approved the detailed project report of the Nashik metro project and sent it to the Centre for its approval. The Centre has sought some clarifications, which will be complied with by the state government,” said Dixit.

“The European Investment Bank is satisfied with the metro projects being executed by Maha Metro. The bank has responded in the affirmative about providing funds for Nashik metro project,” said Dixit.

The total cost of Nashik Metro project is Rs 2,100 crore of which Rs 1,465 crore will be raised through loans. Both the State and the Centre will contribute Rs 307 crore each.

The state government’s contribution of Rs 307 crore is to be shared by Nashik Municipal Corporation, CIDCO and MIDC. The civic administration will have to bear Rs 103 crore. Moreover, NMC will have to provide space at three locations for the depots of Nashikk metro.

The rubber-tyred AC electric coaches with a capacity to carry around 300 passengers will ply on two elevated corridors stretching upto 32km.

One elevated corridor, which will be 22km long, will have 19 stations and stretch from Gangapur via Satpur colony, Central Bus Stand and Dwarka to Nashik railway station. Another 10km long elevated corridor with 10 stations will stetch from Gangapur to Mumbai Naka.

Apart from the two elevated corridors, there will be two feeder routes with a total length of 24km. Feeder buses operating on batteries will ply on the feeder routes and also on the elevated wires.

Title: Chamber hails CM’s scheme for industrial units
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Madurai: The Tamil Nadu Chamber of Commerce and Industry (TNCCI) has hailed the new direct consent to operate (CTO) scheme announced by chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami on Friday, which enables industrial units operating under the “green category industries” (with pollution index between 21 and 40 fixed by the ministry of environment) to obtain faster clearances from the government to commence operations.

TNCCI president N Jegatheesan said that under the scheme, green industrial units will get certification of the agricultural department in 30 days and reclassification of land for industrial purposes will be completed within 50 days as against the present time frame of six months to two years sustained by the entrepreneurs for completion of such processes.

If the approval is not received within the time limit, it will be considered as deemed approval and industrial units can go ahead with the project work. This efficacious initiative will largely benefit industrial units, especially in micro, small and medium industry sector in the state.

With the country witnessing downward trend in industrial production and sliding GDP growth rate, the present initiative by the government to remove one of the main obstacles faced by the industrial entrepreneurs will go a long way in setting up of more such units and additional employment generation. He said the chief minister’s visionary outlook and proactive initiative is laudable and would benefit many.

Title: Bengaluru: Volvo driver suspended for slapping biker
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

A video grab of the BMTC bus driver manhandling the biker in Mahadevapura.

BENGALURU: Bangalore Metropolitan Transport Corporation (BMTC) on Friday suspended a Volvo bus driver after he was caught on camera repeatedly slapping a two-wheeler rider for allegedly coming in his way in Mahadevapura on Thursday.

The bus (KA 57F822) was plying on route 500D (Central Silk Board-Hebbal) when a man astride a bike (KA53 EF 7538) with a woman on the pillion allegedly moved from one edge of the road to the other, blocking the bus. The driver screamed at the two-wheeler rider and got out of the vehicle. He later slapped the biker. The man and woman were not wearing helmets.

The incident was shot by Hamid K, a passenger on the bus, who uploaded a 45-second video on Twitter. The post went viral. “This horrible incident happened today morning on my way to office dis morning. Does BMTC personnel have the rights to take law into their hands and beat up a private citizen in public? (sic),” Hamid tweeted.

In the video, Hamid is seen confronting the driver, Santosh Badiger, from Hebbal BMTC depot, over his action. In response, the driver continues his unruly behaviour and goes on to threaten the passenger. “Who are you to ask? You should speak in Kannada,” the driver is seen shouting back.

Hamid is seen replying in Kannada that he too can speak the language. Responding to Hamid, BMTC tweeted: “Regret the inconvenience caused. Taking note of this, serious action will be initiated against the erring crew (sic).”

Later, Hamid told TOI: “The two-wheeler rider didn’t overtake the bus. He crossed the road in front of the vehicle. The bus was about to move and the driver stopped it almost immediately.”

BMTC managing director C Shikha said, “The driver was a trainee. An investigation has been launched and he has been placed under suspension pending inquiry. Such incidents will be taken seriously and disciplinary action will be taken any such employees.”

However, a BMTC source said, “According to the driver, the two-wheeler rider was speeding and would have hit the bus. He was scared he may lose his job in case of an accident.”

Further, Hamid tweeted: “We need safer Bengaluru roads. Please see this incident and think about necessary corrective actions. The biker crossed over the bus. It caused the aggressive driver to stop the bus in the middle of the road and manhandle the biker. A few BMTC drivers drive as if they own the roads. Safer roads are a bigger responsibility of bigger vehicles (sic).”

Responding to a tweet, police commissioner Bhaskar Rao wrote: “This is institutional road rage, could you share location, law and order police will take immediate action.”

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Madras HC seeks governments’ reply on plea to facilitate return of Tamils in China
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: Madras high court has directed the central and state governments to file a counter on a plea which sought to facilitate the safe return of Tamil people who are stranded in China following the coronavirus outbreak M Samayaselvam, a resident of Madurai and state secretary of the youth wing of Tamil Nadu Construction Workers Union in his petition stated that the association works on assisting Tamils working abroad for their safe return to India in case of any mishap or any untoward incidents.Following the outbreak of coronavirus in China, he has been receiving several phone calls from the Tamils including students who are presently in China. He said that they are in fear following the outbreak and though they want to travel back to their homeland, they are unable to return due to quarantine regulations.Hence, he moved the high court Madurai bench seeking to direct the authorities concerned to provide medical treatment for Tamils affected by coronavirus in China and also sought to facilitate their return.When the petition was heard on Friday, a division bench of justice M Duraiswamy and justice T Ravindran gave the direction to the central and state governments and adjourned the case to a further date for hearing.

Title: Testing time for family after neighbours panic
Content:
Representative image

Testing only at govt labs

BENGALURU: A family of five living in a Bannerghatta Road flat is in the eye of the coronavirus scare gripping the city. The family had recently visited China, raising concerns among other dwellers of their apartment complex.Following an alert sounded by the apartment residents, a team of doctors from the health and family welfare department visited the complex on Thursday night, but the family was not willing to meet them and shut their doors on the visitors.On Friday, an ambulance with staffers was sent to counsel the family and take them for testing. The family finally agreed and went to Rajiv Gandhi Institute of Chest Diseases (RGICD).“They had not travelled to Wuhan, but to another province in China. They returned on January 23 and were screened at the airport too. On Friday, as a precautionary measure, their sputum and blood samples were taken for testing. They don’t have fever or respiratory infection. One of them has gastrointestinal issues,” said Dr Deepak UG, nodal officer, coronavirus isolation ward at RGICD.Meanwhile, 12 people with travel history to China have tested negative for coronavirus. Only one man’s test results are awaited. He is the only patient in the isolation ward of RGICD.While the government has chosen four private hospitals in Bengaluru for admission of suspected persons with travel history to China, their blood and sputum samples will have to be sent to government-run labs.A lab at Bangalore Medical College and Research Institute (BMCRI) and a branch of National Institute of Virology located near RGICD are the only two authorised for testing.

Title: Pondy job fair to fill 323 vacancies in private firms
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Puducherry: The Puducherry labour department will conduct a job fair on February 8 to fill 323 vacancies in firms like Whirlpool, Supreme Industries, Be Well Hospitals and Kalavinka Training Academy. The vacancies are in the Puducherry units of the firms.

The job fair will be held from 9am to 1pm on the premises of the employment exchange.

Candidates aged below 35 years with qualifications like BE/B Tech, diploma, B Pharm, general nursing and midwifery (GNM), BSc (operation theatre), BSc (nursing) and ITI can attend the job fair. Those who have passed Class XII and Class X can also attend it.

The selected students will be offered a salary package ranging between Rs 7,800 and Rs 25,000 per month.

The candidates should bring their resume and original certificates and their copies, said additional secretary (labour) cum director (employment) E Vallavan.

Title: 2 men threaten protesters with a Jamia repeat in Bengaluru; detained
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Participants at the nightlong protest against the Jamia firing and CAA, at Maurya Circle in Bengaluru.

BENGALURU: Two miscreants on Thursday night threatened students in the city who were protesting the firing incident near Delhi’s Jamia Millia Islamia, telling them they would meet the same fate as the injured student.

A minor had opened fire at students protesting the Citizenship (Amendment) Act near the Delhi varsity, injuring one. The Bengaluru incident took place at Maurya Circle, where the nightlong demonstration against the Jamia firing and CAA began around 7.30pm. By 11pm, the number of protesters reduced to 30 but the group decided to stay back after getting the news of another alleged attack on women and Jamia students by Delhi police.

According to Adrian, a student who was at the scene, the small group of protesters stayed within a barricaded area on the road, chanting slogans, singing patriotic songs and playing music. “While we were raising anti-CAA slogans, two men from among us began shouting pro-CAA slogans. The duo was unknown and when we looked at them, they quietly moved away,” said Adrian, adding they were drunk and returned after a few minutes.

Saqib Idrees, another student protester, said the duo began to issue verbal threats. “They threatened us in Kannada that they would repeat the Jamia incident in Bengaluru,” said Saqib, adding the duo also taunted them saying ‘it’s not CAA down down, but you all will be brought down’.

When the students questioned the miscreants, cops stationed at the spot detained the duo. “Police were very cooperative. Almost 20 personnel were with us till 5am,” said Saqib.

Meanwhile, a friend of the duo watched the drama from a distance and approached the protesters to apologise on their behalf. “He said they belonged to the working class and FIRs would destroy their lives. He apologised to us and we decided to let the matter go. After all, we are Gandhians,” added Saqib.

Adrian said though the two men were drunk, their threats exposed their ideology. After the duo was detained, the students continued their protest till 5am and dispersed after singing the national anthem.

According to High Grounds police, the men are bank employees and were detained for disturbing the protesters at Maurya Junction. “They are from Andhra Pradesh and work in a PSU bank in the city. One of them is set to get married in February. He had thrown a party for his other friends for the same reason. The duo was drunk when confronted by the protesters. We booked a case of public nuisance and let them off after a warning,” police said.

STUDENTS’ DEMANDS

Resignation of Union home minister in the wake of Jamia firing as Delhi police are answerable to him

Arrest of minister Anurag Thakur for hate speech, in light of which the incident took place

Strict action against minor who opened fire

Title: Banking services in twin cities hit as employees go on strike
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Services at nationalised banks in Hubballi-Dharwad were hit owing to a strike by the employees

Dharwad: Many people who lined up at some of the ATM kiosks in Dharwad on Friday returned disappointed as there was no cash to dispense at these centres. Although functioning of ATM kiosks was unaffected, by and large, the lack of cash at some of the facilities was a sign of the impact that the strike called by bank employees had on everyday financial activities in the city.

Responding to a call given by the United Forum of Bank Unions (UFBU), an umbrella body covering the employees’ unions of nine banks , officials and other personnel went on strike on Friday thereby bringing activities at these commercial hubs to a grinding halt. The protesting employees gathered at the main branch of the State Bank of India in Dharwad and raised slogans demanding fulfillment of their demands, which include a hike of 20% on payslip components, reduction of the number of working days in a week to five, shelving of the new pension scheme and incorporation of special allowance with the basic pay.

The protesters said that they had been waiting for a hike in salary since November 2017. “But the central government has failed to respond to our demand. That is the reason we have decided to strike work to bring some pressure to bear on the Centre,” they said.

Activities at banks are expected to be affected on Saturday as well with the strike continuing for another day.

Meanwhile, in Hubballi, employees of nationalised banks gathered in front of the Union Bank of India branch near Dr BR Ambedkar Circle to protest against the central government’s failure to acknowledge and fulfill their longstanding demands. The protesting employees warned the Centre of launching a three-day stir in March and an indefinite agitation in April should their demands continue to be ignored.

Title: Conduct indirect election for Thiruppuvanam union: Plea
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Madurai: Madras high court has directed the state government to file a counter on a plea which sought to quash the order that postponed the indirect election for Thiruppuvanam panchayat union in Sivaganga district for the second time, anticipating law and order problem.

In the petition, S Subbiah, a resident of Sivaganga district, and a DMK member, said he was elected as ward 12 councillor of Thiruppuvanam panchayat union.

There are 17 wards in Thiruppuvanam and DMK and its alliance has a majority with six DMK and two Congress councillors’ while there are only three AIADMK councillors. Since the DMK has majority, the officials had postponed the indirect election, which was scheduled on January 11, anticipating law and order problem.

Later, the election was scheduled on January 30. However, it was postponed based on an order passed by the district collector, after the ruling party members submitted a representation stating that they are facing life threat.

Hence, he moved the high court Madurai bench seeking to quash the order which postponed the indirect election and sought the state election commission to notify indirect election for Thiruppuvanam union by appointing an independent district election officer and by providing adequate police protection. tnn

Title: Funds sanctioned for renovation of hall in Meenakshi temple
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Madurai: The Tamil Nadu government has sanctioned Rs 18.10 crore for the renovation of the Veeravasantharayar mandapam in the Meenakshi Sundareswarar temple, which was destroyed in a fire two years ago. Work on the renovation process is expected to begin soon.

In a statement, chairman of the board of trustees of the temple, Karumuttu T Kannan said the government had sanctioned the funds to renovate the mandapam. The entire hall has been documented in detail and work drawings have been prepared based on the documentation works.

Leading sculptors in Tamil Nadu and experts from IIT Madras would work in coordination to restore the ancient mandapam, ensuring that aesthetic appeal is not affected.

Stones for the work are to be obtained from the quarries in Pattinam village in Rasipuram block in Namakkal district, for which the Tamil Nadu government had given permission for the same. Work is expected to be initiated soon and completed within a time frame of two years, he said.

The 400-year-old Veera Vasantharayar mandapam, situated in the temple’s east side, is spread over an area of 7,000sqft. It has many beautifully-crafted statues and pillars. The fire on February 2, 2018 destroyed the mandapam, resulting in many of the pillars developing cracks, and the roof of the mandapam suffering damage. It has been two years since the public have not been allowed to go near the damaged structure. There have been several demands to renovate the structure immediately.

Title: MNGL to provide CNG for 200 city buses by March-end
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Nashik: Maharashtra Natural Gas Ltd ( MNGL ) on Friday said that they will provide compressed natural gas (CNG) for 200 city buses by March-end.

According to MNGL officials, CNG stations will be operational at six locations in the city. These locations have been leased out by the Nashik Municipal Corporation ( NMC ).

MNGL’s promises came during a joint meeting of officials from MNGL and NMC. Mayor Satish Kulkarni and NMC’s standing committee chairman Uddhav Nimse were present during the meeting.

“We are launching city bus service from April 1 with 200 CNG and 50 diesel buses that will be deployed in phases. MNGL will lay 103km pipeline from Mhaskal-Titwala and has agreed to make CNG available through tankers by March-end,” said Nimse.

Initially, MNGL will transport liquefied natural gas (LNG) through tankers to the city and then convert it to CNG. LNG will be transported by roadways from the nearest import storage location (Dahej) and will be stored in containers in Nashik.

The six locations identified for the proposed CNG stations include Adgaon, NMC’s fire brigade station in Panchavati, Truck Terminus at Chehedi, Pathardi, Tapovan and Sinnar Phata. MNGL has already signed a lease agreement with the NMC for first four sites while agreement for the remaining two sites — Tapovan and Sinnar Phata — will be signed within a week.

Once the feeder pipeline between Mahaskal-Titwala and Nashik is laid, the LNG station would be decommissioned since natural gas would be transported from the transmission pipelines through the feeder pipelines.

NMC plans to operate 400 buses through private agencies. Of these 400 buses, 200 will be CNG-operated, 150 will be electric and 50 will run on diesel.

The bus service will be operated on GCC (gross cutting contract) for a period of 10 years. This includes purchasing new buses, maintenance, employing drivers, fuel expenses, among others. The private agencies will be paid on kilometre basis.

The municipal corporation has already finalised three agencies to operate all 400 buses in the city.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Palani temple collects Rs 3 crore as offering in 21 days
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: The Palani Dandhayudhapani temple hundi collection has grossed Rs 3.29 crore this season, one of the highest in recent times.

The temple, which earns the highest revenue in the state witnesses lakhs of devotees from across the nation and other countries during the pilgrimage season between December to January and in March every year.

School children, temple employees, and volunteers were involved in the counting process for the last two days. On Thursday, it was declared that the temple had received Rs 3,29,72,400 in past 21 days. People had also donated 1,010g of gold in the form of ornaments and coins and 41.330g of silver. Nine hundred and thirty eight foreign currency notes were also received. The chief executive officer the temple, Jaya Chandra Banu Reddy, assistant commissioner Senthil Kumar among others were present.

Meanwhile, nearly 10 lakh people are expected to visit the temple for the ‘Thaipoosam festival’ which falls on Feb 8. The district administration and temple authorities have been taking steps to provide basic amenities to during the festival from Feb 2 to Feb 11. In a meeting among the district administration, HR&CE, transport department, police and fire service it was decided that 11 permanent ‘kavadi’ mandapams, 12 general resting halls, and 48 free bathrooms and toilets would be established for the benefit of the pilgrims. Eight permanent shelters and 43 temporary shelters have been installed to take rest. Steps have been taken to combat power shutdowns. Three hundred workers have been appointed to facilitate tonsuring of hair in seven spots near the temple.

Title: Madurai: From Saturday, rank your city on ‘ease of living’ index
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Residents can visit the website Eol2019.org to register their feedback on various topics covered.

MADURAI: Residents of Madurai city can participate in the ranking of 114 urban local bodies based on the Ease of Living Index , a first of its kind ranking process for cities launched by the ministry of housing and urban affairs ( MoHUA ), starting Saturday. Citizens who have spent at least six months in the city, can rate various services and amenities provided to people by agencies such as municipal corporation, district administration and police department.

Madurai corporation officials said the window to rate the city will be open between February 1 and 29. The civic body is taking various measures to popularize the activity to involve more people by means of social media promotion and advertisements through various mediums including outdoor advertising. In all, 100 smart cities and 14 more cities with million plus population are taking part in the ranking, they said. “We have received a communication from MoHUA with a detailed information on publicity measures which need to be taken by the corporation. There are clearcut guidelines on various activities to promote citizen participation in the exercise. Corporation will scrupulously follow all the guidelines and start promotional activities at the earliest,” corporation commissioner S Visakan told TOI.

Residents can visit the website Eol2019.org to register their feedback on various topics covered. There will be at least 24 questions covering health, environment, safety, green cover, power supply, financial services, air quality, opportunity to eke out livelihood, cost of living and quality of life, women safety, entertainment features, transportation, affordability of commuting, education, drainage and drinking water, officials said.

MoHUA had launched Ease of Living Index to rank states in 2018 in terms of infrastructure and governance. This time, the Centre has turned around the exercise to gauge how the cities are faring in governance, liveability and planning. The results of the survey will help officials understand the perception of citizens on various issues, the officials said. With the citizen feedback for Swachh Survekshan 2019-20, which started on Jan 4 completed by Friday, they are gearing up for the next survey. The corporation will increase its activity on social media in order to popularize the survey.

Title: Services hit as PSU banks go on strike
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Nashik: Banking services in the district were paralysed on Friday with over 15 public sector banks with over 350 branches went on a two-day strike to demand revision of salaries.

However, private banks such as HDFC Bank and ICICI Bank functioned normally. Major banking services like cheque clearance, deposits, withdrawal, NEFT and RTGS were suspended due to the protest.

The strike, called by the All India Bank Employees’ Association (ABEA), was supported by eight other bank unions under the aegis of the United Forum of Bank Unions (UFBU). A total of 2,500 bank employees are participating in the protest.

Sources in the banking sector said business transactions worth Rs 500 crore were affected as cheque clearance and banking transactions across all branches in the district were hit.

“Clearance of over 25,000 cheques worth Rs 200 crore could not take place due to the strike. Moreover, banking transactions like withdrawal, deposits of the public sector banks totally worth Rs 300 crore were also affected,” added the sources .

Some of the demands of public sector bank employees are a 20% pay hike with effect from November 2017, five-day week, merging special allowance in basic pay, an increase in family pension and no changes in terms and conditions of the services of bank officials and employees.

Title: Two children killed in house collapse in Ramnad district
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

The deceased have been identified as B Jagadeeswaran and his brother Vishwa from Podhuvakkudi village. They we... Read More

MADURAI: Two siblings aged 10 and 8 years were killed when their house, which was in a dilapidated condition, collapsed while they were sleeping. The incident took place in a village near Paramakudi in Ramanathapuram district in the intervening night of Thursday and Friday. Their mother suffered injuries in the incident.

The deceased have been identified as B Jagadeeswaran and his brother Vishwa from Podhuvakkudi village. They were studying in a primary school in the same village.

According police sources, the boys’ father Baskaran, a private company employee in Chennai was not at home. His wife B Rekha, 40, had gone to sleep along with their two sons after finishing their supper on Thursday night. The concrete roof of the house suddenly caved in and fell on the three. While two boys were killed on the spot, the mother suffered injuries and was shifted to a nearby hospital.

A police team from Emaneswaram station rushed there and conducted an inquiry.

A police officer said the house was constructed using lime and mortar in the 1960s. There was no maintenance work carried out to ensure the stability of the house. Although the house was visibly weak, the family continued to live under it.

The bodies of the boys were shifted to the Paramakudi government hospital, where postmortem was conducted.

A case was registered under CrPc Section 174- suspicious death and a detailed inquiry was under way.

Title: ‘Namma Madurai’ to help raise residents’ social consciousness
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Madurai: ‘Namma Madurai’ a two-day event to highlight various facets of the city and to improve social consciousness of the residents on environmental issues will be held on Saturday and Sunday.

Various events like kabaddi, marathon for kids, cleaning activity, pattimandram (debate), fun street and a star-studded entertainment programme have been planned on these two days. The event is organized jointly by the Madurai Corporation along with Radio Mirchi. Talking to reporters, corporation commissioner, S Visakan said the events are planned in such a way as to improve the social consciousness of the city residents, while keeping them entertained through various fun-filled activities. Social consciousness has to improve to support the endeavours of the corporation in turning the city into a clean and safer one.

“Overall cleanliness of the city has been improving day by day and one can see the visible changes. However, it can be improved more with the cooperation from the residents. We have been conducting cleanliness drive once in a fortnight to keep the Vaigai river clean, but garbage gets accumulated. Cleanliness can be maintained only when people too chip in and play their part,” Visakan said.

Corporation has been taking various measures to curb pollution of Vaigai river. It includes sewage treatment plant at Alwarpuram, underground drainage construction covering 15 wards to the north of Vaigai. There is a comprehensive project in the pipeline to deal with sewage water in southern of the city, the commissioner added. On Saturday, a kabaddi tournament will take place between 9am and 6pm in Race Course, Kiddathon at 6am, Vaigai river cleanup drive at 3pm involving 1,200 people including 600 corporation employees and Pattimandram judged by Solomon Pappaiah. Fun street at Teppakulam has been planned on Sunday.

Title: Rajasthan govt to tag cattle to develop e-market
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

File pic of a cow tagged on the ear

JAIPUR: To develop a market for the cattle and increase the income of the cattle herders, Rajasthan animal husbandry department has launched a new scheme to develop an e-market.

To develop this e-market, the department has started tagging the animals to collect data, to be saved in the website. The workers of the department will go door to door, to tag the animals on ear and collect all the information required. The information will contain – breed, past diseases, milk quantity, vaccination and price.

Joint director, animal husbandry Umed Singh said, “To create a database of the animals, it is important to collect such information. At first, we have launched this scheme in Jaipur district. Later, other regions of the state will be joined.” The main objective of the department is to increase the income of the cattle farmers in the state and they have been working on the upliftment of it. After the process is complete, the farmers will be able to sell their animals from the website. The buyers can log on to the website, choose the animal of their choice and can then bid on them. Recently, Rajasthan animal husbandry department along with Rajasthan Agriculture Competitiveness Project (RACP) started a programme in which they have started tagging goats, wherein their information will be collected and uploaded on the website.

The department has also started a mobile app called ‘Rajasthan Goat’ where the goats can be auctioned. The government has created Pisangan Mahila Bakri Palak Producer Company Ltd (PMBPPCL) in Pisangan with a group of women shareholders, who will run the project.

Title: Maternity centre won’t be shifted; protesters upbeat
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Madurai: There was good news on Friday for the residents of Palanganatham, who had been on a month-long protest against the shifting of the maternity centre which had been functioning there for 70 years. Minister for cooperation Sellur K Raju met the protesters accompanied by officials led by corporation commissioner S Visakan and promised to fulfil their wish.

The minister said that the maternity centre will continue to function at Palanganatham with the required facilities and doctor as well as nurses will be made available round the clock. Following the assurance, the people thanked the minister and corporation officials. The maternity centre has been functioning on 1.5 acres of the sprawling campus of the primary health centre. Residents said it was used by a large number of pregnant women from Palanganatham and surrounding areas. However, officials started neglecting the centre in the past two years and three months ago delivery services were stopped and shifted to Pykara a few kilometres away.

Residents say that an additional building was constructed 10 years ago at a cost of Rs 35 lakh, but it was not utilized. After the maternity and delivery services were shifted, only outpatient treatment is being provided at Palanganatham. P Jothibasu, 50, who spearheaded the cause for the last one month, said, “At Palanganatham, the centre had bigger space and was easily accessed by a large number of people. There was no reason to shift it and merge with Pykara urban primary health centre.”

A former functionary of CPM, Jothibasu had quit the party recently after its leaders did not take up the issue when he approached them, said Jothibasu, who was born at the maternity centre. The corporation commissioner told TOI that medical services will continue at the centre. The required man power will be deployed and adequate drugs stocked, he said.

Title: BJP's election manifesto lacks vision, will end free schemes in Delhi: AAP
Content:
Arvind Kejriwal

भाजपा के मैनिफ़ेस्टो से साबित हो गया कि अगर आपने उनको वोट दिया तो आपकी फ़्री बिजली, फ़्री पानी और फ़्री बस यात्रा… https://t.co/9tDkGbKpCq — Arvind Kejriwal (@ArvindKejriwal) 1580471951000

NEW DELHI: AAP on Friday dismissed BJP’s manifesto as a “jumla patr”, with chief minister Arvind Kejriwal claiming it was clear that voting for the saffron party would mean an end to free electricity, water and travel in bus for women. Kejriwal urged people on Twitter to vote thoughtfully.Complete coverage on Delhi electionsAAP MP Sanjay Singh said the manifesto had no vision on issues like safety of women, education and health. He called BJP’s promise to stop sealing a “tall claim”, adding that the party could have already done so by now, as it was in office in the Centre.“It is a bundle of lies... This manifesto clearly says all welfare schemes will be discontinued: 200 units of free electricity, 20,000 litres of free water, free bus ride for women and the scheme for accident victims will all stop,” Singh alleged. He claimed that it wasn’t a manifesto, but “a scheme to completely ruin the lives of the people of Delhi”. Singh said BJP’s promise to open new schools was laughable. “BJP governments in MP, UP and Haryana have shut down several government schools,” he claimed.AAP also dismissed BJP’s promise to implement Ayushman Bharat Yojana in Delhi. “People whose monthly income is Rs 10,000 or more will not benefit. In Delhi, the minimum wage itself is Rs 14,000,” Singh said. He hit out at the promise of making Delhi cleaner, saying despite BJP running the corporations for 13 years, the sanitation situation had not improved.
