After all, the situation remained unchanged between July 2018 and January 7 this year,” a senior judge said.Interestingly, the jail administration changed its stance on Saturday and challenged the application for a stay, arguing that the death-row convicts could be hanged separately. Earlier, before Delhi high court , it had conceded that the rules forbade separate execution of the convicts sentenced to death in the same case.The trial court, however, rejected this argument and partially agreed with advocate AP Singh, the counsel for the three convicts — Pawan, Vinay and Akshay — that their legal remedies were yet to be exhausted.In Video: Nirbhaya case: Delhi court stays hanging of convicts till further orders

Title: Coronavirus: Centre readies 250-bed facility in Alwar district
Content:
Officials from Centre inspect ESIC Medical College Hospital on Friday.

ALWAR: The Centre has formed a 250-bed isolation-cum-observation centre here for Indians who are scheduled to be airlifted from coronavirus-hit Wuhan city in China. The isolation centre is readied at the Employees State Insurance Corporation (ESIC) Medical College Hospital. Necessary logistical support has been installed in the hospital under the supervision of the Union ministry of health and family welfare (MOHFW) officials in the last two days.Three such centres are being readied across the country, including Indo-Tibetan Border Police Force (ITBP) Hospital (Manesar) and Director General Armed Force Medical Service (DGAFMS), Delhi. Officials said that over 2,500 Indians, mostly students, are being airlifted from China in two batches. The first batch will arrive in the wee hours of Saturday, while the second batch will arrive on February 2.“The newly constructed ESIC Hospital is located on the outskirts of the city and it is barely 130-150 km from the international airport in Delhi. It makes it convenient for the authorities providing any emergency assistance to the suspected persons,” said an official.Medical commissioner (MOHFW) R K Kataria told reporters in Alwar that close to 2,500 normal Indians will be evacuated from China. “They will be quarantined first at ITBP and DGAFMS. Thereafter, the suspected persons will be brought to Alwar for 14 days observation. Those who show no signs of the carnivorous will be released only after 14 days. If any person tested positive will be treated as per the ministry guidelines. The ministry has made all preparations including doctors, to deal with the number of patients,” said Kataria.Off total, 250 persons are expected to be quarantined in Alwar. The capacity of beds at the hospital can be extended up to 500 on need basis, confirmed officials. The hospital is newly constructed state-of-art with a cost of Rs 850 crores.The national carrier, Air India has departed for China this afternoon from Mumbai and will bring first batch on the wee hours of Saturday. The second flight is expected to depart on Saturday afternoon. India has been on toes since one student from Kerala, who is a student in Wuhan has been tested positive to virus in Thrissur.

Title: Activists term dvpt approval at Jayprabha site ‘illegal’
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Kolhapur: A delegation of film activists and corporators on Friday claimed that the approval given to develop the open space of Jayprabha Studio is illegal.

The delegation led by activist Sanjay Patil and senior corporator Surekha Shah met additional commissioner Nitin Desai terming that the city heritage conservation committee (HCC) to a private developer is wrong.

Patil and Shah stated that a resolution has been accepted by the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) to declare the studio and the site as grade 3 heritage building and accordingly it has been included in the heritage site list. They claimed that even the Bombay High Court has given the verdict that the site is a heritage structure. The studio is owned by veteran singer Lata Mangeshkar.

Patil said that the report given by the HCC is wrong. “They have ignored that the site is declared as a heritage of grade 2. A developer has approached the town planning department seeking development permission on the site of the studio. We allege that the members of the committee and the officials of the department have nexus with the developers. They all are trying to sell the land keeping everyone in dark. We demand that as per the development plan, the site should be developed into a garden and no non-film activities are permitted in there.”

Senior corporator Bhupal Shete claimed that the developer has sought Rs 21 crore from the KMC if the land is to be kept undeveloped. “After our opposition, the civic administration is considering various ways to save the land of 3.5 acres. As per the law, the developer cannot develop anything on the land. We will oppose any proposal which will be brought before us in the general body meeting which will lead to encroachment on the site declared as heritage one,” said Shete.

The activists threatened to hold the street agitations if the KMC’s GB approves the proposal which is at present before civic chief Mallinath Kalshetti for consideration. The town planning department can table the proposal in the GB only after Kalshetti’s approval.

Title: Sun rays cover Mahalaxmi idol on first day of fest
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Kolhapur: The festival of rays ( Kirnotsav ) started from Friday, saw sun rays covering entire Mahalaxmi idol in its full glory at 6.17 pm at the temple.

The festival witnesses sun rays falling directly on the deity’s idol at the time of sunset. This phenomenon takes place twice a year -- between November 9 and 11 and between January 31 and February 2.

Milind Karanjkar, associate professor of astrophysics at the city-based Vivekanand College, who has undertaken a study of sun rays, its intensity and possible hurdles, said the idol saw ray intensity of around 35 lux in the sanctorum, which was more than enough to cover the deity’s idol. The minimum intensity requirement is at least 15 lux.

“There were no pollutants or cloud cover, which would obstruct the rays. Hence, the festival witnessed one of the most beautiful views on Friday. The illegal constructions and obstacles removed consistently by the Pashcim Maharashtra Devsthan Samiti (PMDS) and the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) played an important role,” he said.

According to the PMDS officials, for the devotees’ convenience, LED screens have been installed at the Mahalaxmi temple premises, which will function throughout the festival. Hundreds of devotees witnessed the event live in the temple premises on Friday.

It has to be noted that hundreds of devotees crowd the temple to get a glimpse of the architectural marvel, where rays steadily reach the sanctorum of the temple on particular days of the year. The festival is celebrated when the sun rays fall directly on the deity’s idol at the time of sunset.

Title: Karnataka braces for likely cut in share of central taxes
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: There are strong indications that the 15th Finance Commission will reduce states’ share of tax devolution, a prospect that would adversely hit Karnataka, which is already reeling from a shortfall in central grants due to the state.

State finance department sources say, due to the economic slowdown, there is a strong likelihood of the 15th Finance Commission headed by NK Singh, recommending a drastic cut in states’ share from the divisible pool of taxes. The panel’s recommendations are applicable for the next five years beginning 2020-21.

While the exact percentage decrease is unknown, sources say devolution is expected to decrease by 6% — from 42% to 36%. This will have serious consequences on growth in the state as it will lose about Rs 30,000 crore over the next five years.

It may be recalled that the 14th Finance Commission had increased tax devolution to states from the central divisible pool from 32% to 42% for the five-year period 2015-2020. As a result, Karnataka, which had a 4.7% share in the divisible pool of Rs 39.5 lakh crore — the total tax collected by the Centre — receivable Rs 1.9 lakh crore.

"The irony is that Karnataka, despite its good performance on the economic front and achieving targets on tax collections, is poised to suffer a fund crunch," said a senior finance department official. "Since the shortfall will be felt over the next five years, we will have to make corresponding cuts in expenditure. Both welfare schemes and developmental works are bound to suffer."

The 15th Finance Commission has already submitted its first report to the Centre and it is expected to be tabled in the Lok Sabha during the budget session that began on Friday. "The commission’s job is only to make recommendations. It is up to the central government to accept or disregard it," said Kota Ravi, joint secretary of the 15t Finance Commission, while declining comment further on the issue.

Domain experts and economists also pointed out that projected GDP growth of

6%- 6.5% in the economic survey presented on Friday may do more harm than good for the state. "Anything between 4.5 % and 5 % would have been realistic. Considering this, the total amount of the divisible pool of taxes is expected to be way below what is expected and the cut in devolution would be an added problem. The state will suffer," said BDA Satya Babu Bose, executive director of Budget Centre and Governance Accountability.

M Govinda Rao, member of 14th Finance Commission and a member of the advisory council of the 15th Finance Commission, said he fears growth estimation may lead to conflict between the Centre and states in the next five years.

"Both the Centre and states must rely on realistic estimates when they prepare their budgets. While overestimates are reasons for the current shortfall, the reports about reduction in tax devolution are worrisome as it would add to the crisis," said Rao. "I hope [Union finance minister] Nirmala Sitaraman addresses these issues in her budget on Saturday."

Title: Nirbhaya Case: Trust in courts is eroding; Nirbhaya’s mother
Content:
Nirbhaya’s mother Asha Devi

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

NEW DELHI: Nirbhaya’s mother , Asha Devi , broke down after a trial court on Friday deferred the execution of the four convicts till further orders. She said the courts were destroying the trust that she had reposed in them over the years. “I don’t have a big problem with the hanging date being postponed, but I have a problem with how the lawyer of the convicts behaved with me today after the order was passed. He challenged me and said, ‘yeh faansi anantkal ke liye tal gayi (this hanging has been delayed till eternity)’,” a tearful Devi told TOI.Devi said she wanted the courts, Delhi government and the Centre to see what had transpired on Friday. “Day after day, they make us face the rapists. I am in court since 10am. If all they had to do was postpone the hanging, then what was the need for them to keep us waiting? They could have just told us what the order would be so that we could have gone home. We have been waiting for justice for seven years. And above all this, their lawyer challenged us openly,” she said.Devi accused the governments of giving the convicts a chance to exploit the loopholes in the system.“All this because they are men. Did my daughter not have any rights?” she asked.Devi said despite everything, her fight for justice would continue till the convicts were hanged. “These convicts have no right to live. The system keeps disappointing us...but I won’t back down,” she said.In Video: Nirbhaya case: Emotional mother lashes out after hanging postponed

Title: Gorakhpur man first to die of swine flu in Uttar Pradesh this year
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

LUCKNOW: A 41-year-old man has died of swine flu in Uttar Pradesh — the first death from the deadly H1N1 virus in the state this year. The patient from Gorakhpur died while undergoing treatment in Lucknow on January 24, but the death was confirmed seven days later on Friday.

Ironically, the patient’s report for H1N1 confirmation came on the day he died while undergoing treatment for bilateral pneumonia at a private medical facility in Lucknow.

The death was confirmed by the swine flu control unit in Lucknow district. “We have sent a letter to Gorakhpur health department to register the death in their records as swine flu death of that district,” said in-charge, swine flu control unit, Lucknow district , Dr Manoj Yadav.

However, joint director communicable diseases Dr Vikas Singhal said, they were yet to receive a death audit of the patient.

“There has been no swine flu death so far and we are yet to receive an audit of the Gorakhpur patient. If that is true, this will be UP’s first swine flu death this year,” Dr Singhal said. The patient was admitted at a private hospital in Gorakhpur on January 16 after he complained of fever and breathing problems. As his condition deteriorated, doctors referred him to KGMU, but he was put on ventilator at a private hospital in Mahanagar area on January 22.

Director of the private hospital, Dr BP Singh told TOI, “Patient came to us with bilateral pneumonia— an infection of both lungs. His condition was critical since the tiny air sacs in lungs were filled with fluid and puss. We tried to stabilize him, but his condition kept deteriorating.”

“Simultaneously, we also sent the patient’s blood samples to PGI’s lab for swine flu testing. As per the report received on January 22, he tested H1N1 positive,” he added.

Meanwhile, a second positive case of swine flu was reported in Lucknow on Friday. The patient is a seven-year-old girl from Daliganj area of Lucknow. The girl had visited the KGMU OPD following flu-like symptoms on Thursday and was detected with swine flu. A pregnant woman had also tested positive to the deadly virus in the city last month.

Title: AMC schoolteacher molests Class VII girl
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Ahmedabad: Vadaj police on Thursday filed a complaint of molestation against a 40-year-old schoolteacher for allegedly molesting an 11-year-old Class VII student, at the Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) School No. 3 on Tuesday.

In his FIR with Vadaj police, the victim’s father states that the accused, Ashwin Patel, used to pass lewd comments about his daughter and he had earlier made a representation to the school principal, Malti Patel.

Rather than acting against the teacher, Malti told the victim’s father to take his daughter and enrol her in some private school. The victim’s father then told Malti to issue his daughter’s leaving certificate, but she told him that she could not do so during the academic year.

On Tuesday, the girl told her father that Ashwin had molested her during the recess and had bitten her cheek. “On Tuesday, Ashwin had been sent to a primary teachers’ training programme. As it was his birthday, he went to the school to give the children sweets. When he found girl alone during the recess period, he molested her,” the father stated.

Though the girl was scared as Ashwin had allegedly threatened to kill her parents, she still told them about the incident. Her father then raised the issue with Malti, but she still did not act against Ashwin, the FIR states.

A Vadaj police official said the schoolteacher was charged with molestation, causing hurt and criminal intimidation, along with charges under the POCSO (Protection of Children from Sexual Offences) Act. Ashwin is at large.

Title: Beliaghata baby's death: Cops let off caretaker
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: Baren Gayen, caretaker of the apartment , where the 34-year-old Sandhya Maloo had allegedly murdered her two-month-old son, has been let off after questioning but kept “under scrutiny”.

Police sources said there was discrepancy in the caretaker’s statements. Initially, he had claimed that he was cooking at the rear end of the house and had not seen the woman dump the baby’s body in the manhole near the main gate of the apartment. Later, Gayen changed his statement, saying that he was present near the spot but had not seen the woman with the baby’s body. The police have also completed interrogating Sandhya Maloo’s family members in the past 48 hours.

“We have recorded the formal statements of her husband Sudarshan, father-in-law Hemant and mother-in-law Madhu. There were certain issues, for which we needed clarity. We could not speak at length initially as they were in extreme shock. Madhu has hinted that Sandhya had been avoiding to attend to her daughter in the past couple of weeks before the crime. We will now speak to the two lone residents of the apartment, who were in their flats at the time of the crime,” said a police officer.

Police sources said that the forensic experts, who recreated the scene of the crime, have also sent some clarifications. “We will reply to the queries. The chargesheet will focus only on the murder — the scene of the crime and the fact that Sandhya was the only one inside the house at that point of time. The forensic reports are expected to be prepared in the next few weeks,” said the officer. Police sources said that Sandhya has all along been a soft spoken person. “She has clamoured up and psychiatrists have asked us to ensure that she relaxes a bit. Then, she might open up more. We are seeking expert opinion and asking the family to explain what financial constraint (a claim of the family) led her to abort her child two months ago. We will speak to the doctors who have treated her. We have allowed her to interact with her eight-year-old son a couple of times,” said the police.

Title: Madras HC miffed at its 3 ex-judges who took part in rally
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Madras high court

CHENNAI: It is unfortunate that three former judges of the Madras high court participated in a ‘ protest ’ organised on Thursday inside the court premises without permission, the first bench of the high court said while requesting the security committee of the court to take up the issue urgently.

The issue pertains to a ‘peace rally ’ organised by a group of advocates on January 30 on the occasion of Mahatma Gandhi’s death anniversary, which is observed as Martyrs Day. Though the advocates called it a peace march, the deputy commissioner of police, high court security, in his report to the registrar-general of the court, termed it as ‘unauthorised assembly and procession’.

“On January 30, at 10.30am a group of advocates including Vaigai, Sudha, Subha, Girirajan, Milton, Bharathi, Parivendhar and retired high court judges Justice Haribaranthaman, Justice Kannan and Justice Akbar Ali assembled near Aavin parlour, walked in procession to North Gate via Kuralagam, reached B2 Esplanade Gate, entered inside and finished at Dr Ambedkar statue. They were stopped and advised for their unauthorized activities. But they refused to listen to the police officers who were on duty,” the report said.

Referring to the report, the first bench of Chief Justice A P Sahi and Justice Subramonium Prasad said: “Having noticed the report, what is of more concern is that the incident involves and names three former high court judges of having entered the premises and joined the protest that was going on.”

The gravity of the incident, therefore, puts on guard the entire judicial system, as this may have a large impact on the future security measures that may be required to be undertaken by the high court. The incident, therefore, requires an immediate concern to be taken up on the administrative side, it said, adding: “We, therefore, request the security committee of the court to take up the matter urgently along with its suggestions and report the matter back for taking appropriate action on the judicial side or otherwise by the next date fixed.”

The bench issued the directions while hearing the suo motu plea initiated a few years ago for providing Central Industrial Security Force protection to the court premises.

Title: 99% data migration done: SUK
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Kolhapur: The Shivaji University, Kolhapur ( SUK ) on Friday claimed that 99% migration of students’ data has been completed.

Earlier, during the senate meeting, it was revealed that academic details of students that were available with Maharashtra Knowledge Corporation Limited (MKCL) have been migrated back to university systems.

“There have been more than 2.5 crore entries related to the academics from the year 2007 to 2015 with the MKCL. The exam-related work from the said period was then managed by the MKCL, but from 2015 onwards, the university has taken over the work with the help of its IT cell,” GR Palase, acting director of Board of Examinations and Evaluation at SUK, said.

Notably, the university after taking over the exam work had to face many issues in data migration which often resulted in glitches and pending results for many students. And the data was migrated gradually over a period of four years.

“When data of some students could not be fetched resulting in withholding of their result, the university managed to get their data from various sources including their college and MKCL authorities,” an official from the varsity said.

“Such students were often given provisional admission until their data was fetched. With the migration of the data now, it won’t pose many issues to the university or the students,” he added.

Another SUK official said that the university has decided to take over the exam-related work as the issues with the MKCL were on the rise back then in 2015. The senate information stated that information verification was done by the IT department.

The Shivaji University, Kolhapur (SUK) is one of the prominent state universities in South-western Maharashtra with 293 affiliated colleges across Sangli, Satara, and Kolhapur districts.

Title: Tamil Nadu to study, amp up urban transportation
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Urbanisation in the state stood at 48.5% in 2010 and it only grows with each passing day

CHENNAI: In a bid to better public transport, the state transport department has embarked on a study to understand the status of urban transport with the support of private experts. It comes against the backdrop of transportation demand being largely met through private modes, leading to slowing vehicle movement speed and higher travel time.

The state has been witnessing rapid urbanisation in recent decades resulting in high travel demand and rapid growth of private transport modes. The consultant has been engaged to look into increasing share of private vehicles, falling share of public transport, inadequate/ unsafe last mile connectivity and pedestrian/ non-motorised transport infrastructure to provide better services to commuters. In Chennai, the average vehicle movement speed fell from 30kmph to 19kmph from 1993 to 2017, and even peripheral roads suffer. “The primary purpose of the government is to promote public transport in a big way. The survey is going to give a bird’s eye view on the status of transportation. It will tell us about the areas where we do well and the ones where we need to do better,” transport secretary B Chandra Mohan said. The report will be available in a few months.

Urbanisation in the state stood at 48.5% in 2010 and it only grows with each passing day. More private vehicles in Chennai have resulted in fatal accidents increasing from 582 in 2009 to 1,264 in 2017, and total accidents from 5,060 in 2009 to 7,257 in 2017, sources said. Improper planning of public transport services, operational inadequacies, lack of funding, government-related issues and institutional capacity are some of the reasons attributed to slow growth of public transport. With the STUs in the red, the state could not replace 4,646 over-aged buses until September 2019. The plan is to induct 2,000 new buses by March.

Increasing urban population leads to greater stress on urban transport, but the transport department data suggests there is a declining trend in MTC’s daily ridership – from 0.55 crore in 2011 to 0.49 crore in 2016. With 25% of its input, transport sector is a major contributor to air pollution in Chennai. “Chennai’s Streets for People initiative to improve walking and cycling, and the recent influx of city buses are welcome steps to improve the mobility of people. However, steps must be taken to discourage the use of personal motor vehicles,” says Shreya Gadapalli, South Asia programme lead of Institute for Transportation and Development Policy.

Title: Special inspector, 15 policemen will man busy Dwarka Chowk to streamline vehicular traffic
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Nashik: Commissioner of police Vishwas Nangare-Patil said on Thursday that a police team, with a special inspector and 15 personnel, would be deployed at the Dwarka Chowk — one of the busiest junctions in the city — for a week to streamline traffic.

Speaking to mediapersons, Nangare-Patil said, “Police have already issued notifications banning the passage of heavy vehicles in Dwarka Chowk to streamline traffic. We have now asked private tour operators not to stop their buses at Dwarka junction at any cost and instead, use the space near Kannamwar bridge or Tapovan to pick up or drop passengers.”

Deputy commissioner of traffic Pournima Choughule-Shringi said, “There are many notifications which have already been announced by the police. Now, they will be put in practice.”

Choughule said that there would be one police unit manning the chowk from 6am to 3pm. Another team of police personnel would be deployed from 3pm till midnight.

The police personnel will use ropes and barricades to prevent pedestrians from walking on the chowk and ask them to use the underground crossing constructed by the National Highway Authority of India (NHAI).

Police have already readied the pedestrian underpass and put in place bright lights. The underpass too will be patrolled by the police as well as some NHAI officials.

About reviving the notifications that were issued earlier, police said that vehicles would be allowed to ply only one-way on the service roads leading to and coming out of Dwarka.

“There’s no question of two-way traffic on the service roads. Even smaller vehicles will not be allowed in the opposite direction on the service roads,” said police.

Title: KMC officials, corporators observe no vehicle day
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Kolhapur: The officials of the civic boy observed a no vehicle day on Friday, the last day of the month.

Since the last month, the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) has started observing the no vehicle day on the last day of every month.

The officials and the corporators do not use the officials or private vehicles. They travel either by Kolhapur Municipal Transport buses or auto-rickshaw. The chowk of the KMC, Vitthal Ramji Shinde Chowk, is congested at all time. The officials residing in the same localities shared an auto-rickshaw and those residing nearby preferred to walk to the office.

A senior KMC official requesting anonymity said, “The decision was taken to increase environmental awareness among the people. The order is issued to every department a week before the day. We have put up the boards across the city appealing to the citizens to participate in the initiative. It will help reduce the pollution caused by vehicles and reduce congestion. At the same time, it will help increase the revenue of the KMT buses.”

The official said that at present, not many citizens are participating in the drive. However, he said it is just the beginning and the awareness is being created slowly.

A senior official said in coming days, the number of meetings will be held with citizens forum and an appeal will be made to make this initiative a mass movement.

“After discussing with them, we will roll out the plan to get them involved in the initiative through several means. Sharing the auto-rickshaws or providing a separate bus to them can be the ideas that can be used to make the no vehicle day a mass movement. We are also going to study the initiatives adopted in other cities as well,” said another senior official of KMC.

Title: Gujarat: Four including woman loan shark held
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Four of a family, including an alleged woman loan shark was arrested by Gomtipur police after a post office employee Mahendra Parmar, 52, of Gomtipur, lodged an FIR against them. Mahendra accused his distant niece, Gita Parmar, her husband Vasant Parmar, Gita’s sister Rekha Parmar and one Jitu Parmar of abduction, criminal intimidation, extortion and abetment.

He stated in the FIR that his niece was into illegal moneylending business. According to the FIR, Mahendra, who works at the parcel office in Shahibaug, had twice taken Rs 1 lakh from Gita — once during Mahendra’s daughter’s wedding and the next time for house repairs. Allegedly, Gita had lent the money at 5% monthly interest to Mahendra. The loans were taken in January 2019 with condition of repayment within six months.

After paying two instalments of Rs 5,000 each, Mahendra stopped further payment due to his poor financial condition. Thus Gita often came to his house to ask for the money, and then being thwarted, began threatening him for the money.

The accused told Mahendra that he should transfer his house to their name if he was unable to repay the money he had borrowed.

Mahendra has stated that fed up with their harassment, he had locked his house and gone to live in Odhav on rent.

Mahendra has alleged in the FIR that on January 29, 2020, when he was at his office in Shahibaugh , Gita called up on his boss’s phone. “According to the FIR she threatened Mahendra that if he didn’t come out of the office and met them they would come in. Mahendra told them that he would come out and meet them at 8.30pm during recess,” said inspector Chirag Tandel of Gomtipur.

When Mahendra came out, Gita and her associates compelled him to sit in an autorickshaw and took him to Gita’s house. “Mahendra has alleged that he was forced to sign a paper promising that he will transfer his house to Gita’s name if he didn’t pay back the loans within a month,” said a police official.

After Mahendra was released by the accused, he called up Rajnikant, his brother. “Rajnikant called the police control room. Based on that we lodged an FIR under sections 365,384,506(2) and 114 of IPC and have arrested all four,” Tandel said.

Title: Prajwal Revanna: Prajwal Revanna: HC dismisses plea challenging Prajwal’s election
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Bengaluru: In huge relief for Prajwal Revanna , Hassan MP , the Karnataka high court dismissed another petition questioning his election. The petition was dismissed on technical grounds on Friday and comes just weeks after the court had dismissed an election petition filed by A Manju, the defeated BJP candidate.

Justice John Michael Cunha dismissed the petition filed by G Devarajegowda, a voter from Hassan constituency, observing that the petitioner has not complied with the mandatory procedure prescribed under section 81(3) of the Representation of People Act, 1951. The section deals with attesting annexures appended to the petition.

Justice Cunha noted that non-attested annexures cannot be relied on by the court while framing issues against the returned candidate. He said the court cannot proceed further as section 86 mandates dismissal of a petition which does not comply with provisions of section 81 of the Act within the scheduled 45 days. Incidentally, Deverajegowda had rectified the omissions/defects after filling the petition.

Devarajegowda had contended that Prajwal was involved in corrupt practice and hence the 6,76,606 votes he received should be declared as improper reception and void and BJP candidate A Manju should be declared elected.

Title: Lucknow University to mark century with masterchef contest for girls, Amit Trivedi concert
Content:
Lucknow University

LUCKNOW: The historical Indo-Saracenic hallways of Lucknow University will soon be filled with the aroma of various delicacies made by its girls’ hostels residents.In a hunt for the university’s own masterchef, the girls’ hostels will compete with each other with residents showcasing their culinary skills. The unique event will be a part of LU’s centennial celebrations scheduled this entire year.The campus will also echo with musical concerts and cheers for sporting events and will be decked up as a special light and sound show marks the journey of 100 glorious years. After the completion of one month as vice-chancellor of Lucknow University, Prof Alok Kumar Rai listed out the centenary year celebration plans of LU exclusively for TOI on Friday. “As part of the centenary celebrations, we will soon organise the university’s own masterchef contest in which residents of girls’ hostels will compete with each other in events like salad decoration or special cuisine cooking,” said Rai. He added how the exercise had already begun as in a recent puja organised by a hostel, the ‘prasad’ was made by a hostel resident.Throughout the year, celebrations will be an amalgamation of cultural, academics and sporting events, he added.The university will also go big on bringing its former students back to the campus by organising an international alumni meet for the first time.“We hope to see all illustrious alumni from around the globe back to their alma mater,” said Rai.Among sports, a half-marathon, inter-university hockey and cricket matches are on the anvil.It will also be a time for lights, sound, camera and action as Hindi, English and Sanskrit plays will be staged. A light and sound show to unfold 100 years of the university will also be performed.Rai shared that the university will look more beautiful in its centenary year with decorative signages for departments, a grand alumni gate and green grass cover in the arts quadrangle.On the convocation ground of the university, an exhibition on the history of all departments will be held. A guest house is also likely to come up.“The best gift to students in the centenary year will be a lecture theatre complex. At present, a student has to run from one department to the other to attend classes of various subjects. This complex will give a big relief to students,” said the VC. The complex will have various lecture halls with student facilities where faculty will come to take classes.

Title: Thiruvananthapuram: Toddler accidentally run over by father, dies
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: A three-year-old boy died tragically after allegedly being knocked down by a SUV driven by his own father. The unfortunate incident happened at Thottavarambu under Palode police station limits. Vaibhav , son of Santhosh and Shari of Santhosh Bhavan, Thottavarambu is the deceased. The police booked Santhosh under Section 304A of IPC for causing death by negligence.

According to police, the accident occurred around 8.30am on Friday. Santhosh, who is a driver by profession, was returning home after a short trip in his Mahindra Jeep when the toddler ran in front of the vehicle and was knocked down. The child was first rushed to the district taluk hospital at Nedumangad from where he was referred to SAT Hospital for Women and Children inside Thiruvananthapuram Government Medical College Hospital complex. But, Vaibhav died around 11am.

Vaibhav, the younger of the two sons of Santhosh and Shari, was allegedly suffering from speech impairment. On Friday morning, Santhosh and Shari were supposed to take him to a doctor for consultation for the same. In the morning, Santhosh went out of home telling Shari to be ready so that they could leave for the doctor’s clinic as soon as he returned after his trip.

Additional sub-inspector M Hussain of Palode police station said that Santhosh’s residence was located beside an inclined road. He was coming down the slope in his SUV when the child ran in front of the vehicle.

“We suspect that the child tripped and fell down in front of vehicle and Santhosh didn’t see him. He continued driving forward and stopped the vehicle hearing the child screaming in pain,” Hussain said. The child suffered serious injuries on head, face, and chest. The surgeons, who conducted the postmortem examination told the police that the injury on the chest could be the reason for death, the ASI added.

Santhosh’s neighbour Saju told TOI that before entering the sloped road to his house, Santhosh had stopped his vehicle to speak to Saju on the main road. Saju too did not see the child outside when they were speaking.

“The child might have run in from the left side of the road, where the house is located and hence, he must have been in the blind spot of the driver,” Saju said adding that Vaibhav usually had the habit of running out of the house to receive his father whenever the latter came home from work.

Body of Vaibhav was handed over to relatives after postmortem. Vaibhav has an elder brother, Vaishnav, aged nine.

Title: Soon, elevated road at Old Goa junction
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

The elevated road, a Rs 12 crore project, will be ready by December

PANAJI: While the Kadamba bypass may have helped decongest the route leading towards Old Goa , traffic coming from the bypass hits a bottleneck where the road ends, at an intersection at the Haat Katro Khambo at Old Goa. To get rid of this bottleneck, PWD has taken up construction of a half kilometre long elevated road at this junction.

The six-lane elevated road will begin near the Sunshine School and will land near ICAR. It will be constructed at a cost of around Rs 12 crore and will be ready by December 2020, PWD principal chief engineer Uttam Parsekar said.

This intersection has one road that leads towards Ponda , one to the Karmali railway station, while the third road goes towards the Old Goa heritage complex.

To further ease traffic congestion in the vicinity, Parsekar said a vehicular underpass is also in the process of being constructed near Kadamba Fern. This underpass will serve as a service road for those living in the new and growing residential colonies and schools at Bainguinim.

Another congested intersection is the point where the Kadamba bypass starts, on the Panaji side. Here too, an overbridge is planned connecting Chimbel to Ribandar by bypassing traffic going onto the bypass. This work, however, has remained stalled for a long time as residents of a house that needs to be demolished for the work have raised objection.

“Until the time this issue is resolved and the new structure is constructed, we have widened the road at this intersection,” Parsekar further said. The Chimbel to Ribandar overbridge will be half kilometer long and will consist of two sections of three lanes each.

Title: Manager, employee of gold loan firm arrested
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: Police arrested the manager and an employee of a private gold loan firm for refusing to hand over stolen gold jewellery pledged by a burglar at their firm at Palavakkam on Sunday.

A team of police personnel from the Neelankarai police station nabbed burglar Arunkumar, 24, a resident of Kanathur, for breaking into the house of Raja Vairamuthu a few days ago and stealing about 15 sovereigns of gold jewellery worth abround Rs 4.9 lakh.

Based on a complaint from Vairamuthu, the Neelankarai crime wing police registered a case and nabbed Arunkumar.

Based on his confession, a police team took him to retrieve the stolen gold jewellery pledged with a private financing firm in Palavakkam. When police asked the firm employees to return the gold pledged by the accused, the branch manager and an employee abused the police personnel and refused to return the valuables. Following this, a case was registered and manager Louis Arulappan, 36, and employee Sankar, 37, were arrested. Further investigation is on.

Title: Mysuru: Husband stabs estranged wife for TikTok videos
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

MYSURU: A man stabbed his estranged wife with a knife for sending him mocking TikTok videos in Periyapatna late on Thursday. The woman is being treated at government-run Krishnarajendra hospital. Her condition is stable. Srinivasa has been arrested for assaulting Savitha at a function hall.

Srinivasa and Savitha got married a decade ago and the couple has two children. Four years back, she separated from her husband and is ever since staying in Mysuru. The children stay with their father in Periyapatna. He did menial jobs to eke out a living, police said.

According to Srinivasa, of late Savitha is posting him TikTok videos by posing with a man which irked him. He invited her to their son’s birthday at a function hall in Periyapatna to which she agreed. As soon as she arrived, Srinivasa pulled out a knife and stabbed her thrice before she collapsed on the ground. Savitha suffered injuries on her stomach and on her back. She was shifted to hospital while Srinivasa was taken into custody by Periyapatna.

Title: Over 1cr saplings planted in Sangli
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Kolhapur: Around 1.25 crore saplings were planted in Sangli district in the last four years, district information office has said. The state-wide plantation drive which started in 2016 has seen a gradual increase in the number of saplings planted in the district.

The office said that, in 2016, around 5 lakh saplings were planted. The number rose to 8.84 lakh in 2017, 29.05 lakh in 2018, and 72.19 lakh in 2019.

According to further information, the total number of sapling plantation goal for Sangli district was about 1.15 crore. With the help of various non-governmental organizations (NGOs), educational institutes, industries, forest department, and social forestry department’s active participation, around 1.25 crore saplings were planted.

“The survival rate of the saplings has also been substantial over the years. In 2016, around 69.80% saplings survived, in 2017 around 73.62% survived, in 2018 the survival rate increased to 80.49%. In 2019, the survival rate was 93%,” the office said.

Pramod Dhanke, deputy forest conservator, forest department, Sangli, said that the department has contributed to the plantation of around 34 lakh saplings, of which around 30 lakh saplings have survived. The staff members have worked very hard to make this initiative successful.

An official from the district administration said that citizens should take active part in sapling plantation.

Title: Banker gets 4 years jail for cheating in Chennai
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: A special court for CBI cases in the city has convicted two people, including a chief manager of Union Bank of India, in a cheating case and sentenced them to four years rigorous imprisonment. They were also fined Rs 10 lakh.

XI additional special judge S Jawahar passed the order after concluding the trial of the case registered in 2007.

According to the prosecution, M Arjunan, then chief manager of the bank, and M A Bala Sundara Vinayagam of Sri Venkateswara Imports and Exports entered into a conspiracy and defrauded the bank of Rs 1.6 crore.

The issue came to light when the bank audited the branch and found the fraudulent transactions and filed a case with the CBI.

Anti-corruption branch of the CBI charged the duo under Sections 120-B r/w 420, 468, 471 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) and sections 13(2) r/w 13(1)(d) of the Prevention of Corruption Act. Convicting the duo, the judge imposed Rs 3 lakh penalty on Arjunan and Rs 7 lakh on Vinayagam.

Title: Meet today on ways to reduce traffic in old city
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Kolhapur: Taking cognisance of the request made by activists, the district collector has called a meeting with officials of Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC), city traffic police, the regional traffic office (RTO) to discuss and come out with a solution to reduce traffic congestion in the city.

The meeting is going to take place on Saturday at Rajarshi Shahu Sabhagruha of district collector’s office. Civic chief Mallinath Kalshetti has been asked to attend the meeting with officials of the departments concerned.

Last week, the activists had given a petition to the district administration stating an urgent need to work out an immediate solution to reduce traffic congestion. The activists and some of the experts had suggested measures, such as moving government offices from the congesting areas to other locations. The large number visitors to these offices was leading to traffic, they felt.

The activists also maintained that there are inadequate parking places for visitors at tourist destinations in the city. “We have also suggested opening new parking lots behind Rajaram High School and shifting of Kalamba Jail to decongest internal localities. The grain traders from Lakshmipuri area too are reluctant to shift to the shops opened at Teblaiwadi. We expect all these aspects to be discussed,” said Ramesh More, one of the activists.

Desai, in his letter to the officials, states that they had received a petition which claims that around 60% of the offices built away from the congested areas are lying vacant. The petitioners have suggested that many of the government offices can be shifted to the central administrative building located along Kasba Bawda road, where the parking space is also adequately available. A sustainable solution to ease the increasing traffic chaos in the city is urgently required, the letter states.

Title: KMC yet to waive property tax of flood victims
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Kolhapur: The Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) is yet to waive the property tax on houses affected by floods in August last year.

A decision to waive the property tax was taken by the civic body immediately after the floods. Civic officials had claimed that they will carry out a survey of houses affected by the floods to grant the tax waiver.

A survey was later carried out by the tehsil office and was completed in November last year and the compensation for damages was given directly to the owners. However, the property tax department is yet to crosscheck the data provided by the tehsil office.

A senior property tax official said, “We have received the data which has been forwarded to the divisional ward office for identification. The process will complete in couple of weeks. Around 60% of the task has been completed.”

Meanwhile, corporators have complained that despite the decision taken by the KMC, owners from the properties affected by floods have received the property tax bills.

According to a primary estimate, around 250 houses were completely damaged and over 300 got partially damaged. A decision was taken to waive 100% property tax for the totally damaged properties and 50% concession for partially damaged properties.

The financial year is coming to an end and the corporators claimed that they expected that bills with the concession for partially damaged properties would have been sent much earlier so that property owners could get the concession for early payment as well.

Meanwhile, the water tax department is also yet to replace the water meters and pipelines damaged in the floods. Officials claim that most of the water meters are replaced and proposal for the funds to replace the pipelines has been sent to the state government.

Chairman of standing committee Sharangdhar Deshmukh had made the suggestion to waive the property tax and water bills for one month of the flood affected citizens. “The waiver will not have major impact on KMC’s revenue. Waiving the taxes was at the top of our priority list as we don’t have any authority to give compensation of other sorts to the citizens,” he said.

Title: New TPCC chief after Delhi result
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

N Uttam Kumar Reddy

HYDERABAD: Congress high command is likely to appoint a new president for Telangana Congress replacing N Uttam Kumar Reddy soon.

A senior AICC leader said the party had begun consultations on effecting the change of guard in Telangana. “A concrete action is likely to be taken only after the Delhi assembly election results. For now, focus of the leadership is on Delhi polls,” he said.

Among those in the race to become the new TPCC president include AICC secretary G Chinna Reddy, former minister and MLA D Sridhar Babu, former minister and Bhuvanagiri MP Komatireddy Venkat Reddy, TPCC working president A Revanth Reddy, AICC secretary V Hanumantha Rao, former MP Madhu Yashki Goud, MLC Jeevan Reddy, former CLP leader K Jana Reddy, former deputy chief minister Damodar Raja Narasimha and AICC secretaries Vamshi Chand Reddy and SA Sampath Kumar.

For now, the party leadership has asked Revanth, J Kusum Kumar and Hanumantha Rao, among others, to campaign in constituencies of Delhi where population of Telugu-speaking people is sizeable.

Andhra Association of Delhi president R Muni Naidu told TOI that there are eight lakh Telugu-speaking people spread all over Delhi. They mainly live in the 13 assembly constituencies of RK Puram, Patpargunj, New Delhi, Shahdara, Vishwas Nagar, Kasturba Nagar, Rajinder Nagar, Delhi Cantonment, Dwarka, Janakpuri, Bijwasan, Hari Nagar and Sultanpur.

Title: Thiruvananthapuram: Tight security arrangements ahead of anti-CAA march
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Bhim Army chief Chandrasekhar Azad will also take part in the anti-CAA march. (PTI photo)

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: City Police have arranged tight security measures in the city on Saturday in view of the anti-CAA march that will be taken out under the aegis of SDPI taking into account of potential law and order issues that may arise. Bhim Army chief Chandrasekhar Azad who is in the forefront of anti CAA protests will be attending the event.

A strong contingent of 660 police personnel will be deployed along MG Road from East Fort where the march commences to Raj Bhavan where it will conclude. The police personnel will be under the supervision of two deputy commissioners, 11 assistant commissioners, 22 inspectors and 70 sub-inspectors.

City Police commissioner Balram Kumar Upadhyay said that MG Road from East Fort to Raj Bhavan will be divided into four zones with each zone under the supervision of an assistant commissioner. Besides the local police, personnel from Commando Wing of the police department and quick response team will also be on duty. Woman cops and shadow police squad members will also be on duty.

Police will also be regulating vehicuar traffic on city roads in connection with the protest march.

Vehicles bringing participants for the march from various places have to be parked along the NH-66 and Putharikandam ground. There will be strict ban on parking of vehicles along MG Road and other major city roads, including Museum – Kanaka Nagar road, Museum – Nandavanam – Bakery Junction road, Keltron – Manaveeyam – Althara road, Pattom – Kuravankonam – Kowdiar road, East Fort – Attakkulangara – Killippalam road and East Fort – Mithranandapuram – Eanchakkal road.

Title: West Bengal: Smoke sparks panic in Metro
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

The Dum Dum-bound train left Netaji Bhavan around 4.17pm

KOLKATA: Smoke emission from under an air-conditioned Metro rake between the Netaji Bhavan and Rabindra Sadan stations resulted in panic among passengers on Friday evening. Railway Protection Force ( RPF ) personnel used a fire extinguisher to control the smoke at the Rabindra Sadan station. After the passengers were evacuated, the rake was sent to the carshed for inspection and necessary repairs.

“It was an older AC rake. The Dum Dum-bound train left Netaji Bhavan at 4.17pm and a passenger pulled the alarm chain inside a coach immediately after noticing the smoke. A team was waiting when the train entered the Rabindra Sadan station at 4.19pm. They boarded the coach 3414 and the passengers pointed them to a wall panel near the vestibule, behind which the smoke was emitting. While passengers were asked to vacate the coach, an RPF constable immediately picked up a fire extinguisher from inside the coach and tried to control the smoke. A decision was taken to move the empty rake to the carshed. The rake left the station at 4.27pm,” said Metro Railway CPRO, Indrani Banerjee. While some passengers claimed that they had spotted flames under the coach, the person who pulled the alarm chain told Metro staff that he had seen some sparks .

According to another Metro official, sparks are possible when there is a problem with the couplers under the vestibule. “We shall look into the matter and ensure that such incident is not repeated,” he said.

Title: BSY finally gets approval, 10 turncoats may join cabinet
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Bengaluru: Chief minister BS Yediyurappa is likely to induct 13 ministers — 10 newly elected MLAs and three old-timers — into his cabinet after finally securing the nod from BJP’s central leadership on Friday to expand his cabinet.

Though Yediyurappa said the date on which the new ministers will be sworn in will be decided in a day or two, sources say it could happen on Monday or Tuesday.

Currently, there are 18 including the chief minister in the cabinet, which has a sanctioned strength of 34. Of the 16 vacancies, Yediyurappa is expected to fill only 13, including 10 who had defected from Congress and JD(S). But sources said the possibility of inducting all 11 turncoat MLAs cannot be ruled out.

"Most of our suggestions have been accepted by the party leadership and I’m going home happy," Yediyurappa told reporters in Delhi, soon after his 25 minute-meeting with Union home minister Amit Shah and BJP national president JP Nadda at Parliament Complex. His younger son BY Vijayendra had accompanied him.

Except for "one or two", he said, most of the MLAs who won the bypolls will be made ministers, while reiterating there will be no additional deputy CMs. This could dash the hopes of Ramesh Jarkiholi and B Sriramulu, who were eyeing the post. "If there are differences, we will discuss them in Bengaluru and finalise it," Yediyurappa said, anticipating a backlash.

Yediyurappa was keen on completing the expansion exercise quickly, but was left waiting for approval from BJP’s central leadership. Aspirants, meanwhile, were exerting pressure on the CM for more than a month. Opposition parties have also been critical of the BJP and Yediyurappa over the delay in expanding the cabinet, accusing him of being "weak".

The exercise is certain to leave several legislators unhappy. The CM will have his task cut out pacifying at least a dozen MLAs, who are hoping to make it to cabinet.

Title: Hike in standard deduction high on list of expectations
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Nagpur: On the eve of the budget, tax practitioners expressed the hope that the government eases the burden on individual tax payers, as has been done for corporates. There have been demands to increase the standard deduction from Rs40,000 at present to at least Rs75,000 and reduce the peak tax rate for individual taxpayers so that it is at par with corporate entities.

Chartered accountant Naresh Jhakotia said even as a standard deduction of Rs40,000 has been introduced the net effect comes down to only Rs5,800 as the earlier exemptions available on medical and conveyance allowance have been removed. The peak level of income tax for individual tax payers needs to be reduced to 25% as against 30% at present, he said.

Jhakotia said threshold period for tax on notional rent deemed to be received by builders on unsold units also must be extended. Under the current laws, units that remain unsold attract a tax on deemed rent after a year of construction. The tax is applicable even if the unit is not actually let out. The finance minister must either do away with the tax or at least increase the period to five years from the date of construction, he said.

Sanjay Moriani, a tax lawyer, said standard deduction should be increased to ease the salaried class’ burden as there is no scope for tax evasion. Even the deduction on interest paid on home loans should be taken to Rs4 lakh so that it matches the current rate of properties and size of loans.

Kailash Jogani, a chartered accountant and also former president of Nagpur Chamber of Commerce Limited (NCCL), said it is expected that the government will do away with the dividend distribution tax (DDT). This is because the company that pays dividend has already paid tax on that income, but again the person receiving it has to pay tax afresh.

Jogani said it is hoped that the government will also ease the penal provisions on alleged tax evasion introduced after demonetization. He said if the standard deduction is not increased, at least the rebates should be increased.

Tejindersingh Rawal, also a chartered accountant, called for removal of the tax on long-term capital gains on shares. “This has not led to any major increase in revenue. Rather the grandfathering clause introduced for calculating the loss or profit has only complicated the work,” he says.

Former chairman of Institute of Chartered Accountants of India (ICAI), Rajesh Loya said the tax rate of 20% on income of Rs10 lakh should be increased to Rs20 lakh instead. Expanding the slabs will help increase tax compliance. The 60% tax charged on unexplained cash credit and investment is too harsh. The provision introduced after note-ban continues to be applicable even today.

Title: ‘SEZ for IT sector will boost startups, create employment’
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Panaji: Goa should set up at least one special economic zone ( SEZ ) for information technology companies and startups, Goa Technology Association (GTA) said on Thursday in its recommendations for the state budget.

GTA also said that an income tax exemption for 10-15 years should be granted for the SEZs.

“All major IT hubs in India came into existence and thrived due to SEZ. The government of Goa has to approve at least one,” president of GTA Manguirish Salelkar said.

GTA has also put emphasis on the implementation of the IT Policy 2018 in order to support existing IT companies. “In addition to the thrust for startups, support to existing IT companies will exponentially boost growth of the IT sector and lead to job creation,” Salelkar said.

He said that a Skill Goa programme for IT industry should be launched. The programme should be run in association with colleges, companies in Goa, and corporate IT firms like Microsoft, IBM, Google and other IT giants. “In the current situation, the investment in skill enhancements for the youth is important if we need to provide jobs,” Salelkar said.

The other recommendations made include construction of a convention centre to host technology summits, improved internet connectivity in the hinterland, public transport till midnight and funds to boost the IT ecosystem.

Title: Asset case: Court allows Andhra Pradesh CM YS Jaganmohan Reddy to skip hearing
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

YS Jaganmohan Reddy

HYDERABAD: Principal special judge BR Madhusudan Rao of CBI and ED courts on Friday allowed the petition filed by AP chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy to stay away from Friday’s (Jan 31) court hearing in the quid pro quo case filed by CBI against him.

His counsel, N Naveen Kumar, informed the court that they moved a plea seeking exemption from high court and that it was posted to February 6. The trial court judge allowed the plea for this week and posted the case to February 7.

Title: Train timings out of sync on official websites
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Mysuru: Before purchasing tickets through IRCTC, the official website of Indian Railways, it’s better to check with the National Train Enquiry System (NTES) on train timings. According to regular passengers, these websites mention different timings for at least three trains between Mysuru and Bengaluru.

The biggest worry is different timings of Talaguppa Express used extensively by tourists to reach Bengaluru to catch onward buses and trains. As per the IRCTC website, this train is scheduled to reach KSR Bengaluru City railway terminus at 10.30pm. But, as per the NTES website, it reaches the station at 10.55pm. Actually, this train reaches beyond 11.10pm.

Different timings are mentioned for Mys Udz Humsafar Express and Mailduturai Express too. All the three trains are daily express trains.

Divakar S, a regular commuter said South Western Railway authorities must clear the air. "Talaguppa Express passengers are the worst victims. Most passengers catch this train to reach Bengaluru to catch buses, trains and flights to other destinations. But, it reaches Bengaluru way beyond the scheduled arrival time,” he said.

Shoba Sudhakar, a tourist said SWR must look into integrating details on both websites. "NTES is a popular app among passengers. The timetables on the official websites should be the same," she said.

When contacted, SWR PRO E Vijaya said she would look into the issue.

Title: Bring down product prices, simplify taxes
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Nagpur: The Union budget on February 1 is creating a buzz for the Aam Admi (common man), right from income tax slabs to managing the kitchen budget, the recent status of our GDP as well as the economy has left many citizens a worried lot. They have a long list of expectations and want the government to use this budget as an opportunity to rectify financial mistakes.

Finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman is expected to announce several measures to revive the ailing economy.

Nitesh Bobde, an employee of the Food Corporation of India (Nagpur), feels that the tax structure needs to be much simpler. “There are too many complications in our tax systems. Most of our income goes in paying hefty taxes.Tax rates for income earners from 500001-1000000 should be reduced from 20% to 10%,” he said.

Vijaya Waindaskar, a local businesswoman, is concerned about farmer issues. “There is a need for innovation in the agriculture sector and those innovations would be incomplete without incorporating the warehousing sector and agricultural finance. Groceries have become extremely expensive due to less agricultural produce and lack of modernized equipment with farmers,” she said.

Kiran Mundhra, a homemaker, says, “Each time a budget is announced, people assume it to be negative, but that’s not true. There are numerous schemes available and one must make the most of them. I’m hoping that the prices of vegetables won’t touch the skies anymore.”

Poonam Khatri, another homemaker, said, “I struggle to pay for gas connections and the education fees of my children. I expect the government to plan an efficient budget for the middle-class in particular,” she said.

Sheela Khandare, an artisan residing in Vaigadpeth village, 24 kms from the city, wants the government to do something for local artisans to boost their income and exports. “We make very little money by selling pottery. The government has allocated no funds for local artisans and day by day, the cost of purchasing raw materials is increasing. The price rise affects our grocery consumption and sometimes, we have to cut down on our meals,” she said.

According to Dr Onkar Nalgundwar, the government must focus on health and women safety “More technologically advanced solutions are expected to be introduced in areas of women safety in both rural and urban areas, ” he said.

“ Medical procedures should also be made pocket-friendly for the poor, who cannot afford even a CT scan,” he added.

Title: Saveetha Univ arm buys land of energy firm
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Chennai: An educational trust promoted by the Saveetha University group has agreed to buy nearly 15 acres of land belonging to renewable energy firm RRB Energy on Poonamallee Bypass Road for an undisclosed sum.

“We have agreed to sell a part of the land within our facility to them. Since we are bound by a non-disclosure agreement with the buyer, we will not be able to share details of the transaction,” said Sarvesh Kumar, president & COO of RRB Energy. The transaction is part of the firm’s debt-reduction exercise, he said.

While contours of the transaction aren’t available, sources indicated that Veeraiyan Saraswathi Trust is the buyer and a board with its name is already on the premises. At an indicated market price of Rs 9 crore an acre, the transaction could have been nearly Rs 140 crore.

“As of now, we have no concrete plans and the deal isn’t completely done,” said Dr Saveetha, dean of Saveetha University, in a text reply. “Transactions like this suddenly throw life into a dull real estate market. A few more large land deals are expected to be completed before March 31,” an industry source said.

Title: Coronavirus: Mysuru Hospitals told to spare rooms to quarantine people if required
Content:
Representative image

MYSURU: Health officials here are in contact with their counterparts in Kerala and have taken all precautionary measures to prevent Coronavirus from entering Mysuru. As a precautionary measure, both government and private hospitals have been asked to spare a few rooms to quarantine the suspected persons, if any, said deputy commissioner Abhiram G Sankar on Friday.“We request people who had been to China recently with family or on business tour to voluntarily get examined at any hospital. To track those who went to China in recent days, we have told tour operators and hotel associations to help in this regard,” he told reporters. “In two to three days time, we may get those details and our health authorities will go to their doorsteps to examine them,” he said.“At major tourist spots, we are creating awareness about Coronavirus by distributing pamphlets both in Kannada and English. We have also set up testing lab at Mysuru Medical College Research and Institute. In case we get any suspected cases, the blood samples will be collected and examined at MMC & RI. Later it will be sent to Nimhans in Bengaluru and from there it will be sent to Pune for analysis. The official declaration of patient suffering from Coronavirus needs to be declared by DHO,” he added.The DC said that people need not get scared about the virus as it is just one case in Thrissur and nearly 1,000 people are under surveillance. According to health authorities in Kerala, the situation in the neighbouring state is under control and there is no need to panic, the IAS officer said. He also mentioned that due to exams, there will be not much tourists flow till mid of March, which will help in tackling the virus spread.Dr Venkatesh, district health officer and Dr Shivaprasad briefed about the steps taken and said that they have enhanced the surveillance in the district.Manjunath, director, Mysuru Airport, said that the health authorities at the airport are keeping a tab on travellers.C Narayanagowda, president, Hotel Owners Association, said: “In the past few months, there were not much tourists from China. We have instructed all our members that before the tourists check-in, they should know where they are from. If the tourists are from China, they should immediately alert health authorities.”B S Prashanth, leader of Mysuru Travel Agents Association, said: “There are hardly any people from Mysuru who had been to China. Still we have conveyed a meeting of people associated with tours and travels. During the meeting, we will also discuss how to handle tourists coming from China.”

Title: Cleanliness drive in Rangareddy village
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: In an effort to sensitize the residents of Edulapalle village in Rangareddy district on cleanliness, environment and the use of plastic, students from Symbiosis Law School Hyderabad (SLS-H) and Symbiosis Institute of Business Management (SIBM) organized a cleanliness drive in the village. Conducted under their community outreach program, SCOPE, students took the help of Nukkad play, presentations and posters to reach out to the villagers.

“The highlight of the session was on reducing single-use plastic, water conservation and cleanliness to be maintained in and around their surroundings. Special emphasis was given on barrier-free access to drinking water and toilet facilities for Divyang students in all the rural schools where disabled students are admitted,” read a release from SLS.

Title: 200 cops, civilians took part in ‘Midnight evathon’
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Nagpur: City police, assisted by an NGO, had organized an unique ‘Midnight evathon’ on the theme ‘Fear Free Nagpur’ stressing on women security in which 200 cops and some members of an NGO participated. The event was flagged off by Joint CP Ravidra Kadam and Addl CP BG Gaikar.

The event, which kicked off on Friday midnight, was organized by the city police following a circular from the office of the director general of police (DGP). The circular stressed on organizing events priors to the police international marathon in Mumbai later this month.

Police headquarters had taken the lead in organizing the marathon which started from the Police Gymkhana. Apart from the constables, senior officers of the rank of DCP like Vikram Sali, Rahul Maknikar and Gajanan Rajmane, too, participated in the event. In the five-km walk, cops walked from Police Gymkhana to Samvidhan Square and returned.

It’s learnt that there were other events too, like 10-km cycling and running in which several NGO members too participated. The longer version of the events ended at Gandhibagh on Central Avenue.

DCP, Headquarters, Sali, said every month such marathons would take place with different themes revolving around the ‘Fear Free Nagpur’. “We are planning to summon cops from different units and police stations too in the subsequent marathons,” he said.

Title: NSS students assist with disability survey in Goa
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: National Service Scheme (NSS) students from various colleges of the state have been roped in to help with the Goa Disability Survey , 2020. The survey, which began on Republic Day, is aimed at compiling and updating data of ‘divyangs’ (differently abled).

Two volunteers per village and one volunteer per municipal ward have been appointed to record data in unique disability identity (UDID) forms.

Being conducted by Saksham Goa, the survey will be on till February 10, following which disability certificates will be issued to divyangs and they will be registered for UDID cards.

Divyangs across the state are requested to get in touch with the volunteers in their respective villages and municipalities to get an UDID form filled for registration for an UDID card. Contact details of the volunteers with respect to villages and municipal wards are available on www.sakshamgoa.org.

Title: Fire in forest area on Kadamba Plateau
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: Chimbel saw yet another fire in a forest area at Kadamba plateau bypass, in survey number 28.

Fire and emergency services in the afternoon and took more than an hour to douse the fire. Cause of the fire could not be established.

“Incidents of setting fire to green coverage, forest areas are now normal in this region. Many petitions were filed earlier before the forest department, but no concrete action has been taken,” secretary of Chimbel Manch, Tukaram K stated.

Title: SC notice to government on Jairam Ramesh's plea against change in RTI law
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Congress leader Jairam Ramesh (File photo)

NEW DELHI: The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to examine validity of the Right to Information (Amendment) Act , 2019 which gives power to the Centre to prescribe tenure , allowances and salary of information commissioners and sought response from the Centre on a petition by Jairam Ramesh of Congress.

A bench of Justices D Y Chandrachud and K M Joseph issued notice to the Centre and asked it to file response within four weeks on the petition filed by Jairam who alleged that the new law and the RTI Term of Office, Salaries, Allowances and Other Terms and Conditions of Service Rules, 2019 “collectively violate” the fundamental right to information of all citizens.

The plea said the provision of the amended Act “alters the erstwhile fixed tenure” of five years of CICs and SICs, to a “tenure to be prescribed by the central government”. “Section 2(c) of the amendment Act grants absolute power to the central government to prescribe the salaries, allowances, and terms and conditions of service of the central information commissioners that in the pre-amended Act was fixed to be on par with election commissioners under section 13(5) of the RTI Act,” the plea said.

He said the amended Act and rules give “unbridled and uncanalised” discretionary power to the Centre which could “jeopardise the independence of information commissioners”.

Title: Govt to ensure staff don’t loiter during work hours
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Jaipur: The state’s administrative reforms department (ARD) has issued an order to all the government departments to ensure that the employees of the department concerned must “make an entry in the movement register before leaving his office during office hours, i.e. between 9:30 am and 6 pm, and also mention the reasons for going out”.

The ARD order states that “It has been brought to our notice that employees loiter around leaving their office during working hours. It is the responsibility of the department’s heads/joint secretaries/deputy secretaries to ensure that the employees don't leave their seats during office hours and complete the work assigned to them."

“If an employee leaves his office, then he/she should make an entry in the movement register and also mention the reason for going out before leaving. This should be ensured by the heads of all the departments, municipal bodies, boards and other institutions that the employees don’t leave their workplace without permission,” it added.

Additional Chief Secretary (ACS), ARD, R Venkasteswaran, said, “During the working hours (9:30 am to 6 pm), if the employees are moving out of their office, it should be known to the office and, hence, must make an entry in the movement register before leaving the office.

It is an old system. But the practice of maintaining movement register is slowly going out of fashion.”

“So, we have just reminded the employees that the system should be strengthened and every employee should be available for work,” he added.

The circular issued by the department was sent to all the ACS, principal secretaries, secretaries, divisional commissioners, district collectors and department heads.

Title: Olam flea market on Feb 1, 2
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

T’puram: Olam is set to make waves again the next weekend. The third edition of Olam flea market will feature over 100 vendors. The flea market will be held on February 1 and 2 at Tagore theatre .

In addition to an array of innovative vendors, Olam will be featuring various workshops this time. Registrations have begun for workshops on pottery, block printing and salsa. In order to promote inclusivity, a workshop has been arranged for sign language. Lakshmi K V will lead the Keli pottery workshop, while Mariam Jacob of ART-Swathe will conduct workshop in block printing. Kalpana Suseelan will take the salsa workshop.

Some of the major vendors are Karikku Wybe, which is merchandising from the viral web series Karikku, and digital merchandise such as Kokachi, Meen Curry and DoodleMuni. The team Olam is also associating with around 25 vendors for food and beverages.

For details, log on to www.olamfestival.com

Title: Address climate concerns, have a green budget is demand of environmentalists
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

With climate change and environment degradation becoming more palpable in the country, environmentalists and wildlife conservationists have called for a ‘green budget’.

The last few budgets drew flak from experts for being rhetorical and not giving priority to the pressing issues of increasing air pollution and protection of wildlife.

The last year’s budget allocated 10% increased funds to the Union environment ministry but cut it for bio-diversity and wildlife by 10%. “While the extra allocation was used towards various initiatives from climate change point of view, other crucial areas like forests, bio-diversity and wildlife took a beating. Many state-funded wildlife sanctuaries have a perpetual fund crisis which needs to be addressed,” said Nitin Desai, Central India director of Wildlife Protection Society of India.

To have financial accountability of the benefits derived from environment, Natural Resource Accounting should be introduced in the budget. “This should be accompanied by an assessment of the loss of natural capital as a percentage of GDP. Following this, a sum at least equal to the loss of natural capital should be allocated to the environment ministry and the forest departments to enable them to repair the environmental damage,” said Debi Goenka, executive trustee of Conservation Action Trust.

Pointing out that Rs350 crores were sanctioned to tiger reserves in the last budget, assistant director of BNHS Sanjay Karkare said, “Relocation and human-free landscape continue to be big challenges. Also, small but ecologically important fauna requires huge attention, so do birds like the Great Indian Bustard, vultures and many endemic species in Himalayas.”

Karkare further added that climate change, air pollution, poor management of waste, growing water scarcity, falling groundwater tables, water pollution, and soil degradation are also major issues which need budgetary allocations.

In her maiden budget speech last year, Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman had allocated Rs460 crore for pollution control schemes including National Clean Air Programme (NCAP).

Highlighting that many cities apart from New Delhi are grappling with the crisis of air pollution, Sunil Dahiya said, “We expect that the budget provides more allocations for NCAP implementation across India. Also, coal cess which is proposed to be diluted and decreased, should instead be increased keeping in view the rising air pollution, health and climate emergency. The funds collected should be used aggressively for renewable energy infrastructure, capacity and research development.”

In the clean energy arena, the country has set an ambitious target of installing 450GW of renewables by 2030. According to Vibhuti Garg, an energy finance analyst at the Institute for Energy Economics and Financial Analysis, the government’s focus should be on creating an environment where investors’ confidence increases, and deflation in solar prices continues.

“Out of the set target, 100GW of solar is mandated to come online within next two years. The decision on imported solar panels is yet to be taken.
