In Attukal, Iranimuttam, Thampanoor, East Fort, Vallakadavu, Kuriathy, Chalai, Manacaud, Kamaleswaram, Ambalathara, Poonthura, Beemapally, Sreevaraham, Muttathara residents can contact 8547638196, 8547638194.

Title: Telangana: 3D kits help inculcate hygiene habits in kids
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: In a bid to make washing hands, dental hygiene , and cleanliness interesting for kids, Butterfly EduFields has designed hands-on experiments and games.

Speaking at the Ink Wash Summit, K Sharat Chandra, CEO and founder-director of the firm, stressed on the importance of teaching children about cleanliness at an early stage.

“Children understand the issue better through games and 3D kits. Also, we are making them take a pledge to wash hands and keep their surroundings clean,” Chandra said, adding that they have distributed kits to around 10,000 schools in 18 cities.

The entrepreneurs also talked about the importance of water treatment and using the method to overcome shortage.

Gowthaman Desingh of Transwater System, who has built an IoT-based monitoring solution for water treatment projects, explained how treating water at the source can reduce the cost by at least 50%.

“When water is supplied through tankers to be used as coolants, it costs about 14 paise to 18 paise per litre. But, by operating treatment plants, we are able to supply water at 7 paise to 9 paise per litre,” Desingh said, adding that so far they have supplied 46 million litres of water.

They also used the platform to raise awareness on menstrual hygiene, manual scavenging, access to clean toilets, and rainwater harvesting among other issues.

Meanwhile, MAUD minister KT Rama Rao on Friday announced that Sanitation Hub (S-Hub) — an incubator for promoting start-ups and innovations in water, sanitation and other areas — will be established in the state. A seed fund of Rs 25 crore will be earmarked for this initiative, he added.

Addressing delegates at the valedictory session of Ink Wash Summit in the city, KTR stated that S-Hub will undertake incubation of ideas and build an ecosystem for innovations, knowledge dissemination, capacity building in Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) sector.

KTR said that the state proposes to house the S-Hub at Administrative Staff College of India for two years and then establish a dedicated facility at the proposed Centre for Urban Excellence.

He stated that the government has prioritised the sector and is deeply committed to achieving the set targets well ahead of the globally agreed timelines.

Title: Cotton, castor prices fall as virus clouds export prospects
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Ahmedabad: Prices of cotton and castor seed have eased in local markets, as the novel coronavirus outbreak in China has clouded export prospects. While China is a major buyer, Gujarat is a leading supplier of these commodities.

Castor prices have declined to Rs 4,050 a quintal from Rs 4,180 a fortnight ago. Prices in tghe futures market are even lower, due to the uncertainty, market players say. China imports 2 lakh tonnes of castor oil worth Rs 2,500 crore every year, which is 40% of India’s castor oil exports.

“There is no impact on exports currently. However, business sentiment has been dampened due to the coronavirus outbreak. If this situation persists and derivative product makers in China are compelled to shut factories, it will certainly reduce our exports,” said B V Mehta, executive director, the Solvent Extractors’ Association of India (SEA).

According to Arun Dalal, a cotton broker from Ahmedabad, cotton prices have dipped by Rs 500 per candy (356kg) over the past week. The price of the Shankar-6 cotton variety has come down to between Rs 39,800 and Rs 39,900 from Rs 40,300-40,400 per candy.

“Cotton exports to China have also slowed mainly because of the Lunar New Year holidays and the shutting down of a dozen Chinese cities to contain the coronavirus outbreak. Payments are being delayed and letters of credit (LCs) are not being honoured as banks are closed due to the holidays,” said Nirav Patel, a city-based cotton exporter.

“Consignments are lying at ports and exporters are in a quandary as whether to ship goods to China or not. So far 5-6 lakh bales of cotton have been shipped to China from India and 3 lakh bales are presently stuck,” he added.

“60% of the total exports of cotton yarn from spinning units in Gujarat goes to China. With production affected in Chinese factories due to the virus, demand has declined significantly. As a result, the price of 30 combed hosiery cotton yarn, which is exported to China, has gone down from Rs 207/kg to Rs 200/kg,” said Dr Bharat Boghra, chairman, All Gujarat Spinners’ Association (AGSA).

“Several chemicals such as H-Acid, vinyl sulphone, J-Acid, Tobias acid, beta naphthol, naphthalene, gamma acid, K-Acid, among others are imported from China. With the outbreak, prices of these chemicals have risen significantly,” said Bhupendra Patel, chairman, Chemexil Gujarat region.“The prices are expected to remain high as the virus has crippled various provinces of China such as Hebei and Guangdong, where various factories are located,” he added.

20% raw material shortage expected

Several Indian manufacturers are heavily dependent on China for raw-material imports and the coronavirus outbreak and resultant shutdown in China is expected to affect Indian manufacturers in a big way.

Ritesh Goenka, director of an electronics OEM manufacturing company in China, said, “Due to the Chinese New Year, industrial units were to remain shut till February 2. However, based on the notification form the Chinese government, this has been extended to February 10 and it is expected the last even till February 20. As Indian industry is heavily import-dependent on China, a raw-material scarcity to the order or 20-30% of requirement is expected over the next three months.”

“The shortage of raw materials will also lead to a significant increase in prices in the Indian market which will affect demand, as local players will wait for prices to fall. Overall, this is expected to hurt sales by at least 30%,” said Goenka.

Title: Contractor, consultant, engineer get notice for poor paver block works
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Paver block works leave a lot to be desired

Nagpur: The nexus between contractor, project management consultant and Nagpur Municipal Corporation engineer in substandard paver block work has surfaced in Phase-III cement road works in Dharampeth area.

Following directives from municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe, NMC’s executive engineer Amin Akhtar on Friday issued show cause notices to the construction firm JP Enterprises for installing substandard paver blocks on the patch between Ekstambh Chowk to North Ambazari road.

NMC entrusted the contractor with the work of white topping 570-metre road patch at a cost of Rs4.12 crore. The work was supposed to be completed by March 31, 2020.

A delegation of Dharampeth residents under the banner of Civic Action Guild (CAG) met the then municipal commissioner Abhijit Bangar and informed him about the substandard work in footpath construction. Following this, Bangar initiated an inquiry. The report found the contractor had failed use M-45 grade quality paver blocks. The company also fitted blocks before completion of curing period.

“As a contractor, it is your prime responsibility to execute the work as per specification of tender regarding quality of material and execution of work. However, your failure to execute the work as per specifications has led to receipt of complaint. On testing, the paver blocks have not been found as per specification, it has maligned the image of NMC,” the show cause notice stated.

It sought explanation from the firm within three days from the receipt of the notice and reason why it should not be blacklisted. Similar notices have also been issued to Project Management Consultant (PMC) M/s Creations Engineers Pvt Ltd, the firm engaged to monitor the quality of the work, and NMC’s junior engineer G Shrivastav.

PMC was appointed as NMC’s quality assurance and quality control for works under cement concrete road project Phase III. “It is the responsibility of PMC to verify the ongoing works in respect of its quality as per specification and inform NMC in case of any lacunae regarding quality of material and execution of work,” the notice stated. It too has been given three days to submit its say why it should not be blacklisted.

The executive engineer’s office also sought explanation from the junior engineer why disciplinary action should not be initiated against him for monitoring and ignoring quality of works despite being informed about substandard work.

Title: ‘Azadi’ slogans raised at CAA stir in Old City
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Charminar: Muslims in parts of Old City organised a peaceful protest on Friday against the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ), National Population Register (NPR), and National Register of Citizens (NRC).

The protesters gathered outside Mallepally Masjid after Juma prayers and demanded that the central government roll back on its controversial Bills. They raised “Azadi” slogans holding banners and placards and urged everyone to safeguard the constitutional rights.

“We have gathered to protest against CAA, NPR, and NRC. It is a matter of our nationality and everyone should reject the law,” said a protester, Rehan.

Many people, including children, also participated in an anti-CAA protest at Barkas Playground. They vowed to uphold unity and harmony in the country. “It is being perceived that our conscience has died. But the time has come to show them our unity,” said a protester.

Title: Goa: Duo gets 2-year jail term for carrying bombs
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

PONDA: The additional district and sessions court at Ponda on Friday sentenced two Karnataka natives to two years rigorous imprisonment for possessing and carrying 80 locally made bombs in 2009.

Bela N Naik, additional sessions judge, Panaji, sitting at Ponda, has also fined the accused, Shivappa Ganapat Kale, 28, and Dharma Bhagwan Chavan alias Kale, 27, Rs 1,000 each under Section 5(a) of Explosive Substance Act for possession and carrying the bombs.

On December 30, 2009, acting on a tip-off by the police control room, based on information provided by Animal Rescue Squad member Amrutsingh, the Ponda police had arrested Shivappa, Dharma and Hazani Chavan alias Kale, 30, all natives of Hubballi-Karnataka, for possessing 80 locally made bombs (locally called ‘sutali bombs’) made out of strings of gunny bags and powder of firecrackers.

The bombs were being transported from Paikul-Sattari to Margao via Ponda for poaching wild animals.

While Shivappa and Dharma were held guilty for possessing 40 bombs each, Hazani Chavan, who was accompanying them was acquitted by the court on Wednesday, said public prosecutor Satyawan Raut Dessai.

Title: 49 textile units under SGST dept scanner
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Ahmedabad: Forty-nine textile units in Surat have come under the scanner of the state goods and services tax (SGST) department in connection with a bogus billing scam. According to the enforcement wing of the SGST department, 90 places including offices and residences were raided on Wednesday. Offenders had claimed integrated GST (IGST) to the tune of Rs 4.66 crore, while input tax credit worth Rs 2.34 crore was claimed using bogus bills.

In this particular case, 29 textile businessmen had illicitly claimed refund of IGST using fake bills. SGST officials have taken strict action against the offenders by attaching their bank accounts and blocking the input tax credit inflow.

The department officials have blocked input tax credit worth Rs 84 crore for the offenders, while levying applicable dues worth Rs 1.44 crore.

The fake bills used in this case were made in the name of bogus firms. The GST registration numbers for these firms were obtained by illicitly obtaining documents of labourers and peons. tnn

Title: Pune: Soak in the morning sun with a plethora of fun-filled events in Kharadi tomorrow
Content:
Children and their parents can enjoy dancing and participating in an assortment of activities

PUNE: Happy Streets is set to take the residents on a joyride with fitness and games this Sunday from 7am to 9.30am.Hundreds had thronged the Kharadi South Main Road during the special Republic Day edition of Happy Streets to enjoy the fresh morning air with students and the traffic police. This week promises to be as much fun as the last two Sundays.On Sunday, the main stage would feature dance instructors guiding participants during an early morning exercise routine in tune to the latest international hits. Age is no bar and participants, both old and young, are welcome to put on their dancing shoes to shake a leg or two alongside their friends and neighbours.While the children and their parents enjoy dancing and participating in an assortment of activities, the elderly can indulge in yoga and meditation organized by Pause N Learn.A wide array of games are on the cards for visitors, including Toss the Ball, Ball in Bucket, Lasso the Bull and much more arranged by Modern Montessori International Kharadi.Other games such as life-sized Ludo and Snakes and Ladders would cater to different age groups. Tangram puzzles, robots and much more are set to tickle the scientific nerve among those present.Participants can learn about self-defence as well, with instructors from KDKBA bringing some taekwondo moves to the table. They can enjoy a skit on Green India and Clean India, which will be presented by Chaitanya School.The traffic equipment display and traffic-related activities are likely to make it a knowledgeable morning for all.One can simply enjoy a walk or cycle on the road that would be closed to vehicular traffic. Selfie booths at the event site would encourage people to capture memorable moments with their loved ones.Happy Streets is an initiative of The Times of India, in association with Pune police and Pune Municipal Corporation , powered by Nyati Group.

Title: Schools vary as April 3 proposed as a ‘local holiday’
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Nagpur: Though state assembly speaker Nana Patole has proposed declaration of holiday in Nagpur division (except Gadchiroli) to mark birth anniversary of spiritual guru and social reformer Baba Jumdevji on April 3, educational institutes are hoping that the holiday tally does not go up.

Baba Jumdevji was a popular spiritual guru and social reformer from Nagpur, who passed away in 1996 but his legacy lives on through his followers. Government of India had released a postage stamp in his honour in 2013.

A senior CBSE principal , who did not wish to be identified as the issue involves a spiritual guru, said, “With due respect to Baba Jumdevji, we feel academics will suffer if holidays are increased. Yes, if it can be adjusted against some other holiday then it will be fine.”

Another state board principal said, “April is basically the last leg of the academic session for all of us and final exams are being conducted. Given the logistical constraints of spacing the papers, weekends and then freeing up teachers for board evaluation, adding a holiday will make it difficult.”

As per government rule, schools are required to be open for anywhere between 210 to 230 days depending on which level (primary, high school) the institute is.

For Patole’s proposal, state’s general administration department (GAD) has put the onus on Nagpur divisional commissionerate as the holiday demand is only for Nagpur, Chandrapur, Wardha, Gondia and Bhandara districts.

The GAD letter also mentions that the list of public holidays has already been finalized in December itself. The district administration can declare three local holidays, which take care of festivals or major events that are specific to a region. And these, like public holidays, also have been decided in December, which practically leaves no wriggle room for the local administration at least for this calendar year.

Nagpur divisional commissioner Sanjeev Kumar said, “I will meet my officials and see what can be done.”

Title: Maharashtra: 40 per cent work complete on Ramwadi Metro route
Content:
Metro piers on the riverbed along the Yerawada Bridge

PUNE: The Maharashtra Metro Rail Corporation Limited (MahaMetro) has expedited the civil work on Civil Court-Ramwadi elevated route.About 40% of the civil work has been completed. This includes laying the foundation for piers at two places on the Mula-Mutha riverbed.Officials said the viaduct has been installed on a 1km stretch, while four girder launchers have been pressed into service to install segments on the completed piers.The 8.3km Civil Court-Ramwadi stretch is a part of the second line of the Pune Metro project , connecting Vanaz and Ramwadi. Work on this stretch started about 18 months ago. The route comprises stations at RTO, Pune railway station, Dhole Patil Road, Bund Garden, Yerawada, Kalyaninagar and Ramwadi.MahaMetro officials said work on the pier foundations is at full swing across the route. “Barricades have been installed on Raja Bahadur Mill Road, Wadia College and Bund Garden Road,” an official said.Six piers crossing the riverbed are coming up at Sangam Bridge, while nine pillars will come up across the Mula-Mutha at Bund Garden. Barring the foundation for one pier near Sangam Bridge, work on all the other piers is ready, officials said.These piers will about around 22 metres high. “We plan to complete the viaduct work in both the riverbed sections before the arrival of the monsoon. We hope to remove the machinery and temporary ramps from the riverbed by June,” an official said.The MahaMetro has established a segment-casting yard at Wagholi and has approached the traffic police for assistance in launching the segments. MahaMetro has also sought permission from Central Railway to build the viaduct across the railway tracks at Sangam Bridge.

Title: Promoting knowledge centres can help strengthen fundamentals
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Nagpur: Research institutes and academicians have called for more focus on development of scientific methods and technology in agriculture sector as well as making base of youths stronger through knowledge centres instead of innovation hubs.

Physics professor and head of knowledge centre at Priyadarshini Institute of Engineering and Technology (PIET) Sanjay Jain said every college and school must have knowledge centres. “If the government wants to build scientific temperament, liberal funding must be done. In general, this sector gets very less funds. Instead of innovation hubs, knowledge centres must be promoted so that fundamentals are strengthened. We have Raman Science Centre (RSC) but we should have PPP model so that accountability will increase. The gap between arousing interest and teaching science is big,” he said.

Principal of Abha-Gaikwad College of Engineering Prashant Kadu said this is the dream year of Dr APJ Abdul Kalam, where he had given a vision of India2020. “The vision was of making India a sustainably developed country. The FM shall provide special provisions for agriculture, it can include subsidies for use of modern technology in creating better agri infrastructure. Provide funds for promotion of farmer’s producers organizations and MSME clusters for agriculture business. We must strengthen PM-Kisan, MNREGA, etc schemes for rural development,” he said.

Officer in-charge & Principal Scientist at Ginning Training Centre SK Shukla said, “Skill development programme in different areas of cotton processing are needed. Power generation from biomass pellet is being utilized in major countries. The reason is UN has declared that whosoever is using power from biomass will get carbon credit and tagged pollution free. If world over power plants are switching to pellet, India should also give up coal. Government will have to promote use of pellet to cut emissions. Instead of burning biomass, it can generate power,” he said.

Shukla also said there is lack of storage facilities for farmers which must be set up beside agricultural mechanization. “At taluka level, government must invest in bank of machines for farmers,” he said.

MS Ladaniya, Director & Mission Leader (Technology Mission on Citrus), ICAR — Central Citrus Research Institute, said scientific temperament among youths must be propagated. “To generate more interest about science and technology among youths, government should spend more on strengthening schools and science colleges across the country through better lab equipments, facilities and faculty. This will go a long way in building a society with scientific outlook in New India. Presently, our schools and colleges lack trained staff and desired facilities,” he said.

Title: Brexit deal: United Kingdom-European Union divorce final as Boris Johnson hails new dawn
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image (AFP)

LONDON: The UK's divorce from the European Union (EU) came into force on Friday night as it became the first country to exit the economic bloc after 47 years of membership following the vote in favour of Brexit in June 2016.

British Prime Minister Boris Johnson hailed the historic moment as the dawn of a new era for the UK in his address to the nation just before Brexit.

Brexit came into force at 11pm (2300 GMT).

"This is the moment when the dawn breaks and the curtain goes up on a new act in our great national drama," said Johnson, in his video message which promised hope and opportunity to every part of the United Kingdom .

"It is not just about some legal extrication. It is potentially a moment of real national renewal and change. This is the dawn of a new era in which we no longer accept that your life chances -- your family's life chances -- should depend on which part of the country you grow up in," he said.

Title: Man tests negative for coronavirus in Goa
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: The quarantined patient suspected to be infected by coronavirus , was discharged from Goa Medical College ( GMC )l on Friday after he tested negative.“The person who had travelled to China was admitted to GMC on January 28 for suspected coronavirus as a preventive measure. He tested negative for the virus on Friday. After his discharge, his condition will be monitored for 28 days as per the WHO guidelines,” an official said.Two more persons were brought under observation on Friday as they had visited China. This, is in addition to the six persons whose health is being monitored after they returned from China.As part of the all-India surveillance measures, Goa International Airport too started screening passengers since Thursday night. The state government had also asked for scanners to be installed at the Dabolim airport.

Title: 457 associate NCC officers clear Passing Out Parade
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Nagpur: The National Cadet Corps has inducted 457 associate NCC Officers into its fold at an impressive Passing Out Parade held at the Chunni Lal Parade Ground of NCC Officers’ Training Academy at Kamptee on Saturday.

The parade was reviewed by Maj Gen IJS Hundal, Commandant, NCC OTA Kamptee. Lt Vivek Anil Bale and Third Officer Sukhdev Chand won the Director General’s Baton for standing first in the order of merit among the Senior Division and Junior Division respectively. The Director General’s Banner for Inter Coy Championship was won by Shivaji Coy. The Parade was commanded by Third Officer Sandeep Kumar.

The selected professors and teachers from all over the country, trained to be commissioned as Associate NCC Officers, marched to the tunes of “Sare Jahan Se Accha” and ‘‘Kadam – Kadam Badhaye Jaa’’ rendered by the brass band of the ASC Centre South, Bangalore. The ceremony was witnessed by a number of service officers, civil dignitaries, relatives of Officer Cadets, schoolchildren and NCC Cadets.The Officer Cadets went through a rigorous three-month training programme that included PT, Yoga, Drill, Leadership & Personality Development and a host of other military and social awareness subjects like Swachh Bharat Abhiyan, Digital India, Disaster Management and several others; to empower them to conduct NCC training efficiently in their respective units.

The Reviewing Officer in his address, urged the passing out ANOs to uphold the aims and objectives of NCC and work towards effective Nation Building by shaping young minds. He called upon all ANOs to serve as role models for NCC cadets in particular and the society in general. He also reminded them of their bounden duty to ensure safety and security in effective and efficient conduct of the institutionalized and Camp training curriculum of the NCC. He also expressed his happiness on the high standards of Drill and training displayed by the passing out course and complimented Team OTA for the excellent conduct of training in the Academy.

Title: Give states power to decide on CAA, TRS MPs tell PM
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Hyderabad: States should be given the power to decide whether to implement legislation like the Citizenship (Amendment) Act ( CAA ). This was stated by TRS MPs K Keshava Rao and Nama Nagehswara Rao during an all-party meeting with Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Lok Sabha speaker Om Prakash Birla in Delhi on Thursday. The meeting was held ahead of the budget session in Parliament.

“Many state assemblies have passed resolutions against CAA. We said during the meeting that a detailed discussion should be held if the Centre legislates an Act and states pass resolutions against it,” Keshava Rao, who is a Rajya Sabha MP, told TOI. “Now a peculiar situation has arisen as thousands of people are out on the streets protesting against CAA, NPR and NRC. Federalism lies in states getting more powers.”

Telangana chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao has said his government will move a resolution against CAA in the upcoming assembly session.

If the Centre has the power to bring a bill, states have the right to express their opinion in the form of a resolution, he added. “We asked the Centre to think over the situation in the country. Apart from this, we asked for removing doubts on NPR and NRC as some Union ministers had made contradictory statements on NRC,” the TRS MP, who is also secretary general of the party, added.

Referring to GST and IGST dues, he said the present trend of increased centralisation of powers by the Union government was forcing the states to knock the doors of the Centre with a begging bowl for their legitimate funds. “Telangana was entitled for over Rs 50,000 crore dues which were not cleared,” Keshava Rao said.

TRS Lok Sabha floor leader Nama Nagehswara Rao said, “We also raised issues related to the economic slowdown and unemployment and their impact on the state. Besides, we want a discussion on issues pending over the bifurcation of Andhra Pradesh in 2014. Even after six years, many promises, like having a steel plant at Bayyaram have not been fulfilled.”

Title: Implementation of zero budget farming can ease farm distress
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Nagpur: In the Budget speech of 2019, finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman had made a push for zero budget farming, calling it a means to tackle the country’s agrarian problems. This year too, farm activists and experts are hoping for a similar approach for easing the farm distress.

Amravati’s Subhash Palekar, proponent of zero budget farming who has christened the method after his own name, says a lot of planning took place in the last one year. He hopes for some implementation to happen now. Not much could happen on the ground as it takes time for a large-scale conversion to an altogether new system, he says. Palekar hopes that some measures on zero budget may be announced on Saturday.

“The agricultural practice that I have been propagating does not need any budgetary allocation. Instead, the government needs to carry out promotional activities and all that a farmer needs to have is one cow of indigenous breed,” Palekar told TOI.

As Palekar hopes for some measures to be announced on what he calls as Subhash Palekar Natural Farming (SPNF), other farm activists have demanded a bailout package for the sector. There have been demands for loan waiver schemes too.

“The prime objective is to ensure cash flow into the rural economy leaving disposable income in the hands of farmers. The farmers’ income also needs to match the rising living standards. Even the wages under Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MNREGA) have gone up leaving more money in the hands of farm hands. The rates of agricultural produce too need to go up,” said Vijay Jawandhia, a veteran Shetkari Sanghatana activist.

Kishore Tiwari, chairman of Vasantrao Naik Shetkari Swavalamban Misison (VNSSM), said the government should declare a bailout package of Rs3 lakh crore, which can include a loan waiver plan too. VNSSM is Maharashtra government’s thinktank on farm crisis.

He also called for changes in the Prime Minister’s Crop Insurance Scheme. “The area for calculating losses should be brought down to an individual farm holding as against a block of villages or even a single village. At present, insurance companies grant compensation only if the losses are recorded in a block which includes 20 villages. This leaves many without any compensation,” said Tiwari.

Vijay Ingle, an award winning farmer from Akola district, says the government should increase subsidy for drip irrigation equipment. Referring to herbicide tolerant cotton seeds, he also demanded that government liberalize use of technology.

Meanwhile, Palekar said he had held meetings with Niti Aayog throughout the year. “The last meeting was held three months ago. I am not sure, but certainly hope that the government would come up with some more measures this time. I feel both chemical and organic farming are hazardous,” he says.

Title: Jeweller in debt spins robbery tale
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Ahmedabad: A 30-year-old jeweller from the Satellite area of city had on Monday filed a complaint stating that two men sprayed something on him after which he fell unconscious and they stole jewellery worth Rs 56 lakh from him. This has turned out to be a fabricated story, which he said he made up because he was in debt due to the slow down in the jewellery market.

A satellite police official said the jeweller, Bhaumik Shah, had alleged that two men had robbed him of ornaments worth Rs 56 lakh on Monday afternoon. Police had formed seven teams to nab the perpetrators.

When the cops asked for CCTV footage, Shah told them that his camera was not functional. Police later checked his mobile phones and found that various moneylenders had called Shah demanding money. Due to his suspicious behaviour, police questioned him about the incident and found discrepancies in his statements.

When the cops asked about his financial transactions, he broke down and told the cops that he had borrowed lot of money from various moneylenders. He told the cops that he had also thought of committing suicide, but on seeing his family dropped the idea.

To get himself out of the financial mess he found himself in due to the slowdown in the jewellery market, Shah decided to fabricate the robbery story to claim insurance of Rs 90 lakh.

Title: Decorated officer’s wife to give his Param Vir Chakra to ‘family’
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Rajeshwari Rane with her husband’s medals

PUNE: Octogenarian Rajeshwari Rane has always wanted that her husband Major Rama Raghoba Rane ’s Param Vir Chakra , a valued possession, stay with the family.

She will hand over the cherished medal to Chief of Army Staff General Manoj Naravane at Bombay Engineering Group (BEG) and Centre during the bicentenary parade of the Bombay Sappers on February 1.

“The Bombay Sappers have become a part of our family over the decades. So my husband’s medal should remain with the family forever. It will inspire generations of sappers to sacrifice everything for the nation,” she told TOI at her residence in Bhosalenagar.

Major Rane was decorated with the award in 1950. He had cleared a road block and anti-tank mines in Noushera-Rajouri road in Jammu & Kashmir despite being wounded in the mortar firing from Pakistan troops on April 8, 1948.

The armoured regiment could then launch its operation in the crucial sector the next day.

He was the first army officer to receive the award when alive. Rane was also the recipient of a record Five Mention-in-Despatches in operations, recommended by senior officers.

Rajeshwari’s association with the Bombay Sappers began on February 3, 1955, when they got married in Karwar in Karnataka.

“Our school had invited ‘Saheb’ (as she called Major Rane) for a felicitation. I was one of the five girls from the school who sang the welcome song in his honour. He saw me on stage and liked me instantaneously. When my parents got his marriage proposal, my father thought he had a bad leg. Saheb, when visiting our house for the first time, jumped across the well near our home to prove that he had good legs,” she recalled.

Major Rane was strict and disciplined, immaculate in his dressing and his food habits and an avid follower of all sports.

“Even after retirement, he would always wear a tie and polish his shoes before leaving home. He would wear the same attire to visit our farms in Daund . He had maintained this throughout his life,” she said.

Major Rane had shared a close association with Lt Gen PS Bhagat, the recipient of Victoria Cross, the highest gallantry award of the British forces.

Captain Rane was to arrive at Pune railway station on July 30, 1950 after he received the PVC from President Rajendra Prasad. The then BEG and Centre Commandant Colonel Bhagat went to receive him.

A rare Films Division footage shows army officers and the people surging at the Pune railway station to receive Captain Rane. He was garlanded and escorted in a procession in an open jeep through Sassoon Road and Bund Garden bridge.

“Colonel Bhagat was a highly decorated officer. But, he honoured Saheb throughout his career. I see this unique character in all the officers of the Bombay Sappers even today,” the octogenarian said.

Just two months before he died on July 11, 1994 at the Command Hospital, Saheb made a request to his wife. “He said he wanted his last rites performed at the BEG Centre. It was done so with full military honours. I am repaying the respect to that gesture and the affection by handing over the medal to the centre,” she added.

Title: 5 injured as fire breaks out after gas leakage in Hayathnagar building
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Hyderabad: A fire broke out in a newly-constructed building in Hayathnagar on Friday. The fire was caused by leakage of gas. Five persons, including a constable, suffered minor injuries.

The fire took place at 10.20 am in the ground floor in old Munganoor area. Constable Venkatesh of Amberpet police station along with his wife Uma and two relatives were in the building when the fire broke out. “They were doing a house-warming puja at that time,” said Hayathnagar inspector K Satish.

Police said the fire started due to a gas cylinder leakage. “Thanks to good ventilation, the gas did not accumulate,” said Satish. A fire tender and a mist bullet doused the fire. The injured persons were shifted to hospital. TNN

Title: From a quiet teenager who learned wrestling to a gun-toting radical
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

The boy fired at a student right in front of cops on Thursday.

Title: Trichy cops say no to RTI information, Chennai cops say yes
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

TRICHY: The traffic wing of Trichy city police has refused to disclose information on a query sought by a petitioner under the Right to Information Act (RTI) 2005 seeking statistics of cases booked for various traffic violations and penalties collected. The petitioner said that the plea was filed to ascertain whether the city traffic police are giving equal weightage to all traffic violations and not just helmetless riding, something which has been pointed out in complaints from the public. Ironically, he received answers to a similar RTI query posed to the Chennai traffic police for the corresponding period.

K P Rangaprasad, joint secretary of Satta Panchayat Iyakkam (SPI), filed the RTI query in September last year seeking answers to 17 questions including action taken against rash driving and signal jumping which are rampant in Trichy city. Since the traffic police did not provide a reply, he filed an appeal in December. He got a reply on January 13, but the data that he sought — on traffic violations and penalisation between January 2018 and October 2019 — was missing. Instead, the traffic police refused to share the information citing section 8 (1)(h) of the RTI Act which reads “information that impedes the process of investigation or apprehension or prosecution”. “We asked only the number of cases and penalty collected for various violations and certainly not any individual case details. Trichy traffic police have unlawfully denied a reply since they fear that their inefficiency in enforcement may get exposed,” Rangaprasad told TOI.

“If section 8 (1)(h) applies to Trichy traffic police in refusing the information sought on traffic violations, it should also apply to the Chennai traffic police. However, Chennai police furnished the information we asked,” Rangaprasad added. The petitioner said his organisation will take legal recourse in this regard against the city traffic police by approaching the State Information Commission. “We denied reply for the RTI queries only after consulting with our legal experts,” an official with city traffic police wing said.

Title: SCB razes illegal structure in Lalbazar, to continue drive
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

SCB workers demolish the illegal structure in Kakaguda, Lalbazar

SECUNDERABAD: Ahead of Secunderabad Cantonment Board (SCB) elections, officials are conducting drives to tackle the issue of illegal structures under their jurisdiction. As part of one such drive, the SCB demolition squad razed an illegal structure at Kakaguda in the Lalbazar area of Secunderabad Cantonment.

“On receiving a tip off, SCB engineering officials visited the property at Kakaguda and found that the property owner had built nine pillars on G+2 structure, and was dumping building material on the roof in a bid to raise a third floor. We immediately verified our records to check if any requests had been submitted by the property owner to construct these pillars. But so such request was made and no permissions were sanctioned by the engineering wing to the owner,” SCB additional engineer, B Balakrishna told TOI.

“With the permission of SVR Chandra Sekhar, SCB chief executive officer, we deployed a demolition squad and razed the entire illegal structure. We also warned the property owner that severe action would be initiated as per the Cantonment Act, if he tries to rebuild the structure later,” he said.

Authorities said that it was difficult to curb such illegal additions to existing structures as property owners build the primary structures as per rules and construct the illegal additions much later, on the sly.

“Most property owners initially build the structures as per Cantonment law with all permissions and documentation. After a few years, the same property owners construct illegal structures by raising the floors,” a senior SCB engineering wing official said.

While residents claim that official apathy is the root cause for the increasing number of encroachments, SCB authorities said that they have been making consistent efforts to address the problem. Officials said that they were conducting systematic drives in all areas to identify defaulters and were attending to any and all complaints on illegal construction.

Officials appealed to people to approach SCB with evidence of illegal structures in their locality and assured that the informant’s details and whereabouts would be kept confidential.

Title: Expansion mode: Clubs bet on more sports facilities
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

AHMEDABAD: Rapid urbanization has either shrunk or altogether wiped out open spaces and playgrounds. As a result, demand has grown for sports facilities in city clubs. And most clubs that are in the expansion mode are batting for developing sports facilities. City-based developer Savvy group will inaugurate Sports Sanskaar, a dedicated sports-centric club in Ahmedabad on Sunday.

“The sports club has been set up to provide an international-level sports academy in Ahmedabad,” said Jaxay Shah, the managing director of Savvy Infrastructures.

“It will offer facilities and training to sports and health enthusiasts.” The club will house a 500 metre swimming pool and practice and kids’ pool; a football field, a cricket pitch; tennis, badminton, squash, and basketball courts; and a 400 metre relay track.

Some of the older and established clubs in the city — Gujarat Sports Club , Rajpath Club, and Karnavati Club — which have already acquired land for expansion are laying special emphasis on developing more sports facilities.

“There is a space constraint on the current premises which will not be the case in the upcoming clubs and thus, more sports-centric facilities will come up,” said Naimish Marfatia , the honorary secretary of Gujarat Sports Club. “The facilities include three tennis courts, four badminton courts, and a large swimming pool.

Cumulative investments to the tune of a couple of hundred crores are estimated as these facilities get developed. “Rajpath Club plans to invest Rs 50-70 crore for the new premises which will focus on sports facilities,” said Rajpath Club secretary, Mishal Patel .

“Majority of the younger members demand and use sports amenities. A dedicated cycling track in addition to a nature park are also in the offing.”

Karnavati Club is expected house a dedicated children’s park and rifle-shooting range, in addition to other sports amenities on its upcoming premises on Sanand-Kadi Road.

Title: Trichy slips to rank 3 in citizen feedback despite proxy vote
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Trichy Corporation Commissioner S Sivasubramanian addressing the college students on swachh survekshan

TRICHY: Despite the large-scale proxy voting pursued by Trichy corporation in submitting feedback to evaluate its performance in maintaining the city’s cleanliness, the urban local body has slipped to rank 3 among the cities in the state on the number of feedback submitted.

As part of Swachh Survekshan 2020 (SS2020), the ministry of housing and urban affairs has been receiving feedback from residents of all participating cities since January 1. As the feedback recording process concluded on Friday, statistics on the official website of SS2020 revealed that Trichy is behind Coimbatore and Madurai among the Tamil Nadu cities in this regard. The feedback will be obtained by the agency entrusted by MoHUA in multiple modes including face-to-face interviews, outbound calls, Swachhata application, SS2020 web portal and “vote for your city” application seeking responses for questions asked on grading the performance of the local body in maintaining public hygiene.

While it is mandatory for the residents to submit their own feedback, Trichy corporation in the past few weeks registered proxy feedback posing as residents. By obtaining the mobile numbers of the residents, employees and people entrusted by the corporation have been recording feedback for a set of questionnaire, all in favour of the civic body. “During the oral polio vaccination, corporation workers obtained our mobile number and asked us to submit the one time password received in a text message. It seems that the civic body submitted favourable feedback for SS2020 on behalf of us,” H Ghouse Baig, a resident of Khajamalai said. While the survey is conducted for a total of 6,000 marks, 25% of the marks are earmarked for the citizen feedback category.

Title: Dowry: Newlywed woman hangs self
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A newly-married woman hung herself to death in her Vanasthalipuram residence on Friday. Police said S Pallavi took the extreme step following harassment by her businessman-husband and in-laws. A dowry death case was registered. Police, however, are yet to arrest the offenders.

Pallavi, who worked in HSBC before her marriage two months ago, was just 28. “At the time of the marriage, the woman’s family gave Rs 2 lakh cash along with jewellery and household items as dowry. Soon after the marriage, her in-laws started harassing her physically and mentally demanding additional dowry,” said Vanasthalipuram inspector A Venkataiah. Pallavi was an MBA graduate.

Soon after her in-laws went out for a hospital check-up and husband Santosh for business work, Pallavi hung herself to the ceiling fan at her Sri Srinivasapuram Colony residence. “She must have taken the extreme step between 8am and 9 am,” the inspector said.

When the in-laws — Srihari and Vijayalakshmi — came and knocked the door, she did not respond.They broke the door only to find her hanging from the ceiling fan.

Police shifted her body to a hospital for an autopsy.

Following a complaint from Pallavi’s parents, a case was filed against Santosh and the in-laws.

Title: 98-year-old WWII veteran travels from England to bask in his unit’s glory
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

(From left) Lt Gen Michael Mathews, Lt Gen SN Sharma (retd) & Major David Young (retd)

PUNE: Major David Young is 98 years old, but the World War II veteran, a Military Cross awardee who lives in England , came all the way to the Bombay Engineering Group (BEG) and Centre, his alma mater in Khadki , to be a part of his unit’s bicentenary celebrations.

Young who participated in the heritage walk said his visit to the centre on Friday was after 77 years and the centre’s progress had surprised him.

Like him, many veterans of the Bombay Sappers were overwhelmed by the artefacts, wall paintings, medals, and flags inside the renovated museum. Former Engineer-in-Chief Lt Gen SM Sharma (retired), the seniormost veteran, and youngest recruit, Charanjit Singh, inaugurated the museum.

Young, who commanded 30 field company of the Royal Engineers of the British Army in the Burma sector, told TOI, “It’s a wonderful feeling to be here and to spend the morning with officers and sappers of my unit. I am proud of this historic occasion.”

He said the unit had remembered him even though he was in England and had invited him for the bicentenary celebrations. “Remembering our brave men is the core ethos of the Bombay Sappers. Hence, I am here today,” he said.

“In early 1942, we were sent to the Burma sector and were there till July 1945. Post-war, our unit carried out infrastructural works in Malaysia. I was awarded the medal for my contributions in the Southern Burma sector,” Young recalled.

After returning to England in 1946, he said, former Indian Army Chief General KV Krishna Rao, who had also fought in the Burma sector, kept him updated about the Bombay Sappers.

The museum has sections like the martyrs’ gallery, generals’ stand, sappers’ room, sports wing and others.

“We have renovated our old buildings and converted them into the museum. There 75,000 names stored in the electronic kiosk. Each sapper and officer will find his name at a click of a mouse. The remaining will also be included,” Brigadier MJ Kumar, Commandant of BEG and Centre, told TOI.

The martyrs’ gallery has records of the brave sappers along with records, pictures and information about the Bombay Sappers in pre and post-independence.

The heritage walk culminated at the memorial of second Group Subedar Major Savee Erappa Satoor. On Friday evening, Chief of Army Staff General Manoj Naravane attended an orchestra at the Centre.

Title: Warangal: Three students drown
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Warangal: Three students drowned in a temple lake in Gorrekunta village of Geesugonda mandal on Thursday. The deceased have been identified as I Pranay (9), A Ranadheer (9) and B Nikhila (7). According to inspector Shivaramaiah, three students from Christian Colony in Warangal went to the temple lake as it was a school holiday. Noticing the children drowning, locals informed police and rushed to the spot. Revenue staff and police retrieved the bodies. TNN

Title: Edu fair to open avenues for studying abroad
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Panaji: The Overseas Education Fair, 2020 will be held at the premises of Entertainment Society of Goa at Campal in Panaji, on Sunday from 10.30am to 5pm. The fair will open avenues for those aspiring to study in foreign nations by applying to the best universities across the globe.

The Times of India and K C Overseas, one of the prominent overseas education consultants in the country, will organise the fair offering the best of universities, colleges and education programmes across the world by bringing a gamut of top universities and experts from global education domains and delegates from reputed universities under one roof.

Entry for the fair is free and students can avail discounts on spot enrollments for GRE, GMAT, SAT, TOEFL, IELTS or PTE coaching (pre-requisites for admission abroad).

Spot application assessment and counselling will enable students to get an overview about the course options, programme benefits, admission criteria, application process, visa processing, internships, scholarships and job prospects in their desired study destination abroad, as well as post study work visa options.

Title: Eflu nixes latest academic reforms
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Secunderabad: The English and Foreign Languages University (EFLU), Hyderabad cancelled its order pertaining to reforms on admission, intake and evaluation on Friday following protests by students.

For the last three days, a section of students at Eflu boycotted classes and held a protest within campus. An order issued by registrar stated – “The honble vice-chancellor has given approval for the cancellation of the communication no EFLU/RO/2020/67, posted on the university website on January 28. The communication stands cancelled.”

The students had launched an indefinite strike against the orders, which they termed ‘arbitrary’. Following cancellation orders , students revoked their strike and decided to resume classes from Saturday. TNN

Title: SCR cops saved 1,000 kids from mishaps last year
Content:
A similar drive was also conducted to promote safety of female passengers across India on December 4, 2019 (Fi... Read More

SECUNDERABAD: Thanks to round-the-clock monitoring , Railway Protection Force (RPF) personnel saved lives of 67 passengers trying to board running trains and rescued 1,063 children from grave mishaps in South Central Railway (SCR) zone, in 2019.Senior officials from SCR said that RPF personnel have acted as a ‘bridge between state police and railway administration’.“Some 741 cases of unlawful possession of railway property worth Rs 72 lakh were registered and 860 criminals were arrested,” read an official release from SCR.“South Central Railway has been recognized as the second best zone among all Indian Railways zones with regards to recovering misplaced luggage. The luggage was retrieved and handed over to rightful owners on 1,704 occasions,” the statement said.In order to address the safety issues of people with disabilities, officials said that they had conducted a special drive on December 3, 2019 to coincide with ‘international day of persons with disabilities’. During the drive, officials identified 418 members who were misusing coaches reserved for the disabled and they were fined as per norm.A similar drive was also conducted to promote safety of female passengers across India on December 4, 2019. As a result of the drive , RPF apprehended 488 male passengers for entering ladies compartments. The passengers were fined Rs 26 thousand under the SCR jurisdiction.With regard to inspection of stranded vehicles at railway premises, officials said that eight vehicles involved in crimes were found at stations during a special drive in August 2019.“RPF has been working round-the clock and improving its response mechanism. We also aim to provide them with better facilities by adopting several technology-enabled modes of surveillance and security systems,” said SCR officials, adding: “Several measures are being undertaken by our security department for smooth experience of passengers.”

Title: Shroff versus Shroff: Plea for Rs 1.3 crore a month maintenance
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: The matrimonial dispute between Jaidev Shroff, global CEO, UPL, and his estranged wife Poonam Shroff came up before Bombay high court on Friday with the final hearing of her plea for monthly maintenance of Rs 1.3 crore.

His counsel team of Navroz Seervai and Vineet Naik launched a response on law before a bench of Justice Ajay Gadkari. Seervai read out from Poonam’s petition to argue hers was a “luxury lifestyle,” by her own admission, on pages 170 to 184. He argued while she had emphasised on the expenses incurred during travel and shopping, she was yet to account for or establish an entitlement for her claim of Rs 1.3 crore per month.

She had based her plea on monthly expenses, including maintaining her child. Seervai said she was “ridiculously inflating the figures,” but had “not been able to establish even to an extent of zilch” to justify her claim and had challenged the order of the trial court seeking to enhance an already more than sufficient alimony pendante lite to her.

Justice Gadkari asked her counsel Rohit Kapadia to declare under which provision they would proceed. It was declared the matter proceed under Special Marriage Act. It will be heard next week.

Title: Mata Aarogyam Kidzathon at SPPU on February 9
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Savitribai Phule Pune University

PUNE: Maharashtra Times has organized a marathon for children and early teenagers, on February 9 in an effort to raise awareness on healthy living among children.

The marathon, titled the Maharashtra Times Aarogyam Kidzathon, will start at the Savitribai Phule Pune University campus at Shivajinagar and will run under multiple courses, divided into age groups and physical ability. Participants can register for the marathon on the website (www.mataarogyamrun.com) or call on 9657032609.

Running bibs for the marathon will be available at Maharashtra Times’ office on Fergusson College Road on February 7 and 8.

The categories have been designed in a manner that does not compromise the health of the young participants, while encouraging them to exercise and run. Toddlers aged 2 to 4 years have the course marked at 100 metres, while children aged 4 to 7 years will run 1.5 kilometres, titled the ZIP run. The ZAP run, for children aged 7 to 12 years, is 3-kilometres-long. The top category, named the Zoom run, is of 5 kilometres. The course will be located inside the Pune university campus.

A special category, named the Dream Run, has been reserved for differently-abled participants. Differently-abled children aged 16 years or under can participate in the 1.5 kilometre run. Support for the runners will be available throughout the course, including hydration counters, refreshments, first aid, and route support. Participants and runners will get medals and certificates.

As a precursor to Kidzathon, the run’s mentor Prasad Patil will lead a training and conditioning session for registered participants on Sunday February 2 at 7am at the varsity campus.

Patil, the run’s mentor, is a part of the Pune Running Collective’s Aundh chapter. He is also a life coach.

(For details, log onto www.mataarogyamrun.com)

Title: Backward class students launch protest against hostel mess contractor
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Students protest at Babasaheb Ambedkar Social Welfare Bhavan near Deekshabhoomi on Friday

Nagpur: Over 100 socially backward class students staying at the state social welfare department ’s Manish Nagar boys hostel are up in arms after being served inadequate, poor quality and contaminated food by the private mess contractor. They accused the contractor’s staff of threatening them for objecting to the food issues at the hostel, and accused officials of asking them whether they are here for “food or education”.

After the inmates declared an indefinite hunger strike outside the department’s office at Babasaheb Ambedkar Social Welfare Bhavan on South Ambazari Road on Friday, authorities set up a panel of three assistant social welfare commissioners to probe the allegations.

The assistant commissioners of Chandrapur, Gondia and Bhandara will conduct the probe and submit a report in a couple of days, said Nagpur’s assistant commissioner (hostels) Babasaheb Deshmukh. “The guilty should be identified and will be dealt with as per law,” Deshmukh said.

The premises witnessed tension when the students, mainly from SC/ST categories, refused to leave, and demanded immediate sacking of the contractor. Cops were called, after which some of the students were asked to accompany them to the assistant commissioner’s office. The students refused to meet the officer but left the premises when cops informed them about the setting up of the inquiry panel.

BA-LLB final year student Pundalik Pathale said the issues have gone unresolved for the last four months. “We were promised a new contractor would be appointed in September. We waited till January and on the 20th we met the divisional commissioner at this department. He said by January 31 all issues will be resolved. We have been missing classes but authorities are not bothered,” he said.

Pathale said the commissioner has told them to do whatever they want, and asked if “they come for education or food”.

The inmates claimed they have been facing drunk hostel mess staffers who threaten them, kharra residue in cooked rice, and non-veg stuff in vegetarian food. “The problem has increased now. We can tolerate poor quality food but not threats. When we request them not to eat kharra while serving or cooking food, they intimidate us by asking us to meet them outside. They also threaten to hold back our Rs800 monthly stipend,” said BE final year student Vikas Khetre.

The inmates, enrolled for different courses in city colleges, said they even asked for direct transfer of mess funds in their accounts but were told that they will get only 50%. “We want to eat out. The government allocates Rs4,800 per student. But they refuse to give full amount to us,” said Sagar Lanjewar.

BA student Harshal Sontakke also said the contractor’s men told them that they can eat only twice a day while they are entitled to three meals.

Title: Ahead of budget, Telangana eyeing bigger central pie
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Telangana CM K Chandrashekhar Rao

HYDERABAD: As all eyes are on Saturday’s Union budget , Telangana is looking for a bigger central pie. Telangana is among four states in the country which account for higher contribution of state revenues to the central pool but get far less fund transfers from it. Experts said the budget presentation on Saturday will also have an impact on budget estimates of Telangana for next year.

Telangana along with Haryana, Maharashtra and Tamil Nadu has over 70% share of state revenues in the central pool. States like Bihar, J&K, Himachal Pradesh and north-eastern states, however, depend heavily on central fund transfers to manage their revenues.

Haryana tops the list of the states which has 77% of receipts from the state revenues, while the rest accrues from the central share. Haryana is closely followed by Maharashtra with 74% of state receipts, while Tamil Nadu and Telangana share the third place with 70% of state revenues. “This would mean that Telangana has only 30% dependency on the central share of fund transfers. This is certainly not a good sign for a state which was born just five-and-a-half years ago,” a senior official pointed out.

Total revenue receipts of states comprise revenues from own sources and transfers from the central pool. During 2015-20, 53% of revenue receipts of states had come from own sources, while 47% accrued from central transfers.

Own revenue sources consist of tax revenue (45%) and non-tax revenue (8%). Central transfers consist of share in central taxes (28%) and grants-in-aid from Centre (19%). As per the recommendations of the 14th Finance Commission, the share of states in Union taxes was increased from 32% to 42%.

During the 13th Finance Commission period (2010-15), the share of devolution of central taxes and grants-in-aid from the Centre in the revenue receipts of states was at 22% and 17% respectively.

Title: Health care ‘unwell’, so repeat dose of demand for more funds
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Nagpur: More allocation for public health sector, better infrastructure in government hospitals, funds for more medical colleges, tax relief on life-saving medicines, affordable joint replacement surgeries, cheaper diagnostics services and so on — the list appears repetitive but the health sector of Vidarbha is still expecting the same from the government.

Those in the health care sector said the midterm Budget presented by NDA 2 was disappointing. “What can we expect from the Budget that allocates 1% of the total GDP for entire health care sector of the country having 130 crore plus population? Last year, the allocation was about Rs62,000 crore which is nearly 1.1% of the total GDP,” said Dr Deepak Vaishnav , senior executive officer of a corporate hospital in city.

“Central Government has mentioned in its National Health Policy that it will earmark 2.5% of the total GDP for health care. This figure comes to Rs1.50 lakh crore. I expect this Budget to at least come closer to this figure,” he said.

Citizens expect some cut in their monthly expenses on medicines. “More than 40% of the urban population purchases medicines for hypertension and diabetes. These medicines are to be taken for lifetime. So, they should be cheaper,” said Rekha Manwatkar, a housewife.

Private sector shoulders more than 80% burden of India’s health care. The economic slump has affected this sector badly. “The usual 13% to 15% profit margin has shrivelled to 7-8% which not even covers burden of high bank interest rate. Commercial bank interest rates, minimum salary benchmarking, and other government norms are adding to the per bed expenditure leading to significant losses for hospitals,” said Dr Anup Marar , director of a leading private hospital in city.

“Moreover, rates under government schemes are very less. Cashless services, subsidized charges are increasing fiscal crisis. I expect health care sector should come under the 5% slot of GST which may provide some relief,” he said.

Doctors working in government set-up were not willing to be named but their expectations too focused around more allocations to health sector. AIIMS Nagpur is shaping up fast but it needs more allocations from the Centre to recruit staff and teachers for super speciality section.

Other institutions are mostly linked to state government, so they expect that Budget should fill state’s kitty with more money for health sector expenses.

Doctors of AYUSH section too expect more funds. “Entire AYUSH budget for the year 2019 was Rs1,938.76 crore. During the same period, turnover of Patanjali Ltd was more than Rs8,000 crore. Many such companies are making huge money in the name of AYUSH but the sector which is backbone of this economy is in crisis,” said Dr Mohan Yende, organizer of Maharashtra State National Integrated Medical Association.

Yende also wants Ayurveda to be declared as National System of Medicine and promoted in all government and private sectors.

Health insurance is important for salaried class. “Government wants more citizens to get covered with health insurance, but charges 28% GST on its premium. This can’t be a way to encourage people to go for insurance. Cut GST rates and make health insurance affordable,” said insurance adviser Abhishek Ingle.

WISH LIST

Cheaper medicines of lifestyle disorders like diabetes, hypertension

Tax relief on preventive health check-ups

Concession in GST/ other tax benefits for health insurance

Spend 2.5% of GDP on health sector

Incentives for smaller hospitals, clinics in Tier II, III cities

Increasing package rates under Ayushman Bharat/CGHS schemes

Funding, incentives for private sector to increase beds

Digital health care, online pharmacy

Higher pay scale for PG doctors serving in rural areas

This story is from February 1, 2020
