Title: Multi-level parking lot to come up on 1.6 acres now
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Talking development: Mangaluru Smart City Limited MD Mohammed Nazeer (left) addresses the media in Mangaluru o... Read More

Mangaluru: Mangaluru Smart City Limited (MSCL) has changed its plan prepared for the construction of a multi-level car parking (MLCP) complex in the city.

The MSCL had planned to build an MLCP on 2.2 acres at Hampankatta, and a tender in this regard was already finalised. However, MSCL could not come to an agreement with landowners, who possess 60 cents in the area.

Hence, the plan has been changed and the MLCP will be built on 1.6 acres owned by the Mangaluru City Corporation (MCC), said MSCL managing director Mohammed Nazeer .

The MSCL had planned to take up the project of constructing an MLCP with commercial complex and other facilities at an estimated cost of Rs 94 crore though the Smart City mission.

“We held several meetings at the local levels and through the deputy commissioner and chairman of MSCL. However, we could not finalise the project since owners of 60 cents in the nearby areas are not agreeing to the terms and conditions we laid. Meanwhile, the conditions laid down by the landowners are not agreeable for us. Hence, we have decided to redesign the project by limiting the MLCP complex to 1.6 acres owned by the MCC,” Nazeer said.

In fact, the MSCL had in September 2019 awarded the contract to build the proposed MLCP to a company. However, now the plan will have to be changed based on the availability of land, he said, adding that the work is expected to begin in the first week of February.

Initially, the MLCP project was planned through Mangaluru Urban Development Authority (MUDA). However, in 2014, a council meeting of the MCC decided to implement the project on its own through PPP.

However, after Mangaluru city was selected under the Smart City mission of the central government, the MLCP project was included in it.

Title: Gujarat to have website for cadaver organ donation
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A year after setting up the State Organ and Tissue Transplant Organization (SOTTO), Gujarat will now launch a dedicated website for coordination of cadaver organ donation. Dr Jayanti Ravi, principal secretary, health, informed the same on Friday to participants of the 3rd roundtable on organ donation organized by The Times of India (TOI) and Kokilaben Dhirubhai Ambani Hospital (KDAH) in Ahmedabad. Ravi said the website will be launched in February, within a month.

“The development is in final stage. After deliberations, it was decided that it would be modelled on the NOTTO website and hosted by the National Informatics Centre (NIC) to address safety and privacy concerns,” said Dr Ravi. States like Tamil Nadu and Kerala already have such websites in place.

The roundtable was also attended by Jai Prakash Shivahare, commissioner (health); Dr Somnath Chattopadhyay and Dr Santosh Shetty from KDAH, Mumbai; Dr Rajesh Chandwani from IIM Ahmedabad; Dr Dhiren Shah, heart transplant surgeon; Dr Chirag Desai, liver transplant surgeon; Dr Kavita Parihar, nephrologist; and Bhavna Chhabria from Shatayu.

While Dr Chattopadhyay deliberated on hand-holding of smaller centres and hospitals by major hospitals to create a cohesive ecosystem, citing example of Mumbai, Dr Desai advocated a system of transplant coordinators at both transplant and non-transplant hospitals that can work closely with relatives of brain-dead patients.

Dr Parihar put forth the issue of non-representation of private hospitals in SOTTO and said that the robust model should have organ-specific committees involving all stakeholders. Dr Shah seconded her, adding that steps such as generation of common waiting list have not been implemented so far.

“The hospitals affiliated with medical colleges have been authorized for declaration of brain stem death in the state. Extensive training workshops have been organized for the doctors and staff which is yielding good results,” said Shivahare, adding that they will be working on awareness campaigns to dispel myths.

Dr Chandwani said that organ donation is a complex process and at initial stage should focus on organ retrieval. For the same, training and transparency can do the trick. Chhabria mentioned that non-transplant hospitals in Gujarat have no transplant coordinators or ‘grief counsellors’ who could work with doctors and relatives and also stressed on early-stage education initiatives.

The participants said that Gujarat has a chance to learn from good practices from India and abroad with government and health sector-led initiatives including better identification of brain-dead patients, coordination between various agencies, transparent organ retrieval and distribution system and better awareness among citizens.

(with inputs from Kapil Dave )

Title: GHMC tax inspector in net for Rs 75,000 bribe
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: ACB sleuths arrested a GHMC tax inspector on Friday for demanding Rs 75,000 bribe to transfer the title of house ownership of a retired Army Major General . ACB officials said the accused official, P Jagan , insisted on the bribe.

The sleuths trapped Jagan red-handed on Khairatabad main road at 2.45 pm when he accepted the tainted money from Degala Raju, who represented the former Army officer Satish Chandra Nair. Jagan is a tax inspector in circle 18, zone-5, Khairatabad, GHMC.

“The retired officer wanted to transfer the title of ownership of Jubilee Hills house on Road No. 10 from his deceased wife to his son and sent an application with necessary documents through Raju to GHMC office,” said an ACB official.

ACB officials said Jagan demanded bribe from Raju to hand over the mutation proceedings and to continue old tax pertaining to the house in the name of Nair’s wife. After completing the mutation work, Jagan demanded Raju to pay Rs 1 lakh to receive the proceedings and to not increase the house tax.

It was then Raju approached ACB following Nair’s instructions. “Jagan agreed to hand over the documents for Rs 75,000. We caught him while accepting the bribe,” said an ACB official.

He was arrested. He will be produced before the ACB special court on Saturday for judicial remand.

Title: Economic slowdown shadow on Telangana budget
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

K Chandrashekhar Rao

HYDERABAD: The economic slowdown has had an impact on Telangana budget with the allocation pegged at Rs 1.48 lakh crore in 2019-20 though the estimates had put the figure in excess of Rs 2 lakh crore mark.

Looking at the revenue receipts by the end of December in 2019, Telangana has performed well on a few parameters, experts aver. They, however, point to the state receiving far less from the central pool.

The finance department is estimating that revenues for the state would improve in the last quarter of the financial year and budget estimates could look up. However, the state’s own tax revenue growth is not much to talk about.

Sources said the state government is looking at the reasons for shortfall in growth and the budget estimates would be prepared based on this. Thankfully, the grant-in-aid receipts could reach the budget estimates by December-end.

Revenue from excise and stamps and registrations is another worry. In what could cheer up the state, the Centre gave Rs 1,400 crore recently towards GST compensation to Telangana. However, the revenue growth stands at 3.5% as against 16% Telangana had recorded at one time.

Senior finance officials said the budget estimates for the state would depend on what the Centre would grant for projects like Mission Bhagiratha and Mission Kakatiya.

Title: Telangana seeks Rs 1,400 crore to upgrade government hospitals
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

K Chandrashekhar Rao

HYDERABAD: The state has sought Rs 1,400 crore from the Centre to upgrade government hospitals . Officials said they are seeking funds from the National Health Mission (NHM) to give a facelift to the hospitals , especially in districts. Senior health officials will head to Delhi soon to discuss the details with the NHM authorities.

Officials said upgrading equipment, expanding mother and child care centres, purchasing vehicles to transport pregnant women from their residence to hospitals and appointing specialised doctors were among the proposals.

Title: BJP to meet Prez on Tukkuguda election
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Hyderabad: BJP has decided to keep the heat on recent Tukkuguda municipality chairperson election by calling the bluff of TRS. A BJP delegation will submit a memorandum to President Ram Nath Kovind and Vice-President M Venkaiah Naidu. BJP also urged governor Tamilisai Soundararajan to seek an explanation from TRS government on malpractices and irregularities committed during the election of municipal chairpersons and mayors for corporations. It demanded a high-level inquiry into misuse of power and violation of constitutional norms by TRS.

A delegation led by state BJP president K Laxman met the governor on Thursday and submitted a memorandum highlighting irregularities and misuse of official machinery by TRS during and after the polls.

Laxman said TRS went all-out to take control of municipalities and corporations by violating constitutional norms. “It used ex-officio members to win chairman and vice-chairman posts neglecting mandate of people who voted for BJP,” he said.

BJP won nine out of 15 wards in Tukkududa and TRS bagged only five wards. “Yet, it managed to get posts of chairman and vice-chairman using illegal means,” he said. He said TRS MP K Keshava Rao should be suspended from Rajya Sabha membership for violation of constitutional norms.

In the memorandum, BJP said ex-officio member Sabita Indra Reddy was shifted to Tukkuguda in violation of the Municipalities Act though she had chosen Badangpet.

Title: Need more funds for better quality & infra in edu sector
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Nagpur: Academicians are hoping that Budget 2020 will bring in more money for education sector to help improve not only the quality but also infrastructure.

MLC from teachers constituency Nago Ganar has been a strong proponent of increasing budgetary allocation for education. “We need to spend at least 6 to 8% of GDP on education without which quality of existing set-up cannot be sustained, forget about upgrading it,” said Ganar.

Madhusudhan Mude, president of Headmasters Association, said, “What we need to focus on is school education because that is the foundation of creating quality human resource. Funding is needed for introducing technology in all schools.”

Rajendra Dayma, president of Independent English Schools Association, said, “Central government should ensure that ample funding is available for all schemes floated by it. Money for schemes like RTE etc must be given to beneficiaries on time as well at the level it is supposed to.”

Mohd Shahid Sharif, an education activist, said integrated funding for education is needed. “Right from early childhood to higher education, we must have a comprehensive plan. Else what happens is that you have lot of funding going to higher education while schools starve for funds,” said Sharif.

Zafar Khan, founder-president of School Headmasters Charitable Association, said, “At any cost, you cannot ignore upgradation of school education because we need funding for training teachers, upgrading their skills and introducing technology in schools to bridge the urban-rural gap.”

Higher education too is in dire need of attention from the government, say academicians.

Baban Taywade, senior academician and former Nagpur University (NU) senate member, said, “Universities are dependent on quality faculty and infrastructure. And these can happen only if government ensures a steady stream of funding. We need to open more government education institutes as private ones are extremely costly,” said Taywade.

Former NU registrar and noted academician Mahesh Yenkie says faculty is the key. “Lack of faculty is evident in many universities and that’s where the problem starts. We need quality faculty at the helm for which the government needs to provide funding. If you have top class faculty then quality research and development (R&D) will follow,” said Yenkie.

Sanjay Charalwar, former principal of Mohota Science College and NU senate member, said, “There is an urgent requirement for funding of infrastructure. When you build word class institutes and facilities, an environment of excellence is created. Also, salaries of all teachers should be at par and they must be well paid. Funding for regular training is also needed.”

Title: Kolkata netizens wary of posts ‘celebrating’ Jamia firing
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: The minor, who shot at the anti-CAA protesters at Jamia Nagar in Delhi, had reportedly uploaded numerous posts berating the movement and openly threatened the participants. The brazen act has been criticized across the country but what has alarmed Kolkatans is that a handful in the city seem to be “justifying and celebrating” the act.Concerned netizens in Kolkata have, thus, now started reporting all such social media profiles to the Kolkata Police cyber cell. On Friday, at least two citizens — Aiyub Khan and Pablo — tagged the messages that have been “celebrating” the violent act that left a Jamia Millia University student injured.Pablo, an engineering student residing at Sealdah, for example, has decided to approach police after another Facebook user put up a status hailing the minor as a ‘hero’. “I am hoping you would take action,” he said. The cops have acknowledged the awareness among netizens but have not detailed on whether they will probe specific cases.“We will not like to comment on individual posts. We need to look into the legal implications where end ramifications matter a lot. However, we are keeping a watch on online trends through the social media cell,” said an investigating officer.Talking to TOI, an IPS officer stated that they have a standard operating procedure (SOP) of dealing with such cases. According to him, each case is taken up for legal vetting and sometimes, counselling is offered to the accused. This necessarily involves explaining the private and public domain and a distinction between beliefs and clear threats.“Once we get the initial complaint through email, we forward it to Facebook, WhatsApp, Twitter or Instagram authorities, marking out the exact complaint. It usually takes some time for them to respond. Then we launch an initial inquiry. Not all cases can be clubbed under the Information Technology Act. Based on the written and the signed statement — it is compulsory under CrPC — we slap sections of IT Act or IPC sections. But for all such cases, the initial inquiry is most vital to fix responsibilities and gauge the seriousness of the complaint,” said an investigating officer.Bivas Chatterjee, an expert in cyber laws, who is also a special public prosecutor, said the posts show lack of maturity.“Often, fake profiles are used to put out such posts. In a diverse country like India, sensitivity is important. That comes through maturity in internet use. That is missing here. But then, merely putting out views cannot be a crime. The conduct, motive and end purpose are all important in deciding the criminality involved in a post,” he said.

Title: Will take 2 days to fully restore water supply, says KWA
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Kochi: People affected by the ruptured pipelines near Vyttila Junction will have to wait longer for undisrupted water supply. Even with the Kerala Water Authority focused on repairing the three damaged lines, officials said it would be a couple of days before supply is fully restored. The affected portions are on the eastern and southern sides of NH-66 near the junction.

KWA assistant executive engineer Prakash Chandran is confident of completing the work by Friday midnight. “One of the damaged pipelines has already been repaired. Work of the remaining two lines can be completed by midnight. However, it will take a couple of days to completely address complaints relating to shortage in supply of drinking water,” he said.

The authority maintained that it would be able to meet the demand with water from the Aluva treatment plant. While some residents have complained of taps going dry, others have raised the issue of mucky water.

Water supply to Vyttila, Kadavanthra, Elamkulam, Chilavannoor, Poonithura, Gandhi Square, Petta, Champakkara has been completely disrupted since Wednesday.

Meanwhile, traffic cops are having a tough time re-routing traffic, especially heavy vehicles. As the service road on the eastern side of NH-66 has been dug up to repair the pipeline , heavy vehicles are banned from using the Ponnurunni NH underpass to proceed towards Kaniyampuzha Road, Vyttila Mobility Hub or Vyttila Junction. The entry point of Vylopilly Road near Vyttila Junction has also been dug up.

“Construction of the Vyttila flyover has created enough and more traffic management issues. Now, with pipeline repair work being carried out on both the eastern and western sides of NH-66, only small and medium vehicles can pass through Ponnurunni underpass. Buses and trucks coming from the south will have to move through the national highway and take the nearest U-turn head for the Kaniyampuzha Road, mobility hub or Tripunithura regions,” said a traffic cop at Vyttila Junction.

Kochi corporation councillor PS Shine said that once work on the pipelines is completed, the roads will have to be relaid to facilitate smooth movement of vehicles. “While undertaking such works there should be proper co-ordination among the various government departments,” he said, adding that have been several complaints of leaking pipelines at Vyttila Junction ever since the construction of the flyover began. “All these indicate lack of proper co-ordination,” said Shine.

Title: City expects Vid statehood or special projects
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Nagpur: With the BJP losing power in the state, many people, including public representatives, are expecting announcement of Vidarbha statehood with city as capital, or special projects for the city from the Union Budget. Chances of budgetary provisions for execution of pending projects, including Metro Rail phase-II, Nag-Pili Rivers Pollution Abatement Project etc, and continuation of existing projects including Swachh Bharat Mission, AMRUT are high.

Congress city president and West Nagpur MLA Vikas Thakre said it’s high time the BJP announces separate statehood to Vidarbha or special status for the city. “BJP at the centre and state have done nothing much for the city and other parts of Vidarbha in last six years. Existing MIDC clusters are on the verge of closure. Mihan is pending since a long time. Many industries are plunging into list of sick industries. Vidarbha statehood or any special status for the city can help regain lost glory of the city,” he said.

Mayor Sandip Joshi said the Modi government has sanctioned a slew of mega projects in last five years and city will get more in the Budget and coming years. “Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) hopes continuation of funds for ongoing projects like water supply scheme for unauthorized layouts under AMRUT, Smart City Mission, Swachh Bharat Mission etc. City had got series of premier institutes under Modi government and more are expected,” he said.

Activist Prashant Pawar too expects announcement of statehood for Vidarbha. “Upgradation of hospitals, including GMCH, are much needed. Special packages should be announced to boost orange cultivation. Metro Rail phase-II should not be cleared before completion and successful operation of phase-I. The funds meant for phase-II should be given for other urban mobility projects,” he said.

Architect Virendra Khare expressed a need to bring realty sector back on track. “System of input tax credit to builders should be revised on the lines of VAT system. Many people are not getting benefits of PMAY. Flat buyers should get subsidy of Rs2.5 lakh directly and not through banks. Many of the buyers are not able to get subsidy as banks disqualify them,” he said.

RTI activist TH Naidu said funds should be approved for proposed Sports Authority of India (SAI) Centre for its completion within a year. “A special project to develop all playgrounds like Patwardhan ground, Reshimbagh ground, Chitnis park etc should be announced. A policy should be framed for special say of people in urban local bodies. New revenue sources should be provided to cash-strapped NMC. A policy to levy hefty penalties on unauthorized constructions and encroachments should be announced to ensure balanced development of the city,” he said.

Hotel owner Aman Samundre said projects and schemes to generate employment in the city should be launched. “There are no more jobs left in the city. Self-employment is not feasible. Many young people are leaving for other cities to get jobs. Some special initiatives should be taken for upliftment of youth,” he said.

Title: Student group stages street play ‘Omit Shah ka Bharat’ after title row
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Students participate in a dharna highlighting anti-CAA, NRC, NPR sentiments at Samvidhan Square on Friday

Nagpur: A group of students belonging to different colleges on Friday evening presented street play ‘Omit Shah ka Bharat’ during the protest against CAA/NRC and police atrocities on students at Samvidhan Square . They were initially denied permission, allegedly over its title, which was perceived to be derogatory towards Union home minister Amit Shah.

Two earlier titles suggested for the play were rejected by the police as too controversial.

Beside the title, the cops were reluctant to allow the 10-minute drama as the organizers had not informed them about it while seeking permission for the protest, organized under the banner of Youth Federation for Humanity.

The protest ‘Youth Against Fascism’ was held against government inaction in cases of attacks on students, the most recent one being the shoot out at Jamia, and police excesses.

The play was written and directed by BA student Simeen Kausar. Six other girl students; Zaamin, Mantasaha, Farhat, Shahina, Nabeela and Alfaria, played the characters representing student voices against the issues. It was produced by the Aksa Group, formed in the backdrop of the ongoing protests.

Aksa Group’s Junaid Sidiqque said the play highlights the penetration of communal disturbance in schools and colleges. “Everyone is bringing his or her religious beliefs to educational institutions. Now, kids too are getting communal. The play ‘Omit Shah’s Bharat’ showcases our society will be divided,” he said.

The solution is to have cultural exchanges, he said. “We will have to hold a dialogue with each other.”

A candle light march to condemn the Jamia shooting was held after the play. Some students from Jamia too had joined the protests.

Junaid said at the end they pledged to hold workshops on educating masses on digital activism and how to bury differences. “We are launching project ‘Torch’ to educate people on CAA and NRC. Other aim is to make people understand how to identify fake videos or communally sensitive content. Digital nuisance is one of the reasons for the communal tension. We will reach out to students of city and go to their localities and homes with the messages,” he said.

Title: West Bengal: FIR lodged against Dilip Ghosh; Patuli locals rally to support student
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Dilip Ghosh

KOLKATA: The 23-year-old Sanskrit University student (her name is being withheld due to the molestation complaint), who had protested at a BJP pro-CAA rally in Patuli on Thursday, walked into the Patuli police station on Friday morning to file a complaint against MP and BJP state president Dilip Ghosh and other BJP workers for wrongful restraint, criminal intimidation and insulting her modesty by using foul words. The student said she will not be cowed by the threats and will keep participating in anti-CAA, NRC and NPR protests.

Patuli police has registered an FIR against Ghosh and others under several penal sections. No immediate reaction was available from Ghosh, who had left for Delhi to attend the Parliament session. On Thursday itself, the student had indicated to TOI that she would file a complaint against Ghosh. “I went to the police station and lodged the complaint. Police accepted my complaint and I have been told that an FIR has been lodged,” she said on Friday. The student has received support from several locals and together they will stage a protest at the same spot at Patuli on February 3.

On Thursday, Ghosh had said, “Onar choddo purush er bhaggo bhalo je khali poster chhera hoyechhe, onno kichhu kora hoyni (It is her forefathers’ luck that only the poster was torn off and nothing else was done). There are many Baghs and Circuses to protest, why do they come to our meetings? To get publicity, or to get martyred? I say this again, this is no child’s play…we have tolerated enough, will not tolerate any more.”

On Friday, several locals, led by Trinamool Congress minister Aroop Biswas, protested against the incident. The protesters walked from Patuli to Baghajatin, holding each other’s hand as a symbol of solidarity. Biswas said, “We won’t let them divide Bengal. They should apologise for their deeds.”

“Dilip Ghosh should learn to be polite and be a gentleman. We do not speak to anyone in this manner. I believe they are scared. Are they even competent to run the country?” wondered Dipak Kumar Basu, a Jadavpur resident, who participated in the rally.

“We are really scared of going out of the house as the comments that are being passed are really dangerous. He has forgotten his age. The student against whom he spoke would be his daughter’s age,” said Indrani Banik Chowdhury, one of the protesters who took part in Friday’s rally. “We will continue with our protest because they have started treating us like animals,” said Sonali Guha of Bijoygarh.

Title: Goa given 100 days to take over coal block
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: The Union coal ministry has issued a stern warning to the Goa government saying that Goa could lose a coal block for the second time if it does not complete the formalities to take over the Dongri Tal II coal block at Singrauli in Madhya Pradesh.

Industries minister Vishwajit Rane, who met with the Union ministry officials, has sought a grace period of 100 days to arrange the funds required to pay the performance guarantee for the coal block that Goa Industrial Development Corporation (GIDC) plans to operate.

“The coal ministry has warned Goa to take possession of the coal block within 100 days,” Rane said.

Rane had earlier announced that the state would sign the agreement for this block by October 30.

The corporation has already identified a committee to spearhead the process to formally utilise the coal block, which was allocated to the state through a bidding process.

TOI had reported on October 4, 2019, that the corporation intended to rope in validated consultants to help the state with the coal block utilisation and with the auction of the industrial land returned by the special economic zone promoters.

The Dongri Tal II coal block at Singrauli was allotted to Goa as part of the fifth tranche of allotment by the coal ministry.

However, the cash-strapped corporation needs to pay Rs 196 crore to exploit the coal block, sources said.

Coal mines have been allotted to state governments for sale of coal under the Coal Mines (Special Provisions) Act, 2015.

The Centre said it will accept upfront payments in three instalments from successful bidders, along with the performance guarantee — equivalent to a year’s royalty — prior to the formal signing of the Coal Mine Development and Production Agreement (CMDPA).

The corporation had also applied to Coal India for yet another coal block as part of the sixth tranche of coal mines allocation.

Title: Mangaluru: Deputy commissioner says no need to panic over coronavirus outbreak
Content:
Representative image

MANGALURU: Deputy commissioner Sindhu B Rupesh said there is no need for people to panic about coronavirus.Dakshina Kannada zilla panchayat CEO R Selvamani said IEC programmes will be held to create awareness on possibilities of spread of diseases.He also advised people not to follow blindly the advisories being shared on social media without proper verification.“Posts on cures for coronavirus which are not scientifically proven are being shared on social media. Do not follow such advisories without verifying facts,” he said.DHO Dr Ramakrishna Rao said there is no specific antiviral treatment recommended for coronavirus infection. Supportive care for infected people can be highly effective, he said, adding that there is no vaccine available for coronavirus.He also advised people to take precautionary measures to prevent the spread of the virus.“Wash your hands often with soap and water or an alcohol-based sanitiser. Avoid touching your eyes, nose and mouth with unwashed hands. Avoid close contact with people who are sick. Stay home when you are sick, and cover your mouth when you cough or use a tissue while sneezing. Throw the used tissue in the dustbin. Clean and disinfect surfaces frequently,” Dr Rao said.

Title: Telangana: Smooth-coated otter spotted in Nalgonda
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Smooth-coated otter in Nalgonda

HYDERABAD: After north Telangana and Kapra lake in the city, smooth-coated otters have now been spotted near Gundlapally of Nalgonda district. The mammal is listed as an endangered animal by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN).

The state forest department’s wildlife wing has decided to conserve the water body where the otters were spotted as sightings have reduced recently indicating threats to the fish-eating mammal.

Zoologist and professor of Osmania University, C Srinivasulu told TOI, “In Telangana, Smooth-Coated Otters were reported as a common species found in the Godavari and Krishna river basin two decades ago. From 1995 to 2000, our team has conducted an extensive survey and recorded the population of otters in eight to 10 locations. But since then, the sightings have gone down.”

For this Prof Srinivasulu mentioned two reasons. “Unchecked fishing activity in the waterbodies harm otter habitats. They often get entangled in the nets and the fishermen hunt them as well. Due to this, otter population is restricted to major river systems in protected areas where fishing activity is regulated,” he said.

Three years ago, Smooth-Coated Otters were spotted in Kapra apart from Udayasamudram in Nalgonda.

“We thought it will make the lake its habitat,” Prof Srinivasulu said, adding, “The sighting is reported due to increased awareness and maybe the otters are also exploring new territories.”

Title: Tipeshwar control moves from Pench to Melghat
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Nagpur: In a first, Tipeshwar (149sqkm) and Painganga (425sqkm) wildlife sanctuaries in Yavatmal district have been put under the administrative control of Melghat Tiger Reserve (MTR), Amravati.

MS Reddy, additional principal chief conservator of forests (APCCF) & field director of MTR, has been asked to take over the control of two sanctuaries with immediate effect. A GR to this effect was issued on Friday.

Reddy, who already controls over 3,058sqkm area, which includes 8 wildlife sanctuaries and 1 national park in 3 districts, will get an additional control of 574sqkm now. The total area under his administration will be 3,633sqkm. However, Isapur wildlife sanctuary (121sqkm), which is under Pusad territorial division, has been left out.

The logic behind handing over both the sanctuaries to Melghat is that these protected areas (PAs) fall under Amravati revenue division. Till now the PAs were under the Nagpur revenue division. The divisional forest officer (DFO), wildlife, Pandharkawda, used to look after Tipeshwar and Painganga. Now he will report to the Melghat field director.

The area under Melghat now will be nearly close to what APCCF (wildlife), East Nagpur, HS Hooda, looks after. It will be like virtually having two parallel APCCFs for wildlife in Nagpur and Amravati revenue divisions.

Hooda, who has Tadoba-Andhari, Navegaon-Nagzira, Bor, and Pench tiger reserves and Umred-Karhandla sanctuary under his control, will no more be in-charge of Melghat and other sanctuaries which he used to administer till now.

As per the new GR, Reddy will straightway report to PCCF (wildlife) Nitin H Kakodkar, who will be his controlling officer.

Talking to TOI, Kakodkar said, “The new decision is part of the pending proposal sent to the government last year. Both, Tipeshwar and Painganga sanctuaries have been put under Amravati revenue division, which were till now under Nagpur revenue division. We will also hand over control of Isapur sanctuary to Melghat soon.”

“The fresh move will help expediting relocation of villages in which the revenue department has an important role to play. Both the divisional commissioner and the field director, who will be based in Amravati can coordinate better,” said Kakodkar.

Till now Tipeshwar and Painganga, which is 180km and 300km respectively from Nagpur, were under the control of the field director, Pench Tiger Reserve (PTR), Maharashtra. Earlier, there was also a proposal to attach these sanctuaries to the Bor tiger reserve by putting them under new field director but that plan did not auger well with the senior officials.

The state move comes at a time when forest minister Sanjay Rathod, who is three-time MLA from Digras in Yavatmal, wants to expedite the proposal to notify the Tipeshwar sanctuary as a tiger reserve by extending it.

Melghat field director Reddy said, “Getting the tiger reserve status to Tipeshwar will be his priority. We will also implement Dr Shyamaprasad Mukherjee Jan Van scheme in villages around Tipeshwar. I will be taking charge of these sanctuaries on Saturday.”

On the tiger reserve proposal, Reddy said, “When Navegaon-Nagzira and other sanctuaries attached to it can become a tiger reserve, why not Tipeshwar-Painganga?”

Melghat Expanding Higher

Gugamal NP: 361.28

Melghat sanctuary: 788.75

Wan sanctuary: 211

Ambabarwa: 127.11

Narnala: 12.35

Katepurna: 73.69

Karanja Sohol: 18.32

(The above area in sqkm doesn’t include part of buffer zone)

Title: Kolkata: Lake security stepped up after back-to-back crimes
Content:
Winners cops patrol the area

Times View This zone (along with the Maidan) is one of the city’s two most-visited open spaces. This also makes it vulnerable to crime as there are multiple points of entry and exit. Cops have, by and large, been successful in securing Rabindra Sarobar but a couple of problem spots remain. More focused policing on these areas may help.

KOLKATA: In one of the back-to-back crimes reported at Rabindra Sarobar since Wednesday, a sub-inspector was assaulted at Rabindra Sarobar so badly that his hand fractured. Realizing how the south Kolkata green zone, especially popular among morning and evening-walkers, was under threat, the South-East division top brass pressed the emergency button and launched a special anti-harassment and anti-crime at the Lake on Friday evening.In the raid, carried out with the help of Lalbazar cops between 6.30pm and 7.30pm, cops from the all-woman Winners team and the south-east division patrolled the area and hauled up troublemakers. While some were cautioned, a few were detained. Police pointed out that crimes had increased ever since a wall was being built at the Lake, bordering the Tollygunge station. Trouble-makers and residents of local slums would jump over the raised boundary from the station and take a short-cut through the Lake premises, an officer said.Around 6pm on Wednesday, when the city was celebrating Sarawati Puja, six people allegedly molested two women and assaulted their male friend, Abdul Mustaq, a student of Herambachandra College, who went to the Lake for a stroll. Barely three hours later, trouble again broke out with eight youths refusing to leave the Lake premises even after it shut. When sub-inspector Sanjay Pandey intervened, one from the group, Tanmoy Dey, reportedly attacked him, fractured his hand and tore up his uniform. On Friday, a resident, Subhra Mukherjee, posted on the Kolkata Police Facebook page that she and her husband were stalked by half-a-dozen minor boys, commenting on their skin colour and race.In less than 24 hours since Wednesday’s incidents, cops from the Rabindra Sarobar police station made two arrests: Sk Firoz for the molestation of the women and Dey for the cop assault. Two others, Akash Das (19) and Subrata Das (18), both residents of Shahid Smriti Colony in Panchasayar, were arrested on Friday for the first case. “We have stepped up patrolling inside and outside the Lake,” said DC (south-east) Debasmita Das. Around 15 to 25 cops from the Rabindra Sarobar police station will be on duty at Rabindra Sarobar at different points of the day. The Tollygunge police station will patrol the road outside the Tollygunge station, reportedly a “trouble zone”. The current shifts of Lake patrolling, 6am to 10am and 4pm to 10pm, now see 15 men on duty. More cops would be deployed, hinted top Lalbazar officers.When TOI visited the Lake on Friday evening, only one cop was found inside the Lake, while most of the personnel were huddled at the gate near Menoka Cinema. “A wall is coming up at the Lake, bordering the Tollygunge station. Nearby slum residents jump over the wall from the station and take a short-cut through the Lake. People from Gholam Mohammad Shah Road and Lake Gardens are also using the illegal access,” an officer said.Cops said they would slap charges against peeping Toms, booking them under the ‘look case’ (Calcutta Police Act Section 68). If found taking photos or videos of anyone, more stringent action might be taken, an officer said.

Title: MIAL may get Cidco notice for Navi Mumbai airport delay
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

MIAL wants encumbrance-free land to start Navi Mumbai airport work

NAVI MUMBAI: Worried over non-commencement of construction work for Navi Mumbai airport runway and terminal building, Cidco managing director Lokesh Chandra has reportedly asked his officials to examine if a notice can be served to Mumbai International Airport ( MIAL ).

Cidco holds 26% equity in Navi Mumbai International Airport (NMIAPL) as the nodal airport development authority, and MIAL 74%.

At the core is the issue of an encumbrance-free airport land. Cidco has claimed there are less than 200 structures, including 70-odd government buildings on airport land that have been handed over to the concessionaire. On the ground, though, officials said there are close to 300 structures, apart from high tension lines and mobile antennae.

MIAL wants encumbrance- free land to start work.

Cidco officials admit the concessionaire may be facing problems even from its bank, as it might not be ready to disburse funds without encumbrance-free land.

“Cidco has handed over approximately 1,156 hectares of land to the concessionaire and there are about 94 structures eligible for compensation. Besides these, there are about 70 government buildings and community temples. There may be some illegal cellphone structures too,” said a Cidco official. A drone survey was carried out jointly by officials of Cidco and the concessionaire. The survey is said to have confirmed the concessionaire’s claims of close to 300 structures.

“Though Cidco has made sizeable progress in getting the land freed of project-affected persons (PAPs) and structures, unless the concessionaire gets land free of encumbrance, how are they supposed to start work? How can the concessionaire ask its contractor to commence construction work? Apart from structures and PAPs, there are high tension lines that are yet to be shifted. Besides, there are mobile antennae. A majority of pre-development works like levelling of land and diversion of rivers are complete,” said an official.

“Though there are differences over the number of structures, some are illegal and many are unoccupied. We will sit with MIAL officials and work out a solution,” said a Cidco official.

Cidco MD Lokesh Chandra did not respond to calls or texts from TOI. GVK officials refused to comment.

Meanwhile, sources said, Chandra held a meeting with Cidco and police officials to ensure villagers near the airport site do not create a hindrance to removal of high tension lines.

Title: Industry wants CM Pramod Sawant to intervene in SEZ payments
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

CM Pramod Sawant

PANAJI: Industry bodies on Friday appealed to the state government to investigate Goa Industries Development Corporation ’s decision to pay Rs 28 lakh to the five special economic zone ( SEZ ) promoters.

Verna Industries Association (VIA) held an emergency meeting of its executive committee on Friday where the issue was discussed and where industry representatives said that they would explore legal options if GIDC went ahead with the payment of the amount. “This issue is very serious in nature which needs utmost attention of chief minister Pramod Sawant to investigate the incidents at GIDC and to do the justice to the industry and the state,” said VIA president Blaise Costabir.

Goa State Industries Association (GSIA) also met to discuss the issue, and members felt that the state government should issue directions to GIDC regarding the payment of the funds to the SEZ promoters.“GIDC should seek directions from the state government for payment to the SEZ promoters and the decision should not be brought before the board members. The managing director is acting without directions from the government,” said GSIA president Damodar Kochkar.

Industry stakeholders are concerned as they fear that GIDC will try and recover the funds by imposing higher taxes on local units.

Title: Dense fog at Kolkata airport leads to flight cancellations, delays
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

The airport covered by fog on Thursday night

KOLKATA: Flight operation at the airport came to a grinding halt late on Thursday and early Friday due to dense fog. While visibility started to plunge rapidly from 11pm, it hit a low of 25m at 2am before improving gradually. Flight operations at Kolkata airport are suspended when visibility drops below 50m.

The fog led to cancellation of two international flights and delay of nine others, including three domestic flights. Most international flights in Kolkata operate at night.

Fog is a visible aerosol consisting of tiny water droplets or ice crystals suspended in the air near the earth’s surface. It is a low-lying cloud and is heavily influenced by nearby bodies of water, topography and wind conditions.

The chief of meteorology at Kolkata airport, GC Debnath, said the heavy fog formation on Thursday-Friday was an unusual phenomenon and took everyone off guard. “Usually, fog is related to low temperature and occurs early in the morning. But the thundershowers on Thursday afternoon set into motion changes in the weather condition that finally precipitated into fog. Once the sky cleared after the rain, the temperature fell rapidly. This led to moisture in the vegetations in the airport condense to form fog. It is only after after 3am, when north-northwardly breeze set in, that the fog cover lifted and formed cloud,” he explained.

AirAsia’s 1am flight to Kuala Lumpur with 142 passengers and Thai Airway’s 2am flight to Bangkok with 160 passengers were cancelled. Among the delayed flights was Malindo Air and Air Asia’s flights to Kuala Lumpur; China Eastern Airline’s flight to Kunming; Thai Airways, Thai Air Asia and SpiceJet’s flights to Bangkok. In the domestic sector, early morning flights to Delhi, Bangalore and Hyderabad were delayed.

On Friday, two domestic flights to Mumbai and Delhi run by IndiGo and two international flights run by Bhutan Airlines flight to Paro and Bangkok were cancelled because of operational reasons.

Title: Like Nipah, we will control nCoV: Minister
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: The state survived a Nipah scare in 2018 as the disease was brought under control with timely steps. Though it claimed 17 lives, the timely intervention of health department helped contain the disease in limited areas of Malappuram and Kozhikode.Over 2,000 people were quarantined and kept under the observation during the outbreak. The situation was serious and health minister KK Shailaja personally camped in Kozhikode along with senior health officials to review the day-to-day situation.State government even declared a travel advisory to northern districts of the state during the outbreak in 2018. The prevention and precautionary measures taken to check the spread of the disease had received laurels from both within and outside the country.The state government gave increments to 61 employees, including doctors under the health department, to reward them for their efforts in tackling that outbreak. Twelve junior residents and two senior residents were given gold medals for their relentless service in containing Nipah outbreak.“We are hopeful of containing coronavirus by adopting the steps we had taken to curb Nipah. The entire machinery of the health department was in full swing to control the spread of Nipah. We could succeed as people, who were found in the high-risk category, were quarantined immediately. Similarly, this would be the key in the present situation,” said health minister KK Shailaja.Though Nipah resurfaced in 2019, it did not create much panic as it was limited to only one case.

Title: Aligarh admin declares 2 AMU ex-students ‘Goondas’, expels them from district for 6 months
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Agra: Aligarh district administration has declared two former AMU students as “Goondas” and expelled them from the district for six months for their alleged involvement in crimes in the district. Besides, three other ex-students of the varsity have also been issued notices.

The two, who had been expelled from Aligarh, were identified as Nadeem Ansari, former AMU students’ union vice-president, and Amir Mintoe alias Mohammad Aamir, who is also an ex-student of the university. Those who were issued notices for invoking the Goondas Act include Huzaifa Amir, former secretary of the students’ union, Hamza Sufiyan, former vice-president of students’ union, and Vakar Naga, an ex-student.

Barring Nadeem Ansari, all other were named in the FIRs registered against protesters, including AMU students, for their alleged involvement in the violence that erupted on the university campus on December 15. Vakar Naga, who was named in two FIRs in the December 15 violence, was remanded to judicial custody for 14 days on January 28.

A case under the Uttar Pradesh Control of Goondas Act, 1970, was being heard in the additional district magistrate (city) court, which ordered their expulsion on Thursday.

Confirming this, Aligarh DM CB Singh said that the two have been expelled from Aligarh for a period of six months, as they have “become a threat to the general public due to their criminal activities”.

According to an administrative official, Nadeem Ansari was booked four times under various sections of IPC in 2017, 2018, and 2019. This brought him under the category of a habitual criminal. Similarly, Mohammad Aamir was booked for three consecutive years under various sections of IPC, including attempt to murder, in 2015, 2016 and 2017.

Singh said that the district administration is committed to ensuring continuous strict action against people with a criminal history. Therefore, similar action will be taken in the future against the mafia and criminals under the Goondas Act, besides considering their expulsion from the district.

Nadeem Ansari told reporters that such steps are being taken by the authorities to weaken the movement against CAA/NRC. “In order to end the protest in the district, they are invoking the Goondas Act against people actively involved in such protests,” he said. Mintoe said that he has not received any notice so far, but if it is true, then he would like to thank the government for putting him in the category of revolutionary leaders, who were expelled from the district during the British period.

Title: Parents relieved, but fear social stigma
Content: Kochi: Parents in the city were relieved to know that their children, trapped in cities of China’s Hubei province that is facing a lockdown, will be evacuated soon as Centre is arranging transport for them in the coming days. As their children get ready for an evacuation from Wuhan, the epicentre of the coronavirus outbreak, and nearby cities like Yichang, parents are waiting anxiously for more news: arrival and quarantine.Alina (name changed), whose son is studying at College of Medicine, Wuhan University said, “I am relieved that my son is reaching India. I am a staff nurse and I understand the things associated with a virus outbreak. Friends and neighbours might not share their fears that a person is returning from a city ravaged by a deadly virus. It is better to quarantine the kids in the larger interest of the community.”However, she did not know where her son would arrive in India; it could be New Delhi, Mumbai or some other place. “Exact details aren’t available. If he is in India, he is safe. They might take the evacuees directly to hospitals in these metros. Am not sure if arrangements will be made to bring them to Kerala ,” she added.Meanwhile, students who returned from Yichang, one of the cities in Hubei province where travel restrictions were imposed, said that they had undergone health checks at Kunming airport in China. They said that those who recorded temperature variations were allowed to travel as they were returning home.“At Kunming airport, we came across some students who recorded temperature variations. I saw them being held back and being taken for further screening,” said a student on condition of anonymity. At the same time, those who recorded normal temperature could go ahead with mandatory security clearance for boarding the flight.“Moreover, I heard them talking to their parents over the phone about temperature variation and screenings. As they were returning home, they could board the flight,” added the student. Students also said that they were subjected to health checks at Kolkata airport and officials mainly checked the temperature.Those who already reached Kerala said that they were initially asked to stay at home for 14 days. But as nCoV cases were reported, they were directed to stay back for 28 days.

Title: All-women anti-CAA/NRC protests rock Ballarpur
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Chandrapur: Terming the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) as a black law, thousands of women staged daylong sit-in near Ballarpur Municipal Council office on Friday. The protesters also condemned the Centre’s proposed move to go for National Register of Citizens (NRC) despite strong opposition to it throughout the country.

The sit-in was staged under the banner of Women Against NRC, Muslim Ekta Manch and other organizations.

Addressing the all-women protest, Aam Aadmi Party leader Paromita Goswami said the CAA and NRC are not just about Muslims, but also against the OBCs and Scheduled Tribes. “Women will be worst sufferers of this black law as they will have to face Herculean task of proving their citizenship based on their name, which changes after marriage. Many people don’t have any proof of their birth date or birth place etc. Such people will face the daunting task of proving their citizenship,” said Goswami.

Lamenting that so far only Muslim women have stepped out against the government’s move in large numbers, Goswami warned that the anti-CAA/NRC protests would not gain momentum unless women from other communities too join it.

Other leaders highlighted the deceptive nature of the CAA. They claimed that the CAA in its present form poses threat to the Constitution of India and sows seeds of discord between communities living harmoniously since ages.

Women leaders Shaheen Hakim, Nahida Kazi, Shaista Pathan, Shaheen Sheikh, Samina Sheikh, Dr Abhilash Gauture, Pragati Bhosle along with Prof Javed Pasha, Adv Farhat Baig and Amjad Sheikh also addressed the protesters.

Title: Interim DGP office likely to be housed in commissionerate
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Visakhapatnam: With the port city proposed to become the executive capital of the state, officials have started looking for a suitable location to house the DGP’s office. Till then, the new building of the police commissionerate , work on which began three years ago and has now been expedited, is likely to serve as the interim office of DGP Gautam Sawang till a permanent place is built.

The location of the DGP’s office would depend on where the government decides to set up the secretariat. Sawang’s present office in Mangalagiri town, near Guntur, is spread over six acres and is situated inside the sprawling sixth battalion of APSP (AP special police) premises. The five-storied building, with an area of over 1 lakh sqft, was constructed with an estimated cost of Rs 40 crore and inaugurated in August 2017.

The Vizag police commissioner’s office, which is under construction at police barracks, has four floors with an area of around 50,000 sqft. It is likely to be completed in the next four-five months. If the capital decentralisation proposal is passed in the assembly, around 15 IG and ADG rank officers, besides more than 400 ministerial staff, would be housed in this building.

City police chief Rajeev Kumar Meena said if the department needs it they would be happy to house the DGP’s interim office. “We expect the new building to be ready by June. But we haven’t got any communication in this regard ( DGP office ) so far,” he added.

Title: Car plunges into canal; two dead, five injured
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

A car plunged into the left main canal of Vamsadhara river in Srikakulam district on the early hours of Friday. Two of the five people travelling in the car have died. The deceased have been identified as Pavan and B Chandramohan. Both of them are employees of Visakhapatnam-based Coromandel Fertilizers, according to the local police.

Pavan was a resident of Rajahmundry while Chandramohan hailed from Khammam. The three others in the car— M Maheshwara Rao, S Durga Naga Praveen and Venkatagiri Prasad sustained minor injuries. Hiranmandalam police said that a group of ten people had gone to Centurion University in Parlakhamundi in Odisha to attend a meeting. The group was travelling in two cars, with five people in each car. While on their way back, the car plunged into the canal in the dark.

While the three people who survived managed to swim to land, two— those who died got stuck in the car and eventually drowned. Hiramandalam police led by sub-inspector K Govinda Rao reached the spot to fish-out the bodies and the car. The bodies have been sent for post-mortem.tnn

Title: Services hit, ATMs defunct due to two-day bank strike
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: Services of many public sector banks in the city were affected on Friday owing to the two-day strike called by the United Forum of Banking Unions (UFBU). ATMs of several of these banks were also defunct.

Meanwhile, union members staged a protest demonstration near Mahatma Gandhi statue in the city. Around 1,000 employees and officers of various banks participated in the two-hour-long demonstration demanding resolution of long-pending issues.

The demands of the unions include wage revision settlement at 20 per cent hike in payslip components, with adequate loading thereof, five-day banking, merger of special allowance with basic pay, scrapping of the new pension scheme and improvement in family pension.

Members of nine trade unions participated in the demonstration.

Title: Civic body mulls four new flyovers to ease traffic in Visakhapatnam
Content:
Major intersections such as Gajuwaka, NAD junction, Maddilapalem have been witnessing heavy traffic congestion... Read More

VISAKHAPATNAM: The Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation (GVMC) is planning to construct four new 4-lane flyovers in Gajuwaka, Maddilapalem, Hanumanthuwaka and Car Shed junction near PM Palem on the NH to ease traffic congestion in the city. A rail overbridge at Gopalapatnam crossing is also on the cards. The GVMC is currently in the process of appointing a consultant to prepare a detailed project report for these projects.The Chennai-Kolkata national highway network from Kurmannapalem to Kommadi, spanning about 40 kilometres and passing through the core city, has been witnessing heavy traffic congestion. Some of the major intersections in this 40km network like Gajuwaka, NAD junction, Maddilapalem, New Venkojipalem junction, Hanumanthuwaka junction and Car Shed junction are struggling to cope with the increased vehicular traffic, which has grown manifold in the last one decade.To tide over the situation, Visakhapatnam Metropolitan Region Development Authority (VMRDA) has already started construction of a multi-level grade separator at NAD junction, the major bottleneck along the NH. Rs 120 crore will be spent on the project which is expected to be completed in the next four-five months.On the funding and completion deadline of the flyover projects, a GVMC official said they will explore the funding options only after the DPRs are prepared. “Once the DPRs are ready, we can take up these works in a phased manner or on an ‘as and when required’ basis,” he said. He added that the consultant has to prepare a feasibility study, soil analysis, cost and inception report, geotech report, designs, drawings, financial analysis etc for all the five locations.The consultant will also need to do a social and environmental impact assessment, traffic, land use and road inventory surveys, land acquisition proposals required for the project and utility shifting plans for each location, the GVMC official said. The consultant, while preparing the DPRs, should also consider the alignment of the proposed 140km metro rail project, besides assisting the civic body in bidding process and other works, he added.

Title: Kerala House ‘rejects’ opposition move to seek Arif’s recall
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Kerala governor Arif Mohammed Khan (File photo)

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The Kerala assembly will not discuss the notice for resolution moved by the leader of opposition Ramesh Chennithala asking the President to recall governor Arif Mohammed Khan over his stand on the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, sources said.

The matter was taken up by the Business Advisory Committee (BAC) of the House on Friday and it was decided not to take up the matter for discussion. “The opposition had asked for time to discuss the content of the resolution. The BAC came to the conclusion that due to the short session of the assembly there was lack of time to discuss the matter,” assembly sources said.

The government had not agreed to the content of the debate, the sources said, adding in effect the discussion will not happen. The resolution had sought recall of the governor for “violating all democratic principles and publicly questioning the pride of the legislature”.

Law minister A K Balan told reporters that the government wishes to go only by rules and did not want to go against the spirit of the constitution.

Assembly Speaker P Sreeramakrishnan earlier had held that the notice for UDF resolution was permissible under law and a final call will be taken after discussing it in the BAC.

Reacting to the development, Chennithala said he would demand discussing the matter in the BAC once more.

The government decision was a challenge to the people of the state, he said. “If this government respected the people's sentiments, it would have allowed the discussion on the resolution,” he added.

Title: Capital ready: Plan in pipeline to run prison dept HQ from Vizag
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Visakhapatnam: With the city on its way to become the executive capital of Andhra Pradesh, officials of the prison department are chalking out plans to run the headquarters of the prison department from Vizag Central Prison temporarily.

Currently, the department is headquartered in Amaravati. The department of prisons in Andhra Pradesh is divided into two— coastal Andhra and Kadapa ranges. Each range is headed by deputy inspector general (DIG) of prisons.

While one of the headquarters is located at Rajahmundry in East Godavari district, the other is located in Kadapa in Rayalaseema.

Speaking to TOI, a senior official of the prison department said that if the capital is shifted from Amaravati to Visakhapatnam, the central prison located in Adavivaram area in Visakhapatnam will be the headquarters temporarily.

As per the preliminary plan, the office of the director general of prisons and correctional services will function from the guest house of the department, located near the central prison. It is being expected that at least 50 officers from Amaravati will be shifted to Visakhapatnam.

Meanwhile, once the city becomes the executive capital, the prison department is expected to be set up in Bheemili in the area where the unused Bheemili sub-jail now stands, the official informed.

Work is also on for a Borstal School at Kondavelagada village under Nellimarla mandal in Vizianagaram district. This will be the first Borstal School in Andhra Pradesh and is expected to house 100 inmates. The school is expected to be inaugurated in the coming months, informed Dr Indla Sreenivasa Rao, DIG of prisons, coastal Andhra range.

The state government has allotted over 25 acres land at Kondavelagada for setting up a Borstal School and a new district jail in Vizianagaram in 2017. The entire project will cost the exchequer around Rs 20 crore.

“The state government had planned to set up a prison either in Vijayawada or in Amaravati for it felt that the capital should have a prison. However, now the government seems to have dropped the proposal due to the three-capital theory,” said another senior official.

Title: Lourd Mata fest commences with prayers by devouts
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

Nagpur: Devotion to Mary , the mother of Jesus, is as ancient as Christianity itself. This is because God himself has shown through many signs that Mother Mary, as she is known, is the greatest of all saints ever born.

Her apparitions have been most common in the world. Of the most popular of her apparitions was the one at Lourdes, France, where she appeared as a little girl named Bernadette several times and gave messages to her and the world. She cured many sick. Mother Mary is honoured in the city at Lourd Mata Grotto.

The annual feast, known as Lourd Mata Mahotsav, commenced with the hoisting of a flag at Seminary Hills grotto on Thursday. The theme of the flag hoisting was ‘Mary, star of evangelization’ and it was conducted by St Francis De Sales Cathedral.

In preparation of the annual feast that will be celebrated on February 9, Novena prayers are scheduled for nine days at 6.30am and 5.30pm, respectively.

Churches from around the city will organize novena prayers on the themes like repentance, Marian devotion, holy Eucharist, our lady of good health, pray the rosary for world peace, return to God in love, immaculate, the brown scapular and universal motherhood.

Novena prayers will be held at St Antony’s Church, St Pius X Church, Our Lady of Fatima Church, Infant Jesus Church, Holy Family Church, Queen of the Apostles Church, and others.

A group of people will pray for various needs of the people daily at Lourd Mata Mandir from 10am to 1pm.

On February 9, holy mass will be offered in six different languages commencing at 6.30am. Mass will be offered in English, Konkani, Marathi, Telugu, Tamil and Malayalam, followed by rosary and later, Eucharistic adoration and healing service.

Archbishop of Nagpur Elias Gonsalves will celebrate holy mass along with a large number of priests.

People from Maharashtra, Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Odisha, Assam, Delhi and other states will be visiting with faith and devotion in their hearts.

‘Preeti bhoj’ will be given to all the devotees on the feast day.

The thanksgiving mass is scheduled on February 11.

Title: Road accidents: Cashless hosp support without time limit likely
Content:
This story is from February 1, 2020

NEW DELHI: The government is likely to provide free and cashless treatment facility to road accidents victims till their condition stabilises rather than setting any time limit such as first 24 or 48 hours. The road transport ministry is currently framing the rules under the amended Motor Vehicle Act to provide quick and seamless access to accident victims under the Cashless Treatment Scheme.

Sources said a panel set up by the road transport ministry is working on the definition of “golden hour” and how a Motor Vehicle Accident Fund will be created to take care of treatment of injured persons and compensation to kin of a person who died in a hit and run case. The issue of nation-wide rollout of cashless treatment of accident victims came up for discussion at a conference on vehicle insurance last week.

TOI has learnt that the government is exploring different options to get enough fund in the corpus and methods to replenish it to meet the requirement. One of the options is to provide seed money and then allowing insurance companies and corporates to contribute for this cause. “The idea is to ensure that no road accident victim is denied of getting treatment, if he/ she is transported to a hospital. While the expenses of those having insurance cover can be borne by the insurer company concerned and this can be settled easily, options are being explored whether government insurance schemes such as Ayushman Bharat and PM Suraksha Bima Yonja can be linked to this scheme,” said a source.

According to a Law Commission of India report, nearly 50% of those killed in road accidents could be saved by providing timely medical assistance. In 2018, over 1.51 lakh persons lost their lives in road accidents.
